Additional Comments:
This database is only possible though the people who spend time filling out their classes! Submit your classes:  (Last updated June 14th 2023)

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1ieV9hByRgtBzp4mrEwRcNBNFnLC9f4XfZ6RPoa-NrD4
if you just do the essays and participate a little in class you can get an easy A. Professor Brookshire is super nice and accommodating.

Nicole Strathman is a very chill professor. Class is not that difficult if you go to class and take notes. No homework, gave out extra credit which was to go to a museum and answer the questions, she gives out pop quizzes which are short answer(about 3-4 questions), midterm was short answer questions and a page front and back of multiple choice (midterm is easy only if you study) gotta rememeber the images she shows, final is online and she posts questions all you gotta do is answer each question using key terms and at least a page each. legit all her quizzes and tests are all on the lecture so just show up to class. sounds like a lot but its really not. good luck.

gave 4 quizzes instead of two midterms so it made it easier to memorize the information, final project, and a final exam. Puts powerpoints of the lecture on ilearn and the points for discussion sections are just attendance

Took Spring 2021 (online) w/ Katherine Rush. Pretty easy course, just take notes and participate every once in a while. Lectures are recorded and discussions are mandatory. There's readings but you mainly need to read short articles for discussion and skim through lecture readings b/c the assignments require it. ~6 writing assignments throughout the quarter and 1 final paper (make sure to be really specific when explaining). Pretty easy class and its interesting. Prof is also really nice and understanding
Professor Weems is great. The exams aren't particularly easy, but not that bad.

LeBlanc is a good prof and entertaining, gives 2 midterms and one final and an essay and make sure you do well on those if you want a good grade. Her exams are heavily memorization based so get ready to memorize 10+ images per week with the dates, medium, artist, culture, etc. Overall the class is difficult but not impossible if you put in work.

Taking this class online is difficult because Professor Le Blanc spends about half an hour talking about the Dodgers or politics before finally settling into the lecture. She also rambles a bit so you have to really pay attention or ask specific questions. The material isn't really difficult to understand, it's just that whatever she says in lecture is so niche that you have to be present. Our midterm was assigned over three days, and it was THREE five page essays regarding images on slides that gave no further information than who painted it in what year. And on top of that two weeks later we have another five page essay due that isn't even a final.

Had it with LeBlanc. The class is based off slides and extra readings that can be from 10-20 pages long. Discussions are based off the readings but you can sometimes just skim through the reading and you'll be fine. You need to sign up on a website to get your participation grade which is only 3 lectures but you don't actually have to participate. Lecture isn't mandatory only the 3 days you sign up. There are 1-2 paragraph unit responses which weren't even that bad and are due every 2 or 3 weeks I believe. 1 midterm, 1 paper and a final. Midterm consists of 3 questions 5 pages in length and she only gives you about a week to complete. Final is the same format. If you don't like writing, then I wouldn't recommend this class.

Summer 2022. Online. No discussion. Took with Molly Bond. Simple class with easy quizzes based off asynchronous material in class. Attendance matters. The final is an essay regarding various pieces of art. Super easy homework assignments. Make sure to read the readings.

Spring 23, in person with prof. Kotz. Not a good prof for this class. I did not learn much and she is extremely scatterbrained. She has never gotten back to many of our emails and her guidelines for assignments are very vague. She has not even graded anything and by the time I am writing this it is week 9. She does not know how to use canvas. I would not suggest this professor at all. This class should have been online.
Prof. Sally Ness: 1 MT 1 Final Non-cumulative. Minimal reading (only to keep up in discussion). At minimum: take notes in lecture, attend and participate in discussion.

I took the class with Prof. McMullin. She assigned 3 essays, with 1F and 1M. There is assigned readings but not really any hw besides readings and essays, I only remember having to write like a paragraph and turn it in online. She links back readings and videos we watch in class to lectures, expects a mention or 2 in your essays, and many questions on the midterm and final are based on them. In short, doing the readings, they're pretty important. Her TAs can be strict or lenient, pray on that, as they grade your 3 essays. McMullin is very much lenient herself, she gave us an extra credit opportunity for 30 free points on our 200 point midterm and even gave us the final's essay questions as take home. 

TLDR: Easy class, IF you do the readings. DO READINGS.

Class is not difficult, but the way your TA grades makes a huge difference. You need to go to lectures and all discussions, counts for like 10%. Pray that your TA is lenient, because the essay rubrics are very subjective (10 points can be docked off resulting in a B- just for "lack of persuasiveness".) Do the readings, the exams are based on them and lecture. Overall, the material is not difficult, but the grading is sooo subjective, even for the exams.
Homework, Professor was boring, exams were lame.
I had Prof. McMullin. A LOT of reading.
Took it with Dr. Nida; Go to lecture for clickers, read occasionally, and go to discussion and you should be fine, passed with an A+
Had worku nida, its an easy class but a lot of homework. Dont sit at the front of the class if youre shy

Easy with Professor Nida. 1 midterm (50 multiple choice) and 1 cumulative final (100 questions). 4 one page movie reviews, 2 two page papers, and attendance is taken through poll everywhere. Many extra credit points available.

took it with Dr. Nida this quarter, honestly he is a good professor. just do the readings because some concepts are not intuitive. 3 assignments in the entire quarter and clicker questions that are answered on a free app during lecture.

A lot of homework and reading, just go to class for poll everywhere questions. Midterm had 60 multiple choice questions with 3 extra credit multiple choice questions. (63 total) He gave 15 extra poll everywhere points to everyone so there is possibility for extra credit.

Worku Nida has a thick accent but you get used to it. He uses poll everywhere so attending lecture is kinda mandatory. We had two 2 page papers to write which you got an A on if you put any effort into them. It was a very interesting class and I would recommend.

Dr. Nida - I wouldn't say this class was free. You definitely need to read to do well on the midterms and finals since the questions are based off of the readings. However, everything else was easy and if you are diligent in not missing points by not attending lecture, answering clickers, doing the extra credit, you can easily get over a 100% in the class. The extra credit literally boosts your grade by 4%. His RMP rating is deceivingly bad but I would still recommend taking this class.

Dr Nida is a wonderful and sweet man, and obviously knows the content he's teaching, but unfortunately he can't lecture to save his life. I believe he teaches during fall and spring quarters. Attendance is done through PollEverywhere so show up to lecture for that. Otherwise if you do the readings, show up to discussion (my TA was wonderful - Breidy if you're reading this you're the best!), and do what's required you'll be okay. 3 assignments, 1 midterm, and 1 final which is only cumulative for everything covered after the midterm. There is also 10 points of extra credit. I finished with a B+ in the class and I think I could have done better if my participation grade were higher.
Just read the text book and all of the tests are multiple choice.
I got an A+ without studying that much-review the study guide and go to class, participate in discussion

Took it online with Prof Worku Nida. He does prerecorded lectures. His class consists of 2 essays (one is 2 pages long and another is 3 pages), 1 midterm and 1 final (which he gives out optional practice exams before each), and discussion is mandatory. Pretty easy A.
Had Nida, he is the best ever for this class! I loved him, easy A if u put in the work.
Easy Class. Every exam questions are on quizlet. Please always submit your work on-time and attend to all lectures if possible.

dr nida winter 2021: super interesting subject, lectures optional. never really had to study past the weekly homework "quizzes", and grading of writing assignments all depends on your ta--i got really lucky w reed who was super nice and lenient.
Had this with Professor Nida. This isn't a difficult class at all and was my first Breadth class I took at UCR. As long as you study before the exams, you should be good.

Took with Dr. Nida W22. Very easy class. However, you have to pay a lot for the ebook, and some assignments. Never went to lecture, still got an A. 2 easy essays about covid and your culture. Did not like the Public Anthropology essay. Had to pay $15 just to turn in an essay and have it peer reviewed. That could have easily been assigned in canvas.
Winter 2022, I had Nidua? Never attended lectures only discussion, easy A. Great breadth class.

Took it in Winter '22 with Prof. Worku Nida and it was a pretty easy class. I never went to lecture and just did the assignments, and got an A. My only issue with the class is that you have to pay for EVERYTHING. You are required to pay for the textbook, quizzes, journal, and our "project," which was literally just to write a short letter and do some peer reviews. All of these things could have easily been done on Canvas, but instead we had to pay $50+ for it all. In short, the class is an easy A if you are willing/able to pay for all the materials.
This class is extremely disorganized and lectures are hard to understand, but the material is common sense for the most part. Prompts are terribly long when they don't need to be.

Took it with Professor Nida. Easy class that mostly consists of busy work. However, if you're up for the challenge, you could probably complete most of the busy work within the first week. Exams are replaced by papers you have to write, and you're given plenty of time to complete. Honestly, the most important part for this course is the discussion section. Since Nida basically doesn't talk to students, any questions you may have should be asked to the TA. Discussion sections are also mandatory, making them just that important. Overall, fairly easy A.
Took it with Dr. James during Fall'22 and course was based on discussion assignment and 2 papers which were manageable!

Easiest class I have taken in my life, I got an A+ and didn't even attend lecture, the essays were super easy. Attendance only counts towards discussion and that is it, overall one of the easiest class I have ever taken in my life. Also you can do the homework or inquisitive quizzes in about a week, I mean all of it. Just go to TA office hours for clarifying questions.
Took this class with Professor Greer.  Really nice guy and funny at times.  Final exam is easy.  Study his powerpoints (he posts them on iLearn) and you won't even need to read the book.
Pretty easy class for the most part with Greer, but for Midterm 2 and the Final, there were a lot of primate species to memorize, and check the notes on the bottom of his lecture slides.
Took with Dr. Greer, you have to memorize his slides.

Took it with prof becker, 2 midterms + cumulative final but it was mostly multiple choice, got a c on final and ended with an a in the class, reading helps a lot with understanding material and answering pop quizzes (easy points), discussion wasn’t that helpful but i had a bad ta so
Read the book and go to lecture and you'll be fine. Took it with Sara Becker
it is pretty difficult and tests were not curved for me
Pretty easy if you go to lecture and do all the homework. Dr. Becker is a pretty good professor and she knows her stuff.

Took this class online with Dr. Berger and found it to be very easy. No midterms or finals. Only required assignments are weekly quizzes based off the textbook, as well as a short essay (4 pages) at the end of the quarter. She offers a lot of extra credit and additional optional assignments (extra essays, a podcast, infographic, etc.) meant to help raise your grade. Would definitely recommend.

Took this with Berger, and I loved it! You get out of the class what you put in...literally. You choose your assignments worth diff points to build your grade with only one essay being mandatory to pass (beyond discussion work and attendance).

Taken Fall 2020 with Dr. Berger, like others mentioned you get out what you put into the class. There's no formal midterm or final and with the bare minimum effort of showing up to class, discussions, doing the weekly open book/note lecture quizzes, and one 900-1200 word essay you'd get a 75%. Doing additional assignments (another essay, an infographic, an around 10 minute podcast/YouTube video, or a research poster) would raise your grade by 10 or 15 percent each.

Had Maureen Hickey (Winter 2023), and as long as you put in the bare minimum effort for the class (attending lectures and doing the homework) you should do well. Attendance for lectures are required and recorded through a PollEverywhere, and homework consists of 15-18 multiple choice questions per chapter. Homework is based on mastery, so you can easily get 100% for each assignment. First half of content is really basic bio, but the second half picks up with more specific taxonomy and primate classification. During discussions right before the midterms/final, the TAs will give you topics and practice questions that pop up on the tests verbatim. She's really nice and enthusiastic about bio anth! super sweet prof

Professor Schwartz. Imo, not too terribly of a hard class if you keep up with the readings. I did not keep up with the readings. The class is split into the lecture portion, and the discussion portion. In discussion, you will research an archaeological site (Giza, Technotitlan, etc...) and give an oral presentation, write a group paper on the site, and an individual paper about one certain aspect of the site (indigineous people, religion, tourism etc). This is worth ~50% of your grade. The other half is the lecture portion. I personally did not care at all for the material presented. It was all dates and sites of importance cause they found evidence of fire here or whatever. Very uninteresting stuff. One midterm, one final. The average the midterm was a C, i believe. Shows how much everyone didn't understand what was going on. The average on the final i believe wasn't much better. I ended up with a C- in the clAss, which I'm honestly ok with. Difficult class, imo. Take cultural anthropology. I've heard its easy. Definitely easier that world pre history lol

Prof. Thomas Fenn:
Memory-heavy, bi-weekly short writing assignments
The professor doesn't communicate with the class much, so be ready for a pretty independent experience. Studying for the midterm and exams can be done in less than two days.
A little tedious, but definitely not hard. Imagine your typical AP History high school class but with less work and heavier exams.
I took it with a professor named Jennifer Sylversten (I totally butchered her last name now). She was really chill and made the class easy.

Take this with Karl Taube. Easy class, one midterm, one final, each worth 40% of grade. Discussion section attendance worth the other 20%. He hands out an outline of the lecture at the beginning of class. Read the textbook and go to lecture.
Took with Karl Taube. He's a nice cool professor but his lectures make you fall asleep.

Took it with Professor Stanton and his grading policy is very straightforward. He doesn't post slides online, so if you don't attend lecture regularly, you'll most likely fail the class. Easy to follow the class but it could get really boring sometimes. Going to discussion and following the study guide helps a lot for the exams
Ok teacher, not hard and not easy. Memorization is key
The midterm and final require lots of memorizing, however, a fairly accurate study guide is given. The writing assignments and quizzes are super easy and should be an easy grade booster.

Took this course online w/ Stanton because of quarantine. I did not watch all of the pre-recorded lectures because I relied more on the textbook (which he wrote himself). The online reading quizzes were easy and directly pulled out of the textbook. The five assignments in section are really easy. Two midterms and one final, all multiple choice.

I had Professor Tsukamoto as my professor, and I had a lot of fun in class. I'm not really interested in archaeology, so I was a little hesitant taking the course, but I'm happy I did it. I will be honest though, he is incredibly difficult to understand due to his thick accent, but if you read the book he provides you, the class is incredibly easy. The quizzes are very straightforward and short, the exams are exactly what he describes them to be. My TA Johanna Najera was also super nice and she is very knowledgable on the topics that we learn. She also worked with the professor on various excavations that he went to. Overall a pretty easy and engaging class, just make sure you show up to every lecture because he asks mini quiz questions throughout every lecture.
Two midterms and a final and online chapters quizzes, overall, interesting class and if you take notes it will be easy.
So fun I loved this class with Tsukamoto and you just have to keep up on the vocab and put in a bit of effort into the exercises and you’ll be good
Took it with Professor Stanton. Very awesome professor. Very understanding. It was asynchronous and heavy on memorization. The lectures were a little boring sometimes but overall a good class.

This class is pretty lecture heavy BUT there's no exams, only writing assignments / "projects" and so it's a pretty easy class if writing is your thing. Professor Santasilia is kinda strict at times and lectures are mandatory but it's a great class

(Spring 2021 Online) Professor Stanton. Maybe it's because the course was online but it was really simple. He had pre-recorded lectures but also held lectures that were optional. I never went and I did well on my quizzes/exams just by using the resources given by him. The class itself was graded by a few assignments given during discussion, easy chapter quizzes, 2 midterms, and the final. Discussion attendance is a must. (Be prepared to pay for the website/book he uses). Again, this course was online for me so it might be different when courses are back on campus.

DO NOT TAKE IF THE PROFESSOR IS NAWA SUGIYAMA. She's sweet but she goes through the ppt slides way too fast for anyone to take notes, and the "study guides" for the midterm and the final are literally just pages and pages of terms to memorize. And when most of the class bombed the midterm (the class average was a D-), she didn't curve it. You also *have* to buy the $80 book or you literally won't be able to complete any of the quizzes that were assigned for homework since they're on a separate website connected to the book. The midterm/final was a bunch of mc questions, pick 3 short answer questions, and one long essay question. She always uploads the slides and everything is in the textbook anyway so there's really no point in going to class.

Easy A. Took it with Stephan James. Completely asynchronous (10-30 minute podcasts). A couple of 3-4 sentence short assignments, a presentaion (3 minutes long, it is meant to be commercial of sorts for your final project) and a final project on a language of your choice(your given multiple options on how to do it: essay, powerpoint, art peice, presentation, podcast). Discussion section was just going over key points, show up and you get participation points.

Took it Winter '22 with Prof. Hyejin Nah. Professor is super nice and accommodating! She accepted late work from students all quarter without docking points and even dropped the last assignment to give us more time with our finals. Also, lecture and discussion attendance is mandatory.

I took it with Isabelle Placentia. She's pretty nice but not the best lecturer. She has a lot of requirements and specifics for assignments but doesn't really get into them. She believes there should be a discussion section for the class but there isn't, so she makes you do a lot of discussion type stuff to make up for it. One take home midterm and the final is a research project with a group. Attendance mandatory.

Took it iwth Isabelle Placentia. Very sweet woman and easy grader. You are graded by attendence, attendence at discussion, a midterm, and a research project (includes: Proposal, Outline, Annotated Bibliography, and the 5 page paper). All the readings are posted on ilearn.

Took with Professor Isabelle Placentia Fall 2021. The class was asynchronous bc the university overbooked her quarter and she had another class to teach during our scheduled time. Professor herself is super nice and understanding; she makes a real effort to help her students succeed. We met synchronously online for our discussion sessions. The class is graded on very few things; discussion attendance, a midterm, and a final paper. Discussion is really chill -- you just talk with your TA about the lecture. Midterm was MC, free response, and an essay question. A big chunk of our points came from that but it's super doable. There is a LOT of reading, but you don't need to read everything to do well. The paper covered health and healing techniques used by certain groups of people (ex: Shamanism). It was a group paper; each person wrote about 500 words to make a 2,000 word paper. Very easy class and interesting class. HOWEVER, this does not count for anthropology credit; it will count as an elective course. So if you want to knock out your sociology/psychology/anthropology breadth requirement, this course will not do that.

Took Professor Young Oh. 10 weekly response posts (500+ word response) and 2 response posts (100+ word response). A debate  video (group work optional; 10-30 minute video of you taking on the role of an anthropologists and debating a chosen topic). You have the choice of taking a comprehensive Final exam (multiple choice, True-false, and essay questions) or writing up a thesis (15 page summary-argumentation essay on the class). You can easily get by without the readings or videos, just familarize yourself with lecture slides. Hardest part of the class is if you try to keep up with all of the readings and videos, there are at least 10 each week.

Took Sara Becker. There are two major projects in the class, each being a month long. The first gives the option between a cemetery anaysis (going to a cemetery and writing a analytical report on it), and a monument burial analysis (you are given a fake monument burial scenario and have to analyze that). They are meant to be 5-6 pages long and you have the option of either doing it alone or as a group of up to 5 people. The second project is a oseobiography (choosing some bones and using knowledge learned in class to try and write a biography of the individual based on their remains; this being a 3-5 minute recording of you talking over a powerpoing and a written commentary - a couple pages). There are weekly discussions, lowest grade dropped. The midterm is about 40 questions long( multiple choice or matching letter to picture; all material from the lecture). You are allowed 1 page of notes, only one side. Final is in the same format but with a few more questions.
2 midterms, one take home quiz, and one final, good teacher, but you need to study HARD! Memorization is key to passing

Avoid Karl Taube. The class set up seems really simple but is stressful. You are only graded on a midterm and final. But his lecturing style makes note taking difficult. He does lectures in a story telling way and jumps back and forth between locations and time periods. The transition between topics is also very fluid and unclear. There is an extra credit paper you can do that will bring up your grade by a whole letter grade (a professor approved topic, 8-10 pages, with at least 3 sources). The midterm and final are 14 questions long (12 questions are identifying the who, what, and where of a site, defining a term, andor describing a prominent person; the last 2 are picking 2 essay questions from 3 given topics.). If taking him be sure to put major focus on memorizing names, dates, and major events tied to the sites he mentions.

Took it with Dr. Nawa Sugiyama. She works at a very fast pace and squishes in so much information into one session. Take pictures of the slides instead of taking notes so you can pay attention to what she is saying. There are weekely quizzes (only need to do 9 of 10), she uses PollEverywhere in class for participation, and there is group project on an ancient city of your choice (includes: the presentation, choosing an article for the class to read, making poll/quiz questions, and making a blog).

Online Summer course with Francisco Ramos. Very laid back professor. He grades mostly on effort of your assessments. There were 4 assignments, each being 1 - 2.5 pages (MLA format). For the online course we only had to attend class once a week. You could honestly get away with not readings or modules. Not sure how much will change once we go back to in person classes but he practically hands out A's. Textbook is given for free by professor along with any other reading materials.

Took it with Young Oh. LOTS OF WORK, AVOID THIS PROFESSOR. You are given 3 options: take weekly quizzes(10 total), 1-2 theses at the end of the quarter(7-12 pages), or a final exam(multiple choice, TF, Short answer, and essay questions) . There are weekly readings, weekly recorded lectures, 3 reflection posts(300-400 words) + feedback(100-200 words), 2 reading posts(400-800 words) +feedback(100-200 words), a book club meeting(30-90 minutes recorded and sent to professor), a meeting with the professor to discuss the topic for your eco-ethnography project, a climate change critique post(600-1000 words) + feedback(100-200 words), and an Eco-Ethnography project (includes: proposal, feedback, and the paper(2000-4000 words)).
no final, just write random stuff on your homeworks and you pretty much guarantee at least a B in that class
Avoid taking with Karl Taube

Took it with Professor Hyejin Nah. Just show up to class and turn it the assignments and it's an easy A. If you're doing a BCOE major this is a good one for DEPTH requirement if you happen to have a LING020 credit like I did.

Took Phuoc Duong. Weekly Responses (5 -10 sentences; 10 total). 1 syllabus quiz. 1 midterm (multiple choice; 52 questions). 1 Final (multiple choice). 1 final essay(6-8 pages)(For our class he took it out and added essay questions into the final due to time constraints.)Graded for attendance to lecture. Graded for attendance to discussion section. Lectures are a bit useless since he reads straight from the slide show, but he grades for attendance. before the midterm you can get away with not doing the readings since there are only 2-3 questions about the readings in the midterm, but after the midterm he starts to heavily rely on the readings in the weekly responses. Not a whole lot of work, just tedious.

Took it with Maureen Hickey. Its not a hard class itself but it was made more difficult because the lectures are so dry. She also loves break out rooms and will often leave you in those rooms for 30-40 minutes, way longer than needed. There are two midterms (30 multiple choice + one essay),a final (45 multiple choice + 5 writing prompts (1-6 sentences)), a term paper (4-6 pages), and a 30-60 second presentation on that papers findings. Be sure to make a group google doc so you can all add information for the midterm s and final, its really what got me through the class, cause it is impossible to pay attention.

Elizabeth Berger is pretty great. The course is generally hard due to you having to memorize the human skeleton but she makes it a bit easier by breaking it down. She does a quiz every Friday to test your knowledge. There are no midterms or final, just 10 of the Friday quizzes. There are also in class labs that you work on every class. Not too complicated or long and she is more than willing to go through it step by step if you ask. There is no set due date for any of the labs - just get them in when you finish. Slides for lecture at posted on elearn and the book is available on Amazon. She’s a pretty nice teacher and is no too harsh of a grader. No sure if it will continue but this quarter they are testing out giving students full skeletons to take home to study with - personally never took it out of the box.

Took Professory Anthony Jerry. There is a quarter long group project. There are 4 individual parts to turn in; question section, data section, methodology section and final report; all of it worth 175 points and takes place instead of a final. discussion posts (18 total; 2paragraphs minimum) with 2 responses (1 paragraph minimum). No midterm. He posts summaries of each readings instead of having lecture, you can read these instead of the readings, much shorter and to the point if you are short for time. He really takes his time grading, so don't expect to see anything graded till the end of the quarter.
ONLINE FALL 2022, EASY MONEY, quizzes every week but you can just do all of them at the start cause theyre all on quizlet, midterm and exams are easy too

This class is easy, just show up, take notes, and listen. They require you to do homework but you should go for the online stuff instead of purchasing the book because it is useless and you never use it again.

I took it with Anna Betbeze, but generally this type of art class is very subjective and no one is ever told "your drawing sucks." I got an A in the class, but you shouldn't struggle to get an A whether you're an Art major like me or not. When you register, it shows the class and studio time. It's one after the other, so you're there for nearly 3 hours. Don't get discouraged by the time, it's necessary to have a long class for art because of the activities you're doing and sometimes there will be critiques - where everyone goes around to talk about what they liked about the drawing and what could be improved/done differently. Attendance is mandatory, if you miss one class you can miss out on a lot if it was on a critique day. Your homework is 3 large drawings each week, and she gives you a theme for the drawings, it's all still life for the most part. This class does require you to buy art supplies.

(COVID ERA) I took this class with Gerald Sheffield and it was extremely easy. Art is a subjective course so you can pretty much do whatever you want in this class (as long as it pertains to the theme). Every week there's a new theme (figure, landscape, still life, etc.) and you just need to paint things based on that theme. The materials can get really pricey but Gerald was pretty lenient with whatever material you use. The online class was set up with you logging on and following Gerald's painting examples but there were also times where you explain your painting process and thoughts when you showcase and review your pieces in class. If you want an easy course without minding spending somewhere between $50-$100+ on materials then go for this class.

Online summer course with Pearl Hsiung and Rosie Galanis. Easy enough class. The hardest part is dedicating enough time to paint the assignments. There are a 3 smaller assignments focusing on color and scales, 3 medium paintings and 1 final large painting. If you take the class be sure to shop around as soon as you get the requirement list so you can get the best price. The kit she recommends to get for the class starts at about $120. Don't be afraid to get cheap materials. The art department also has free art supplies they give out, so be sure to check with them too.

took online with professor conaway, assignments were pretty simple and class time was mostly her showing photographers' work as examples or us presenting the photos we took for an assignment. labs are by appointment so you don't need to go unless you need help with smth. she was really nice & class was fun and straightforward!

OMG EASIEST CLASS EVER WITH SARAH first day of class mandatory, it's soo easy mondays are when she shares the images you took in class and wednesdays she would show slideshow of pics SUPER EASY CLASS i would barley even attend class and i got a A little photography assignments like taking 5 portrait pics for one week SUPER EASY RECOMMEND 100%
Super easy with Professor Charles Long. There is reading tho.

Took Young Joon Kwak. Only difficult due to the professor having poor management skills. I took them in the fall quarter so thanksgiving got in the way of the final project. We only have 1 in class day to work on the final project and have to take it home to finish over break. The class over all is relatively chill. Since it’s an art class the art is subjective. Professor just needs to see that you have put in effort. There are 3 reading - 2 require write ups- and each project requires a project statement. Also different from the name you are not working with clay or ceramics. The class is about building sculptures with wood,metal,plaster, etc. It’s definitely a messy class, have clothes you don’t mind getting dirty.

took online with professor larios, you can probably get away with not doing anything for this class but you'll understand the material more if you actually attend class. lectures were pretty heavily discussion-based so it was mostly us talking about the readings/videos but you don't have to talk at all if you're not comfortable. in short, the class was easy and the material is very thought-provoking but can be hard to digest sometimes.
Great class. Mostly analysis of videos and the class is genuinely fun. Find a way to take it while the sun is up though cause walking back to the dorms from the Art Building is kind of scary.
The professor is really chill. If u get 85 or above, you get an A

I took this class with professor Paul Larsen and honestly one of the easiest classes I’ve taken. Everything is online, open note, open internet. There’s only two projects and overall he literally just wants you to listen and learn. Discussion is optional. Lecture I reccommend going to not because the material is hard but just he is a really funny guy and the stuff you learn is actually really helpful if you wanna learn about how to eat healthier .
Wet lab fairly simple but fitting everything in flowchart is a little tedious. Computer lab is easy but the quizzes kind of suck. Only need basic chem knowledge.

Molecular graphics portion was super easy, wet lab was a little harder with more math, but overall everything was easy. Molecular graphics test was a project and the wet lab final was open note and take home. Easily the easiest A I’ve ever had.

(Took it during Winter 2021 when classes were online) The class was relatively ok. The first half taught by Dr. Dingwall was more structured and I think easier to follow along with because it is similar to other underdiv wet lab courses. The second half that was taught by Dr. Fan was a lot more difficult for me mainly because it was unlike any other class I had taken before. You had to use this other online software to analyze molecules and you basically just followed along as Dr. Fan would show you what to do. Homework was assigned weekly and that wasn't too bad as long as you paid attention during lecture. Overall, the class isn't difficult; it's just tedious and requires a lot of time.

Basically a freshman seminar for students who are majoring in Biochemistry (Pass/No Pass). Super easy class and you need to seriously try if you want to fail. Professor Debus makes it really easy for you to get points (4 question quizzes that you have unlimited attempts to finish by a deadline and Poll.ev aka. think of a clicker but online). All of the lectures are useful for you as a student because it introduces you to different resources that will help you find your path and support you during your time at UCR. Although I had enough points to pass the class, I still went to lectures for that reason.

Took it with Richard Luben. At the first class, he said he would take attendance using Poll Everywhere but he never did, so majority of the class never went. Pass/No Pass class that's super easy as long as you complete the online quizzes about each presentation posted online. Even though the overall class was boring, some of the presentations taught me about more opportunities to get involved in UCR and the community to help me build up my resume as a freshman.
Very useless class. Mandatory for Biochem majors with medical emphasis. One paper on plan for medical school. Class was a rehash of BCH 95 but just with the paper.
Dingwall is the best prof for this course. Cutoffs are awesome. But dont fall behind in her coursework.
The only reason i didn't give this a 10/10 for difficulty was the pass rate was 95%

Taken with Paul Larsen. Honestly was much easier than expected. Test are fair, he tells you what will be on it. There is a lot to memorize but if you keep with it it should not be a problem. Larsen is also really funny and makes class enjoyable, would recommend recording his lectures!

I really liked P. Larsen. He was really funny which made it easy to pay attention in class. He had 5 quizzes taken during discussion so we didn't always have to go to discussion every week. We had only one midterm and the final. He recorded lectures which was really nice because he tends to talk fast. Just make sure to be on top of your stuff and you'll do well.
Medium difficulty; take it with Paul Larsen. He teaches well, gives extra credit, and curves the class as well at the end.
Dingwall was amazing and fair. Focus on her lectures to do well on the exam. Grade is determined by 8 homework assignments. Grade is determined by 1 midterm and 1 final

Took it with Dingwall and Eulgem online during Spring 2021. Tbh one of my favorite classes at UCR so far. The profs are extremely passionate and very helpful if you go to office hours. The material is a bit difficult to keep up with at first, but it is very manageable. To study for midterms, I would write out notes based off of the learning objectives. Then I would make Anki cards using my notes and the exact wording that was used on the learning objectives. Try to start memorizing pathways 2-3 days before the exams (at least).

Dr. Dingwall is amazing! Everything you need to know is on her lectures, so really study them and understand it inside out. Midterm and finals are similar to quizzes and homework. Very nice professor and tries to make subject as easy as possible.
take with Larsen, great teacher, cares about students and super hard to fail class (you would have to really try to fail) he gives you so many redemption points
Dr. Dingwall is the best! As long as you study how she tells you to, this class is an easy A.

Spring 2023, all in person. Exams are all free response. Points system (total 400 points). 150 (2 midterms), 80 (9 weekly homework, drops the lowest), 70 (weekly quizzes, drops lowest), 100 points (final exam) 

Professor Dingwall is amazing. Great lecture and teaching style. Taught this class like it was a story and used real life examples in every lecture. There was a logical and reasonable order to the topics we were learning. Lectures were very enjoyable and entertaining. She uploads lecture slides a week in advance, but I didn't need to look at them beforehand or studying anything before. I just showed up to class and did all the studying after. The exams were fair. Exam viewing and not giving back tests was a new concept to me. I understand the premise, but it did make studying for future exams different and more difficult as I wasn't able to go back and see how she likes to structure her exams. But, I don't disagree or believe it drastically affected my grades and how I study/learn. The lecture slides are very helpful as well as her summary outlines. I especially like the templates she provided and how she drew them in class with us. The most important study tool I utilized in this class was rewatching the lectures through Yuja. I did not do this for every single lecture, only the ones where we were filling in our templates. It was vital for me to be able to go back and look back at the videos as she does not post a completed version of her notes. Her office hours were helpful as well. She was very approachable and encouraging towards me as a student. Content was very dense for this class, but it was as expected. I like how we had homework every week as it kept me on top of my studies as well as the weekly quizzes. It helps cushion my grade in the class so it is not only the midterms and finals that compose of my final grade. Thank you Dr. Dingwall.

So many reactions, so little time.  Dingwall is a wonderful professor with terrific cutoffs (average is about a B-, I think), but the material is difficult, so give yourself lots of time to study and prepare for each exam.

Biochemistry is a very difficult subject going into if you don’t put in the work for the class. Took this class with Dr. O’Leary and Dr. Blaha and both were really great professors. Dr. O’Leary kept the lecture a little more upbeat than Dr. Blaha but both of them truly want their students to succeed. Averages are mid to high 60s but the deviations for grades are huge. An A is definitely attainable and having them record their lectures and post them up on iLearn was really useful when wanting to study for exams.
Avoid Blaha, he's very boring lol

The material itself was not bad, it was actually interesting. The only problem was that there is so much material you have to know but only a few would show up in the exam. Exams were difficult, some were straight from the power point, but some were also from the power point but written differently. Understand the material and you'll be good.
Had it with Dr.Dingwall, she is an amazing professor but don't fall behind on the lecture notes/material

Lots of work, but Dingwall makes the class a great experience. Her and the TAs are very open to helping you, so don't hesitate to go to their office hours for help. If you put in the effort you'll definitely get that A

The instructor is super dry but the class is early in the morning which lets you get it over with early and all of the slides are there with the information to memorize and they have outline questions to help. Get the big concepts down and you'll be fine.

The class consists of pure lectures and talks from research professors and faculty from different branches of the bioengineering department. Really cool stuff, only homework is a one page summary of each talk. No final, only presentation of senior design projects.
Easy A. Just make something that works & present it (if it doesn't, do a proof of concept/analyze why it doesn't work).

Took it with Dr. Grover. Really cool class that finally lets you learn more about actual bioengineering and creating projects relating to bio instruments and we got to learn how to code with arduino, and we also learned Matlab programming and COMSOL Multiphysics. Really cool class. One easy midterm and final presentation group project.

Dr. Mckee typically teaches this. It was super dense but interesting. Exam avgs were super low and he gave us terrible 1 minute pop quizzes that everyone tanked. The "projects" were dumb and the hw assignments were massive

Took with Dr. Rodgers. You have a COMSOL big group project, two very tough exams (averages were never above 50/100, last exam average was 37/100) and HW that is very long but if you push through they help you understand concepts.

wow <3 this class is genuinely dreadful. One of the most universally loathed courses among bioengineers. Study hard, take excellent notes, and prioritize the quarter-long group project (it was worth ~45% of the total grade for my year). The first two exams had a 25% and 40% average, and the final avg was 12% (TWELVE.)

Taken with Rodgers Winter 2022 (ONLINE), and easily the worst weeder class one must encounter in their career as a Bioengineering major. Heavy on DE concepts, and there are 3 midterms that make up the majority of the grade, along with a project with randomly assigned groups that require you to present at the end of the quarter about COMSOL simulations. The midterm averages were never above 50%, but if there is someone retaking the course as a 5th year, the curve would be completely shot. The concepts are extremely difficult to answer, and Rodgers likes in-class participation, so be prepared to be called on when you are in lecture, and if you want to ask a question, Rodgers will answer your questions with even more questions.
Interesting material and doable assessments. Dr. Park is always a good professor -- you can tell he genuinely enjoys teaching and cares about his students.

Worst class I've ever taken. Dr. Christopoulos' has a thick greek accent and speaks at a mile a minute so it was frankly impossible to keep up while writing notes. The material is pure abstract math with a linear algebra lean. Exams were awful with avgs in the ~50-60 range. There's a final and a final project involving a group term paper.

Took with Dr. McKee. Nice professor, he is a little disorganized but the class is just mostly pretty easy. Weekly quizzes instead of tests, a project due at end of the quarter. Class covers some Biochem/Bio and focuses on genetic cloning.

Taken with Liao Winter 2022 in-person. Class is very heavy on lab-time and lab-times are long, since protein purification requires a lot of waiting/watching/idle time. Most of the grade is composed of the lab reports you write, which would be easy if you go to lab discussions and TA's office hours and just badger them with questions (they just give you answers at some point and teach you how to solve for a lot of the calculations).
I took this class with Dr. Freedman. It's basically EE001/005 part 2. Review your circuit theory and don't procrastinate on the lab reports.

Taken with Freedman Spring 2022 (ONLINE). The lab portion of this class was very intensive, as in you will be assigned to a random lab partner and if your partner does not pull their weight, you will be stuck in lab for all 3 hours. The reports were relatively long, but not harshly graded, and the majority of the exam questions (multiple choice and free response) were on Canvas and the concepts were in the exam study guides/slide presentations.

Took with Palermo, grade was made up of 2 exams and a project. All the exam questions were from the textbook, the answers to which were gone over by the TA in disucssion. Averages on exam were 95+%. Project took ~4 hours to complete
I took this class when Dr. Palermo was teaching. She's super sweet and accomodating but very scattered and Very Italian. When I took it the course breakdown was 50% MT 50% Final. Total breeze.

Took with McKee. Is a hell of a lot of memorization, on average each lecture has 50 slides and is densely packed with chemical and physiological information. Averages on quizzes/exams are chronically low due to the sheer volume of information. Interesting class, dedicate a lot of time to this

Taken with Dr. Mckee. This class was super interesting, but incredibly dense and information heavy. Strong emphasis on memorization. Difficult weekly quizzes with notoriously low averages and exams that follow an FRQ experimental design based format. Study hard!!! Write extremely detailed notes and you should be fine.
I took it with Dr.McKee and this class was extremely easy. It was a straight Biomaterials memorization class.
Dr. McKee is one of the sweetest and most caring professors. The class is incredibly easy.

taken with noshadi, who is very nice but a little inconsistent between slides/lectures due to disorganization. mostly memorization, pay attention to lectures to catch the discrepancies between his words said in lectures vs. his slides (his speech/lecture would be the accurate one), and you will be okay
More challenging than 140A but only barely. Put effort into the weekly literature reviews.

Typically taught by Dr. Park. Not an easy A, but really fascinating material if you're interested in optics/biomedical imaging. He gives you everything you need to succeed on the HW and exams as long as you focus and ask good questions.
The labs are easy enough, but unnecessarily time consuming due to waiting around for limited equipment. The lab reports are gnarly but necessary for performing well on the final group presentation.
Long live Dr. Grover. This class was graded purely on 3 extremely easy and fun projects. All of my friends and I ended with a perfect score.

Taken with Grover Fall 2022, it was an easy A considering Grover is the most considerate/thoughtful/nice prof in BIEN at UCR. You will be assigned to 3 projects, the lectures are not graded based on attendance, and you just have to show up to the 3 activities in your own time and complete them before the quarter ends. The 3 projects are consisting of microfluidics and microscopic activities, and one presentation where you simulate your own microfluidic chip and how it would work with flow, and the TA will be there to help you out throughout all the activities. There are no HW assignments, just the 3 activities/projects.

Senior design is what you make of it. Choose your group and project VERY CAREFULLY. They will make or break your entire year. I took w Dr. Park and Dr. Mckee and their lectures were marginally helpful. Assignments were repetitive and time consuming.

Taken with Park/McKee co-teaching, and most of it was busy work (a lot of writing/documentation/literary research). Put a lot of time into going into office hours and ask questions so the professors think of you highly since most if not all skills acquired in senior design is self-taught (e.g., SolidWorks, MATLAB, etc.). Assign yourself to different tasks, be organized, and communicate with your teammates thoroughly. SD is tough in general just due to how BIEN is structured at UCR, but you can do it

Taken with Vullev/McKee Winter 2023, the brunt of this quarter for senior design is mainly the building of your device with your team, and programming it. There was an individual interview assigned at random on a weekly basis rotating through all the students to make sure you were doing equal work/not slacking, and you are graded heavily based on the individual interview and the presentation at the end of the quarter. At around week 8, there would be demos/presentations to show that your device could complete at least one (+points if <1) functionality, and you could explain to the rest of the class why this functionality is important/significant. There are also biweekly progress meetings with TAs you have to schedule in your own time, to update them on how far your device has gotten with progress.

Taken with Grover (as part of his research lab) as Special Studies in Winter 2023. Depending on your prof/PI, you will be asked to submit a journal/apply+participate in a research event (like the Undergraduate Research Symposium, or Undergraduate Mini-Grant), requiring you to show up in lab for at least 12 hours a week. Grover wasn't strict about the hours nor the topic presented at the Symposium, so long that all of his undergrads get involved with industry professionals for better of their futures. No assignments, no exams, just deadlines running on UGR schedule (which does not update online often so be vigilant about the deadlines)

Took w Dr. Nam. Bar none my favorite class so far. Material was engaging and incredibly fascinating. Exams were challenging and assessed genuine comprehension of the lectures. It was easy to put in substantial effort into this course because I woke up excited to attend.

Cellular basis of life, taken with Quinn McFrederick. Class itself isn't too difficult. It's biology for non-majors so no-one expects too much of you. General intro to biology course. Labs require a lab coat though, which is fun. Midterms and final aren't too bad, just study mastering biology and the previous in class material and you'll be fine.

Took the class with Maslov. Maslov only had exams, but you'll be fine even if you never went to lecture by simply studying the slides as well as the past midterms he provides for the respective midterms. Labs were easy, since you never really do anything complicated and could just follow the lab manual step by step, and most of the time, they were short and you'll be leaving early.

Took this with McFrederick. The midterm and finals are based on previous homeworks and quizzes and they are open notes. Class is pretty free as long as you do the quizzes and homeworks. Homeworks and quizzes have unlimited tries and they take the highest scores so basically full points on both categories. Labs are extremely easy as long as you follow the instructions which aren't difficult at all.

Took the class with Lucy Delaney and the course was really easy. Only 5 quizzes throughout the course for the lecture, which is 70% of your grade, and the other 30% comes from lab. Lots of extra credit opportunities to bump you up as much as 15% if you decide to do everything. Easy A class if you need a biology as a breadth requirement.

Professor McFrederick is hands down one of the best professors at UCR. In my four years at this university, I've never met a more passionate professor than him and I'm not even a biology major. I wish more professors were like him and were passionate about the subject rather than trying to weed out students with their hard tests and assignments. Dr. McFrederick really cares and is a cool person and generally wants everyone to succeed and have a greater appreciation for biology than before you took his class.

Took it with Spasojevic/Regan. Pretty easy A if you studied for the exams and understood the labs. None of the labs took all three hours and weren't too hard, they were just repetitive. The exams were pretty straightforward but there is definitely a lot of information that needs memorization. There were clickers but they didn't dock off points for getting the question wrong and they gave full points if you got at least 70%. I missed a couple of classes but was still able to get the full points.

Had Marko Spasojevic. He posts the slides after every lecture. One quiz every week (no matter what you get you will get full credit for just attempting it). Two midterms and one final (all of them being multiple choice). As long as you review the slides given and retain some of that information, it is a pretty easy class. Labs: Be sure to read the lab handout before class as there will be a quiz at the beginning of every lab covering information from that week's lecture and from the given handout. Beware of Scott Mondrala, he's an older dude and drags on class for much longer than needed. He knows his stuff but is not the best teacher.
Maslov is an easy professor. Test averages 60-70
Just go to lecture and actually pay attention
I found this class to be the easiest of the series. Take Nothnagel/Martins-Green if you can. Their curve is generous and they're very nice people.

Read the book and go over posted powerpoints.  Maslov and Kaloshian post practice problems too, so go over those to get a feel of the midterm/final styles.  No need to go to class if you read the material.

I had it with Maduro -- he is doing this new system where he made ~50 videos covering the material, and instead of having lectures has the videos due semiweekly (with "clicker" quiz questions inside) and holds office hours for lecture. I actually really enjoyed it, most of my friends didn't attend lecture if it was their first class and still got A's (I got an A-). One thing to watch out for is he will try to trick you on the midterms (all multiple choice): you will read the question, immediately know the answer, and when you get the midterm back realize you read it wrong! Be sure to read each midterm question carefully, and if you are choosing "the obvious answer" read the question and think of the concept carefully. Beyond that, he is hilarious, the videos are hilarious, but the lecture/OH is a bit boring (he repeats himself... a lot). Still, most I know really struggle with Bio 5A, Maduro knows this and tries to give us as much help as possible without throwing A's at us. He'll give you every exam he's ever written (some going back to 2006 I think?), do them all! Oh, and a pro-tip I wish I discovered sooner: the video have a "view captions" tab, and most of the quiz questions (which halt the video) are discussed right after in the script, so you can look there "to confirm your answer".

This was the hardest class out of the BIOL005 series for me, as it was extremely focused on chemistry. I took it with Sarjeet Gill and Omar Akbari; Gill was a good professor but he went so fast during lecture while Akbari was the opposite and Akbari's slides were a mess. Akbari seemed like he was extremely passionate in teaching but you can be as passionate as you want and still be a not so great professor

Class was split between Katayoon Dehesh and Maneula Martins-Green. While Dehesh was a bit all over the place, her test questions were more straight-forward than MMG, whose questions are more similar to AP Bio questions.

Not hard but covers a lot of material in a short amount of time. Just stay on top of your studying and you should be fine. Had Dr. Adler and Dr. Mauck. There were 3 midterms, a final, and no homework.

Took it with Dr. Dillman and Dr. Mauck. I prefered Dillman of the two becuase kahoot really allowed you to pinpoint what you knew. Mauck had activities that layed out all the sequences though. Other than that you dont really need to go to lecture. Had 3 midterms and a final, all of which i thought were pretty straightforward. Just study outside of class, do well in discussion, and you should be good.
This class was extremely hard. Points only stemmed from quizzes, two midterms and one final. Don't mess up on any of them as it will extremely affect your grade in the end.

Took it with Dr.Gil. One of the most tedious classes. Covers lots of material, so make sure to read the book and get all the concepts down. I think we had one midterm and one final. The problems were multiple choice, but they were very specialized on the comprehension of processes and concepts.

Take Maduro's version if you can. His averages are higher, he gives a ton of his past exams with answers, and you do not have to go to class. But definitely you have to be self-motivated to do the weekly videos which count for points. His exams test for real undrstanding and he gives new questions each time so you can't just memorize the old tests. The videos are straight forward/to the point and I saved a ton of time by doing them on my own and skipping the classes. THis is totally the way an intro Bio course should be done, sitting in a class watching someone go through a bunch of powerpoints in an hour doesn't really work and Maduro gets that.
DO NOT TAKE WITH MARTINS GREENS. study the book and go to class or you wont do well.

Had Professor Ray Andasknar and Professor Alder Dilman. Dilman taught the first half, and his midterm was pretty straight forward. If you read the reading notes and looked over the notes for Dilman his exam wasn't bad. For Professor Ray it was a harder midterm because he kinda cant word things good (ex. grammar issues) but they aren't bad either. For him you're gonna need to put in more effort though. The final wasn't bad, but don't cram for the final as it was worth a lot. Overall, 5A material isn't hard you just have to make the time to study which is what gets to people.

Had Dahesh and Martins-Green. Dahesh is charismatic and made the lectures engaging. Martins-Green seems to get a bad rep, but I think she means well and really wants students to learn. Overall I didn’t find lectures to be enough and needed to read the book. Exams are multiple choice. Midterms were about the same difficulty but final had more convoluted questions imo.

Took it with Dehesh and Martins-Green (Dehesh for the 1st half, Martins-Green for the 2nd). Both use clickers in class and the questions sometimes end up being on the exams. Dehesh's exams were way more straightforward and Martins-Green's exams required slightly more analyzing (similar to AP Bio questions in high school) but were still manageable. Reading the textbook helps a lot with filling in the details because both professors go over topics very generally (especially towards the end). Personally, I found this class relatively manageable but that's most likely because I've taken gen bio courses before.
Very hard and conceptual test questions given with a very limited time frame! Wish I had more time to finish the tests! Also wish the teacher taught more material

took this class w/ professor Maduro during spring 2020, even though I enjoyed the recorded lectures and ability to earn points through them, his tests were extremely difficult for me. The tests were not similar at all with the practice exams. If you want to pass, you NEED to study, and really grasp the application of the concepts.
Maduro is picky so u have to really try to get an A average was a 54 percent for most tests and that ended up being a B
Maduro is the best professor, esp how he formats the class. His class could get difficult, but do the practice exams and that should help a ton

[COVID-19 SPRING 20] Took this class ONLINE with Ryan Joseph and Zhenbiao Yang. Both professors are very nice and passionate about their field. Joseph is an exceptional teacher and organizes his slides in a very efficient and easy to understand way. I definitely learned more from Joseph. Some of the information he teaches coincides with what you learn in Chem 1B (for the first few weeks at least). Yang is not as good in terms of clarity and presentation of information, but he will gladly answer questions and explain topics more thoroughly if need be. Both professors opted for online videos that you could watch at any time. Yang held his Zoom lecture at the scheduled time, but also uploaded said lecture online. There are two midterms and a final and it was all open book. As long as you take detailed notes from the slides, you will earn a good grade.

Took Martins-Green/Dehesh in Winter 2021. Honestly, I was struggling during the class. I barely understood what was being said, despite reading the book chapters assigned. Definitely skip. Grade is based on discussion, two midterms, and a final.

Had it with Mauck/Atkinson. Mauck is pretty good but Atkinson isn't the best lecturer as he goes on tangents and isn't very focused. The class grading is very generous as discussion is 35% of the class and its easy to get an A+. Still recommend

LOVE Professor Delaney wish we had her the whole quarter but they switched off halfway to Professor Atkinson. Delaney is literally the sweetest and the best professor I've had at UCR so far. She makes the lecture really interesting and you can tell the effort she puts into her slides. I also really loved her lecture style and annotating on the slides. Atkinson, on the other hand, it was really hard to pay attention during class. He said a lot of words but none of them were getting through to me. His slides are really cluttered and confusing and his voice is so monotone. But both their exams are pretty easy. No homework :)) I don't know if that was a good thing or bad.

had it with maslov and martins-green. Maslov is a good professor but martins green is pretty difficult and her lectures are hard to follow. she has unreasonable expectation of students and thinks everyone wants to cheat. try to avoid

I took it with Professor Sachs. He's chill at doing lectures and office hours, but for his exams are pretty tough due to questions being too ambiguous that there's no clear answer choice to answer them. It's more like select the best answer choice and there's some questions that are none of the above as potential correct answer. I would recommend go over the practice exam qs, attend his office hours where he'll do more practice exam qs, go to SI, attend TA's office hours, and simplify lecture materials/concept for easy memorization. He also do extra credits (10 points max) that'll make a huge difference for your grades where you ask him a question in lecture and he'll give you extra credit slip (earn only one per lecture). Overall course is based on 2 midterms, weekly discussion quizzes and hw, and 1 final. There's grade cut-off where getting 80% out of total will be considered as A-. Take him as an alternative option if you don't find a good BIOL005A professor.

Had with giraldo and martins-green. Giraldo was great, she told us everything that was expected of us and put all her content on slides. MG is pretty difficult, lectures are confusing, expects you to remember examples that she doesn't include on slides, and her exam questions are application heavy and confusing.

Quizzes are easy and short multiple choice questions.  Lab exercise grades depend on pickiness of TA.  Final sucked hard--it had material that wasn't learned in class.  Whoever wrote it didn't have good English skills either.
Overall not too hard. Actually try on the worksheets and read the lab manual before each lab and you should be fine. Final is difficult and dropped me 6% but the curve brought me back up to an A.
Overall, the labs were easy but my TA was too harsh on grading. Final was also really focused on the expected results per lab.

The lab portion itself is easy. You do worksheets in the class and the material correlates a lot to lecture so it helps with the learning process. The prelab quiz are really easy and a quick skim though the lab manual you can get full credit on those quizzes. For the 3 major quizzes thought the quarter, really focus on the results and the procedures and look over the worksheets and you will be good. This quarter (Fall 2019) I thought the lab final was cake, as it was just all the worksheets and the practice exam that were on the exam, but do study if you want high grade. I think they might've change the 5LA final because people previous quarters told me it was very difficult and stuff on it wasn't learned, but that wasn't the case this quarter.

Labs are easy, but my TA graded harshly and people rarely got full credit on assignments. Worksheets are straightforward and the 3 bigger quizzes emphasized results. I’d study learning objectives, review results and the reasoning, not many calculations or stuff about procedure. Overall, I was more worried about my lab grade than the actual class grade which is lame.
It was very easy don't stress about it

BIOL05LA labs are easy but very time consuming to do where some experiments take longer to do it along with answering the lab worksheet qs. It depends, but you have to draw diagrams of lab experiment's procedures as pre-labs. There's some point where you have to do exactly as the procedure tells you to not screw up, and there's some cases where you might have to re-do the lab experiment in case of mishaps. In addition, sometimes the TA grading are weird/ a bit harsh as they mark off points for some worksheet qs that are wrong despite your answers are correct but looks wrong. So, re-read the lab manual and make sure that you can find the answer of the worksheet qs from the lab manual. Midterm and Final are mostly conceptual from what you are learning while doing the labs, not based on procedures of the lab. Lastly, 1 group project at the end of the quarter based on fish frauds through DNA labs.
Heavy memorization

Avoid Chappell at all costs. This class is challenging regardless of the professor but Chappell makes it absolute hell. I've heard that Redak is still kind of hard, so keep your guard up around him too.
Avoid Chapell if he's still teaching. His tests are extremely difficult
Make sure you know everything on the notes. And I mean everything

It was incredibly difficult because there is a lot of information that you must memorize. It is a requirement for most CNAS students and some BCOE students but overall it was an interesting class, but lots to memorize!
Redak's material was hard.  Study for the final.

Had Regan/Hammond. No curve that would help your grade. Regan gets questions from the textbook. Hammond creates her own questions. Pure memorization. Hardest out of the BIOL 5 Series. Its normal to retake the class.
Much tougher than Biol005A as there is a lot much information to learn. Understanding the main ideas, trends, and applying them are key to succeeding in this course.
Extremely hard if you get Chappel
Chappell is the destroyer of GPAs.

This class is hard in general, heavy memorization and application. Everyone says to avoid Chappel but honestly hes a good teacher and his curve got me an A. Make sure you got all clicker points, and a very high grade in the lab.

Took it with Dr. Chappell. One of the hardest classes I’ve ever taken, he covers so much material during lectures and he has extremely hard clicker questions. He tends to ask questions that require a very high level of comprehension of material. Two midterms, one final. I remember scoring class average (20%) but huge curve saved us!
Had Redak, his exams are based on his lectures but will force you you to think outside the box most of the time. Trust your gut.

I thought it was harder than BIOL005A because there is a lot to memorize since most of what we learn is about animal and plant diversity. Definitely stay on top of studying/reading because it's a lot to memorize.

Took with Santiago and Campbell. The class average on the final was 57% and the curve will likely help me pass. Lab is the key to passing. Don’t slack off in lab. Heavy memorization and less application based than 5A

Took it with Redak. There's a ridiculous amount of information to memorize and his questions are messy and really test your conceptual understanding of the material. However, getting a good grade is completely doable as long as you keep up with the material. Pay attention to small details in the slides. Going to lecture helped a lot in pin pointing what would be on exams, but he mainly just reads off slides so its not completely necessary. He said he wouldn't curve, but most of my friends ended up with half a letter grade higher than expected. However, I wouldn't rely on this as I know he did not curve the quarter before I took the class.
Study the slides given in class and you will do well. I had santiago and got an A. Also make sure to do well in Lab those are easy points.
Class is not bad. However, make sure to study consistently. Also, there is a curve usually if you take the class with Santiago.

Multiple choice for all test questions. If you have Mauck, her tests are more analysis of the material rather than memorization. If you have Atkinson, his tests are more memorization than analysis - he uses questions from the practice tests sometimes or similar ones. Stephanie is a great TA - stick with her if you end up getting her. In general tho - TOPIC NOTES. They save your life.

5B was a trip. Definitely hardest of the series in terms of the amount of material you're expected to know. BUT I had Ryan Joseph who is a LEGEND for 5B. His lecture notes are really organized and structured in a very clean and organized way that made studying for this class easier and not have to scramble through slides and whatnot. He also post study questions for each lecture that are crucial for doing good on the test. This is a memorization class but his questions really helped you pinpoint what you should know for the exams as his exams were fair and reflected the study questions he posted. Rack as many points as you can in lab because if you do good in lab it really boost your overall grade. I would highly recommend Ryan Joseph for 5B as this truly is a weeder class.

Had it with Redak/Campbell Spring 2020. They were really nice and understood what everyone was going through. The class was hard as everyone made it seem - lots of memorization especially the first half. It gets easier when you get out of the animal section. You could get A's on the exams by memorizing the lectures, I didn't open the book once the entire quarter.

Took it with Meyer Summer 2020. Lectures and slides were clear and he is helpful in office hours. Meyer was also extremely fair with grading. Tests were not difficult if you studied (they were also open note because of remote learning). I thought the content was easier than Bio 5A. Lab and homework was super easy too. Grading scale: 45% Tests (15% per exam), 35% HW, 20% Lab.

(Fall 2020 Online) I gave this a 8/10 in difficulty. This class is HEAVY MEMORIZATION and there is so so so so so so so much information. It's not the professors fault honestly, it's just what this class entails. You also have to be able to build upon information. I took it with Dr. Scott Kelly. He does recorded lectures with set of notes and holds live office hours. The videos can be long and kind of boring because of his monotone voice. I recommend you read the notes before you start the videos, that way you learn and retain more during the videos. There are 2 noncumulative midterms, 3 noncumulative quizzes, and 1 cumulative final. Please take this class seriously and study at least one week before each exam or quiz. Dr. Kelly did a great job of providing "What you need to know" slides at the end of each lecture so that you can really pinpoint what to study. There is NO CURVE and NO EC. I also recommend doing well on the very first midterm as that will set the stage and also get 100% on your lab portion as that is 25% of your final grade and can really give you that boost. I somehow scraped by with a B.

had it with santiago and delaney spring 2022! very good combo theyre the best :) extra credit and they tell you exactly what u need to know for the exams. try to take them!! no cumulative final; just 4 exams
Had Delaney, she's a really good prof. She lists everything that we will need to know for the exams. Material itself isn't hard, it's mostly just memorization

memorization heavy, so far the hardest class I've taken in college and required a lot of study hours. the tests are super hard and the lab TAs really control your grade so if you have a harsh lab ta its really hard to do well. destroys gpas
Do worksheets and get easy points that go to lecture grade.

My TA was Sabbir Ahmed (spring 2020). He didn't answer any questions during the zoom labs which made it really hard to understand the worksheets especially as we couldn't do the lab in person. Otherwise a cool dude, just didn't adapt well.

(Fall 2020 Online) I gave this class a 4/10 in difficulty because it was a pretty straight forward lab. Just do the assigned reading chapters and you will literally get 100% on all the quizzes as the questions are picked from the chapter. The worksheets are also straight forward and the TA sometimes goes over them in class so that you are able to check your answers. This lab is worth 25% of your final BIOL005B Lecture so do well!! It can really make a difference between a C and a B-.
Easiest of the bio 5 series
Easiest in the series, just keep up with it. Make sure to know the notes at least
Pretty easy stuff.  Know the calculations portion.  Nunney and Rafferty were pretty good.
Easiest of the series. Took with Rafferty and Nunney. Just make sure you study a lot of people get cocky and end up doing poorly on the 2nd midterm and final because of it.
Took Nunney and Rafferty (not sure about spelling) Keep up with the lectures and you should be fine.

Had Prof. Rankin (teaches first 5 weeks/Ecology), and Prof. Stouthamer (teaches last 5 weeks/Evolution). Overall, wasn't all that bad. We had three tests total; two midterms and a final. All were multiple choice. Rankin's portion was slightly harder because we had to analyze graphs and make sure to know when to apply certain formulas (but she always gave us a formula bank so that was good!). Stouthamer's portion was -personally- a bit more boring, but if you study his slides you'll get by alright. Pulled a B+ but I believe an A is definitely doable. Lab portions are easy.

I think I got a relatively bad grade but I really neglected studying for this course bc it really is one of those you can get away with skipping lecture and cramming with. I took it with Michael Anderson/Bai-Lian Li.

Relatively easy class. Took it with Rafferty/Degnan. Rafferty content is super easy while Degnan is much more difficult and dense. No books required, only clickers. Grades are about 70% exams, 10% clicker, 20% lab. Two midterms, both worth 10-15%. Final is a big chunk being about 45%. Lab portion super easy.

Huge step down from BIOL 005B. Studying for this class is much easier than it was for BIOL 005B. For the lab portion, your grade in lab is highly dependent on participation and this final  group project. The group project is pretty easy as long as you have a good group and an easy project. The exams were not too difficult to study for, but for the final exam, make sure to study the lab portion because there will be 10 questions from the lab portion that is not covered in lecture.

Only reason why I gave this such a high difficulty is because the professors are complete assholes when it comes to grading for 5C. Please for the love of everything do not take Prof. Ponisio, this quarter was hell in 5C cause of her and her lying and unprofessionalism. Prof Hansen for Evolution was more understanding and more content on her notes so studying for her part of the class was easier. 5C material is the easiest of the series and the professors know that students push this class on the backburner so they make the grading scale harder than of 5B and 5A. If you study consistently then you can easily get an A, but I studied the night before the exams and walked out with a B.
Not a hard class, but don’t neglect it, as information piles on fast. 4 tests so you do have tests often, but material is not cumulative so its not too bad

Genetics and evolution. Pretty digestible concepts and easy math. If you took AP Bio, this is review. Very cram-worthy considering midterms (2) and the final were taken almost directly from the slides. Never attended lecture and did fine. Barry Li and Ring Carde.

Class is chill. Not a cake walk, but chill. Most professors are fine. You'll be fine in this class. The ONLY exception is a professor named Ring Carde. DO NOT take this class with Ring Carde because when I had him as a professor, the entire class panicked for the final. 

- He is a boomer when it comes to technology (he posted 3 hours videos because he forgot to stop the recording after the first hour, and would make an announcement to the class saying "I dont know why this upload is taking forever" yeah well its because you forgot to record so the file is massive).
