His final also showed the answers early, so if you were on the phone with someone else while taking the exam and one person turns it in, they can tell you what is correct and incorrect which I think everyone didn't expect.
- His videos were boring and the slides were poorly made (you would see text boxes all over the place)
- He was supposed to be giving out quizzes but completely ignored the syllabus, other professor (Larry Li) had to take care of that mess
- His final exam was completely incorrect on more than several questions. The slide had WORD FOR WORD the opposite statement to the answer on the exam which he did not correct. He actually only corrected one single question...
- When we emailed him about the final, he didn't respond to a single email (everyone was talking to each other at this point).

I don't doubt he's a passionate guy nor do I think he's a bad person. But when he taught BIOL005C for me in Fall 2020, he was the worst professor I have ever had (and I'm about to graduate as I write this, no one was worse than him). Please drop that class IMMEDIATELY if you see him teaching BIOL005C (maybe other subjects he's fine, and not online). You will not get a good experience.

Equivalent to BIOL05LA, so you won't need to take BIOL05LA if you take this class. If you're taking this class, you most likely won't have a choice in who you get in terms of professor and TA. Useful class since it teaches you the basics in lab techniques and equipment. Be prepared to learn beyond what you may expect in regular biology. At the end of the class, students are expected to give a presentation about their project and a paper about the same project (project would be given to you by professors in the class; you will understand what this means when you get to that point in the class).

Took with Alex Cortez, but most of the grading is done by the TA, which, depending on how picky they are, can make or break your grade in the class. Better lab experience than BIOL 05LA, but a lot of work for a 2 unit class.

One of the hardest classes I've taken at UCR...a lot of work for a 2 unit class. Took a lot time that could've been used to study for other hard classes. Save yourself the time and take BIOL05LA instead.
As long as you do the homework and understand it well, you should be fine. The best way to succeed in this class is by doing the problems over and over again until you understand it.

My professor was Alex Cortez. The first half of the course isn't too bad, but sometimes the lab writeups take some time to do. This class is kind of like a biotechnology/intro to research stuff class since you do PCR and gel electrophoresis a lot. Just make sure to understand the concepts since the midterm and final is all application. People generally do bad on the midterm, but better on the final. The second half of the course was focused on a research project for an actual research lab, where you had to really understand the experimental design and do a lab report and presentation. This class is good experience for those interested in research.
Lots of work in the class.  Heavily dependent on how hard your TA is.

One of the best classes on campus!! Yes, its hard work and sleepless nights and a class full of confused faces but I believe this class has shaped me into the person I am today. If ur concerned about ur GPA don't take this class.

Had Burnette. I love the man in that he's super nice and you can tell he really likes what he teaches. Provides a lot of advice and is great at answering questions. Just pay attention in class and read the experiment PDFs he provides.

Great class if you're into research. Read and take notes of material before each class. Had Dr. Chetty and she's alright. Huge curve at the end of the quarter. I finished off with a B- and my grade went to an A- but I'm not sure if it is because we took it online during a pandemic or if grades are usually curved.

Dr. Burnette is super chill and the class isn't an issue. The quizzes and midterm are super straightforward-- I would never study and get 100's on everything because he only tests on general facts in his lectures. You learn a lot of introductory lab processes and it was genuinely my favorite class of the quarter.

Took with Alex Cortez. A lot of the material on the quizzes, midterms, and final were not discussed in class, so make sure to do the readings. They are also very application heavy. The first half of the class is intro to a lot of techniques used in the second part of the class, which is an actual research lab. The research we were doing wasn't explained to us well and I had to look up a lot of terms and concepts from the procedure. You have to do a lab report and a presentation about it. Alex was pretty lenient with grading but our TA wasnt. Overall a really great class for getting involved with research

I took this class Fall 2022 with Alex Cortez. Very kind and accommodating teacher. To do well in the class, read all of the lab backgrounds and asks lots of questions to fully understand the material. The quizzes, midterms, and final often contain free response questions somewhat similar to lab conclusion questions, true or false based on definitions found in the readings, drawing diagrams and the PCR results depending on different scenarios, and also fill in the blanks. When asked to design an experiment, most of the time remember to include PCR analysis and running gel electrophoresis because that was the main focus of the class. I had Aimee and Archie as my TA and lab assistant and they were super helpful and sweet. Pretty easy grading on end of quarter project presentation (average was 93 in our class) and project research paper was canceled because of TA strike. Alex also offered 20 EC points at the end of the quarter and a lot of people ended the class with at least an A despite not doing well on the first few quizzes. Did not regret this class at all.

As long as you kind of pay attention during notes/studying the slides on your own, you will likely pass this class. Very little study required even for an A if you are good at memorizing facts/anatomy.

I have a bit of a bad taste from this class but it I took it because it was supposed to be an easy A. Class is more for younger people that don't have much sexual education from classes and personal experience. TA made discussion an absolute chore to get through. I got an A but I realized a little too late that I didn't need to work that hard to get it. LOTS of fluffer points from discussions, quizzes, and assignments.

Professor Kahn was pretty good. The class was pretty interesting even though plenty of people seemed uncomfortable every moment we were in discussion. The exams were open note and I did well overall. Would recommend to most.
Took this during Fall 2020 (virtual), asynchronous lectures, weekly mandatory discussion. open note quizzes, midterm, and final. Only 2 assignments and they were pretty straightforward,

Took this class during covid with Professor Kahn. I am giving the class a 4 because even though the assignments, exams, and everything was easy you needed virtually all of the points to actually get an A. She claims that she doesn't curve the class at all. The class was out of 500 points and there wasn't any homework. You can really not mess up on any assignment or there goes your A.

Class is History of Infectious Diseases Took over the Summer with Eleana Guardado. The material isn't super easy, but definitely not hard. Definitely easy as far as BIO classes go. All quiz and exam answers are from the slideshows she posts on iLearn. There were 3 "projects" during the quarter: a timeline of events you make from the slideshows, a "diary" about the diseases we learn about, and a very short "essay" about a disease of your choice. The material is SO interesting, especially during a pandemic.

Legitimately not that hard.  Many complain Maslov doesn't really teach but learning genetics is mostly rote memorization and practice.  You're just getting the basic principles down.  He provides lots of practice problems and old exams, so if you go through those and understand the problems, you're guaranteed an A.

Had David Nelson for this class. His lectures are useful, but it is very important to read the book in order to do well, as he takes a lot of concepts from the book for his exams. Generous curve, so if you study hard you should be able to get an A.

Had Gachomo for the first half and her teaching consists of reading the slides while the midterms consists of material we rarely went over. Her midterms not only cheated our time but she would have so many questions that were impossible for many students to finish in the time allotted. Bachant was an amazing professor in the second half. Definitely understood the struggle of the students and thoroughly went through the material. The material itself isn't that hard except that if you miss a part then it gets slightly confusing.

Took with Dr. Arthur Jia Spring 2021. AMAZING professor he truly cares for his students and wants you to do well. Ample opportunities for office hours and midterm review. HOWEVER, his two midterms were short answer, fair, and closed book. Final was 25 mc closed book. Class is graded on a class scale (20-25% get A's etc.)

I took it in the Spring of 2021 and had both Gachomo and Roose. Gachomo has much simpler concepts to go over so she makes her midterm questions harder. Roose has much harder concepts to go over. Both are pretty bad professors and I came out of genetics not knowing anything. If you take Roose my advice is to memorize his slides and make it through midterms. Do not take him if you want to actually learn genetics.
No homework is due, it’s hard to stay on track as all material is asynchronous, but 95% of the midterms and final questions come verbatim from the lecture practice questions.

I don't think the material was hard but it was having Dr.Chen as a professor. He can get off track easily and disorganized. He said he is changing the class layout next time he teaches because he found out that his class correlates with BIOL 121 a little too much.

Chen and Jin were a little difficult to understand (accents). Jin's midterm had some stuff we covered in the second half rather than the first. Chen gives you possible things that will be covered on the final but not all of it will appear. The good thing is that you can bring in a full sized cheat sheet for the final. The curve was legendary.
The class is not easy. It is difficult and time intensive. Also, there is barely any curve in this class with Hailing Jin, so avoid taking the class with her.

This class is HARD, but it is a hard class in general. Personally I loved Dr. Nagel. Her content was straight forward, if you watched the lecture, studied, and wrote notes, you will be fine. I watched her lectures, wrote it in a notebook, and made a quizlet for each week and went to office hours. I got almost a 100 percent on every test because I put in effort. This is NOT a class you can just slide by in. You have to put in major effort.
 Though, Dr. Nagels material for the tests were all from the her slides, and there are only 35-40 slides per lecture. Take her over the other professors if you want to learn the material and have a clear shot of getting a good grade if you put in the effort. Please ignore bad reviews from her, she was great. 
Very exam heavy- 90% exams, 10% discussion quizzes, a possible 5% extra credit.

Don't take with Prof. Nagel. Her grading system isn't the best and she makes it super hard to accommodate to students for any missed exams or quizzes. Her exams weren't too bad if you studied but she would throw in a few curveballs. 107A isn't that hard but there is a lot to know, so if you study regularly then you'll be fine. I would study only two days in advance for exams and walked out w a B+ after her small curve. Recommend taking someone else tho
Very interesting class; great professor and good curve; Lots of calculations and research articles to read in discussion

This was a fascinating class (Human Genetics), one of the most interesting I took as a Bio major. You can't just memorize facts, you have to understand how things work and make predictions. Maduro also makes it impossible to cheat, he keeps class attendance through quizzes and has different exam and homework versions. But as hard as the course was, the average garde was a B or B- which is fair.

Maduro is the only one who teaches this class. He's kind of arrogant and wants you to know a lot of details. He provides all the notes, slides, and practice tests for his class on day 1 and his tests are open note (bc online learning), but it's definitely a hard class with a ton of material. His questions are worded extremely carefully and he has an algorithm that generates test questions so there's never the same question twice.

This class is one of the most interesting classes iv'e ever taken and Maduro is super organized but he was really uptight and sucked at answering questions. You would go to office hours and he would not be able to dumb things down for you. he would constantly critique the class on how easy a topic was even though all of us were failing. The answers on the tests had like 10 answers all very similar too so you would have to know your shit. we had very little time for exams and no backtracking so most of the class didn't finish a couple questions but he's so stuck on not being able to collaborate/cheat he will not adjust this method. A average grade was a b to b- though, but you do not even know where you are in terms of the class until you see your grade on your transcript
nice guy, talks slow, watch out for case studies in lecture

I had Anderson. Funny guy, laid back. Class was boring at times, but he showed a lot of videos. His exams sometimes require notes taken from his lectures. His slides are mostly pictures so you kinda have to go to know what he says. Avrg for midterms ~85%
took it with Nicole Rafferty. She is a sweetheart. The lectures are alright and her tests were straightforward. You should be as long as you go over the lecture notes.
Relatively easy class, open note exams, just requires regular studying

Took with Dr. Regan. It was fully online and exams were all open note. Lectures were asynchronous and most of them were 30 minutes or less. They provide a transcript along with each slide for convenience. Most content is pretty simple to understand. 45% of the grade consists of discussion attendance, quizzes (unlimited attempts), and discussion assignments which are all free points. Each midterm is worth 15% and the final is cumulative and worth 25%. Some of the exam questions are kind of detailed and requires you kinda dig through the lecture notes, but she said she does that since the exam is already open note, so you kinda got to be careful when reading the questions and referencing your notes. Each midterm has 25 questions in 50 minutes, so relying solely on digging through your notes may take up too much time. Averages were typically high, so no curve was needed. The final felt easier than the midterms and had the highest average.

took it with Rafferty. The class material is interesting if you like learning about conservation and biomes. Her slides are straight forward, but her exams are not. There is also PollEv so you will have to go to class. No curve. Only pointless rounding that doesn't do anything for your grade. This is an easy C+ or B-, not an easy A. Discussions are also really stupid because you don’t go over lecture material. All you do it read research papers or so stupid middle school activities. I say this because even the TA said she has no control over it and it was just busy work.

Straightforward and a little difficult because memorization of slides and stuff is somewhat required. Good curve at the end of the class. Koenig and Chris are very nice and lab is simple as long as you pay attention to what is said.

This class is not difficult. However, Koenig is very lackluster at teaching. The lectures themselves are not very useful in getting a good grade in the course. But, the subject itself is very interesting.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Koenig is your typical unclear bad professor. Yeah sure we all have bad unclear professors, but they still make up for being bad teachers by making their tests reasonable or having a curve or even having fair cutoffs. He does NONE OF THAT. His midterms consist of free response and multiple choice, let's just say he is the harshest free response graders on the planet. The TA was horrible, could not speak english clearly at all (not to sound racist or anything). She tries to answer your questions but she never does a good job and you just end up more confused than ever. Both of their office hours are at unreasonable times and the day the week I was able to go to office hours, the TA on Monday announces that she will have her office hours on Tuesday. Like how unorganized can that be!! I dropped this class week 7 in the winter quarter, although I could not see if he did not curve or not, but I don't think that he will. His grade cutoffs were even ridiculous from the beginning. This class has been one of the worst classes I have taken at UCR.
Take with Roper

This class was easy with Hsiao. Just focus on objectives and HW. Go to office hours and he'll tell you the extent of what he wants you to know. Second exam is the hardest so don't let your guard down. 100 pts extra credit available and a few % curve at the end.
The class is not difficult. Roper is not very good at lecturing and the class is heavy on memorization. There is barely any curve at the end of the course.

Professor Borneman taught this quarter. His exams are straight from his review slides, so if you memorize them you can easily get 100 on his exams. The most tedious part of this course is having to attend lab twice a week, in the first few weeks you will stay the entire 3 hour time slot, but in the latter half of the quarter you will only need to be there for an hour or so. Lecture meets once a week, these past two quarters at 8 AM so don't sleep in for exams. Overall, lecture/exam portion is easy, actual lab and lab reports are graded a little more strictly but an overall really fun class. Usually a requirement for PA school, nursing, and Optometry school.

Took with Walton. Pretty dry with a lot of equations and charts for population dynamics, but not bad if you keep up with concepts. Formulas were provided on exams which helps. Multiple choice exams and Simutext software homework assignments and a group project.

If this course is offered and is being taught by Raphael Zidovetski, DO NOT TAKE IT. The class is graded only by: 35% midterm and 65% final. He does not curve and is very inaccessible. He will probably not answer your emails or answer your questions directly in office hours. The class is asynch and the recordings are the same from 2020!!!! He has not changed the videos at all and even when asked to said he wouldn't. Exam wise, you get 2 questions for the midterm which involves having to reproduce entire immunological sequences and the final is 3 questions. Luckily the final was 2 questions from the review questions he provides and 1 new one. HOWEVER unless you're willing to memorize complex diagrams to reproduce them on your exam, do not take this class with him.

I took this course with professor Lukaszewski and he failed the entire class for the final. There is no direct grading scale or textbook for the class. The midterms were essays which we could revise but there was no guidelines or rubric. The final was based on 10 questions pulled out of a 40 questions study guide. We answered the questions based on the content of his slides but they were still considered wrong. He is highly condescending and said his previous students were “bitching” about this class being hard. If you’re planning on graduating, avoid this professor at all costs.

Prof: Adler Dillman. Make sure you know all the parasites' life cycles and the assigned research paper very well. Midterms are about 60% questions on the parts of the life cycle and 40% questions from research paper. A lot of memorization in this class.

Loads of parasite life cycles to memorize.  Dillman also expects you to memorize the scientific papers he assigns as well.  Final wasn't great, but I don't expect much of a curve.  Also, we had to summarize a paper into kiddie language and got docked based on a nonexistent rubric posted after grades came out.  The TAs only gave verbal guidelines to it in discussion and didn't seem in consensus with even the prof about certain things.  Don't know why they didn't give us the breakdown in the first place so we would know exactly what to include. The final draft is only worth about half of discussion credit, but without a curve, any loss of points is extremely damaging to one's grade.

This class is an amazing class!!!! Dilman is one of the best professors in the biology department. Really good for premed students who want to learn about human parasites. Just memorize your life cycles and his slides, and you'll be chilling for a half of the midterms. The second half of the midterms are based on research papers he picks himself based on parasites studied in class. They are quite hard to read but actually give you a good scope of what most modern scientists do and is a quite different change of learning in college. Definitely would help prepare students for the MCAT especially because sections like bio/biochem require being comfortable with reading passages that are excerpts from primary research articles. The only problem with this class in my opinion is the research project that you have to analyze a research paper of your choice on a parasite you pick and dumb it down for 5th graders. Pretty pointless, but thats my only complaint.
Lots of memorization, but not the worst. Springer has easy questions, Reznick has hard questions: a + c, b + c, a + c... etc
Extremely easy upper division class; took with Woodard; covers insect behavior and there are only 8 quizzes and no midterm or final exam

Woodard is the best! She's pretty sensitive to students' hardships and appreciates feedback. During remote learning, she did away with all exams, and focused on weekly quizzes/assignments, an insect picture collection, and a virtual presentation that were all WAY less stressful than they sound.

This class is awesome, IF YOU LIKE BUGS or are interested in the topics at hand. Professor Ysabel Giraldo is passionate about the topic and won't try to trick you, but many people took this as an "easy" class and were rudely awakened when they had to actually put in some effort. Nowhere near the effort of say, biochemistry, but certainly not en introductory course. Try to leave room in this class for people who are actually interested.

This is by far one of the best biology upper divs UCR has to offer. The class is not hard, but very demanding. There are weekly field trips (you get 2 overnight trips), lab practicals (2), a project, and lecture exams. This class is a survey of mammals, birds, and reptiles (including dead specimen identification in lab and maybe some live specimens during the fieldtrips). If you are interested in any kind of field/conservation work this class is for you. You will learn to identify so many animals and learn cool facts that the knowledge will stay with you (I still remember things and it's been over a year). Super fun class and the professor is nice and accessible.
Fun class with interesting material, field trips every weekend takes up a lot of time and energy

Took the class online. Field trips were fun to go on. Prof Clark is a really great lecturer and very accessible. This was probably one of the coolest classes I’ve taken. I’ve always been into wildlife and evolution, I imagine anyone who is would get a kick out of this class.

This class had two professors, Natalie Holt and Wendy Saltzman. This course was mainly online and the midterm and final were online and open-note. Not sure what would change if this was in-person. Midterms included multiple choice and free response questions. Take very detailed notes to study later. The test questions were framed after the lectures mainly.

Took it with Garland and it was pretty straightforward. All questions on the midterms and final came directly from the readings and lectures. He pretty much read from the lecture slides but overall was straightforward and really nice. There's a lot of memorization and he goes through info pretty quickly
Fairly easy, basic math with physics concepts in a biological medium

Class isn't hard honestly, I was just lazy and this was one of my 'easier' classes for the quarter. You do need to know the hormone cycles and basic info on her slides, so draw them out couple days before exam and doing her practice exams helped. Prof. Wendy is really nice and she is very understanding in these COVID times. I got average all both midterms and 100% in discussion and the annotated bibliography and walked out with a B- so I'd say that's fair. Get a good TA that will definitely boost your grade at the end.
open note class

Took Danelle Seymour. Laid back professor, lecture is a bit dry. Lecture recordings and slides are posted after every class, only discussion has manditory attendance. 3 quizzes (15 questions) - completely open book (written notes, electronic notes, the slides from class, the book are fair game), a recipe paper (3 pages on vegetables in your favorite recipe), a plant identification chart(fill in the blank paper for the botanical garden), and a group project (3-4 people doing a 12 minute presentation on a chosen fruit/vegetable - covering a variety google and wikipedia level research). easy class, only downside is having to hike up to the greenhouses - very steep walk.

Took with Professor Walling. This class wasn't too difficult, it is just mainly memorizing. Lots and Lots of memorizing as it is 5 units. It takes a lot of effort to study for the midterms which is a large chunk of your grade (25% for each three) because of the amount of content. If you start studying for each exam early via quizlet or your own flashcards, you are guaranteed a B. Lectures are in the morning, but going helps as the professor gives mystery questions that are on the exam and lectures help with memorizing exam content. Also, many questions that are on the exam are homework questions so look out for those! Would recommend, just make sure you have the time for it.
Do not take this for an easy A

While the material is generally pretty simple for an Upper div bio class, there is a lot to memorize and the class is test heavy, with 2 midterms, 2 practicals, quiz every week, and a final. Not bad but if all your looking for is an easy A look elsewhere.
Not extremely difficult but also not an easy A. Study hard for the exams and lab practical and you'll do well. Springer is a great professor, and curves the final grades.

Juan Pablo is an awesome professor, and the test and quizzes are very fair, just study the notes. The one thing I will warn about the class is that the lab is a lot of work, but if you go the the TA for office hours they will help. While not the easiest A, some effort will make this classvery rewarding.
easy class but many assignments
Easy Class. it's a S class so don't really have to worry about anything. But there are many assignments in comparison to the regular english class.

Class is a remedial class. Focus on the feedback of the professor and use your essay as a standing point. The class is a S/NC so focus on getting easy point early  and not worrying on the final later on.

might be a hard class if you are not native speaker, but professor Fenton is super nice if you go to his OH and watch his pre recorded lectures. Don't bomb your essay cause those are like 75% of your grade. At the end this is only a S/NS class.

This class fail you twice or more on purposely so u can take it again before you get ready for engl 004, especially ucr English department or UC trying make money from our pocket. U only get 5 tries then they automatically move you up to engl 004. Personally I would definitely not take that class again Bc it’s just waste of time, units and dragging ur own major requirements, so I would said take “city college classes” to skip bswt 003 and English 004, so u can waive out engl 1a. Used “Assist.org” to help which city college class can transfer to ucr engl 1a. In the end, don’t waste your energy this class because bswt 003 is joke and rigged asf. I wouldn’t recommend it if ppl got place this class after taking AWPE, either place to bswt 001, 002 and 003. It just waste of energy and time investment.

I have Rob D' Annibale and he's kinda chill and caring enough to make sure that everyone can pass although some will fail at 1st time. 2 essays, 1 examination with essays, 1 final, and the rest are grammar quiz/workshops. He's tough grader on essays and grammars. His lectures are mostly clear, but he could make a misstep in his lectures which can affect the entire learning process. If you're struggling, go to his office hours for feedback or ARC. Overall, I wouldn't blame the professor, I blame the course for being too tough and painstaking. Just try passing the AWPE or take CC English courses to avoid falling behind in English requirement.

Took it w Ballard. It honestly wasn't that hard, I just personally really struggled and hated writing essays so it stressed me out. There were two take home essays that were abt two pages long each, one in-class essay, and a final. The only downside of this class is the amount of materials you're required to buy, which is around $200 in total. The prof is fairly easy to talk to, and would point out things that was wrong in the essay that u wrote, u just gotta take the initiative to actually talk to him. Overall, and easy class since it's a S/NC.
Raj Singh the first of many extremely easy classes by him. Do online quizes and the extra credit assignments for an easy A.
I should have gotten an A, but I missed quizzes during lectures. Make sure you attend lecture for quizzes

Not an easy A despite what ratemyprof says. Choose your members for your group project carefully, and if there are any problems (ie them not doing work) tell your TA and she will handle it. I got low B's on both midterms and final, but I worked really hard for the business plan and got it checked by my TA twice. And got the only A given in that discussion on the business plan.
They changed the format of this class so that a different professor teaches each lecture. This is kind of confusing, but you should be able to get a good grade if you go to class and study.

Took it in 2019 with the new professor rotation format. The midterm average was like a 53% but there was a roughly 30% curve. Easy class and lectures optional. Make sure you study from slides posted online. No homework or essays. Grade is entirely midterm, final, and discussion

Fall 2019. New curriculum with rotating professors, which is still adjusting. The first midterm was ridiculously hard (but there was an extremely generous curve), but the final was ridiculously easy. No mandatory attendance except for discussions. Overall the class was really easy.

Took in Fall 2019. They rotated out different professors every other day, so many days were not worth going to class.  Discussions important for participation and no quizzes in discussion. 1 Midterm and Final, which was very easy if you study the lecture slides the day before.

Very easy. Took Fall 2019 with the revamped class. Professors switch off teaching once every few days. Attendance is not mandatory; I never went to class because slides were posted online. Just attend discussion for participation points. There's no homework. Midterm is worth 35% and Final is worth 50%. Midterm was pretty hard but it was curved greatly to make the average a B-. Raw score average was like an D or F. Final was extremely easy, it didn't need to be curved. It boosted my grade from a B+ to an A-. The class might be changed again.

I had professor paul kirwan and he was interesting. He really goes through the whole chapter of the book in one class really quick so TRY TO COPY SLIDES DOWN BEFOREHAND. His midterms are kind of hard if you do not read or know any of the concepts.

Paul Kirwan Fall2020: Zoom lectures required. He reads off the slides and that doesn’t really help. You have to find the textbook but you don’t need it imo. Chapter tests, group discussions, group project, final.

took with prof Kirwan and did not attend lectures since hes literally reading everything out of the book. Read over the book chapters instead and taught myself and got A's on all of the midterms. Midterms were also open book. Only hard thing about this class is the group project since you have to create your own product or service to sell and pretend you're a business.
Basically a vocab and concepts class with a group project. Read the textbook and you should be fine. Kirwan lowkey sucked as professor though.

I had Professor Kirwan for Fall 2020 online. Due to health and connection issues, lectures were cancelled at times and some students were unhappy about this. The only homework we had was from discussion, and there was a stressful group project. Midterms and the final are not super easy, but they are open note and manageable.

The lectures and discussions are mandatory but he was out sick a lot so the schedule changed constantly. Would highly recommend studying from the textbook as some of his questions are very specific that he doesn't go over in the lecture. Group project was okay, definitely regret not starting earlier and I ended up having to do most of it myself.

I had Intro to Business with Raj Singh, he is nice but goes on long tangents, it gets super boring. Lectures are hard to pay attention to. There are 2 midterms, 1 final (not cumulative), 6-7 homework assignments, 1 final project (+ presentation), and a couple small e-portfolio presentations. Do not let the prof’s boring lectures get in the way of you getting a good grade. Use the Cengage practice questions, do the textbook reading, and try to pay attention during lectures. For the final project, make sure to pick reliable people and refer to sample projects! Ask your TA’s to review any parts of the project you don’t understand (the rubric is confusing). If you focus and don’t treat the class as a joke, you can get a good grade.

Super easy class, professor Raj gives so much extra credit and just a breeze with the open note first 2 tests. The final and project are heavy weighting but can ace everything else in the class. super easy
The final is so hard that it is majorly curved.

Took it with Ivy Zhang! At first I thought it’d be hard because I’ve heard about the previous professor but she’s completely different. It’s helpful to go to all the lectures because she explains pretty thoroughly. She also does Poll Everywhere so might as well go to class. She does online homework but you have unlimited tries, and there’s also online quizzes but the quesrions mostly online. Midterm was fairly easy, as long as you keep up with your stuff and GO TO DISCUSSION, it really helps!

No one has no clue what's going on in this class. Just do your homework. Lectures don't help since they are on the homework due the week before. Your TA is your best bet in learning anything. Average grade for the final was 55%
Samuelson is hard to keep up with sometimes. Material gets hard after the midterm. Everyone fails the final but it is curved.

[COVID-19 ERA] Took this class with Naman Desai, it wasn't really too useful too be honest. The professor was passionate about his subject and really understanding towards the students during this difficult time. But in that process unfortunately students had to suffer through recorded lectures and a subpar standard of teaching. My TA (Arthur Hou) wasn't much of a help either which only added to the stress of this class. I wish this class was in-person so I could've fully understood these concepts as accounting is an extremely important and useful subject.

Took it during COVID. I felt that bc of how people were getting adjusted, this class just.... was not the class to take. Taking the class, it felt like it isn't something you can reliably teach online. Props to the teacher for being positive and continuing but it just felt like no communications most of the time. Definitely not recommend during online learning.

I took it with Naman Desai winter 2021. Class was asynchronous with optional zoom lectures on thursday. Two exams and about 7 or so quizzes total. Not the most organized class tbh but just go over the practice problems from the recordings and you'll be good to go.

I took this class during winter 2021 when classes were online with Naman Desai. This is probably the worst class I have ever taken. The midterm and exam weren't too difficult. Honestly, if you just find random quizlets with accounting questions and use those to study, chances are that you'll see similar questions on his exams. The prof doesn't really teach - he just shows you how to do textbook problems without explaining anything. He assigned us weekly quizzes, but I didn't find them that useful. They only showed us what types of questions he was going to give us on the exams. He also didn't give us a practice midterm or final which I thought was inconsiderate, considering we were online and he wasn't that good of a professor. The TAs were also barely useful. They would just upload videos explaining the answers to quizzes, but those explanations weren't that good in my opinion. I think that this class was manageable, but not a good experience.
Barry Mishra is a horrible professor. He steals lectures from other professors and does not care about students. Basically self teach

I had Mishra and he was alright. tuesdays were asynchronous lectures and thursdays were synchronous but not mandatory. the asynchronous lectures were the most helpful because the practice problems he went over were the same format as test questions. the material was pretty hard tbh but if you're willing to study and do practice questions it should be manageable.

Worst class I've taken this year. This is an introductory humanities class. I took it with Bruce Samuelson spring 2022. For the final and midterm we literally had A STUDENT teach us the test information because our entire class was so lost. His entire class was horrible. During lectures he would read off slides and ramble incoherently. Despite the HUGE curve on the midterm someone received a 9.0 out of 100. 9 POINTS!!!!!! That is fucking insane. Safe to say Samuelson is a complete imbecile. DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE TAKE BUS020 WITH SAMUELSON. Unless you took accounting in highschool or are a fucking aerospace engineer this course will not be fun. We also had to pay $130 to pay for textbook/hw program. Now I am down $130 and my gpa is completely tanked.
$150 mandatory website code to do homework, SAMUELson is hard

I had Corrine Knight. 4 books needed for this class but they weren't expensive. 4 essays in total: first was easy, second was alright but a bit hard, third was hard, and fourth was easy for me. Quizzes were given randomly and sometimes in the middle of lecture, so go to class on time. Only one midterm and all questions come from quizzes so it's easy. Two presentations (one video pres.) but they're pretty simple. TAs can be a bit strict in grading essays so try to get feedback from them.
Be prepared to do the most for this class just to get a passing grade. The essays are very time consuming and are scrutinized by the TA's

I took this Winter 2019 (i think). TAs grades based on the syllabus the professor gives but the feedback will always be ~2-3 week slate and by then you will have to start on your next essay. What the professor says to do and what the TA says tend to be different AND the TA's have to give 3 essays from each of their discussion to the professor to be graded. 
One incident where a student had an A paper but the professor graded it to a C paper because the tone of her essay wasn't professional enough but the TA said it was perfectly fine. The first midterm is really easy because it's all lecture-based but the final is a timed write and basically feels kind of like an AP Lang/Lit timed write.
There are around 4 essays total. Just don't take it with other heavy writing business courses

I had it with Acker and it was an easy class for me, someone who sucks at English. There's three main assignments and a project. The textbook is also really helpful and there's a required workshop course you have to enroll in (0.5 units). Before every assignment (except the final paper), you have to go to this workshop. Overall, this class is definitely not a stress inducer.
Took Bus100w online. Prof Acker is really cool and the projects are very easy. Don't really need to pay much attention in his lectures and his quizzes are moderately easy.

Took class with Dr. John Acker. The lectures are mostly based on his PowerPoints, which are regularly posted to Canvas. There are 3 writing assignments that make up the final grade, but the professor gives two or three weeks to work on each one. Definitely worth attending discussion to get feedback on writing assignments ahead of time.

I took it with Rich Yueh. One of the best business professors you'll have imo. He's new to UCR but he knows his stuff and actually relates to us. I will admit, lectures were boring every now and then, but he had a good sense of humor that made up for it and the material was pretty easy to understand. He's really nice and accommodating, and goes the extra mile for students. Posts slides on iLearn but they're not that comprehensive, so you need to go to lecture for a more detailed understanding of the material. Five homework assignments but were super easy and quizzes given in lecture every other week, no midterm or final. No book needed for this class. Overall, a fun, easy class with a great professor.

Class is really easy, Professor Rich is really awesome. No book was needed because he said he knows college is expensive. Material is really easy, but if you have no coding experience the latter half of the class might be difficult for you because you have 2 assignments that require you to know Python

Professor Rich is probably one of the best professors UCR has to offer. The final project requires coding so if coding isn't your thing then oof. Overall, I enjoyed this class a lot and I was bummed that it had to end.
easy A, basic coding. 5 labs and 3 projects

This class was mostly grading on coding. Where the professor has 3 project 2 of the projects were coding and the last project was a presentation. There were also labs were it was mostly coding. The first two weeks of class your going to learn Java script and the rest of the class was mostly on python. Literally by the end of the quarter the professor emailed the whole class that people were cheating on the first two project and there was a person who got caught cheating on the second project but they never cheated on anything as every other student got good grades for their codes even if they cheated. For some reason they think the professor sees their code and compares it to everyone else and just says that they’re cheating when they’re literally knowing what it’s code does and how it works and still ended up getting written up to the academic integrity department where everyone else is free. And this was like one of those public sights to deal with python codes where the public can see your codes and you can’t do anything about unless you pay for it’s services to make your code private. Once you meet with the integrity office person and said what you did and how it came to this then once they meet with your professor they’ll say the opposite of what you said and what you did wrong then your getting the blame for cheating. If you’re going to take this class just be careful about your codes and hope there isn’t any relations to other students code or else you’ll probably get an email saying you’ve cheated an assignment.  Also if you’ve got written up for academic dishonesty for some reason after your case has been dealt with, you’re not able to email the professor and saying that they’ll change your grade for us and would say that who ever is the person you’ve been dealing with the case their just going to say the professor has to change the grade for you and you’ll won’t know how to be in contact with the professor because they’ll just ignore the email about this. This class shouldn’t be too difficult unless you know how to do code but they gave it a 10 due to this experience being that they know how to code and everything for some reason the professor just accused them for cheating when they weren’t. Students shouldn’t go to UCR because most facilities are just finding new ways to get money and when you realized during the orientation it was mostly that the school wanted more money and that’s why the school accepted more students due because once there were more students equals more money to the school it really sounds like this is a corrupted system.

Took class with Prof Rich Yueh. Lectures are not mandatory, but worth attending if you’re interested/concentrating in Information Systems as they provide useful information. The projects are mostly Python programming, with the final being an app prototype. The difficulty of projects will depend on your knowledge of programming logic, but can definitely be accomplished if you go to office hours for help when needed. Overall, a good class to take.

It's hard to rate this classes difficulty since it was entirely artificially difficult. The professor, Sean Jasso, caps all of the grades on any assignment at a high B or a very low A, essentially ensuring that you will receive a B or B- in the class. If you want to receive anything higher than a B or B-, you'll have to go to office hours and do a little brown nosing of the T.A and the professor, as well as do any "value added" activities that he assigns in the class. When you do the writing assignments make sure that you write each one out to the maximum length. I.E, if he tells you to write 3 pages, write to the very bottom of page 3, no more, no less.

The other answer on this explains it pretty well already - Professor Jasso caps the assignments at a B+/A- for some reason. The worst part of the class is that it's at 7:30 AM, so he knows that a lot of people aren't going to attend lecture. Honestly, he's a cool dude and pretty funny at times, but he can be THAT professor that takes attendance when he sees that people aren't showing up. There are weekly reading assignments that you have to write in 10 pt font single space. You get used to it and it really doesn't seem that bad when writing - the reading part is what takes a lot. In the syllabus there's a format for all the readings, so make sure you answer the questions, using the key words of the format. The TAs are going to receive hundreds of 3 pages of 10 pt font single space assignments, they're not going to read it word for word. For the midterms (2 separate days of 2 questions out of 4, so one day one question, the other day another), Jasso is going to choose it by random. He crumbles up papers with the question numbers on them, makes students switch it around, and reveals it in front of the class. With all this entertainment, the midterm and the final (that's during week 10, but choosing 2 out of 5 questions) only allow for 30 minutes of writing time. On the exams, he does say to reference lecture for some of them. It's hard to go to this class with it being so early in the morning, but hopefully you all have the drive to do it. If you do end up not going to class, try your best for the ones before the midterms and finals. He might talk about it. If this is one of the first core classes you take, brace yourself for another Jasso class with the same format (BUS103).

Lectures are a waste of time, but go after the 1st midterm they take attendance. When doing your reading notes do it in this format: summary, pro/con analysis, sprinkle in a few buzzwords from the book that Jasso hasn't reviewed yet, throw in a personal reference in your life that is a real world example, and then conclude it with how you could use the concept in your future life.
Reading Notes are a pain. Get started on your marketing plan early. Tests aren’t too bad

Took online with Nik Terhani. Great Professor! Have to do discussion papers weekly on what we learned that week and then do open note quizzes. His midterm was open notes as well and we have a group project at the end of the quarter. TAKE HIM IF YOU CAN!!

I took it with Kamvar Farahbod. This class isn't too hard to be honest. Homework usually had 4 to 7 questions and lectures were super boring because he reads off the slides. The slides are posted on iLearn but aren't always easy to understand imo, so I highly recommend buying the book because it teaches you the material better than he does. Doesn't always take attendance but might do so if he feels that less people come to lectures. Quizzes are given in discussion every week, so definitely attend. One midterm and one final; midterm had 35 questions (i think) on chapters 1-4 and final is on last four chapters. Overall, an okay class and you'll likely get a B or an A.
All the learning comes from the discussion. Heavy curve in the midterm and final
Professor is super boring but the homework and tests are not that bad.

I took it with Mohsen El-Hafsi. Class was a mess lol. He only gave two attempts on the webassign homeworks which was quite frustrating. Study the midterm review and final review and discussion problems those are extremely HELPFUL.

Decision Analysis with Prof El-Hafsi. Webassign homework assignments every 2 weeks, and 1 midterm + 1 final (not cumulative). No recorded lectures and mandatory disc attendance. The content became progressively harder as the quarter went, around week 8 the homework became very difficult. Do not procrastinate hw, it takes time. Pay attention and take notes on how to use solver. It can be a difficult class but if you do practice questions and keep up with lectures you will be fine. TA’s were mostly unhelpful. Take notes, practice, learn how to use solver and you’re good to go. Don’t forget to study conceptual content for the exams. (Exams were all multiple choice, in person.)

I had Prof. Turcic and watching lecture and looking over the slides is a must. This course is new content for most people so set aside extra time to digest the info. However, once you understand it it is actually pretty easy concepts to grasp. He also lets you take your homework and exams with unlimited attempts, but you don't get your score until the deadline passes.

Took with Adem Orsdemir W21, fully asynchronous - 20-40min each lecture, released during official class time sharp, attendance taken via simple quizzes on lecture material. He teaches materials well, but it would definitely help if you have an interest in it beforehand and you need to get used to his accent. Very understanding, allowed midterm retake and drops lowest homework.

Production and Operation with Gurumurthi. His syllabus says no midterm, but he gives one anyway. 1 Midterm, 1 cumulative final, some easy hw assignments, in-class quizzes, and 1 group simulation. Nice guy, he can get in your face if you aren’t paying attention in class. Go to lecture, he randomly takes attendance and assigns in-class quizzes (he usually tells you the answers in class). Not a difficult class, take good notes because his exams are usually online, open book/note. Make sure to create all the spreadsheets with him, you can plug numbers in later to solve questions on the midterm/final.

I took it with Professor Peter Chung. Easily the worst professor I have ever had. He is so hard to understand and is an extremely harsh grader. If you do bad on the first midterm, the best grade you can get in the class is a C.
This class was not hard at all, as long as you understand the formulas and you'll be fine.
Forget what the person above said about the professor. The class is pretty doable and I got an A. Just know how to use the formulas and the concepts behind the math problems and you'll be good.

Took the course Fall 2020. It was online. Professor Chung was very accessible and the TAs put in an impressive amount of work. The course was difficult in that the material can be foreign and the conceptual questions in exams really test your knowledge of the material. 3 exams (2 MT, 1 final), noncumulative. Homework was very doable.
easy A . Professor Malousak Seyednematollah exam and slide exactly the same, so as long as you review the slide you'll be fine.  four case analysis, 1 midterm ,1 final, 1 group project

Took it online with Dr. Damian Dunbar in Spring 2021. The class is really not that difficult if you do the extra practice problems and skim through the textbook to gain a better understanding of the concepts. Do well on the homework and the extra practice quizzes because some of the questions are the same as the exam questions with only a few numbers switched around. Would also recommend doing the textbook problems for more practice.

Took it with Kyle Ingram. I feel like the professor made this class harder than it needed to be tbh. Weekly readings assigned but they weren't too long. 4 randomly assigned quizzes in total, but the fourth quiz was basically showing up to the case competition presentation for credit. Quizzes were multiple choice and short answer, but were hard because the TAs were harsh graders. In fact, there was some grading discrepancy since one TA graded easier than other TAs. The prof. posts lectures on iLearn but you should still go anyway. One group project presentation and term paper assigned too. Discussion was useless imo but go for attendance. You don't need the textbook for this class but buy it if you don't understand the class material. Overall, not easy to get an A in this class.

Professor Ingram is no longer teaching the course but he gave 4 random quizzes worth 10% of the overall grade each. They are pretty difficult because he does not say when they are going to be and what they are about. So always review before lecture! The last quiz was free because you just vote on the group presentations. The group project is not that bad but it depends on how motivated your group members are. Make friends with your TA because they grade your term paper.
You need to buy a new book for the online code.
Wasn't too wild but professor Woody Liao is extremely difficult to understand. Unfortunately he isn't great with technology either. A lot of self-learning was done in that class.
Took with Raveendran online Spring 2021. Super easy course, some busy work but insanely doable. Consider her as your professor as opposed to Jasso or Weigel if you don't like suffering

Took with Md, insanely easy course. Had a group project, 4 labs that included excel, tableau, and Azure, 2 writing assignments (super easy), and midterm + final. The only way to fail this course is to literally not do your work.
Took with Thomas Karmer for fall2022. only 1 midterm and 1final (40% & 60%) so if you are not a good tester then you gonna failed.

if you have this class with jonathan lim, it is very easy. all you need to do is know the weekly content, fill out a google form answering questions on the content of that week and 3-4 group work that is based off if what is taught in class. no exams at all. he does grade a little hard on the group work but if you try you will be good

This class is a very easy A! I would highly recommend taking this class if it is professor Raj Singh. All of the questions are online and the projects are fairly easy. I would not worry too much about this class since it is fairly easy.

Midterm one, average was 60% and the final was about 55%. Final and midterms are 60% of your grade. 20% of hw, which is super easy. 20% group project for research presentation. Overall, class was hard. It wasn't hard for me since I have the analytic computer science background but for your average business student, it can be hard.

Material was complex, and the professor's lectures made it even harder.
The class was mostly excell based so you really only had to memorize how to model everything, but I had a hard time understanding the concepts behind the mechanics of building the models.
Like why does one problem use binomial inverse instead of normal inverse. 
I would have appreciate it a little more review into calculus before the class got into full swing, but I understand that the winter quarter is scheduled tight especially for Mon/Wed classes

[COVID-19] Took it with Long Gao. Definitely not fit to write a proper comment because I chose to not participate in the class anymore lol. This is an all Excel class and it teaches you how to use it in realistic situations with businesses. It's a pretty challenging class - almost all of the homework is about 1 to 3 problems, and you have to apply what you learned in lecture to these problems. On the first day you'll be able to assign yourself to a group on a spreadsheet - there will be two group presentations every lecture to go over the homework problems. The professor walks you through the logic of the homework problems but you'll have to set up Excel yourself. He gives you a template in PDF form so you can't copy and paste it onto Excel, but you have an idea of what you have to do. The first midterm is one question that was similar to the homework question. That's all I can say for the class cause the rest I didn't even try, sorry. Seems like a pretty useful class.
Highly recommend that you take this class AFTER having at least completed BUS 104 and BUS 105. (I was unaware of this and took it as a junior for my first quarter at UCR - it was brutal)

Dr. Linda Penas is very nice and a pretty good instructor, though she has a tendency to just read off of her slides. For Spring 2020 (everything online), she only uploaded lecture slides that had material that would be on the exams (1 midterm, 1 final). There is also a weekly lab using Minitab 19, and it is really easy. The material is mostly just different procedures/concepts of statistics used in business and manufacturing situations to determine quality of products/processes. Equations are WAY easier than in most statistics classes and you are allowed to make a "cheat sheet" for exams so you don't really have to memorize any. DEFINITELY useful for Business majors; a bit less useful for Statistics majors/minors in terms of material we will use someday, but it's good for seeing how to apply statistics in real life.

The content of the class itself is not that hard, but for me the professor sucked. I took the class with Jean Helwege in F21. She tends to go off topic, so you don't really know what is most important. For exams, she asks questions about things that were barely mentioned in class, like the name of some obscure person. The paper she assigned for the end of the quarter was the most difficult. She didn't give us proper instructions and just expected us to know what to do based off a complicated example. She also graded us relative to other groups in the class, so in a way it wasn't fairly graded.

[COVID-19] I took this class with Ye Li and it was honestly a really good class. At first, it was annoying that he sends out about 5 emails reminding you to do the web assignment before the first lecture (basically a ~15 minute survey for every class that relates to the lesson - he collects the students' stats to present in class). The professor is pretty lenient with the web assignments being submitted a little bit late, but that's not the case for the write ups. In the class besides the web assignments, there are 5 write-ups (with assigned readings ranging from like 5 to 15 pages, a big one being 30ish) in total that you need to do out of 8 offered in 10 weeks. The first two write ups (counted as 1) is with a randomly assigned group and was 600 words each. The rest, you are free to chose as long as you have done 5. There's no midterm and only a final - the final you have the option to go solo or choose a partner/have the professor choose one for you. The final is about a case study with 6 questions and all he tells you is that you have to use class concepts for it. You have 5 days to complete it and it had a word limit of 2000. The professor is great, he makes every topic interesting and has a lot of opportunities for extra credit throughout the quarter. Should basically be a pretty easy A class as long as you make the effort to do the web assignments and write ups. They're due every Thursday but if you turn it in the Sunday before, you get an extra credit point added to your score. I'd really recommend this class as an elective! My concentration is IS and this was definitely one of the easier classes I've taken and it was genuinely a good class.

Professor Ye is amazing and the class is really interesting. Your grade is based on 4 write-ups (you can pick from out of 8 topics), participation, and a final. The class isn't hard at all if you spend time doing the readings and listen in class.

Fairly easy. Quizzes are online, two page essays every week, 15 page research paper within a group. Just must attend class because activities are like 20% of grade. Overall, the work is easy just requires a bit of work.

This class with Haibo Liu is a really fun class about entrepreneurship. It mainly consist of a midterm presentation, a final presentation, a take home final, and participation credit. Doing the bare minimum and showing interest can get you a good grade in this class.

Took this class with Maciejovsky. Probably the most interesting material in any business course and would highly recommend attending lectures. A Couple 600 word essays that are fairly easy. No final except for a group presentation at the end. Easy weekly hw assignments that take <5 mins. Highly recommend.

Took it with Alcaraz, not really hard, just beyond annoying that 30% of your grade is a group project and presentation in a pandemic. the prof also has attendance and participation as about 25% of the grade, and he’s never clear as to how those are calculated considering he said attendance wasn’t mandatory at the beginning of the quarter

Fall 2020 (online b/c Covid); Raj Sign taught this. If you have Raj as a professor (like in 107) then you will know the format. You will have a group project that is due at the end of the lecture week. The course materials itself aren't really hard and all of what he teaches are on the lecture slide. You can buy the book but tbh I'm not sure it's beneficial to learning. If you are a person who needs the book copy, just buy a pdf of it (usu. around $20 if you know where to look or maybe even free). You have 2 quizzes that are unannounced and will tell you about them when the time comes. There are 2 exams (open-book)and 1 final. There is HW and it's better if you do them as you finish the chapters. The HW is due at the end of the week 10

Fall 2020 (online b/c Covid); Raj Sign taught this. If you have Raj as a professor (like in 107) then you will know the format. You will have a group project that is due at the end of the lecture week. The course materials itself aren't really hard and all of what he teaches are on the lecture slide. You can buy the book but tbh I'm not sure it's beneficial to learning. If you are a person who needs the book copy, just buy a pdf of it (usu. around $20 if you know where to look or maybe even free). You have 2 quizzes that are unannounced and will tell you about them when the time comes. There are 2 exams (open-book)and 1 final. There is HW and it's better if you do them as you finish the chapters. The HW is due at the end of the week 10

Had Prof Ke Li (Fall 2018). This is one of those "weeder" classes. If you truly want to pursue accounting, this class requires you to attend EVERY SINGLE LECTURE. The book is not required, you just need to purchase an access code for BUS 165 series, this code will be used for the entire series (A-C). Attendance is mandated and points are deducted for every lecture missed. There's a total of 20 points, miss 10 lectures, you receive no participation points when calculating grades. The course is challenging, yes, however, study well and try to achieve the highest possible score possible on each assignment (homework, pre-lecture quizzes, tests, etc.). You will need to keep track of the assignments due after and before each week as he does not remind you, and it's a lot of assignments if you don't keep up. The class is graded based upon the weighted grade or total points achieved, whichever one is higher. This is a class where if you don't put in work, you will fail, even if the professor says "85% of the class will get a B- or higher". Exams will have questions from the CPA exam. Overall, if you think accounting upper divs is an easy A, this major/concentration is not for you.

Winter 2022 Class was doable, easier compared to 168B, took it with Eric Allen, tests were free response so there are a lot of possible partial credit points, grade consisted of 2 exams, discussion during lecture (you're assigned a day and you're expected to contribute to the discussion on that specific day), and the end of the quarter group project where you guys complete a 1040 together with little to no help

Spring 2022 Was significantly harder than 168A in my opinion; 2 exams online, homework online, end of the term project - had to fill out tax return (if i remember correctly it was either for a partnership or corporation, you get to choose) - Pittard is a good lecturer but the topic in general is just difficult

Took class Fall 2020. Class was online. Kan was a great guy. We had 1 final and 1 midterm, noncumulative. Homework assignments were very reasonable. He recorded all lectures and only required 2-3 in Zoom sessions whereas the rest of the course was done asynchronously.

[COVID-19] Had Kan Wang after taking 171 last quarter with him as well. Pretty easy class and it has been in the same format for both. The class is mainly asynchronous with 2 live sessions - one on the first day and another around week 3. One midterm and one final (noncumulative) with most questions from the textbook and a few made by him based on the homework. There are about 4 homework assignments spread out evenly, so make sure to start a little earlier. He has extended one homework before due to some students being unable to install Microsoft Office software properly, but be reasonable and don't start the day before it's due and ask for an extension lol. Two out of four were using Microsoft Access. The last homework is always a small research paper where you have to explain a concept (for this class it was the difference between relational databases and NoSQL). Pretty easy class if you just do the work.

5 quizzes worth 30% of grade, 1 midterm 30%, 1 group project 30%, and participation 10% the class is hard if you don't know SQL and you will have to put in your own effort to do well because a lot of the work is not mandatory but just recommended
only a few homework assignments, midterm, and group project. relatively easy and a chill info systems class

Took with Underhill, insanely easy professor that accomodates and understands his students. Just do the work, most of it is guided and not hard at all. The only reason you fail this course at all is because you decided to do all your work the day it was due (all our work was due last day of week 10 btw).

Amazing professor. He is quite young so he relates to his students a lot. Very easy weekly labs because all of them have a step-by-step guide on how to complete it. Offers good insight and is very kind/caring.
Rich Yueh is an amazing teacher to have. Class grading structure was easy and the ARCGIS platform was interesting to learn. Majority of the class is based on labs and application of labs in Projects.
extremely easy class, homework takes on average a couple seconds to a couple minutes. introductory class about the cahuilla people and language. highly recommend for breadth requirements

Bachant is a terrific prof.  He provides all you need to know in his slides and supplementals.  The final was harder than the material from the first two midterms though.  Don't expect a huge curve since averages on midterms were 77-80%.

Took it with Bachant. Cool dude, but its a hard class. He gave us supplementals for the lectures and they are REALLY useful. Tests seem impossible at first, but they make sense as you read it a couple of times more.

This class is very interesting. Santhakumar was a great professor. She gives practice exams, clarifying slides, etc. She also gave a huge curve at the end of the course, so it is not hard to get a high grade in this class.

Zur nieden and Karginov: class was split in half and the first half was very difficult. We just had a quiz and a midterm (create your own study guide). Quizzes were very difficult with zur nieden. Study guide was graded based on comparison, not how you study, which defeats the purpose of the study guide. The 2nd half was much easier. Brought my grade back up.
Zur Nieden is great. Had the study guide midterm assignment and thought it was an easy A. Quizzes were okay but easier when studying with friends.

Vijayalakshmi Santhakumar taught this class very well. She did a hybrid of online and in-person for those who couldn’t come into class. Her tests were online and open-note. I would suggest really studying for this class ahead of time to understand the concepts and the material, such as re-watching the lectures she posts. She also posts a lot of additional information to help you understand the material. She was always available during office hours as well.

No homework, but there is a lot of material to go over, especially post midterm. Make sure you are on top of all the material, because it’s honestly a bit too much to cram right before the exam. Class is was really interesting though!
Very interesting class; study regularly and it will be easy to do well

First half I had Dr.Anderson, very straightforward guy. Even when he "tries" to trick you, its not difficult at all. Just lots of material as any upper div bio class. His average was around 67
Second half was with Dr. Hongdian. He has a rep for teaching the more dense/confusing stuff, but its not that bad at all. Just go to class so you can understand what the diagrams mean - its really straightforward if you attend his lecture and  listen/write what he says.
The discussion section requires a brain anatomy practicum so study hard for that one.
Class is not hard and exams are open note; there is a small curve ; highly recommend taking it in the summer

Online exams were no back-tracking, but it wasn't bad. Very straightforward questions, and Dr. Fiacco had lecture outlines that were really helpful when studying. Really enjoyed this class overall! :)
Took it in Fall 2021, 97% of your grade is midterm and final, 6% discussion. Final is not cumulative but the exams are tricky. Understand the material well enough to answer tricky mc questions.

3 exams. not cumulative. I took it with professor Dr.Fiacco and he was incredible! Provides lecture notes himself. Study those for the test AND study the pictures of brain slices presented in class if he talks about those regions in his notes. tbh lots of material but if yeah neuro nerds this class is for you
Had it with Daddy Fiacco. Study often and when you do actually write out the terminology/area/function because it helps with fill in the blank exams/quizzes. GL.

For Michael Adams, JUST AVOID HIM AT ALL COST. Class averages were always around 50%. If you are not a NURO major, I would not even take this class AT ALL. Studying is super difficult for his class because his slides are blank and refers to outside articles.

For Cho, he is a great professor for this class and only teaches the most important things in NURO. I would take him, again, if you are a NURO major and need this course.

Hybrid Class
Powerpoint: Almost all pictures. Think of it as TED talk style presentation where you focus on the person instead of the presentation, unless he refers to it.

Professor's ability to engage: 3.5 since he talks slow and takes pauses from 5-10 sec to an occasional 30 sec. Reading the content on your own is more amusing than focusing on his words. For those who like structured lectures... you better make your own structure because this professor is like your grandparents where they tell you a narrative and somehow, we get too deep into one idea that is not relevant to the exams. Overall, it's disorganized learning.

Contents in exams/quizzes: Based on another student who only listened to lectures, he has a >90% on Midterm; another one who focused more on the notes has around 80-90%. Open note. Half/half context or terminology, the other is calculation and reading graphs/charts

TAs: they're straight-forward and their content is more informative.

Tips for survival:
-When studying for this course, organize your notes by the following: 
1.) what/how/why of each article he's discussing
2.) Terminology and the general concepts of a specific structure
3.) Formulas and graphs/charts that he's referencing about.
4.) Actually practice math, because this man barely reviews about it and it's 1/4 on the Midterm

Avoid if:
1.) Planning on missing lectures
2.) Lacking in auditory learning 
3.) Cannot tolerate monotoned voice or long pauses

Opinion: As a student with ADHD and currently on meds at its peak while taking his lecture, I was very surprised he was able to disengage my interest in paying attention to class. This class is narrative based and contains a lot of reading without clear guidance on what to actually study. If you find yourself getting frustrated with him, just remember that he's willing to teach you if you ask and that he's just a human being with feelings.

Michael Adams; Lab reports are graded by TAs and it was fairly easy. As long as you answer the questions on the lab manual and explain the figures, you should be fine. Adams is very lenient when it comes to extensions. He extended all of the lab reports with no questions, just ask! Nice man, but very monotoned.

Took with Peter Hickmott. Love him! Lab reports were heavy (20-30 pages) and graded harshly by TAs but there was a big curve. Also allowed extensions, but I recommend always doing reports ahead of time.

Took this class with Martin Riccomango and he has a very heavy accent. It’s hard to understand him at times, but his exams correlates with his lectures. Tests in person were difficult, but manageable if you watch lectures/attend meetings.

Dr. Riccomagno was amazing for this course. His tests are based off his slides. Slides are more filled with images rather than words, but they were fairly easy to understand. I really enjoyed this class a lot.
Studying at least once a day three times a week helped.

With professor Curras during covid. She is horrible. Does not teach in zoom, instead, she posts a lot of lectures that actually have a due date, so you have to watch it before the deadline otherwise it closes. She requires both yuja and a lockdown browser. She does not make accommodations

Had Curass (Fall '21) and liked her. The posted lectures had a recommended due date only for time management purposes but you can still watch it after. 2 midterms and a final. I did rough on the first midterm and final but still got an A with the curve.

Took this Fall '21 with Garret Anderson. Nice professor but difficult exams. (It was my first in person course since the pandemic).  There is mcq, frq and a matching with drugs and their mechanisms of action. VERY interesting course but required a lot more studying than other CBNS upper divs imo. Course is basically 2 exams + discussion presentation on a drug.
Took it with Dr. Hickmott and his tests were pretty difficult. You had to know everything. His TA Sarah was terrible. She's very strict and grades harshly on presentations.

Took it over the summer with Professor Kurt Spurgin and it was pretty easy going. Questions are straight from notes/slides. Dont need a book and no discussion so that was great. Lots of info but memorizing is enough for this course, averages for his were around 70-75 so pretty high
A+ lecturer, but the multiple choice on the exams will leave you praying to any and all gods you can think of.

2 MT's that aren't cumulative and a final that is. 7 quizzes in discussion and you present a research article in either weeks 8,9,10. First half will be easy, but the second half the information becomes a lot more difficult. MT2 was extremely difficult.
VERY easy class. Just write essays
Just listen to special guests. There's 4 very short essays to write, and by short, I mean like a little over half a page. No exams or other assignments but attendance is mandatory.
Just had to listen to guest lecturers once per week, only 4 one page essay assignments

Concepts are fairly easy to understand. Took with professor Yan. Just review the slides every so often. Beware of the final paper and presentation and try to work on it asap, pick a topic not too complex or that at least one group member understands well. The final was very unexpectedly strange. The midterm was very fair.
Easy class but make sure to take good notes because quizzes are open note and very specific.

I had Dr. Ivey. Weekly homework, sometimes there are quizzes in discussion. Cheat sheet allowed on exams, midterm wasn't particularly hard. Based off her CHE110A, I assume the final won't be any harder either. Material covered: Real/ideal gas states, energy balance, engines, entropy, steam tables. Some of the HW assignments take forever to do and she was inconsistent with the points allotted for each assignment. Overall, okay class if you know how ideal and real gases work and understand engines well.
Dr. Ivey is a very fair professor. Review the homeworks and her slides before the exams and you'll be fine. Thermodynamics is a pretty wack class but just trust that it'll be okay

Took with Bryan Wong. 2 Exams worth 45% each. HW is 10%. You can take 1 sheet of paper as a cheat sheet with anything on it (typed, written, painted, etc...). Midterm exam was based on the homework. Final was cumulative but not difficult, easier than the midterm. Most people finished well before the time limit. Curves the class so that its a standard distribution. If you get >80% on both exams and do your hw, you're likely to get an A.

Took with Professor Kandis Leslie Abdul-Aziz. Shes a very sweet and understanding professor. There were simple quizzes once a week to make sure you keep up with the content, there was an extremely fair midterm, and the report and presentations were very straightforward. Nothing tricky. Her notes are also very easy to follow. Overall a great class.

Had Nosang Myung. Lecture was hard to follow so I mostly learned through the textbook. Suggested problems (no homework) were difficult. If you can do those, you can pass the midterm. Know how to read your graphs (they get real weird looking). This course is big on balances (mass and energy). The material also overlaps with CHE100 a bit so I would suggest taking that cocurrently.
Fundamental course for ChE and EvnE. Calculus heavy.
