If you get on the professor Min's good side you will be fine. Asking for help makes this class 200% easier. She will curve the tests if people do really bad and give second chances if you mess up, or at least if enough people have an issue with failing lol
Calculus heavy.

Clark is super difficult and incredibly rude. Does not accept late work whatsoever and purposefully makes the tests very difficult (he even told us this in class), doesn't curve. Exams are open book/note. Expect to see topics that weren't covered on the exams. Expect to spend several hours per question on the hw assignments.

Took with Dr. Clark. While the class was difficult, I think he was a good teacher and his lectures were easier to follow than some of my other ChE professors. He was not rude, despite the general consensus amongst the class, but he did have some strange rules, like no tolerance for iPad submissions. I don't think he will be teaching this course again, but in mass transfer generally expect to spend a significant amount of time on homework problems (taken from textbook). Most exam prep involved redoing homework problems, it is worth spending time on the homework to do well in the class. The problems will click after redoing them repeatedly.
For Dr. Wu, exams are open note. Abuse the hell out of that for an easy A

Group Project is pretty hard, since it's a research paper on a material and the rubric doesn't do a great job of telling you what kind of information to include. The class is pretty easy and honestly interesting if you are half interested in material science as a chem/env e.
Very general chemistry, just know your stuff
Had Professor Harman.  Easy as long as you read the book and practice homework problems.  Know the math.
Easy class, but Harman gives hard tests just for the curve, so be prepared to do a lot of math and very little conceptual stuff.
This class is basically dumbed down AP chem which I took and got a 5 and didn't get credit for because the AP credit system is broken. Hybridization is not taught well.
Hill is hard. Try to rack up points on the quizzes and just practice alot for the midterms and final.
Eichler is a funny professor and easy to keep up with. Beware of his second midterm. It screws a lot of people
Had Professor Chang, accent makes it hard to understand but the material was relatively easy. 3 midterms and final.
Had Bartels. He's a pretty hard teacher but class is still doable if you study hard enough. Go to lectures and pay attention to discussion and clicker questions, they pop up on midterms and finals
Dr. Harman: Midterms were very easy, very much like the questions in the back of the book and Smartwork (online homework questions). Final had some curveball questions (~5 small detail questions)

If you passed the AP Chemistry Test in high school, this class will be a good review for you since it will cover topics from the different models of atoms, types of bonding, intermolecular forces, and stoichiometry. (You should still cover the material so you have a good foundation and an easy time in the class though) If possible, I would recommend taking it with Fokwa. Has a thick accent but sets up the class in a way that makes it super difficult to fail (you seriously need to not do anything to not get points). He has a redemption system so you can get points back if your final exam grade is much higher than your midterm exam scores. All of his exams have extra credit problems that he will give you to do before the exam day (yay!), but he has no curve. So scores on the exams depend entirely up to you. Homework is an easy 100% as long as you do it before the deadline and gives you unlimited attempts and no score penalties (unlike other professors that I have known).

It was Ludwig Bartel who was difficult. It was not your ordinary chem1A class. The average score on the midterm was a 52%. We didn't even find moles or anything, we were going over nuclear chemistry on the second day of lecture lol. The class is okay though once you study and try. Apparently he was on academic probation before this year for failing so many students, sooooooo yeah. If you do get this professor, good luck and just try. I ended up with an A, since he makes a 900/1000 an A. Yep. Good luckkkk.

Had Professor Harman for this class. His class is graded on a curve where the top 15-20% get an A at the end of the quarter, which was pretty doable. Class was pretty easy and the midterm and final weren’t that bad. Second midterm was definitely harder than the first though, with the final being harder than both. If you study the problems in the book and homework, you’ll do well!
Had L. Bartels. His tests were all free-response with no multiple choice, and were mostly conceptual and drawing based. Fairly difficult, you would need to study a decent amount to get an A.
Professor was always aggro. Tests were tricky.

I had Professor Lavallo and he was, well, interesting? He has a slightly condescending attitude which could be very offputting/intimidating for a student  who wants additional help or ask extra questions. His midterm was a bit difficult, the final was unexpectedly difficult, but he gave the class a MASSIVE curve and even curved the final grade; aside from the curve, the saving grace for me was that I had a a really good T.A. though I know plenty others who weren't as lucky. He was ok, not terrible (though many others would say he was), but if you have the option to avoid him, I would. But if you do end up with him, it's not really a big deal, just try to adjust around his personality, I guess. He's also extremely conceptual, and his exams heavily reflect that  (hence, the difficulty), so you have to make sure you 110% understand concepts and how to apply that. If you only understand the concepts on a surface level, you won't do so hot on the tests. Also, homework is optional and not graded, so really try to understand literally everything on it if you want to ace the exams.

If you took honors chem in high school it's exactly like that. Covers lewis structures, bonds, intermolecular forces, stoichiometry. Took with Fokwa. Midterms are EXACTLY like practice problems, so do those and review the notes and you're good for the midterms. The final.... hardest exam ever lol... the exam was nothing like the practice final exam he put out and he even emailed us saying that it was mistakenly harder so he gave us only 15pts extra and NO curve for the class or the exams :/. He isn't a good chem teacher, but if you can learn on your own then take his class because I taught myself 1A during summer and pulled a B.
Professor Fowka had reasonable exams and a curve if you do well on the final

I had Bartels (AVOID IF POSSIBLE), he focuses on concepts over calculations and he ends up covering material that's not supposed to be covered until later on. He teaches super fast and with an accent, so it's hard to understand sometimes. If you haven't taken AP Chemistry or a Chemistry class at all in high school, this class is one of the worst ways to get into chemistry.

I had Chang and from what I heard and seen of other professors' exams, our midterms were very easy and shorter and all multiple choice, but the final was harder and longer than midterms. Just make sure you understand all the concepts and calculations,(which are mostly simple) and you should be fine. She has clicker questions so you should attend class.

Took it w Bartels. AVOID bartels if possible. The course is out of a thousand points and everything is weighed equally. All assignments and tests are assessing a conceptual knowledge of chemistry, so very few calculations. He prefers many drawings and explanations. Lecture and discussion are both mandatory bc of daily clickers. There's also hw almost every day, but he only grades 40 of the hw assignments, the rest are dropped. Form study groups early bc discussions seemed to help my LC. I hated this class with a passion. Tests are difficult, especially when you aren't told what you missed points for. STUDY the practice tests that he posts and any test from him that you can get your hands on bc he likes to recycle questions. We had this one question that was on both midterms and the final. There's also two midterms, but he only takes the higher grade. gl if you get stuck w bartels
Avoid Bartels !!!!
Chang had a difficult accent to understand.

Took it with Dr. Hill. Avoid him if you can. I scored right around the average on first two midterms (65) and had to nearly ace the final to get an A- in the class. Midterms are really time constrained so rack up as many points as you can for the quizzes in discussion, go to your TA's office hours, and know how to do hw problems really well because they are harder than the ones that show up on his exams.
5 unit quizzes, a midterm and a final all online
Don't take it with prof. Chang. Can't understand a word she says and her final is hard af. I had a 89.86 and got a B+, she didn't care to round it to an A- even after me practically begging her.
Professor Eichler was funny and passionate about the topics he covered. Study his lecture presentation slides and worksheets
Professor Bartel is pretty good, though he expects a lot. All exams are free response. He’s really generous with extra credit though so do the extra credit!

Took it with Fakwa. Two things that made me not like this class and changed an overall positive to a negative. He's pretty slow with teaching material. We were consistently 1-2 chapters behind the other classes and by the end, he sped through slides and it felt rushed. the other thing was the final exam. Might just be me but the final exam felt so different from the midterms in terms of difficulty. Still passable. I wouldn't say don't take him if you are looking for a super easy A but an A is achievable.

Avoid Bartels at all costs. This man singlehandedly made my quarter hell. Midterms are all free response sketches and you only get 30 minutes to finish. The grading system was a mess. COVID really inspired this professor to make everything even more confusing than it should be. He basically hid our grades and made them impossible to calculate until after the P/NP deadline. He also made the final exam an oral interview. If you take this class with Bartels, also expect to go beyond Chem1A, because he starts teaching OChem stuff like Mass Spectrometry. He also gives out weekly discussion homework and homework every day (including holidays and weekends). Lecture clickers are graded on accuracy. Super difficult class for intro chem.

Took with Professor Hill Harman during Fall 2020(online b/c of covid). I highly recommend taking his class, especially if you're a first-year. It's a great transition from high school chemistry to college chemistry(especially if you took AP chem in HS). He's a pretty good prof and very kind and helpful. Midterm 1 was not too bad but he made midterm 2 harder on purpose to get the average score lower, but he does curve based on that. Midterm average is usually in the C range but it will be curved to a B- which is pretty generous. Go to lecture because he explains concepts that will be on the exam very well and does virtual clicker questions that you have to do bc they count towards your grade. The only concept he was kinda bad at teaching was hybridization so I'd recommend going to SI sessions for that. Overall, if you put in the work and don't slack off you'll be fine.
Had Eichler, even though we had things like quantum numbers and chirality, which weren't super huge focuses in AP Chem, the class was easy.

Had Bartels for Fall 2020 (corona time). Do all the daily homework (25% of grade), he assigned 60 and counted 40 with the highest grade you got. One practice and real midterm: both fairly difficult but he only takes the grade of the one with the highest score (you can't make it up if you miss one; he'll just take the grade of the one you took). Final was an oral exam that took like 10 min: groups of 3 and he asks you questions live in a circle. Clicker questions during every lecture so you have to show up. Discussion work was in a group once a week (basically just busy work). Caught cheating in a groupme so he might just fail 200 of the 300 students that were in his class.
Fokwa was a great professor in my opinion, and his class was relatively easy and offered a lot of extra help during office hours. His exams were easy as well.

I had Fokwa during Fall 2020 and I thought it was an okay class. He's lecture heavy with a bunch of PollEv clicker questions. You don't really need the book to do well since his practice exams mirror his actual exams and he offers a bunch of extra credit with the PollEv and bonus test questions. As long as you attend lecture and pay attention you should be fine, discussion with the TAs also help a lot.

I had Fokwa in Fall 2020 and personally, I really liked his class overall. There were times where his lectures were kinda boring but there are also times where he really gets into his PollEv questions and lectures. He really wants his students to succeed, so he will help you in any way that he can (i.e. he matches your worst midterm grade to your final grade if your final grade is higher than your lowest midterm grade). This class is relatively easy in all aspects if you took chem in high school but don't slack and still put aside time for studying.

Professor Genereux is extremely knowledgeable about chemistry and was receptive to students' needs. However, I found it difficult to understand his teaching sometimes as the explanations would skip over steps. I personally did not attend his office hours because I had other classes to attend but he was available for questions. This is not to say though that I did not understand any of his teaching. He answered students' questions to the best of his ability and tried to make class enjoyable, especially with it being on Zoom, which was very appreciated. I sought out outside resources such as the ARC's tutoring and YouTube videos that greatly contributed to my understanding of the material. The exams were especially difficult and even when I felt I had a solid understanding of the material, the questions were still hard to answer. Professor Genereux though was a very understanding professor and he provided many opportunities for extra credit, which was very helpful.

Bartels was the cause of not one, not two, but three entire meltdowns that made me question my future career choices. I only took regular chem in high school and slightly struggled in that, so keep that in mind when I talk about the difficulty of this class. Clickers are questions that we had about one minute to answer during lecture and we did between 2 and 7 for every lecture and discussion. They make up 20% of your grade, so if you don’t understand a concept or don’t answer in time, you’re screwed, the bottom 20% of your scores from clickers are dropped. Group homework is done for the most part during discussion, and the questions have little to no relevance to the current course material. The midterm is 30% of your grade, and you really need to know your diagrams and graphs. If you do well on the practice midterm, you basically don’t have to do the actual midterm because he takes the higher score. The final is a short 10 minute oral final with two other people. It isn’t terrible if you know all your terms and diagrams, but he just tells you to study the slides so it's frustrating to study for - this is 10% of the grade. Online homework is assigned almost daily and at random times, so you have to keep checking if he posted the homework. It is quick, and doesn't usually take more than 10 minutes.

Take Fokwa, he gives lots of extra credit. No curve for this class, but there is a redemption system if you screw up on the midterms. If you've taken AP Chem this is basically just a review of the first few chapters so not too hard, just study. Final exam was rough on everyone, gave everyone an extra 25 points. Advice: do the homework without looking up the answers and make sure you understand why the answer is correct.
As a senior in STEM, this class was a piece of cake. Took with Eichler. However, a lot of freshman (mainly in CHASS) struggle with this course.

Eichler for CHEM001A is very doable if you put in the work to get the grade you want. His lectures were online except his discussions and his weekly online quizzes are open notes. His midterm was easy but his final was a bit brutal for some people (MCQ was the hardest part actually imo). Eichler is def easier than most CHEM001A profs but don’t slack off just bc he’s “easier”. Go to office hours, listen and take good, thorough notes on his video lectures, and review review review! Other than that, eichler is very easy to approach in office hours if you need any help and explains concepts very concisely.

AVOID LAVALLO AT ALL COSTS. Prof gives unfair exams and teaches incoherently. My largest complaint is that he taught incorrect information because the correct information was “outside the scope of this class”?????

I always looked forward to Lavallo's zoom lectures but not because he's good at teaching chem. Most of class is him going on tangents about having fun with his best friend R-OH or him ranting about his iPad not working ever since he ran over it with his car. Basically a self-study course with 2 midterms and 1 final. If you score higher on the final than the midterm, he replaces your midterm grade with your final exam grade. HW is optional but you should do it because most of the exam questions come directly from the HW. Weekly quizzes in discussion for bonus points. It's basically impossible to fail his class since a 40% is passing, but you won't learn anything. If you are confident in your knowledge about the first two units of AP Chem and are looking for a low-commitment class, then take Lavallo.

I had the course with Vincent Lavallo. The workload for this course is extremely light because there is no homework. Each discussion week, you have a chance to earn extra credit points which is really nice. The class is mostly based on tests, the final is a gigantic 60% of your grade and replaces your midterms if you do better on it, so make sure you study for the final. Your grade for this class is entirely based on two midterms and one final at the end, so study hard for them. Lavallo's tests are also very conceptually based, so you won't have to do too much work, just make sure you understand the concepts well because the questions he asks on his tests are tricky and can fool you if you are not prepared. There is a very large curve at the end of the quarter and the A cutoff for my class was an 84%
I had it with Joseph Generoux, easily the best professor ever!! very laid back, super helpful, funny, and wants students to get an A in his class. Open note tests and take home!!

Took it with Fokwa for 5-week Summer Session A. He's kinda mid, not too strict nor the best. His lectures are kinda broad and not very informative as he recommends you to go over the lectures slides that he already provided before coming to lecture. He does a couple of clicker questions per lecture based on the lecture slides which could be tricky if you weren't paying attention to the lecture slides. He's generous on clicker questions where everybody gets full credit if 80% of the entire class got the question correct, and few extra credit questions on the practice exams that you can check answers with him through email so that you'll already know the answer to them during the exam day. His exams are almost similar to the practice exams, but he might add few trick questions that are specific enough that they might catch you if you don't pay attention on lectures and practice exams. Knowing the answer choices on the practice exams can also help you as well so that you'll know when the answer choices will be correct on the real exam questions with different wording. He only curves based on how many points between the student with the highest score to reach the perfect score which isn't that much. Since this is a fast-paced course, it's recommended that you try master your understanding on certain chapters/concepts within a few days before the exam so that you'll have enough prep to do well on the actual exam. If you don't understand his lectures very well, always seek outside resources like SI, textbook, youtube vids, etc. TAs might be helpful depending on how informative/strict they are. If you can't handle the fast-paced course, it's best to wait until next year unless it's mandatory to catch up your 4-year graduating plan.

I had David Hill for chem001A. Class is graded on a curve out of 480 points. Quizzes count for 80 points, 2 midterms 100 points each and a final 200 points. Quizzes are free response and Exams are multiple choice. He tells you what is exactly on each quiz and on exams before them. The reason why class averages on exams are in high 60s is because they don't do the homework!!!! If you are comfortable with the homework you should get 80%+ on exams.

Took with lavallo, he's very conceptual and focuses on bonding theories a lot. All his lectures were online, discussions were optional. He posts recordings but doesn't use slides for some chapters. Grading scale was 2 midterms worth 30%, final worth 40%, and optional discussion quiz for up to 10% extra credit. Midterms are group midterms and open everything, final is in person and no notes allowed. Lectures and course outline are confusing to follow and midterm/exam problems are way harder than the material in class. TAs help a lot and you can go to any TA's office hours, sergio and Anton helped me a lot. I ended up with around an A in the class, but I had to actively study and put in a lot of effort.

Hartman is the best. It was his first year teaching and I seriously recommend him. He is so chill and his policies were awesome. You get a retake on your mini test and midterm in case if you did bad on your first attempt. Final score can replace your mini test or midterm score if you did well. There is extra credit in this class. His OLI homework and textbook system is very informative and I learned more chem than I needed to for this class which could be useful for chem1b. Make sure to put in the work and you’ll do just fine :)

Content is pretty similar to AP Chem (periodic trends, stoic, balancing equations, lewis structures/vsepr, electron configuration, nomenclature, etc). Overwhelming and difficult if you have never taken chemistry in high school. Professor Hartman is really good at explaining the content and is very understanding. Assigns weekly homework that is pretty time consuming, but allows retakes for every exam and midterm. Offers extra credit and participation points.
DO NOT take it with Lavallo. You will end up mostly learning from TAs and the class was so bad the curve was a 86 for an A.

Took this class Fall 2022 with Fokwa. Lots of buffer points from hw and the redemption system on the final which makes it difficult to fail. Only complaint is that he did not allow make ups for Poll EV questions which sucked because I missed class for a week because I was sick and didn't get any points back. Midterms and final were alright not impossible and didn't really contain trick questions just do practice exams and study the smartwork. Also, each exam had an EC bonus point that he gives out for you to work on before the actual exam so that was really nice

I repeat and I repeat again to NOT take this class with Vincent Lavallo. Hands down one of the worst professors at UCR. I'm surprised he hasn't gotten fired yet.

He was so hated that the class discord server I was in had a special channel just to make fun of him for being so pathetic.

Extremely disorganized and inappropriate professor. There is no flow to his lectures and often you are wondering where this is going. My guy just lectures from the comfort of his own BED where he wears only boxers and an dirty undershirt. His conduct is completely disgraceful as an middle-aged adult man.

Self-studying is key. Your TA will definitely be useful since they feel sympathy for you. One of the TAs when I took the class was practically teaching the class when Lavallo should be doing his job. This TA was a lifesaver.


The class is test-heavy so do what you can to pass the tests. Final is weighted heavy as a percentage of the grade. 

Do very good on the extra-credit quizzes in discussion. You need the extra credit to not fail the class.

The only reason why the curve is good because of students over the years complaining about how the class sucks.

now i give this an 8, because I was forced to take this immedately due to the LC system despite having no prior experience in chem, so I struggled deeply. but if u took like ap chem prior or something, youll prob be good
Read the lab manual and do well on quizzes and reports.  Don't sweat about doing poorly on the final.  Just make it above 50%, which is generally the average.
Always come to class with the previous weeks lab report and conclusion(unless it was already turned in) and this week's lab procedure and prelab. My TA was very lenient with grading imo.

Super easy. Labs are kinda boring since it's all basic stuff. For lab quizzes, just make sure to know the procedure and some background info from the lab you are doing that week and the week before that and you should be fine! For lab reports, just make sure to include everything that is necessary, and make sure to check your work on the "lab report" worksheet from the lab manual because points are taken off for wrong answers.

Always read the lab manual before you even start the class to get an idea of what you need to do. I recommend not doing everything last minute because lab is a chore and you have other classes to worry about as well (do a little bit everyday!). Pay attention to your syllabus in terms of deadline since sometimes you may need to turn in your lab report early. Just review the material ahead of time and ace the quizzes (you should be fine).

Read the manual and underdtand how to do every calculation for the final and you’ll be fine. Average for my classes lab final was like a 50% but the test was basically all calculations with some concepts.

Experiments are easy. Just know the concepts and calculations. Manuals are decent at explaining calculations, but my TA was cool and taught us all the calculations before the labs started so that helped (for the few experiments that required math). Quizzes for 1A labs aren't hard either, just review pre lab calculations/ and the material in lab manual for that experiment and your good. The final tho.... that sucked ass. For not having so much calculations in 1A the final had mostly calculations lol. Study your pre-lab and quizzes for the Final. Final brought me down from an A- to a B+ :/, so just study well in advance and go to TA and hopefully you'll be alright.

If this is your first lab class, it will be a little tough. Be detailed in your reports, go to TA office hours, and be friendly with them. Study hard for the quizzes by reading the prelab in advanced (cannot stress that enough) and doing the prelab questions on your own. For the final, the curve (although usually pretty generous) is dependent on how your section is doing, so make sure you're racking up as many points as you can. Know all the concepts listed on the objectives sheet posted in ilearn because thats literally the layout of the final. Finally, if your TA isn't helpful, don't be afraid to go to another ta who can explain concepts better.
Make sure you use sig figs!!

Having labs online made it easier to not mess up any numbers since we just watched videos of the guy doing the lab. The most entertaining part was that has face had the look of someone being held hostage.
Use sig figs, be thorough in your lab reports. Grade depends on the TA that you have but it is normalized at the end.

Most labs never take up the whole 3 hours which is nice. The workload was too time consuming considering it is only a 1 unit class. Your grade depends on your TA because all of the work is graded by the TA. Dr. David Hill was really good. Gave thorough explanations and was really nice to talk to. He was a harsh grader compared to the other TAs, but the final and class was curved at the end.
Not as easy as 1A but it's not too hard. As always just know your stuff
Had Prof Mueller.  If you read the book, going to class is optional.  Practice homework problems and know concepts in great detail.  Final exam is difficult.
Sort of easier than 1A. Jason Cheng is a really good professor and funny at times. A lot of concepts are taught so go to lectures. I had clicker so you might too.
Took with Quan Cheng. If you understand how to use formulas and have a good TA it's not that bad of a class, but Cheng does not explain anything at all.

Had Prof Davies. His lectures were boring (nice accent though) and basically annotates his slides. Had 2 midterms and they were both hard (class average was low). He uses PollEverywhere for participation and Smartwork for homework.

Took it with Quan Cheng. He explained everything thoroughly. Just go over the questions during lecture, clicker questions, and do the Extra Homework since some of the questions on the exam stem from that. Overall, this class was not that hard.

Had Yinsheng Wang, not a bad professor by any means, but his exams are hit or miss, either really easy or ridiculously hard. Material itself isn't too bad to grasp, just make sure to understand the homework. Best way to get an A though is to read the textbook before lecture to get a grasp of the material ahead of time.

Had Dr. Chang and he's honestly really boring and its more worthwhile to read the book than to listen to his lectures. He has clickers so you're forced to go to class but as long as you do enough of them then you could honestly just go for the clicker and then just ditch. Overall CHEM001B isn't bad but it's a little more difficult than CHEM001A. I heard from my upperclassman friends that it's the hardest in the CHEM001 series, but we'll see. Just review the end of chapter problems, do the practice midterm, review the clicker questions, and the homework before the midterms/final and you'll be set! BTW he gives a lot of extra credit opportunities.
Not very hard, but make sure you do plenty of practice problems to prepare for exams; also David Hill is one of the tougher chemistry professors

Going to lecture is useless if you have Quan Cheng. A great guy, but he doesn't know how to utilize his time. I just stayed in the back and left after the clicker questions. Go over his practice tests! He copies and pastes some questions into the test and it's just good practice if you don't go to lecture.
Took it with Cheng and the midterms and final were super easy because they were mainly based off of the practice exams and the homework.

Had Cheng. Exams are straightforward and should be easy if you study the stuff he gives you: clicker, hw, practice exams, back of book practice problems. The stuff shows up on exams. His class breakdown is VERY forgiving. Lots of opportunities to earn extra points. Got a C- on first midterm, but was able to make up those points and get an A in the end.

Had Proff Zhao. Chem1B is very mathematical, lots of equations and solving word problems. As long as you know how to use equations given, you’ll be fine. Zhao is a pretty good teacher, would recommend his class.
I had Dr. Linlin Zhao. Great professor, easy to understand, pretty good policies in syllabus. 2 midterms, final. Content not too difficult.

[COVID-19 SPRING 20] I had this class ONLINE with Linlin Zhao. Attending the Zoom lecture was recommended and he occasionally tossed in some clicker questions to reward those who actively attended. Chem 1B builds off of the information you learned in Chem 1A so it's good to brush up on some of those topics. Like others are saying, this class is a lot of equations and plugging and chugging. The word problems are tricky too. Each chapter was a new concept for me, so it took me a while (and a lot of Khan Academy...) to fully understand the concepts and how the equations worked. Reading the textbook is extremely helpful and he bases most of his exam questions off of what he teaches on the slides. Zhao presents his information pretty thoroughly and takes the time to help students who are stuck. This class moves fairly quickly, so understanding all of the concepts is vital to earning a good grade. Unfortunately, the exams are all closed book and proctored. Clicker questions (20%), discussion points (10%), and homework (20%) make up 50% of the grade (as well as potential bonus points). For us, the homework had unlimited tries and there was no penalty for wrong answers. There are 2 midterms (10% each) and a final (30%). The exams aren't curved (I think), but the final class grade is based on a curve. Overall, I enjoyed this class a lot and I recommend taking it with Zhao!

I took it with Prof. Tim Su and he was amazing. I still got not so good grades on midterms and exams (like Ds lmfao) and thanks to his generous grading ended with a B+. He was an amazing prof as he really cared about his students. I would definitely suggest taking Chem 1B with him if you can

Not very easy but not very hard. Had Eichler and it was asynchronous. He is very good at explaining stuff. Graded by weekly canvas videos, weekly quizzes, hw on chem 101, midterm, final and discussion attendance. He offered extra credit throughout the quarter and his grading scale was point based. No matter how much the total is, as long as you got a certain amount of points then you got the letter grade assigned on the syllabus.

I had Timothy Su and honestly he's a good lecturer/professor. My only complaint is that his tests were nothing like the homework/lectures. The wording was different, which threw me off. At the same time, I guess I could've started studying earlier for them. He lets you have a cheat sheet during the midterm/final though, which was pretty helpful. I feel like I learned a lot through the homework and lectures but the tests/my grade didn't reflect that.
I had it with Tim Su, straightforward notes, chill professor. his practice exams are almost identical to his midterms and finals; very helpful! attend review sessions with the TAs they help a lot

Took it with Professor Yin in Summer Session B, he's an amazing professor. He's very helpful and caring during office hours. He's also informative when going over the lecture slides with enough details. His midterms and finals are very similar and exact to the practice problems, if you understand better on the practice exams, you'll have no problem on doing the actual midterm and finals. Exams aren't too hard, they're pretty fair and able to solve them. Really recommended him.
Easier than CHEM001LA.  Not a lot of new material.
Easier than Chem01LA.

Little harder than CHEM01LA. No extra credit ;-; quizzes get a little more detailed. TAs make it seem like the final is going to be killer but honestly just review everything in your manual and the quizzes and you should be fine.
Honestly I feel like CHEM01LB was easier than LA. Maybe cuz I got the hang of it this quarter but I feel like the lab reports weren't as hard.
It's all equilibrium, once you understand it it's no problem
Eichler doesn't curve. Go to class--he doesn't really teach the book.
Jiang was chill but no curve :(
Easier than CHEM001B. Jiang is fair, though no curve. Lots of clickers and unlimited attempts (no penalty) on HW. Midterms look like clickers and practice exams.
The early two chapters about acids and bases are the toughest in the course and the difficulty drops off as you move through the course.
Professor Min Xue was extremely fair. His exams were all similar to the homework and study guides he put out for us. Gives out a lot of bonus points as well

Class was pretty easy once you can see the patterns to the problems. Jiang is great, clickers and practice exams similar to actual exam. You almost have to learn to do the types of calculations for clickers on the fly, but they are fair enough
Had Ming Tang. Kinda hard to follow at times. Midterms and final are nothing like the practice versions. Read the book

Took it Dr. Eichler, a very fair professor and makes lectures fun to attend. I thought it was easier than CHEM001B just because some were stuff that we learned in previous chem classes. He offers a lot of extra credit and clicker questions and iLearn quizzes (which are worth more than midterms). His exams have free response questions which are harder than multiple choice questions so look out for those.
Dr. Eichler is a good professor and offers a lot of extra credit. I would recommend him. However, he does do mc AND frqs for his midterms and final.
Easiest of the series. Jiang was fair. Exams resembled clickers and practice exams. Extra credit is available but only if you get really high clicker and homework scores

Had Eichler. He's a good lecturer, but he had us do this "creative exercise" where you had to write 10 statements about a certain chemical situation and most of your statements had to come from the material you just learned (which sounds easy until you actually do it). His midterms were not anything like other professor's midterms that I'm used to. Each exam has about half your points in free-response. Final had some curve ball questions -- make sure you know your material from past chem classes in the gen chem series...

I took it with Ming Lee Tang and the class was...strange. Discussions are only quiz-based and none of the material from lecture really gets retaught in discussion. Midterms and the Final are pretty tough and under a normal grading scale, I believe around 60-70% of the class would have failed. She's not a very approachable teacher and the same goes for the TAs. Luckily, she's not a cruel professor and curved the class so that the average student got a B. For reference, class averages for the midterms and final were around D-F range. I got above average twice(about 1-3 points above) and below average once(1 point below), and I got a B+ in the class. Tang's class is really a tossup

Had Ming Lee Tang. Decent lecturer, but her exams were DIFFICULT. practice midterms did not reflect the difficulty at all and no amount of studying could have properly prepared me. Got a low C on both midterms and a D on the final, but the curve brought me up to an A so there's that.

Had Professor Harman. Uses smartwork which is very good resource for studying for the final and midterms. It was his first time teaching 1C and so it wasn't the best but better than Hill lol, but still he was a good lecturer and made me want to go to class and pay attention. If you read/ skim the book (for the conceptual questions) and do calculations similar to the ones on the homework, you can get good scores on midterms. Final he repeated questions from midterms so do go to office hours and TA office hours to see your exam and review the ones missed. 1C material isn't hard but the chapter on acid and base and its equilibria was I thought the hardest. Easier than 1B though imo.
i have no problem with how test heavy the grades are but i really hate how the professor teaches in his lectures.

Had Eichler (think that's how he spells it). This was my easy class for the quarter so I was able to kinda neglect it and pass but it got pretty tough so that's how I ended up with like a C in the class. Also, c'mon fellas... his jokes are funny stop trashing on him for it

Took it with Jiang. Highly recommend not taking with Jiang if you don't already have experience with gen chem (ex: taking a year of chem in high school/ap chem) because he can tend to be very conceptual instead of mathematical (and the midterms are mathematical). The poll/clicker questions can be pretty difficult because he doesn't really teach them beforehand so you're kind of learning as you go. The homework can also be frustrating because in the later chapters he doesn't do a lot of practice problems that are similar to what's on the homework. The midterms are pretty ok as long as you review the quizzes, poll/clicker questions, and homework. Practice midterm was helpful too because he goes over it in class. Overall unless you don't have previous gen chem experience it's pretty manageable and fair.

Had Ming Lee Tang Spring 2020. Cannot lecture to save her life and her train of thought is so hard to follow. Exams are hard and can not be compared to her quizzes and homework assignments. She curved it so that the top 30% got an A, middle 60% got Bs/Cs, and the bottom 10% failed.

Take MingLee Tang! She is really considerate of her students during difficult times (COVID-19, fight against police brutality). She responds to emails faster than any of my previous professors, and she uses piazzi which is really useful

First half was super easy. Second half ramped up the difficulty. It's not too bad as long as you do the homework. I had Jiang. There were no "replacing of the midterm with final score" type of redemption. But due to recent world events, he changed some grading to a "no risk" type of final.

(Fall 2020 Via Zoom) I gave this class 7/10 in difficulty because I had a hard time working through the calculations. It's not like math where you know exactly what equation to use. You have to be able to read the word problem and realized if an acid is weak or not and from there see which, of the various equations, to use. I had Dr. Xue. He is a laid back professor and does a good job at teaching the material. He applies it to the real world as well. Homework is assigned through smartwork and is due at the end of the quarter before the final. He also assigned practice quizzes which are really important because they are exactly like the midterms and final. There are 2 midterms and 1 final. Your better score is weighted heavier so that you get a better grade and exams are not proctored. He also offers 100 EC for good questions. Each question is worth 1 extra point. There is also a decent curve. I was at a C+ and got a B.

Take with Professor Xue Min! Still have to do your Smartwork Homework but test questions are just like the homework problems with different numbers.Quizzes are optional. Grade is just homework, midterms, and final. Tests are all open note.

Avoid ryan julian; class itself is supposed to be easy(ish) and his tests are open notes but theyre timed like crazy and he rly is out to get his students. He posts slides missing important information, and gives difficult problems on tests on purpose. 3 quizzes instead of midterms, final worth 40% of grade, he thinks a 50% average on his quizzes is good :(

I took it with Eichler while in-person lectures, he's pretty chill professor and informative in lectures. He also post lecture videos on canvas where you do them and there's also lecture video quizzes that's worth a lot of points like a video quiz question that's worth 5 points. Polleverywhere questions are based on the materials and lecture vids, so do the lecture vids first before going to in-person lectures. Discussions are mandatory where you have to attend all of them to get attendance points, but Discussion TAs are pretty helpful at covering materials from lectures, and materials that'll be on the exams. For exams, they're mostly average to some that are difficult due to being more of an applicable qs than conceptual qs along with calculation qs as well. There's also FRQs for the exam which is based on mostly calculations, drawing, and write to explain your answer. So, do the practice problems, asking qs to TA/Eicheler's office hours, form a study group, go to SI, etc. Overall course is 1 midterm, 1 midterm re-take, 1 final, lecture vids/lecture quizzes/qs, discussion attendance, and poll qs. Grading is based on points grade cut-offs, earn as many points as you can. Eichler also do some extra credit points from either completing his potential surveys, answering pizzara qs that students post, etc.
Standard material.  Arguably easier than LB.
The labs manuals are already poorly written from when you take 1LA, but the 1LC manuals were the probably the worst written. Vague instructions on calculations, and you better hope you have a good TA

Hardest lab of the series. The calculations are a bitch because the lab manual is HORRIBLE at explaining how to do them. When doing the lab reports, refer to your prelab and it helps but still the lab manual is the worst one out of the entire series. Some more complicated labs but nothing too crazy and most of the times I was out with good amount of time. The final wasn't bad I got a decent score and I studied the prelabs and the practice final and read over the major points in the lab manual. Good curve though, but still try.

Compared to the first two of the series this one was ridiculously hard. I breezed through the labs the first two quarters and was stuck for hours each week trying to finish the reports. You better hope you have a good TA who answers questions unlike mine.

(Fall 2020 Via Zoom) I gave this class 8/10 in difficulty because the labs were very calculation heavy and had many little details. The quizzes were also pretty hard as you had to be able to recall the lab details. However, if you did well in 1LA and 1LB then you should be fine. The curve is also decent when it comes to the TA grading adjustments. I BOMBED the final (almost everyone did),  and I walked out with an A-. Try to take it with Brandon; he's chill and super helpful when it comes to answering questions.

CHEM01LC lab is harder than the previous two CHEM labs. A lot that you need to go through the lab manual along with lots of calculations. There's always a possibility where there's an error in lab experiment that can ruin your lab report's calculations/results. Grading can also depends on the TAs, some would give partial credits if you did the experiment wrong. So, go to TA's office hours to double check with the lab report and pre-lab for accuracies to get the full points. In terms of the final, the qs are very tough based on calculations, what did you learn from all the experiments, concepts from the lab manuals, and sometimes asked what materials you used for the experiment. Overall, practice doing the calculations for all experiments that do required them and understand what you did for each experiment/lab manual.

Content and labs are similar to genchem, but the labs emphasize precision and accuracy. Difficulty depends on the TA and when you take it. Some TAs require 5-ish page lab reports for every experiment and others don't. There are 12 labs total, so try not to take it in the summer because it was a 5 week session. Writing reports will prepare you for CHEM125W.

Had it with professor Cheng in the summer, he's was a pretty generous and kind professor. He was pretty understanding and his examples were pretty easy to follow. Tests weren't surprising. and they were open book and open notes (no internet). He has poll everywhere questions and credit does depend on whether you get it right or not, but almost everyone got full points. Material-wise, it's all just gen chem stuff, but more in depth. Curve was really generous. As for labs, because it was in the summer, we had a 4 hour lab period every day (mon-thurs). During the school year it's twice a week. The TAs are super nice and helpful, and overall are pretty generous graders. However, your lab grades do depend on how accurate and how precise you are. Just be extra careful when using those micropipettes and you should be okay. Lab reports can be pretty tedious and long, but the calculations are pretty straightforward and you are allowed to use excel.
Note: Formerly CHEM012A
Hooley is a tough grader but a better teacher
if possible, take Cassleman
O Chem 12 Ais a a good challenging class, when you finally understand, it all clicks

Hooley: Posts a lot of his own problem sets and practice exams with keys that really help for the MTs/Final. Go to SI. Fast paced lecture, but very good teacher. Mechanism focused, doesn't like nomenclature.
Casselman is overrated; 90% of grades is 3 midterms. Study and memorize everything

For Switzer over summer 2018 > class is very fast paced but I still passed, average of the curve is set to be a B- and the standard deviation for the final was around 30, midterms were 14-15. The average for my class was 60+ though, study smart. I recommend doing textbook questions BUT at the end of 8B he told us that the manual for Carey had lots of errors when he was going through hw and that he doesn't even actually do the questions. He does select them and put them on the midterm though which is odd pretty sure as a last minute resort. Also there's a seating chart for his tests but he didn't post them until literally right before the test, I remember once he posted it a few minutes before the test began and all of us had to shuffle
Hooley talks kind of fast. All free response tests. Gives a lot of study materials that really help on the test.
Casselman is cool. Work on problem sets and invest in Organic Chemistry as a Second Language as a supplemental book.
dude casselman sucks he literally is like a 5 year old.  if you put him in a bad mood your grade gets affected. I rather take it with Pirruing than this mutha fucka
Casselman grades the exams very harshly. There is no partial credit. He does not teach well either. I would suggest taking Hooley or some other professor.
Just study don't memorize and you should be good :)
Take with hooley, if you do his problems you will atleast pass his class.

Took it with Casselman. Good professor but class is very difficult. About 50% receive As/Bs. Grades are determined mostly by exams (85% - M1+M2+Final), the rest of the points is by online assignments which are easy. I recommend Casselman for people, but your success will be determined solely through your outside study. He gives practice exam sessions which are not there for learning but to get a grasp on the structure of the exams. I highly recommend you to get Organic Chemistry as a Second Language, it is the reason why I got an A.

I had Casselman for Fall 2019. Majority of your grade will be coming from the midterms and final exam, so it is important to do well on them. I highly recommend going to office hours and reviewing the material after every lecture to get used to it. Taking this class was difficult because you have to learn how to visualize and think in 3D to understand what is going on. Otherwise, if you are able to do that, you should be able to breeze through the exams just fine. For the exams, I recommend you to go through both the practice sets and the practice exam problems that Casselman gives out AND go to the review sessions!
Casselman has almost no homework--which if you're like me and need a ton of practice problems is quite bad sometimes. His exams were fair but a little hard. He's an awesome lecturer though :)

Ochem is hard and definitely do not slack off! Stay on top of your studies and even get ahead so you can be more prepared for the exams. Do A LOT OF PRACTICE QUESTIONS, it'll definitely help (recommend David Klein's Ochem as a Second Language).
Casselman is a great Professor and made the class much easier

Took with Casselman. Honestly was not as bad as people say. As long as you study; go over the ppts, watch yt videos, go to SI you will be FINE!! It gets hard but as long as you keep up and do not give up it will get easy!

Had Casselman for Winter 2020. I had a good ass time in 8A because I used Organic Chemistry as a Second Language, so I highly recommend that and do the practice problems. Casselman is a really good lecturer and his teaching style is very simplified and breeze that it made 8A material easier. I didn't read the textbook at all and walked out with an A, just wrote down notes, studied that and did tons of practice problems. Oh and forsure go to the session reviews he holds, those help a lot in terms of going over how to do his exams and how he wants things which helps a lot. Highly recommend Casselman for 8A

I took it was Casselman while classes were online. The material is definitely difficult, so I would recommend going to SI regularly from the beginning of the course. Lectures are recorded and uploaded onto iLearn. He provides a lot of points with assignments which helps to balance out the final. Since we were online, we didn't have any midterms and our final was open note. Instead of a midterm, we had weekly in-class activities/learning modules based on the material covered that week. It was basically group-work, so they were just free points.

Casselman did a great job adjusting for online. He keeps a google drive folder updated (daily) w the annotated slides, class activities, practice questions, and anything else from lecture. He also has a series of videos on youtube going over concepts in greater detail. No midterms, but a thorough final. Homework is based on slides and textbook, but still takes some thinking bc it's mostly free response. Tbh homework is more like a weekly quiz but you get a week to work on it. He also posts the homework keys, which is super helpful for final review. Oh yeah, he also hosts review sessions starting a few weeks before the final, they go over literally everything using practice problems that he then solves for you.

Took with Casselman, Winter 2021. Expect it to be difficult. Casselman's structure for the panoramic was top tier, most of your grade is homework/activities and as long as you have almost all of those points, the final will just decide if you get a C,B, or A. Go to SI discussions and just stay on top of your stuff.
This course with Larsen is the reason for me dropping out of CNAS.

Winter 2022 Casselman was a good lecturer up until we were behind and he crammed 5 lectures into 2 days and expected us to have everything nailed. Exam was MC and free response. No homework. There is already a set grading scale, and emphasized on "not curving" 85% were exams. There was a lot of opportunities to improve your grade. STUDY EVERYDAY. Cramping simply does not work for this class

this was a difficult class. i took larsen. i was absolutely positive i failed the class since i was getting 30s on exams when the averages were 50-60 range but i was so surprised when grades came out and i received a C-. so overall the curve was so fat but i learned absolutely nothing. i wish i went to office hours (i couldnt because conflicting with another class) to gauge how she was as a person but she seemed nice enough for an ochem prof. her notes are super disorganized though. i used youtube and it was enough to know some necessary things.

I took it with Casselman. He absolutely made CHEM008A more manageable to learn and understand well with the materials. His lectures are easy to follow and understandable. His exams are quite fair based on how much practice you've been doing from the weekly practice activity he did every Friday and the self-assessments. He's also quite helpful during office hours where he'll let you try answer the problems first, then he'll guide you the rest when you're unsure of solving your questions. Overall, he's a pretty nice and caring professor. If you want to succeed more, then do the optional textbook problems he will assigned which makes you more well-prepared, and/or get more supplementary instructions from the SI leaders which were also quite helpful to me for more understanding of what Casselman covered in lectures.
Easy if you spend a decent amount of time on lab work.  Final is easy if you read all the manuals again.

The lab itself is kinda fun but the post labs can be extremely hard since the lab moves faster then lecture at times. Invest in a chegg account and you will be ok. DO NOT sleep on the final, its not terribly hard but alot of people fail it and its worth more than half your grade
Memorize the manual aka look for bolded words and make sure to pay attention to any pictures or diagrams you see.

Relatively easy. Make sure to read lab manual before class, quizzes can be difficult and specific. Final is pure memorization, you are given 80 questions to remember and 24 will be picked out to be used in the exam. My only problem was with the method they used to distribute grades. I got a B with a 92. Hooley decided it was best to rank students in their lab section against one another. fk hooley

Your overall grade in this class is determined by your scores in the lab reports and the final assessment. The final assessment is the easiest part of the lab. They will provide you both the questions and answers for the final assessment, so I recommend you practice these questions over the quarter on a regular basis to memorize the answers and score perfect on this category. What determined your final grade came from how well you did overall in the class RELATIVE to your peers in all lab sections. Many people found out the hard way that their "raw score" didn't not exactly correlate with their final score. (e.g. 94% raw score is actually a B in the class because Hooley gave out letter grades after "adding the normalized lab scores (average ~200), the lab exam (average ~230), ranking the class and assigning grades based on that ranking. [...] Your grade is NOT dependent on a raw score, it is dependent on your position in the class." So beware of that. :)

Took it during COVID. Honestly your TA makes or breaks your experience. My TA was really bad, so I had to go other TA's office hours to get help with the lab reports. The labs weren't too confusing to understand, but sometimes they word things weirdly and I would need clarification on that. The lab final focused a lot on the material from experiments 1-5 in my opinion (chair structures, IR spectra, acids and bases are the main topics I can think of). Don't think you can study for the final in one day, because you won't be able to.

The overall lab grade really depends how much your Lab TA will be lenient or strict. For me, my lab TA was a first-timer TA. So, overall made my experiences in CHEM08LA a bit more lenient. For the materials/labs, it's very time consuming despite that it's not that difficult to them as there's multiple parts with repeated steps in certain labs. The very first wet lab made my lab went overboard on the timing since it took forever to obtain the necessary data. So, just plan ahead on what you will need to do and get started asap so that you don't have to wait in line to grab the necessary materials. In terms of the grading, it really depends on how well you do in the lab, the experiment data, and your understanding throughout the labs. So, just double check your understanding and lab report during any TA's office hours or by emailing for feedbacks/extra help.  The lab final were alright since it's based on the tophat qs and what you did throughout the previous labs along with calculation qs when doing reagent tables. Overall, the lab is quite average in terms of understanding the materials and the procedure you will be doing for each lab.
Note: Formerly CHEM012B
Avoid Morton
Larsen jumps around when lecturing
If you have Larsen, first of all I'm sorry, but seriously  just memorize all her notes
Take Casselman if he's teaching it. Larsen is an okay second choice, though she as a professor can be confusing. Avoid Pirrung and Morton.
So much material. So little time. Stay away from Morton. Pirrung was good

Morton: Talks slow, writes slow, and yet you still are lost during lecture. Go to SI and find outside help. Become a master at and keep up with his "unknowns" example problems. Exams are very challenging and time pressured. Average 35-40%. Posts a couple past exams with no answer keys.
100% exam based
Hard grading and exams in Hooley.  His average is a B- tho.  Posts a lot of practice exams that are really helpful.  No need to read the book but definitely show up to class
Larsen: Memorize reactions & basic mechanisms. Mostly MC, free response is drawing products/starting materials. It's funny when she yells at people outside the lecture hall.
Hooley is a fair professor. Make a godly cheat sheet (aka copy down all your notes) and you will be fine.

had casselman for 8B. it was a lot of material, and he knows it so his exams arent that hard. As long as you know what youre doing and you feel comfortable with the rxns, you'll be fine.  if u care about your gpa, go to SI.

had casselman for spring 2020. It was tough way harder than 8a. you NEED to go over notes and do practice problems, dont fall behind because theres so many reactions etc. Last 2 weeks of the quarter, he becomes super moody and thats when everyones grades drop so do good before hand. I was going to get an A but ended up with a B bc he gave me a 30% one the last hw when my hw avg was 92%.

Took Spring 2020 with Switzer. His lecture notes are kinda dry, but if you read the textbook it helps alot as his notes are just a summary of the readings. I did the practice he assigned and a few did show up on the midterms (word for word) but you can get away with not doing them and still getting a decent score. FATTT curve for online 2020 (said he'd curve the same for summer 2020) and he is very caring as he made our final optional. Overall he isn't a bad lecturer but I did read the book and did practice problems as his notes are kinda dry.

Kevin Kou is the best OCHEM professor I've ever had! His grading scale is really nice, his lecture notes are very clear, and although the exams are free response and pretty difficult, they are fair. As long as you do your part, you'll pass. He's very kind and truly cares about his students. the best professor at UCR

I had Kou for this class during COVID and I didn’t really like his teaching method. He is a really nice guy but the exam format and homework doesn’t help at all. There are 2 midterms, both worth 22.5% and a final worth 35%. He gives out free-response exams, which don’t really make sense and for a class like organic chemistry, it makes learning the material for the class even harder. His practice tests and homework don’t really help when studying for this class.

TAKE KOU!! best professor ive ever had and genuinely cares about his students which makes a big difference in a really difficult course like ochem. he did redemption on the final for winter 2020 but final was cumulative. VERY FAIR GRADER

(Took online in Winter 2021) Dr. Kou is the GOAT. He cares a lot about his students, is extremely nice to everyone, and is always looking to improve or make changes to make the experience better for students. He always stays an extra hour or more during office hours and sometimes stays after lecture as well to answer questions. The content of this class is difficult and definitely requires a lot of studying, but his exams are fair. The problem sets are optional but definitely help a lot in preparing for exams. He grades fairly and he also allows regrades on Gradescope. He handwrites all his notes and they are really neat. Dr. Kou is probably one of the best professors at UCR and I highly recommend taking his class. He also bumps you up a grade letter if you are borderline. (I was ~1% away and he rounded up for me and I heard he rounded someone up 3% to the next grade letter, so he is very generous).

I had Dr. Kou for this class during COVID. Dr. Kou was one of the best and most understanding professors throughout the pandemic. You could tell that he genuinely cared about his students. Personally, I found the final to be the hardest, then the first midterm, and then the 2nd midterm. I would HIGHLY recommend going to SI as much as possible. I think that was the main thing that contributed to me getting an A in the class. He will also most likely assign problem sets throughout the chapter. I would also suggest keeping up with those, instead of saving them all for the week before the exam. The material in this course is inherently more difficult than that in CHEM008A, which is the only reason I would give it a relatively high difficulty score.

Kou (winter 2023): Dr. Kou is really nice, but be prepared for fully free response tests. If you're adjusted to a different professor's teaching style from 8A (like Hooley with his cheat sheets) and you can take them again, I would recommend it. Same grading scale as Casselman, same "I won't curve" mentality. Our first exam was curved by 2% (down to the highest score since no one got 100). Otherwise, the other two exams were not individually curved. The all FRQ with no cheat sheet can be really difficult, lots of mechanisms to know for 8B. Kou takes the notes with you during class and will stop to write down important points, he really does want us to learn. Lots of problem set practice and go to OH/SI if you can. I scored around average on all my exams and got all my participation (poll ev) points, should've ended with a D+, but because of my average scores and full participation, he curved me to a C (without me even asking!!).

Take with Hooley if you can, his exams are hella curved, basically if you get around a 50% on each exam you'll definitely pass. DO THE PROBLEMS SETS AND MOCK MIDTERMS, it will all be similar to the exam. Overall if you put in the work its not a hard class.
Harder material than LA.  Large curve overall
Fast labs. Not too much to memorize for the final. Keep a look out for emphasized detail in the manuals like color changes and specific processes.

Labs are generally easy and finished with good amount of time. TA wasn't too picky and the final was just memorizing the given questions and answers, so it wasn't bad. Sometimes the lab does go ahead of lecture so beware of that, but experimentally isn't hard as you learn all new stuff like C13 in the begninning.

(during COVID) Pretty similar to CHEM08LA in terms of difficulty. I would recommend completing your lab report as early as possible so you have ample time to ask your TA questions. I did that for the second half of the quarter and that helped my grade a lot. I would also recommend reviewing the corrections you get on your graded reports. My TA messed up my grading A LOT, so I was able to get back a bunch of points just by checking his work. The final was easier than CHEM08LA's final in my opinion.
Note: Formerly CHEM012C
Take Switzer if you can, he's very clear about what will be on the exam and gives good lecture notes on ilearn

Not that difficult with Pirrung.  Just memorize all the obscure structures and generally know how to apply the reactions and you're all set.  He basically gives everything in class, so show up and take notes.

From what I've heard, difficulty is highly professor dependent. Larsen will make this class significantly harder than it needs to be. Content wise it's undeniably easier then 8B but if you had a good 8B professor and not so good 8C professor you may struggle.

Taken with Switzer. The first half is very difficult as all the reactions look the same, but the second more biochem focused half is generally easier. Memorize switzers notes and the answers to book problems, as they always show up on the test and its free points if you know them. Theres 2 curves.

Honestly the class concepts itself are much easier than the others in the series, but depending on your teacher, it could be a lot harder than it needs to be. I took it with Larsen this quarter, which I do not recommend. However, if you have no other choice, memorize her notes and you will do well.
Not too difficult,

Took with Switzer Fall 2020. Three midterms and third midterm was our final and not cumulative. 8C is easier than 8B and there's less reactions as most of them just tweak stuff already learned in 8A/8B. First two chapters are probably the hardest of the entire class, and after CH 18/19 the rest of the class is biochem focused and generally the material is easier to understand as nothing new is learned, just apply ochem to bio which isn't hard. Do the practice problems as usual for Switzer as some pop up on the exam word for word and going to SI really helped. Easier than 8B though and not a bad time.

Took it with Switzer online during Spring 2021. The actual material is not that difficult, but his notes are extremely vague so you have to do a lot of self-studying to gain a better understanding. I highly recommend going to office hours and SI and studying a lot for the first exam, and then taking it easy from there. His grading system is based off of curved exam grades, so the average for the exam is a B, one SD above is an A, and one SD below is a C. Also do as many of his practice problems as you can, as it will give you a better idea of what he wants you to focus on for the exams.

Took it with Prof Catharine Larsen in Spring 2023. In person. 25% MT1 (100 points), 25% MT2, 50% Final exam. All MC, except for some fill-in/draw the "product" answers. Mechanisms were multiple choice, just select the correct arrow pushing for the named reaction. This quarter it was in between Larsen or Switzer. I chose Larsen. Great professor, can sometimes come off as passive aggressive, but she is just doing her job and gives very straightforward and to the point answers. She is not trying to overcomplicate things. Streamlines concepts. Makes it easy to learn to learn the hard concepts. Office hours were helpful to answer questions and address confusion about the lecture notes/problems. She uploads her pdfs of her notes she writes in class under the doc cam. EVERYTHING IS IN THE LECTURE NOTES. No funny business. Relieved some of my test taking anxiety because she really isn't trying to trick you. Concepts are easier to grasp then 08B and seems like we learn less/less rushed but still there was a good amount of studying to do.
More guesswork in the lab work.  A little more difficult than previous quarters of chem lab.  Final is the same as always.  Pirrung writes them, so memorize the manual.

Taken online so the labs were different. Lab TA are picky as hell during online so really put in time and effort. I hated using the Marvin sketch for drawing the mechanisms so be prepared for that. 8LC final wasn't hard you just need to memorize the answers to the post lab questions. Just the TA I had was too damn picky lol.

Took it online during Spring 2021. Lab was much easier than prev ochem labs. Reports are entirely based on NMR and are extremely short, so try to finish it during the actual lab period while you have the TA there. Don't underestimate the final; it was much more difficult than previous courses.

Took this with Rena Hayashi in Summer 2021. One of the worst classes I've ever taken. The entire lab is figuring out NMR charts that are incredibly complicated and not intuitive at all (multiple charts have peaks that are on top of each other and are hard to decipher). The lab manual itself had a ton of typos and alot of the information was straight up wrong or came with some caveat. Also completely dependent on your TA. Mine wasn't helpful so I often had to go to Office Hours for multiple TA's per day. Labs were assigned Monday and due Tuesday, but ZERO TA's had Office Hours on Mondays, so I had to completely rely on the hour after class to get help. The final is also super scary and some questions were insane. I got an A by working day and night on Ochem and going to Office Hours almost everyday.

rena hayashi changed the whole grading scale and coursework for this lab class. instead of simply scanning in your observations and answering a few questions for the postlab, you are now required to write full on lab reports. you slowly work up to writing a complete report by the end of the quarter but tbh every report of mine was over 5 pages long. you CANNOT pass this class without going to office hours - manny’s to be specific. manny was a great ta and super helpful in office hours but he is a very true grader, meaning he won’t give you an easy A and goes by the grading scale that was created by hayashi. (took this fall2022)

Yo, this class is some serious business. The exams are actually really simple in concept but you still need to bus' down for that A. Doctor Debus is an absolute G when it comes to asking for help and if you go to the discussions you should be able to pull off that A.

This class is the real deal. The material is confusing and unintuitive and ranges from thermodynamics to quantum chemistry. There will be moments where the notes make absolutely no sense no matter how hard you try to understand them. So getting an A is difficult, but not impossible, so long as you're willing to put more work in than usual. The curves are generous, and Dr. Debus gives homework that is (mostly) representative of his exams barring any conceptual questions, and those are generally straight forward. 8/10

Ok, this class is easy to understand, hard to master. You can score 100% on the exama if you do ALL evens on the back of the chapters. Kawai Tam uses chapter problems as the problems in her midterms/finals, so always do them as extra apart from assigned wileyplus hw, you can get an easy A this way while the rest of the class who doesnt do this struggles at a 50% midterm score

Don't cram for the final. It won't work. The most important thing you need to learn is how to properly label systems with flowcharts. The actual calculations are of little consequence. If you study regularly, you'll do fine.
Second midterm a lot harder than first.
If you can do dimensional analysis and solve a systems of equations this class is a joke, professor Ivey is very fair and is understanding of a lot during covid.
material was not too difficult, definitely go to class tho, and brush up on math or you'll have a hard time

Class is sometimes needlessly complicated because the prof micromanages everything from student time to ta discussions. do all the homework. If you work well on cheat sheets the exams are *doable* though far too long.

This class was insanely easy (I personally took this class with Professor Jingsong Zhang). Quite a bit of homework was due, but it is very manageable. All equations are given for each exam, and honestly it just comes down to whether or not you know the units for each of the variables or not. 10/10 would recommend. Very cool. Averages on exam were around 50-60%, but if you know the variables and have a general idea of what is going on (as you should) getting an A is VERY possible (especially since most upper division classes are curved based on their averages/standard deviations).

Majority of your grade is based off of the labs. Lab reports weren't too bad but definitely go to the TAs' office hours if you're having trouble. No midterm. You have to do a poster presentation on one of the labs (randomly assigned), not too serious though. Final based on labs, simple data analysis.

(Distance Learning) Very little new content, but the labs and reports are long. Different TAs graded each report so the grading was a little inconsistent. Follow the guidelines they give for the report format and you'll do fine. Practice good time management. Final exam was multiple choice and open note/open book. Profs were helpful and nice.

A lot of information, but you're allowed to have cheat sheets on the midterms and final (1 for midterm, 3 for final). The actual content isn't that hard to understand. Labs aren't too bad in terms of difficulty, but expect to type up 3-5 pages for lab reports. Will also be using excel a lot for making calibration curves and tabulating data.
Beginning of the class was easy but gets tougher once you get to symmetry. Really important to understand symmetry as it relates to all material in the course after the easy stuff.

Absurdly easy until the final project which they give you terrible instructions on. Whatever you do, DO NOT BUY THE TEXTBOOK! In fact, you shouldn't get it in any form, as all of the ideas in it appear in a much better structure in What I Wish I Knew When I Was 20 by Tina Seeling.
winter 2021: completely depends on how comfortable you already are with mandarin tbh & your previous background with it. fun class
Professor Shih is super kind. Lots of memorization as that is what Chinese is. Decently easy A unless mandarin is not your first language.

winter 2021: v much a breadth course. couple excerpts to read or watch each week but the subject matter is SUUUPER interesting and opened my eyes to a side of Chinese history I never otherwise would've known about

Taken with Hsu Shu-Liang for this class and the subsequent 2 (101B and 101C). Great professor that really gets you dialed in on learning Chinese. There are almost daily quizzes for vocab but are really easy. Be prepared for a lot of homework though, but honestly it really helps if you want to retain what you learned. Practice really does make perfect in language classes. There is a midterm, a final oral presentation, and a cumulative final. Attendance is definitely mandatory and the class size is usually under 10 people and the same people for A,B, and C usually. Fun class if you're serious about learning Chinese!

Do the reading, and do it before class (as instructed). It doesn't matter if you don't understand what's going on, at least you won't be hearing about it for the first time in class, and you can ask better questions in class. Generally the class doesn't have a lot of people and doesn't have a discussion.

These entire Classics 10 sequence is usually taught by Raschke. She might seem a bit intimidating at first, but don't let her scare you, she's actually awesome and super passionate about what she teaches. As long as you go to class and actually pay attention (seriously, listening to what she says and emphasizes is the main way to make sure you are prepared for her exams) and take good notes, you'll be just fine.
Had Christopher Simon and there were boring lectures but he's a great person, consists of 3 quizzes, 2 mini papers, and a final. Also go to lectures because that's how he takes attendance.

These entire Classics 10 sequence is usually taught by Raschke. She might seem a bit intimidating at first, but don't let her scare you, she's actually awesome and super passionate about what she teaches. As long as you go to class and actually pay attention (seriously, listening to what she says and emphasizes is the main way to make sure you are prepared for her exams) and take good notes, you'll be just fine.

take it with Christopher Simon! wonderful person, great lecturer, gives you study guides for the tests. tests are pretty easy as long as you stay on top of the reading (there isn’t much) and come to lecture. he does take attendance with an app, but his class is fascinating and I’d really recommend showing up!

Prof Colbourn - just for my quarter(Winter21). I didn't even need to do anything. He made slides, explained everything, gave out the question bank which he'd use for the midterm and the final. Without him, can be pretty boring. Just ask anyone who took this class in Winter21 for the notes and you'll be all good.
Took with Colburn (only taught for one quarter in Winter 2021), but it was pretty chill - just take notes and use the study guides provided and you'll do fine. Two essays, one midterm, and one final.

if you know nothing about greek mythology, do not take! the professor chris is super nice but if you do not know anything you will not do well. the class is interesting and the midterms are multiple choice but i was so bummed because i thought this would n fun to learn about. ended up dropping week 8

These entire Classics 10 sequence is usually taught by Raschke. She might seem a bit intimidating at first, but don't let her scare you, she's actually awesome and super passionate about what she teaches.
