Labs can be tough but not as bad as some other classes. Mostly effort based. One project at the end of the class, not too bad, implementing some sql and stuff with user input and a java wrapper. 4 homeworks from the book. Not the easiest upper div but definitely not the hardest.

Chinya Ravishankar, remember that name. That's the professor, he is terrible. One of the worst professors you'll ever have in your life. This guy has daddy issues. In class, majority of his discussion is about how smart he is and how dumb we are. The finals are stupid hard. He doesn't give any instruction or outline on what to focus on. I understand how that's okay but this class has a lot of information, it seems fair to help us a bit. The midterm average was a D and final average was an F. Professor doesn't curve.
Vasilis Tsotras cannot fucking teach

This class in itself is hard, but in my opinion manageable. The lecture from Vassilis J. Tsotras is quite boring but I suggest that you attend anyway because it is important to your midterms and finals. The lab and project, however, sucked so much! It's like they did not put in ANY effort whatsoever into designing the lab and projects! Pretty much all of their scripts provided fail out of box and you have to spend extra time for some really unnecessary debugging, such a waste of time!
Update Fall 2022: Vasilis Tsotras still cannot fucking teach.

The class went to hell as soon as the TAs went on strike and that was when we were working on the final part of our projects. There was no help at all, and it was just chaotic and stressful. Garbage graders and TAs that were clueless during labs. Vasilis Tsotras lectures aren't even worth attending besides one time when he asked a personal irrelevant fucking question on one of the quizzes and didn't make it extra credit, nor made it any easier to answer.

CS166 was not hard conceptually, but what made this class hard was the professor being an awful lecturer, but the overwhelming amount of work. Final project plus weekly labs as well as homework every two weeks and quizzes corresponding to those quizzes. It’s an overwhelming amount of work.

Ahmed Eldawy is an excellent professor, one of the best CS professors I've personally had at this university. This was a unique class in the sense that we had 3 midterms but no final, and labs were heavily emphasized as well. Not too hard but difficulty varied throughout the quarter, some labs were just a pain to get through while others were done in an hour. An eye-opening class into the world of Big Data and you learn a lot, we probably learned like five or six different programming languages. Some of the concepts will overlap with other classes like SQL.

Take this class with Eldawy. The labs are very annoying and tedious so be ready to go to the TAs office hours. The exams are alright, I didn't do too well on them so I relied on labs, final project, hws, etc to bring me to a B.

Took this class with Professor Eldawy in Winter 2023. The class was not too hard. Sometimes the labs took a really long time to finish but that was mostly due to issues that I had when I had to set up a lab. Other than that, the labs were relatively easy especially if you ask the TA for help when you need it. Although I recommend doing the labs the moment they are released in case you run into any issues during the week (especially when we were only given less than a week to complete it). The exams were not hard but still have to study for it of course. Overall, not too hard to get an A if you put in the time and effort.

Took with Eldway in Winter 2022, it was a chill class, midterms were REALLY fair, no final, 3 midterms, and final project. Attend class to pass, he does in class assignments that are close to midterms and how he'll ask the questions! Only downside was final project, it was a pain and my senioritis kicked in, but got it done! overall not a bad tech elective to take

Took with Sheldon Tan in Winter 2020. Not too bad. The homework and tests were mostly just evaluating logic statements, interpreting transistor-level circuits, or some sizing calculations which comes down to plug and chug. Labs were as easy as following the instructions exactly as they're written, it just got annoying having to correct literally 1000 errors. It isn't hard to correct, it's just tedious since you're making sure you don't let two transistors get too close in a circuit 1000 times.

Labs are very very very tedious. The lectures are really hard to follow. If you aren't a CEN/EE, leave while you still can. If you haven't taken EE100A yet, make sure to do that before taking this course. It's doable without, but it's definitely easier if you have that background (still very hard anyway).

As long as it’s taught by Eamonn Keogh you’ll have a great time. Super cool professor with an Irish accent who really loves Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. He makes the material pretty simple, the exams pretty straight-forward, and always plays really cool music videos before class starts. He assigns 2 projects with an arseload of time to complete them.

This is the class that doesn't exist. A CS upper div that doesn't completely kill you. It's not easy per say, but a lot easier than some of the options out there. W/ Eamonn. 2 projects, written in whatever language you desire. No discussion. Tests - 1 midterm 1 final. They were during class hours, multiple choice. Some quizzes, but he'll give you notice of them beforehand so not too bad. All in all an interesting class. Easier than most of the other upper div cs ones so keep an eye out.

Take it with Eamonn Keogh if you can. Midterm and final were completely MC and he assigned two project with a lot of time to do them. There was one HW assignment as well as a couple quizzes. No discussions either. The tests might be relatively difficult, but overall the class isn't very demanding and shouldn't take up much of your time compared to other CS upper divs.

Took it with Dr Keogh, and this class was very simple and fair. The two projects were as easy as Dr Keogh suggests. That doesn't mean you should not start it early. The reports are what takes your time. The exams are multiple choice and very fair. He gives out some quizzes, which have been known to have questions that show up on the final.
Lovely professor. 2 relatively easy projects. Infrequent quizzes that he gives you ample notice of. Exams and quizzes worth small portions of grade and are straight from lecture
Class was easy with professor Keogh, two projects , final, midterm, one homework assignment overall super easy

Took it with Niloofar Montazeri even though everyone said to avoid her. Her lectures are hard to understand.. There is no curve. Exams easier than expected. Theres two big coding projects that your grade relies on that she grades very generously. The first project had an average score of 105% lol

When you read the title of the class you probably think "Sweet Machine Learning, this is going to be awesome" but it's a trap! TBH this class should have several pre reqs that are really needed in order to succeed. You need to def have Calc3/Physics > above level math skills. You really need to take Statistics before this class. Lastly you need to at least be an intermediate Python user. You will be doing proofs and if you're proof is wrong there is no way to complete a HW assignment. You need to be familiar with Python or be confused with how to do the HW. The lectures are terrible. It's just the prof reading his slides which are 80% just unlabeled graphs. The slides provided have no context so you have to come to class to understand them but even if you do no one knows what the prof is talking about and are too afraid to ask for clarification, everyone literally admitted this during a talk in the discussion. The exams don't really test you on topics the prof taught but rather you're general knowledge of the algorithms basically he expects you to know the ins and outs of the algorithms even if he didn't directly tell you about them. If you really want to take a Machine Learning course just watch Andrew NG's youtube videos, you'll learn more, not be stressed out, and you'll actually have fun. If you still want to take the course I hope you're a math god that studies every night.

This is probably one of the hardest CS technical electives I have ever taken. I took it with Christian Shelton who is probably one of the best and smartest professors in CS. He's very passionate and interesting to listen to and he teaches the material in a way that keeps you interested. But, ML is inherently a very difficult field to understand, so there's only so much he can do. There are 4 homeworks(he calls them Problem Sets), two midterms and 1 final. Homeworks count for 33%, midterms count for 33% and the final counts for the last 33% of the course grade. Homeworks are done in Python on JupyterHub where he usually gives you a little bit of skeleton code.
Do not be like me and think that ML is some Computer Science magic that makes you an oracle who can predict the future. Because it's not CS. It's linear algebra and statistics except we program it so they call it a CS class. But conceptually, this is almost purely statistics/linear algebra.

Professor Shelton is definitely smart and capable to teaching lots of difficult concepts, but this class seems inherently difficult. I'm an ex-math major, and even I found the math to be a bit hard to wrap my head around at times. In this class, you learn the theory of many classic ML algorithms, and then you are expected to implement them. Overall, I think that this course requires more time for what is covered.

It's honestly not too bad. I think the first couple of lectures definitely scare off a lot of people because of how much math there is, but it's honestly not as difficult people say it is. Definitely recommend taking it with a friend though, since it'll make understanding material a little easier if you have someone to talk it out with. Highly recommend going to office hours too because Shelton does talk a little fast. Overall learned a lot and didn't really "struggle" that much compared to what other people are saying, would definitely take it again.
It hurt so fucking much.

Most painful and rewarding class I've ever taken in my entire life. Everyone was numb and scared in the end including the big brains that always sit in the front. Take with Shelton if you really want a challenge.

The class lectures are super important, so going to class is necessary to pass. The slides Dr Shelton uses don't have much information on them, so you need to go to class or office hours to understand the material and examples well. You will need to study the slides well, because the exams are difficult if you didn't understand a topic went over. The final exam was the hardest. The homework sets we're difficult, unless you started them early enough to ask questions properly.

I thought this would be an awesome chance to continue learning about ML stuff because it's always stood out as something interesting to me. Oh my fucking god this one class actually just made me so sad, you really need to have a solid understanding of lin alg going into the class or you're already screwed. Taking this probably hurt my chances at grad school a bit too.
I think the CS department should rework the prereqs for this course because it's anemic and setting some bright-eyed students up to fail. To do well, you absolutely have to be passionate about the topic and theory. Having the mindset of "oh ML sounds cool, I should take it," is imho, not enough for you to succeed. You gotta know that this is what you want to do and be ready to commit your soul and final 2 brain cells to this course, I recommend taking easier breadth courses in the same quarter as this class to relieve pressure, don't double up with other major req'd courses or tech electives, you're absolutely going to regret it and be depressed and in pain while regretting it.
what the fuck

Fun course topic, but incredibly challenging. By far the hardest course I've taken in all of my 4 years at UCR. There are no easy or "free" points in this class. Every question on every problem set, midterm, and final are very involved and a minor mistake can lead to only getting half/partial credit. You'll need to be very comfortable with Python by week 2 or you will not be able to keep up with the assignments even if you have a solid understanding of statistics and math. I thought I was comfortable with the prereqs, and still ended with a C-. (Shelton)

iEvals are out for Spring 2021 so I figured I'd update here too. Asif lectured this quarter my perception is that he's slightly easier than Shelton but you still learn a lot. The class is super hard, but also very interesting and rewarding if you like the topic

Took this class with Professor Salman Asif. His exams aren't that bad, but his homework assignments are absolutely brutal. The TA isn't very helpful (at least for this quarter), and if you don't take this class with a friend it's very hard to get by. You need a combination of Linear Algebra, Multivariable Calculus, and Statistics to get by in this class (like a very solid understanding). It's definitely more of a math class than a CS class. I think Professor Asif is a passionate professor and really tries to help anyone as long as they ask for help.

Taken with Christian Shelton in Spring 2023. Honestly, the midterms kicked my butt but if you start the homework relatively early and attend office hours, you'll be fine grade-wise. Studying the practice problems was not enough for me, but it's difficult to study the concepts even more than what's provided with the slides and example problems. I recommend finishing PS2 (homework 2) before the first midterm or at least looking over logistic regression as that was a big component on the first midterm, but the due date for PS2 was after the midterm, so I missed basically two questions on the midterm. Points are very scarce in this class, so try to maximize all the points you can with homework and answer everything in the midterm to try to get partial credit. The curve at the end of Spring 2023 was actually about 10%, so you can expect something around a whole letter grade curve at the end of the class. Good luck, and make sure to just study the slides/problem sets. The problem sets are okay if you go to office hours and reference the professor's personal notes. Overall a rewarding class, but definitely one of the harder tech electives.

I've taken the class with Professor Mariam Salloum, and she's honestly so great. Her lecture slides are super clear and straight to the point. She's super helpful and always answers the questions to the best of her ability. Discussions were actually pretty helpful. Assignments(2 in the quarter) were super easy and actually pretty fun to program. She does keep track of attendance and gives quizzes, so be sure to keep up with the material. There's 2 midterms and no final, but she assigns a project instead to make up for it. Overall, Information Retrieval is a super interesting class where the information and assignments are doable. Also curved my grade to from a B+ to A- even though I was 0.7% from a 90%.

Took this with Dr Salloum. The slides for the class have too much information on them, so it's hard to tell what to study for the exams. Dr Salloum gives out study sheets, which tell you what to study and they are useful. The homeworks can be difficult if not started early. The final project is done in either python or Java. It can be easy if your group partners are good.

I had Vagelis Hristidis (Spring 2022). I choose this class to satisfy the computer networks requirement for CSBA and tbh its not that bad of a class, its just that Vagelis is not the best at lecturing and explaining the concepts. The midterms weren't too bad, but those true/false questions stumped a lot of us for sure, mostly due to how poorly worded they were. Also for the projects make sure you get into a group with people you can trust to finish on time and know python/java. Theres also a huge curve at the end went from a C to a B+

Get a good group. The entire class is just one huge group business project with CS and if your group sucks well...
 This class has an amazing professor though who loves participation so definitely participate in class and he gives really cool life lessons. He keeps saying not to worry about grades so we’ll see how the quester goes (Spring 2020, online)

Not too bad. Faloutsos is a great professor, and it's more fun if you participate (but it's also an 8am class). Attendance, reading, and participation are self-reported. Most of the grade hinges on your final investor pitch, but you should be totally fine if you just do the assignments earnestly and have a small demo product (doesn't need to be complex).

One of my favorite classes! Faloutsos is S tier, and you will learn a lot. It's a great class if you're considering to make a startup. Try to come in with a team of people you trust though, since the whole class is basically a group project where you make a startup.

The class is just one big project with 4 phases. If you're a pro at Java and CS152, then this might be easier for you. The CS179 courses are pretty hard overall, so you really need to choose the focus you understood the best...unfortunately not all senior projects are available in a quarter.

Took the class during summer 2022 and the class wasn't as bad as I thought it would be but I recommend starting the projects as early as possible. Setting it up was a hassle and would recommend using IntelliJ than VSCode as its easier to debug there than the latter. The ta was very helpful as he helped my group understand the concept and answered our questions. Also for this quarter the ta asked the professor change his gradings where your grades are determined by the amount of testers you passed but it also includes the effort or amount of code you done (meaning the code would work but just have a bug) though I'm not sure if the system is being kept for the next class. Overall not too bad class, and depending how good of a java coder and how much you know of compilers from cs152 would determine the amount of time you would work on the projects. START EARLY!!

Take this class with Heng Yin. Yes it’s operating systems and it sucks but the class was easy. Choose one of his listed projects, find it somewhere online as someone’s hw assignment and list that as the source and work on your project. He has check-ins here and there but wasn’t too strict. Ended with an A+ and honestly we didn’t even work till the last week and kept showing random code during the check-ins. Report heavy so make that look good and you’ll be fine.

5 Lab assignments with grading scripts. No demo. If you know what you're doing, it will be easy. If you don't know what you're doing, some Chinese guy on the internet did know what they were doing and posted the solutions online.

Took with Chengyu Song. It's basically an extension of CS153 labs. You have 5 labs that are taken from MIT's 6.828 (Utilities, Allocator, Copy on-write, File system, and mmap). Each lab is worth 20% of your final grade. You will also have to turn in a lab report with each lab. There is a lecture once a week and a discussion once a week. Attendance not mandatory. I ended up with an A, so I didn't think this class was that bad, but others might think otherwise, since some of the labs towards the end are pretty time consuming/confusing.

Took with Mariam Salloum. Plan, design, then build a project involving a database. Weekly status reports are straightforward and fairly quick. One ethics essay in the middle of the quarter. A few presentations to the class. Course is not meant to be difficult. The difficulty really depends on how ambitious of a project you choose and how well your team works together. Enjoyable class overall

Took it with Najjar. I was pretty scared going into this course because I hated CS120B but it wasn't bad at all. You have a lot of leeway with what you want to do for your project. Our arudino setup was super simple and the majority of our project was just code. He's a pretty relaxed professor who just want to see you enthusiastic about your project.

I took this class with Professor Keogh. This class barely had any AI at all and was basically an extension and more complex version of the 8-puzzle project from CS170. It had some business-like elements to this class such as preparing questions to ask the customer (who is the professor) and presenting a project pitch to the customer. I feel like a bit too much time was spent towards this business part of class. The last few weeks you just work on coding your project with your team. We did not have too many class meetings during the last few weeks since we were mostly coding on our own. The professor often had office hours to help with anything. Our project was missing a couple features and had a couple bugs but we still managed to get an A. I would say the GUI part of the project was a pain if you lack experience so make sure to start on that early. Overall, I wish this class delved more into AI. This was not an entirely easy class but you can get an A if you put in the effort and time into it.

Eamonn Keogh runs this senior project class every once in a while. GRAB IT IF YOU CAN, realistically the class is mainly about working together and prepping a business pitch rather than coding. Coding is prob like 15/100 of the credit you get for finishing the quarter long project. SUPER CHILL, loved it!
super easy. Student presentations and a final project. Meets once per week for one hour and one lab. Just build a game or something. Had Tamar but I don't think that really matters.
All you have to do is make a game in a group of 4 to 5 people. As long as you show good progress in each demo and make sure your scrum sheet's in order, you should be totally fine. Easy A

Super fun class. Make sure you have a group of 4 other people that you trust! It's basically a requirement that you have experience with a game engine like Unity or Unreal. It's a great opportunity to put something on your resume and make something you're passionate about!

The whole class is esentially to build something. Anything really, but they give you a list of things at the beginning and you present a thing at the end. Most of the class does like android applications or websites/stuff like that. Make sure you have a solid team. There is no midterm, the final is ok, fair since he tells you what to study for. Took w Zhijia Zhao.
This class is really dumb. Study up on some front-end tech like react or angular, or hope someone carries you.

Took it with Manu Sridharan. The midterm and final were pretty straightforward as long as you review the slides. Coding is only done when dealing with the class project which is like 50 pts out of 100 total points so pretty important.

I gave this class a low difficulty rating but really it depends on how comfortable you are to the technology you will use and your team mates.

First thing is first. This is a group project class. If you don't already plan to take this class with people you know you may already have an increased difficulty. Overall the class is basically "make anything" and present it at the end of the class. The lectures are basically a repeat of what you've learned from other classes like CS 100. Basically it focuses on Agile Development for a majority of the time. 

The class tends to push you in the direction of make a web application but really they tell you you can make anything with any tech you want but because you have team mates they will more than likely make you pick a web application as well. The first lab is in React.js so you'll more than likely choose that to work with. 

For those who don't know anything about web dev stuff make sure to get a team that does because tbh it's to late to learn a lot of this stuff. Web dev consists of HTML, CSS, JS/React, and some back end Server stuff. There is no way you'll learn all of this in this semester. You either already know some of this or you'll just be a drag to you're team mates. I suggest learning as much as you can before taking the course. Try the site Codecademy. They have HTML,CSS, and React lectures for free.

I rated this class a 6 because I already knew HTML,CSS and had a very rough understanding of React. I definitely grew in terms of React knowledge but did have team mates intimidated that they didn't know what was going on.
Make sure you match up with people you can trust in the project!

I took this with Professor Manu and found this class pretty easy going since I was familiar with web dev. We had quizzes and homework, no final, just a final presentation. The quizzes and homework are stuff from the slides, but quizzes were in person so it was all from memory. The final project which spanned 7 weeks which was just taking CSV data reading it and creating a backend off it without using a database. Then making a frontend to display that data through API calls to the backend. If you are unfamiliar with React, HTML/CSS, Django or Express, JavaScript, Python, then you should probably study up on some these before taking this class. Otherwise be willing to learn your part of the project so you don't drag your teammates down. Doing well on the quizzes and homework really determines whether you get an A or not. If you don't do well you'll most likely end up with a high B. Hard to fail this class, but hard to get an A as well. Professor Manu is really cool and relatable though!

Hardest class you will ever take in your entire life. Only take it if you are 100% into Computer Science, otherwise if you're a normie like majority of CS students, you will for sure fail or get a really low score in the class. 
Shelton is great professor, but this class really hits hard with the assignments. Problem Sets (4% of your grade, given 5 times in the quarter) are doable, but if you aren't a great programmer, you will not be able to get by since the Programming Assignments are 8% of your grade and there are 4 of them in the entire quarter. Exams are honestly not too bad if you are paying attention in class.

Took with Shelton. He is a great lecturer and professor with a clear passion for teaching. However, he likes to challenge students in programming assignments. Tests are easier as long as you make sure to study the topics well (the textbook is helpful when studying for tests). 

There was homework due every week, alternating between "problem sets" (standard question&answer homework; there's 5 of these) and "programming assignments" (4 of these). No programming questions on the tests, just knowledge based questions on different aspects of programming languages (note this may include writing snippets of code as examples of whatever the question is asking about). 

Overall, I found the class to be on the difficult side, mostly due to the programming assignments. I am still glad to have taken it however, as I do feel I learned a lot. Also there seemed to be a curve applied to our grades at the end of the quarter, even though Shelton is reluctant to admit that his classes are curved (for our class it seemed to be 7-8%, ymmv).

Took with Manu Sridharan. He's a good professor, but the class's difficulty mainly comes from which open-source project you pick. A gamble, really. You can team up or do it on your own. The goal of the project is to get you familiar with testing and generating code coverage. The project isn't exactly graded on how correctly you test, but rather if you can successfully test and use your testing tools (i.e. JaCoCo for Java). You document all your testing in a final project report at the end of the quarter.

Lecture/Discussion uses Java and Gradle, so you may have to do some research if your project uses different tools. When picking a project, try to pick one that has good documentation and already has tests - saves you a lot of time. If you pick a big project, you can opt to test only a module of the project instead of the entire thing. A great way to find projects is the CodeTriage website.

No midterm/final - just a couple of quizzes that cover concepts from the slides + homework.

I hated this class. Jason Ott normally does it. It's basically IT class. It seems pretty easy but my lack of enthusiasm (especially in the beginning) made things harder. I didn't know "Systems Administration" meant IT, and when I did, it was too late to drop it. His lecture slides aren't that great. You're better off showing up to lecture and taking good notes. The slides won't help all that much when it comes to studying for an exam. He's not terrible at teaching it though.
take it with Jason Ott, good teacher and easy class

Took with Abdoli. It's an overview of managing/maintaining a UNIX server and it's a pretty nice class. It gives you some good breathing room for your other classes as a CS major, so keep that in mind. Labs are done on a CentOS vm and they're pretty straightforward. Sometimes you'll have to script in Perl/Bash/Python. You'll be told which slides to study for the midterm/final, although the final is cumulative.
Took with Alireza Abdoli. This guy is G. TAKE THIS CLASS WITH HIM.

Took this course with Prof. Zhijia Zhao, winter22. This course mainly explains some knowledge about the middle end of LLVM, the course is well structured, Professor Zhao lectures quite well, there are 5 assignments and 3 projects, homework questions and midterm and final questions are very similar, project may take some time for the first exposure, once you understand, the project can be said to be very straightforward, and at the same time can help you deepen your understanding of the course content. If you want to take this class, I recommend it.

Had Gupta in Fall 2022. A lot of the course material isn't too difficult to grasp, but because there aren't a lot of examples, it can be hard to solve problems on the exams. I recommend making your own examples, and going to him for OH about them. There isn't a ton of resources on the material online (as is for most CS grad classes), so this can really hurt you when you may not understand edge cases and whatnot for a problem. Besides that, the project can be very overwhelming, so start learning how to work with LLVM and Clang at the beginning of the quarter. Basically, these allow you to parse a cpp file, and perform analysis on it. There isn't a lot of beginner-friendly documentation on this either, so you ought to get started as soon as you can.
Fall 2022, Prof. Hyoseung Kim, Lots of research paper critiques, Lots of lab assignments

As a CS student, I had to take 2 out of 3 core courses and I chose Operating Systems as I enjoyed it as an undergraduate. While this course has commonalities with my previous course, it was more rigorous and I had to spend significant time on my labs. There are multiple graded components in this course: Examinations, Paper reviews, Labs. It is important to choose good team members as finishing the labs along with your coursework can get very hectic. The examinations are straightforward and the professor clearly explains what questions are going to come in the examinations. The critiques can be demanding. I think that this was an easily-scoring core course than its counterparts. Some nuggets of advice from my end are: a) Manage your time efficiently as the quarter system gets over quickly and the labs/critique reviews require sufficient time and effort. b) If you are struggling with the course, talk to the TAs, they are very helpful :). c) I really liked Udacity's OS courses that acts a good review for similar topics. Neso Academy's OS Playlist is also good if you have doubts.
Labs are relatively easy. Go to class and you will be fine.
Midterm, project, and Final are crazy hard.

Take this class with Prof Daniel Wong if you can, even if you're CS trash like me and have no interest in computer architecture. You learn a lot and it's bizarrely not that stressful. 3 coding assignments that he sets up to be extremely simple to jump right into and reinforce the concepts taught during lecture; it's the kind of coding/problem-solving that's challenging and satisfying. The final project is harder and less structured but he's super helpful. Midterm and final were really straightforward as long as you did the assignments and study the sample(s) he provides. Prof Wong is the best and just wants everyone to learn and succeed. HIGHLY HIGHLY HIGHLY recommended core class. Like you should take this class just because Professor Wong's friendliness and attention to detail is a breath of fresh air

Took this course with Prof. Hung-Wei, Tseng in Fall21. Each week there are some papers that are required to read, and do read them, some will appear in midterm and final. Moreover, there is a project, you will need to do quite a lot of search when working on it. Generally speaking, this course is challenging, but you will learn a lot even if you're not interested (or your main study field) is not computer architecture.

There is weekly reading of up to 3 articles/chapters with reading quizzes. The homework is long and arduous start early or you will suffer. This class is homework and test based now. Be prepared to show up and talk during class.

DO NOT CHEAT and you'll get a good grade easily. Class depends on midterm(30%), 2 projects, reading and 2 paper presentations. Grading is super lenient and Prof. LePendu gives out a lot of bonus points.
Project and exams are crazy hard

Took with Shinar for Fall '22. 80% of this class is linear algebra. 40% of the grade is homework (there were 5 hw assignments but she drops your lowest), and 30% is midterm, 30% final. This class requires a lot of practice, and because there's a lot of material, it's important you organize all of it so you can recall it all.

The description is a bit vague this is an applied linear algebra class. Professor was very fast paced and difficult to follow because of that. Consists of around 8 homework, midterm and final. The tests are very difficult just doing the homework will not be enough know the material well.
Inherently difficult subject. However, professor Amey offered a lot of help and a decent amount of extra credit.

This class is definitely a fun one if you're paying attention! Prof. Wong gives awesome lectures that help out with the assignments and final project. As long as you thoroughly pay attention during the lectures, this class will be enjoyable. If you give it your best effort, you will have a good time! Also, this class focuses on how GPU's can be used for their parallelism capabilities rather than anything related to computer graphics (although the topic does come up once in a while).

Prof Lonardi is the best for this course and is a very good grader. The subject itself is difficult but with enough effort, you'll ace the class. Do the homeworks yourself and exams will be a breeze. Finals carry a lot of weight(50%)
5 coding assignments, midterm and a project with poster presentation. Prof. Eldawy is amazing and a very good grader!

Shelton is awesome, but holy hell this class is hard. I took it before 224 was an option and I was excited to take this class to find out if ML is for me... it most certainly is not. It's all math, most of which went over my head. The saving grace is that fat curve; you can expect a B as long as you put in honest effort. During the low moments when this class had me questioning my life choices, it was genuinely really comforting to know that I could expect to pass. You're gonna get your ass kicked by that brutal 3 hour final.

Took with Papalexakis. He's an awesome professor, and gets you thinking more like a researcher. 60% of your grade is a project that you need to present as a research report. The other 40% consists of quizzes (reading research papers), the midterm, and the final. It's a great experience, but start learning Python early if you don't know it yet. Specifically when it comes to using sci-kit and implementing a clustering/classification algorithm.

Took it with Papalexakis. All multiple choice quizzes and exams, and a project that was worth 60% of your grade. You work with 5 other people and implement 6 different machine learning models. I think overall the class wasn't that bad, just the organization of the project was all over the place. Regardless, there was a hefty curve at the end and the class was very interesting.
Entire class grade is based on a project, midterm, and final. Pretty easy if you can stay awake during lecture.
This class isn't to hard the lecture can be very boring, the tests are multiple choice and there is a project.
Course entirely based on project(100%). Prof Faloutsos is very cool and grades well if you do a good job on the project! Equal contribution from team members is crucial.
The grade depends on quizzes, project, 1 assignment and a midterm(40%). Grading is super easy and the subject is a sure-shot A. Plus, Prof. Hristidis is amazing!
Great course.Very good class, only midterms and two projects, weekly quiz, but also very easy. The only point to notice might be to find a good team to do the project.

One of the worst grad classes I've taken. I often refer to this class as a catfish class because the title is very misleading to a lot of students. It's called Real-time Embedded Systems, but you won't be working with bread boards or anything. In fact, you won't really be working with embedded systems at all. Most of the class focuses on the "Real-time" part of the title. So actually, most of what you'll be learning relates to operating systems and considerations for these systems (communication, power, etc.). The material itself isn't extremely tough, but the lack of guidance on the labs will throw you for a loop. Overall, one of my least favorite CS classes I've taken at UCR.

The lectures are a bit hard to understand what is happening. The project was a bit tricky due to concurrency needed and trouble debugging that. The tests are free formed so be prepared to info dump so be sure to keep up and study. Professor Ravishankar is very knowledge in the area
Super easy. Just show up and dance. Three essays. Super simple.

Easy. Luck of the draw in terms of who's teaching but it's mainly just dancing and maybe some outside "projects." One mandatory essay (minimum) across the classes and you must bring someone to watch for your final.

I rated it as difficult because I ended up taking it with the TA Jennifer Wong. If you end up with her, please do not take the class; you’ll be taking contact improvisation, a very uncomfortable class. Example: we were told to lie down while our partners have us massages. I ended up feeling violated, seriously. Jennifer was nice, but naive at times about how uncomfortable people were. Don’t tell people to lie down for massages, Jen. Not everyone wants a full body massage. Anyways, contact improvisation is a very touchy class . So, if you’re the type of person who wouldn’t mind giving someone a full body massage, take it. If you’d feel weird and grossed out about it and wouldn’t want someone you may barely know, DO NOT take it. Don’t make the same mistake that I did!!!
Took the Filipino Countryside Folk Dancing class; a little bit difficult if you’re a beginner but it’s easy to get an A by the end of the quarter. Jim’s harsh but means well.

Entirely depends on the TA that you get! Each TA specializes in a different field of dance so there were hip hop classes, west African, Filipino Folk dancing, etc. Some people got marked off for lack of effort/ participation so just be engaged in class.

I had it with Dava Hernandez for Mexican Folklorico and its pretty easy. She's super nice, understanding, and flexible. You just show up to Zoom and dance/participate. There's some readings, discussion posts, and papers but its not too bad. I looked forward to this class cause it got me out of my chair and moving.
Highly recommend taking during online classes, all we did was discuss dance videos and do a one second a day midterm and random dance video for our final.
Super Easy, we only had to show up once a week to class and keep a journal, that was it lol

I had Manny and our focus was modern dance. it was really chill and easy. the first half of class theres some dancing (easy exercises and moving around) and the second half was the lecture (all slides were online). the midterm was a combo of multiple choice q's, short answer, and an essay based on a dance performance you have to go to. it sounds like a lot but its rly not. final is a 2 min group dance performance that you choreograph together and a few paragraphs about the process

Very fun and easy class if you wanna fulfill your breadth requirements! The class was online for me unfortunately, but I had a lot of fun anyways. I had Yeji Moon (TA) as my instructor and our genre of focus was K-Pop which made it even easier for me since I already listened to the genre on the daily and have a background in dance. 2 dance video projects, 1 essay, and weekly discussion posts you have to participate in. As long as you try on the assignments you’ll be fine, and you don’t really need a background in dance to do well. Don’t forget to participate on the weekly discussion posts because it’s very easy to forget, and some easy points to lose if you don’t do them. Attendance isn’t mandatory for the class, but you should go to the sessions where you have to learn your dance piece to see what is expected of you regarding your dance video projects. Overall great class that doesn’t require too much effort!
I got Al as my instructor and she's great. This class is overall really chill and fun but you definitely will need to put in efforts for this class and pay attention.

Just show up to class and do the dance journals (only 250 words) and it's an easy A. I had Johnny Castro for hiphop and I'm actually kind of sad it's over. It was a fun class in the midst of all the STEM classes.

IF YOU GET FABIOLA TORRALBA DROP IMMEDIATELY and choose another section with another TA. She makes the class more philosophical than it should be. We spend a maximum of 3 hours out of the 30 hours of attending class to learn any sort of choreography, the rest of the time its just her talking about her life or walking around the room for a good 2 hours. The class should not have been as difficult as it is. There are many long assignments that she assigns, none of them relating to dance at all. She kind of picks and chooses how many points she wants to give out to certain students as well.
took with yeji moon about kpop and really loved it! pretty simple dance class. make sure you end up with a group you like working with, though!

Professor Reynoso is extremely passionate about the topic which is great, but sometimes he expects you to know as much as he does. During his lectures, he presents slides with A LOT of important information, but it is kind of messy and hard to read. he also mumbles a lot so its sometimes hard to understand what he is saying and he really dislikes it when people use their phones so don't expect to be able to use your phone or any electronics at all. he assigns readings but he goes over them in class, but sometimes he makes you discuss with you neighbor. There is 1 midterm, 1 paper, and 1 final.
Taken Fall 2022 with Shea Murphy; lotsss of writing (essays, ejournals, discussion responses, etc.) and it's very time-consuming. The content was interesting though and it's manageable.

Lots of essays so just be sure to pace yourself. Its nice that you can write about what you like so long as you meet the requirements. There is a required workshop that takes place every other week I believe. The class tutor didn't help me at all so I would definitely recommend going to ARC if you need a tutor/someone to help you with the essays.

took with anthea kraut. i took it online wint quarter of 2021. so easy sll you had to do was write and be super descriptive of dance moves. you write a big paper at the end but you work on it throughout the whole quarter and u focus on one dance sequence of your choice.
Intro to latin dance. Easy A. Just show up and dance. Very enjoyable even if you never dance before
Pretty basic intro to econ class. Had a good TA so discussion was helpful

It's a basic econ course. I took the class with Matt Lang. Lang replaces your quiz scores with your midterm if you do better and adds more weight to you final if you do better on it than your midterm. He doesn't curve though. If you put actual effort into the class, it should be an easy A. I only studied the day before each exams so I only got an A-.

The class was straightforward. Pay attention in class and you should be fine. Look over the notes every now and then to make sure you understand all of it. Class is exam heavy but can be replaced. Do homework ahead of time and understanding questions makes it easier. TAs helps to clarify material.

If you can, always try to take it with Lang! Doesn't require you to buy a physical textbook (an additional $10 if you want), but does require you to purchase a TopHat subscription (basically an online version of the clickers and it counts toward your grade). Attendance in this class is crucial to your success since everything he talks about is literally on the exam (unless you have the textbook, then you might be set for the class). All of the exams are multiple choice and are very similar to the homework problems. So do your homework problems as practice before the exam! (He gives you unlimited attempts for homework problems as long as you do them before the deadline, so you have no excuse to not get a 100% in that category for the class!) Can't use a graphing calculator in class so be sure to have a scientific calculator for the calculations.

Lang is a really great teacher! go to class, get tophat points and take better and more concise notes after lecture. Do well on both midterms so you dont have to worry about your grade later because he veers of the grading stated on the syllabus. And it kinda gets messy at the end
Matthew Lang does a great job in explaining concepts, and if you pay attention all of his exams are pretty easy. Highly recommend taking this class if he's teaching it.
joab, a bit harder than econ003 but still the same

Lang - get the book, it's 10 bucks with top hat added on, really worth it because he basically covers the lectures from there, so if u miss class the book suffices. Also, the exams are all MCs so less room for error. If u study book thoroughly, hw questions, and tophat qs, should be fine

Had Matt Lang for Econ, and he's a very good professor. Makes the class a fun environment to learn, highly recommend reading his textbook (it's a very easy read) to secure that A. Other than that, if you pay attention in class you will do fine.
Make sure you listen to to the lectures and you will be good to go for the class.

Took it online with Prof Lang. Easy to pass with A if you do the work. One midterm and one cumulative final, all open notes. 4/7 lecture quizzes need to be passed with at least 80%. 4/8 discussion questions need to be done prior to discussion. 3 homework assignments. He also posts his recorded lectures on YouTube. Highly recommended.

Not a very hard class, Joab Corey is an excellent professor, probably one of the best I've had in lower div classes at UCR. Got a 98.25% in the class and it was my least busiest class the whole quarter.

Took it with Prof Joab Corey Fall 2020 pandemic. Prof is readily available to help and the course itself was pretty easy. There were 2 midterms, 1 final, and weekly modules and all of them were pretty easy. There is a lot of opportunity for extra credit.
Took this with Joab. Amazing professor. Very organized. Knows how to explain economics really well. Offers a lot of extra credit and a lot of extra practice and review for tests. Highly recommend!

Professor Lang is super chill and accommodates to the best he can for the pandemic. The class overall was easy, one midterm one final, half of the weekly quizzes and discussion activities were dropped as well. Everything was on tophat and he even negotiated with them to give us a lower price for it.

Took it with Matthew Lang. Material is made easy to understand. The class is made very fun and entertaining. The only manditory work is to complete 5/8 lecture quizzes, 4/8 discussion activities, the midterm(30 multiple choice), and final (50 multiple choice). Take good notes and familiarize yourself with the formulas and you will pass no problem.

Took with Lang during Covid Winter 2021. The class was pretty easy and his lectures were live. You have to buy tophat but it comes with his textbook which is optional to read (but I recommend reading it since he uses questions from the textbook for quizzes sometimes). Midterm and Final are open note and not proctored, and I'd recommend going over the textbook before taking the exams.
Super easy with McLaren, just really boring

Took it 2021 FALL online: You need to study and go to lecture. Matthew lang is nice but there are definitely works you need to do. He might curve the final depend on the performance of the class. This class is cool, recommend for general educationt

Took with Matt Lang Winter 2022. People say he's an amazing professor, and he is great, though I think he's overhyped. It's extremely easy to pass as a lot of quizzes and assignments are dropped. There's also minimal homework as other reviews have said. Personally, I thought his lecture notes were a bit messy and it was hard to know what was considered "important" or what he thought was just "fun facts." I personally wish he would've specified "this is important to know" during his lectures. It also may be easy to pass, but it is difficult to get an A as he doesn't round grades because of his generous grading. Overall an easy class, but final grades/midterms determines a chunk of your score.

Matt Lang is an amazing professor! He is funny and laid-back, and one of the best professors I've had. However, the course material is really difficult to grasp, especially if you're not naturally strong in STEM. I was expecting the course to be an easy A, but the exams were hard and I ended up with a B.
Very easy class if you pay attention and take notes. Joab care's a tremendous amount about his students and puts in a lot of effort to have things run smoothly. 10/10 recommend.
Easy A if you pay attention and study. I did my studying last minute and never went to lecture so I got a C+
Bree Lang is pretty easy. Her homework assignments are almost exactly like her exams.

The class is relatively easy. Pay attention and review every so often to retain material. As long as you complete homework on your own and understand the topics it should be straightforward. The exams were relatively from the material and were not to difficult. If you feel lost, TAs are helpful in getting you back on track. Homework and Test heavy.

Definitely take this with Joab Corey if you can, he keeps every lecture interesting/funny and explains all the topics really really well. Go to all lectures for sure, there's transmitter questions for points during every class + without showing up for notes it'll be almost impossible to pass
Bree Lang is nice, is pretty straightforward. Her exam questions are not. She will trick you into thinking answers. Read everything carefully
Joab was easy, first midterm is just like ECON002 which is easy. after first midterm you kinda have to pay attention one topic is similar to the next

Bree Lang is so nice! Take it with her since you will definitely enjoy the class. However, the grade for the course is weighted extremely heavily on exams so participation and homework barely bumps your grade. Exams are tricky but doable. Discussion sections are optional so you can ditch if u want.

Took it with Professor Bree Lang. She’s super nice, but no curve or extra credit. Has unlimited tries on homework so you can’t get below a 100 and it’s basically a free class; she doesn’t use textbooks or top hat. Understood everything in class but the homework, midterms and finals are really hard because of the wording. She gives you a practice exam before every exam but the practice doesn’t cover everything on the final, so good luck studying with no extra materials. Discussions are optional.

Bree Lang is one of the best teachers ever! she doesn't curve, but she does update grades quite frequently and she makes learning fun. Her tests are similar to the homework's, but still study. Exam 1 is a breeze, exam 2 : study more, and as for your Final: says 50/50, but chapter 8 and 9 are heavily emphasized!!!!!

I like how professor Bree is always enthusiastic in lecture. This is not a hard class if you put in the effort and stay on top of it. However, the exam questions can be tricky and because I haven't really paid attention to this class, I struggled a little. No curves and no extra credits were offered

I took this class with prof Bree Lang. She was a phenomenal professor, with a clear enthusiasm for teaching. The subject matter can be a bit tricky at times, but she's very responsive on explaining things on the class discussion board. Attendance is mandatory in lecture as we have "clicker" questions. Her midterms are pretty straightforward, the best way to study for them is to study the clicker questions, homework, slides, and practice midterms that she posts. I got a 92.75 in the class, which is technically an A-minus, but she curved me up to an A :)

[COVID-19 ERA] Class wasn't too bad before the midterm, really picked up after the midterm. Bree Lang is an amazing, understanding professor and I would definitely recommend her, it was a superb class.

lots of “work” but it’s actually just a few homeworks, lecture quizzes, and easy discussion assignments. These take very little time. the material is easy, Bree Lang is a fantastic teacher. she’s very compassionate. I’m just a little upset my 99 counted as an A and not A+ lmao.
Professor Joab Corey is one of my favorite teachers. As a CHASS student, econ isn't a favorite subject of mine but he has everything asynchronous, super detailed videos, and is great at teaching.

With Professor Joab it's super easy especially during the pandemic. open note tests, 2 mid terms, one final his lectures are so easy to follow i suggest taking notes as you watch and it says three times a week, but everything is recorded and he's super chill and easy to talk to YOU WON'T REGRET IT

I took it with Joab Corey and he is such a great professor! He makes all the concepts easy to understand and is always available to help. There's weekly modules that need to be completed with 2 quizzes, but you can use your notes on all the quizzes. 2 midterms and a final that weren't too bad. He has good grading policies too.

Take with Joab Corey if you can. Its completely asynchronous with some optional review sessions you can go to if you need help. He's very accomodating to his students. I was supposed to take 3 finals in 1 day but he let me push the final back to another day. Module and discussion quizzes are easy enough. Watch a couple lecture videos and you'll be fine.

I took this class during COVID with Professor Joab Corey. You can tell that he's passionate about the material and cares a lot about his students. There were weekly quizzes, but you could use your notes for those. The 2 midterms and the final had questions similar to the quizzes and the practice exams he gave us. As long as you keep up with the lectures and take notes, you will most likely get and A. I also took the honors version of this class (ECON003H), and that just has essays every 2 weeks and a book project at the end. The essays and book project were super easy (i'm pretty sure he gave everyone 100s on them).

I took this class with prof Joab and I can honestly say he was the best Econ teacher I've ever had. He makes the material very easy to understand for it being online and his classes and discussions are asynchronous. Workload consists of weekly quizzes and discussion modules and the exams which are all fairly easy. Definitely recommend taking with him!

I took this class with Bree Lang and she was super kind and connected really well with her students. It was obvious that she really cared about helping us get a good grade. The major assignments in this class was broken into the categories of: Discussion assignments, Lecture quizzes, midterm (only 1), final. For the discussion assignments, if you get 20/40, she considers it full credit while for the lecture quizzes (8 in total), she considers 50/80 full credit. I struggled a bit in this class because you really need to be careful with reading the questions and you need to have good reading comprehension to not make mistakes. I got a D on the midterm but for the final I got a B and eventually passed with a B+ so even if you don't do well on the midterm, just make sure you get full credit of the LQ's and the DS's. Every exam was open notes too.

Coming from a POSC/AS student, Economics is really boring LOL. But Joab Corey makes the class as interesting as he can by putting pop culture references or letting you watch movie clips to better understand the information. Lecture was in person but also asynchronous. I heard no one really went to class in person though. Asynchronous really helped because I was not willing to wake up at 9 for a 10am class LOL. Overall, good teacher, just really boring material that he tries to make up with pop culture jokes LOL. I feel like he actually cares about his students too.
Winter 2022, Take with Joab very understanding professor. Every was on quizlet when it was online.

Took Bree Lang. There are 8 quizzes worth 10 points each (you only need to get 50 points total to get full credit for the quizzes), 4 discussion assignments worth 10 points each(only need 20 points total to get full credit), a midterm, and final. There is also free "good citizen" points - don't disrespect other studends and you get the points. Lecture, slides, and notes are all posted to elearn - attendance during live lecture is not manditory. Bree Lang is very nice but during our class we were always falling behind schedule because she constantly got side tracked and off topic.

By far the easiest class I've ever taken at UCR. Just find two-three friends to take this class with who can help you out, and poof! You get an easy A. Definitely recommended as a breadth course for CS majors.

Joab Corey is a very understanding and kind professor. He makes himself available to students and provides a lot of opportunities for you to succeed. The concepts are not too hard to understand, especially if you have taken macro econ before. Joab designs the class to also be asynchronous if you want to, but I always found it better to attend in-person lectures. Very interesting concepts and ideas and you can learn a lot with effort! Tests and quizes may have multiple attempts and should not be too difficult with all the review materials he provides.

Took this with Joab during COVID, he is an amazing professor! He is truly passionate about the subject and enjoys teaching it which makes lectures interesting and easy to follow. Content is easy to understand and he was very understanding of the online environment. Honor students took the same class as non honors but had additional writing assignments which were just reading analyses that were not bad at all. Would definitely take this class again, Joab is a a great professor!
w/ Foster. Lecture slides appear on iLearn the day of, and he makes a study guide for the final
6 Problems Sets (1 Drop), Clickers via Kahoot, 1 Midterm, 1 Final. Most of the class was easy. Final was hard to study. Very generous curve.
Dr. Tellez Foster is a very passionate and engaging teacher but fuck me, the material is very hard to self-study for and the textbook is sooo boring. Make sure to go to his study sessions.

Prof. Matt Lang teaches this (Fall 2018) - get him if he is teaching it. Sure, it's an upper division class which is why it's rated on the higher end. But if you have taken STAT 048, you should be fine. Other than that, you would only need to study a night or two before the exams to do well (noted that you have paid attention in class - you can search on YouTube for how to do the statistical part). However, showing up for the lab and discussion portions are  mandatory as attendance and assignments in these sections count towards your final grade.

Professor Vel. Really easy teacher one midterm one final and the rest of the grade is based on discussion and lab. Not hard it’s basically an intro stats class so if you have taken stats before you should do well.

Took with Tae-Hwy Lee, attendance is not mandatory nor does it help.  Professor mumbles and his notes are pretty difficult to follow along. Discussion and lab helped a lot since all the TA's went through almost every homework problem.  Material is pretty easy, the textbook isn't the greatest, but using Google/YouTube should help.  The class was also curved heavily, one midterm and final.

Very statistically focused, but you dont really feel any economics lol, I dont think we talked about economics at all. Wouldn't suggest if youre not a econ major or if you dont care/need about statistical models( p-value, z score, etc.)

I took this course with Veronica Sovero in the Fall of 2022. There is 1 midterm and 1 final, which aren't too difficult. Most of the class is graded on easy weekly labs and 2 lecture quizzes per week. Make sure you do well on them because some of them can get pretty hard. The final was curved a little bit. Keep in mind that Veronica is a new professor at UCR, so she might switch up some of her methods. I ended the class with an A-, which I thought was fair since I got a C on the final.

Take with McLaren! 2 midterms, 3 homeworks, and 1 final. All are short worksheets that you can take on your own but within the time frame. Also really appreciate how he added the video recordings to the elearn! attendance is not mandatory and the exams are based off of the homework! Thank you professor McLaren for an understandable easy class!
-professor Ortego Marti - Hw weekly - 1 midterm - 1 Final. Midterm is doable with a lot of studying , Final is very hard . There is a curve at the end.

First midterm was hard but the TA's really helped afterwords. For the rest of the midterms/finals most of the questions were based off the practice questions he gave out so it was pretty easy to get an A. Lectures were not that useful and were in the UV for me. Professor was Silvitu.

Professor Kenneth Kim-- Honestly, very difficult class and Prof. Kim did not make it any easier... He's bad at controlling a class and jokes around TOO much at times. Hard to take him seriously, which doesn't help you with grasping the material as he reads off his slides. Yes, he does homework examples in class, but even then he incorporates a joke or two. *Need the book for homework*

Had Prof. George Sarraf - class should be alright if you pay attention in lecture and properly (they post answer keys and chegg has everything ofc) do the homework assignments. There are only 3 hw assignments throughout the quarter, but they're pretty lengthy, so I suggest you start early if you have Sarraf. He has an accent, but it isn't too bad, and he likes to crack jokes. There's 2 midterms and a final during week 10 that is not cumulative. He uploads the slides and likes to write on one side of the white board in Life Sciences so it pretty much made people not attend lecture. He mentioned that only 30% of the class shows up in lecture so he doesn't think the class deserves a curve.
Class was hard due to being online and lectures pre recorded. Lectures did not help on the midterm nor final.

Intermediate macro with Abubaker. 1 midterm, 1 final. Very short hw assignments every couple weeks. Prof has no structure to the class. In-person lectures are not worth it. Go to discussion, do the hw, and go to 1-2 classes before the exams for review sessions and you’ll be set.
The professor was very nice and understanding but the material was math based and challenging.

Took Fall 2019 with Urmee Khan. The material can be challenging and the class could be much harder, but the professor makes the exams a lot easier then they could be. I went into the class not knowing much about calculus but was still able to get an A in the class. The professors teaching style is hard to follow along to, and I learned mostly from the lecture slides and discussions. The most important thing about this class to succeed is to do the practice problems and understand what's going on when you do the homework. The exams are almost identical to the sample ones given.

(Urmee Khan - Fall 2020) - she is literally the worst professor I've ever met.  Her handwriting is absolutely atrocious, it is extremely difficult to read what she is writing in her recorded lectures (she has a thick accent as well).  For a week, we didn't have live lectures because her computer broke and it took ages for her new one to come in.  I stopped going to lecture because it took too much effort to read what she was writing and I was learning more through YouTube/self studying.  She made the entire class buy Pearson ($100) for homework and only assigned 4 assignments throughout the entire quarter (the last two assignments were given out at the 2nd to last week of the quarter).  Her mid-term was pretty easy, but her final literally bent everyone over (she left the country almost two weeks before the final, no live lectures during this period).   If you do not have a steady foundation in Calc, do not take her.

I took this course with Bree Lang in the Winter of 2022. This class is a more in-depth look at what you learned in Micro Econ principles, but with more math. A lot of students had issues with the calculus that was taught, but if you ask questions during lecture/discussion, you should be okay. While the exams were open note and online, she made sure they were more conceptual and difficult. Still, Bree Lang is a very approachable professor. I ended the course with an A-.

Had some slight derivatives, but they are not like in calc class, way easier. Teacher was Bree Lang, she was super helpful and enthusiastic. I said in the discord that I was sad that the final was very soon after my other final that day(literally 30 min) and without asking she offered to delay it another 30 so I could relax and prep between them. Class is easy if you study well enough, and I would argue anyone could get a B in this class

Pay attention in class, homework assignment every week, can find it online. Before Midterm  has a review session which is practically the exam, so attend it. Final is cumulative but the questions are from his homework assignments. The Final is multiple choice, true and false with explanation and mathematical questions(the HW but numbers changed)

I took this class with Bandy during covid and it was the worst Economics class I have taken so far at UCR. I am an economics major and I swear he was so unorganized. His tests were very hard and he thought since he can do them in 10 minutes we should be able to do them in 50 minutes. If someone does not know how to teach themselves they will not know what is going on in this class. I got a good grade in the end because everyone complained and he curved the class so he wouldn't fail everyone. But I am a good student and this class would have ruined my record. I know this is supposed to be one of the hardest classes but I can't help but feel that if B. Lang was teaching it, it would have been easy yet hard.

Had Professor Guo. Attend his lectures. That's what's key to getting an A. He drops key information and test questions in his lecture. Also he give worksheets which are the exams split up. If you practice the worksheets. You'll do great on the midterms. There's 2 midterms and the final

Fall 2021 (Online), Prof. Lee - Pretty easy class, most of his problem sets were online and midterm/final were open book.  Attendance was not required and problem sets carried my grade.  There is also a paper due near the end of the quarter, basically BS'd it and got a 91%

I took this course with Dong Lee in the Fall of 2022. There is 1 midterm, 1 final, and a short paper due at the end of the quarter. The exams for the class were difficult, and the average score for the midterm and final was an F. Thankfully, he curves the final grade of the class. The team-project paper is super easy and it's pretty much a grade-booster. The homework sets were pretty straight forward, and accounted for a decent percentage of the final grade. I ended the class with an A+.

Had with Prof. Dongwon Lee, lectures can be pretty boring as he goes off the slides. He does go over problems that are very similar to what is shown on the exams. Class covers the same concepts as intro macro with slightly more math (nothing more advanced than algebra). The curve is also set so that the average student gets a B. Grade is 30% midterm, 30% final, 30% hw, and 10% a term paper.

Took with Lee Dongwon. His lectures made me feel  sleepy lol, but he uploads his notes and they are really great, I can always understand whats in the problem sets when I find the correct notes. 5 problem sets with one  being dropped, a term paper, and midterm and final. Everything is based on curve.

Avoid Professor Riyad Abubaker - his lectures are incredibly difficult to follow along, the slides consist of vague graphs and he would write notes on the whiteboard with messy/small handwriting.  If you have to take him, you'll need to put in some effort self-studying.

I took this course with Riyad Abubaker in the Winter of 2023. The class isn’t really too difficult, but the professor isn’t amazing. He hardly goes over notes during lectures and usually spends a ton of time just telling stories. There is one midterm and a final, both of which make up a substantial part of your final grade. Just make sure you go to discussion and office hours if you don’t understand something in the class. I finished with an A-.

Topics aren't super hard, took it with Abubaker and he barely taught. The TAs covered the problems and concepts you need to know and the professor also basically tells you what is going to be covered on the midterm and final. If you take the time to review the material and do a couple practice problems the course is very easy.
Professor Shi kind of boring and lectures make you want to sleep. The material is really hard.

Took w/ Professor Ozkan Eren - he seems passionate about the class but it was difficult to understand him at times, he sometimes speaks so fast I had no clue what he said.  He will go over 1-2 questions from the midterm/final during lecture (at random times, but before the actual exam).  Lab and discussions helped in understanding the homework, but pay attention to what prof. looks for during lecture examples - simply answering the question isn't enough.  STATA was also used in lab, but my instructor never really went over code; he handed us everything.  Final is not cumulative and blue books for required for both midterm/final.

I took this course with Ozkan Eren in the Winter of 2023. I thought that this class was going to be difficult, but the professor made it very manageable. In discussions and labs, the TAs basically gave out the answers for the homework assignments. We also used STATA in this class, but you don’t need any prior experience to understand it. The midterm was easy, but the final was much more difficult. Thankfully, he curved both exams. Overall, I got an A in the class.

Took it with Jeff Allen. Very straightforward class, just remember the major events and how they connect to global economic development. His tests are a bit picky in that he wants detailed answers(free response) and to clearly demonstrate your understanding of the event. Would take again

Health Economic with Matt Lang the material is not hard he only had 4 quizzes, a midterms
 and a final. Just remembering how the graphs move and why is super important.

Took with Kenneth Kim during Fall '22 (in-person).  Probably the worst professor I have ever seen in Economics, lecture compromises of 50+ slides that are copied/pasted from the textbook.  During lecture, he glances over all the slides giving vague information to each new topic presented to class.  He goes off on a tangent frequently and does NOT give a clear direction when it comes to the material covered.  When asked about what would be covered on the midterm, he mumbled and told the class to study "everything".  He gave a key term guide (100+ key terms) a day before the midterm when he could have given it a week before and reviewed it instead of wasting our time with the pointless slides.  Midterm consisted of multiple choice questions from our weekly quizzes and FRQs from practice sets that were given out as class work practice.  Take another class to fill the requirement, it isn't worth the headache to take this class with him.

It's the stock market class (business elective) with Professor Silviu Velovici. It's kind of hard to say how difficult the class is due to the project that he gave us last minute. Cheat sheets are allowed for the two midterms and the final. The midterms are based on the homework, but he switches the questions slightly (ex: "increase" from homework to "decrease" on midterm). It's basically a class with a lot of accounting stuff. He came up with a group project the Monday before Thanksgiving break, so we had to find group members outside of class and not within our discussion. So many people sent out emails to find a group and other members, so it probably delayed a lot of people in starting it. Since it was so last minute I thought it was pretty disorganized - I'm pretty sure no one wants to finish up a project during their break. The final ended up being based on the project, so just doing your part in the project probably wouldn't have been enough to know everything. It was decided that he was going to take the 3 best grades out of 2 midterms, the project, and the final. So make sure you do well on at least 3 of those. I think it's a class worth looking at, but the best experience would be going to lecture and actually knowing all the material for the group project if he decides to do it again. He's a pretty cool and funny guy - since very few people showed up to the lecture right before Thanksgiving he gave out some extra credit.
Joab Corey’s an interesting and fun teacher, relatively easy class, no discussion section!

Took it with Kenneth Kim. Course was heavy on math and required most econ knowledge from macro/micro. Dont reccomend taking it with him. Professor goes over slides very fast and does not have organized notes. Course will require reading textbook and individual study. Curve was big tho, most of class got C/D.
The midterm and final was just the homework problems with numbers changed plus True/False explain questions that the professor mentions in review session.
Quizzes every lecture, HW weekly, midterm, and final. Both exams were based on the homework
Try your best to avoid Bandy

Avoid Urmee Khan - she is a nice professor, but her notes are difficult to follow along because of grammar/diction issues and the slides can sometimes be vague.  During lecture, she'll handwrite some notes on the board to explain more on vague slides and I found it difficult to follow because her handwriting is atrocious.  She created her own homework prompts, but the difficulty does not match the midterm or final (many were unprepared with some of the questions on exams).  This class requires constant self-study and going to class to ask questions is a must because her email response rate is poor.

Taken with Kenneth Kim. Easy A with the overall grade curve at the end but avoid if you aren't into the whole read off the slides for the entire lecture thing. Groups of 4-5 for both homework assignments during the quarter. One midterm and one final (cumulative).

I took this class with Dongwon Lee Fall 2022 and Im ngl, this class was pretty hard. He grades your problem sets (they're usually due a week after being assigned) pretty harshly. We only had one midterm and one final AND THEYRE SUPER DIFFICULT. You would have to actually study for them and try in this class, but the good thing about this course is that he curves so nicely. I got like a 13/50 as my raw score on the midterm and passed the class with a B.

This class should be manageable if you take it with Bree Lang. She will most likely post lecture videos, slides,  and notes so that's a plus. You have to do reading assignments and lecture quizzes, but you don't have to get a perfect score in order to get full credit for them. To get a good grade on your midterm and final, I highly recommend doing the practice questions that she gives you. Good luck.

Professor Gutierrez is super easy. No tests or quizzes. Just 2 two-page papers for homework and midterm and final are papers too. Lecture is just taking notes, but it's kinda useless and so are the readings.

(COVID time) I took it with Gutierrez and she's really nice but unorganized. I relied on the groupchat to help me and I heard she could take weeks to answer emails. No hw but readings every week. I stopped reading them cause she goes over it during lecture (optional) anyways. A few discussion questions every week since Discussion is basically office hours. 2 papers, 1 midterm research project, 1 final paper
PLEASE ATTEND. participation and attendance was worth 30% of my grade and was the only reason why I did not pass with an A.
Lussier was easy and wonderful. It's a pretty useful class.

A high school freshman student could pass this class, it’s crazy to think I’m paying to take this class. It’s an easy and chill class about “learning strategies” (ex. Get a planner, have time management). The catch is the prof doesn’t post the slides so you do have to come and do the notes. However, the prof posts relevant study guides which makes things even easier. Consisted of a few small writing assignments with one large final writing prompt and 2 midterms with no real final.

Winter 2023 with Prof Lussier. All online. Randolph was my TA. This class is super easy but has a lot of busy work. A high schooler could pass this class, but honestly, this class was quite useless to me. It was a lot of generic information that a senior doesn't really need, it is more geared towards freshman. So if you are looking for an easy elective class I would recommend this class.

Had this class online (all lectures recorded, discussion online). There are "modules" (lectures and readings) every week and at most 2 quizzes due every week. There are 2 projects, no essays or exams.

Taught by Begoña Echeverria who reminds me of a strict annoying high school teacher, the type who yells at you when your phone is out. One of the more “difficult” lower-div education classes, or for a better word tedious. It’s a lot of dense reading from a dry textbook about the history of education in the US, not that fun. Also, the class is mostly essay based, the prof even mentioned wanting to make it a WAC class. Wouldn’t recommend as an “easy class” unless you like history and writing.

Super easy class, lectures are honestly optional, but are a lovely time. Dr. Lee's teaching style allows for everyone to participate and overall the most welcoming course I've ever taken. Weekly reading response assessments (which are 2/3 - 1 full page) about 2 articles read per week (1 scholarly one, 1 video/podcast/article that relates to real world).
