Pace yourself because those essays get long (ex. 7-8 pages) and go to office hours! They are more than willing to step-by-step guide you on your essay. There isn't a lot of busy work besides the essays because pretty much all your assignments are done in class or are very short annotations which you can easily complete. If you are familiar with essay writing and how to make essays long, this class is pretty easy for you.

I took it with Carrie Jean. Pretty standard english class with 3 essays which are the bulk of your grade. Carrie is very kind and understanding, gives great feedback on papers, and very helpful office hours. There was also a pretty long book to read that tied into the themes of the class and connected to the final. Make sure to give yourself enough time to work on your essays, and the class should be fun!

I had it with Professor Rust, it was really easy, but with it being online and all. Got a B+ in the class so it wasn't bad. Only thing was annoying is that the Essays prompts werr confusing. Just go to Office Hours and you will be fine.

I had Cassandra Van Zandt in Winter 2023 and she a very nice and understanding teacher, she would push back due dates if she saw that as a group we needed it, she gave in class work as cushioning for our overall grade and we only had 3 essays and a final which was a choice between a final paper and a creative project. Choose the creative project, its easy and you’ll probably get the same grade or better as a final paper. She lets you resubmit one of the first 2 essays at the end of the quarter after fixing it. I will say she is a bit of a tough grader when it comes to essays (which is why I chose the creative project) but if you go to her office hours with a draft and fix what she says, you can get a high B or an A. We also read a book that she provided a free version of, but most of the other readings were not long and from the text book. As long as you try you should pass, I probably would have gotten an A- but thanks to the creative project I got an A+.

spring2023 took with prof george cunningham, not hard but a LOT of busy work. just be ready to do some assignment every other day that honestly doesn't matter. 3 major papers - mostly research, and 1 final exam (on a book). goes on a tangent sometimes and isn't very organized though
Easy A if u just do ur work on time.
Hackelton was a good professor but a hard grader.  Easy to get a B, hard to get an A.  Lots of in-class essays and the final was take home.  Would give pop quizzes so show up to class!

I took this class with Alexander Sterling. He is my favorite professor I've ever had, so I would recommend trying to get him. He will definitely make you do work/set up ways to make sure you're staying on track so there's almost always some kind of assignment due. Even though it was kind of annoying to have a lot of work sometimes it really helped my writing improve in the end. Just make sure you do what he says.

AVOID THERESA LEE! SHE IS THE DEVIL!! I put soooo much time and effort into her class but for some reason she had some sort of a personal vendetta against me. She gave me an 89.99 on every single essay I turned in to avoid giving me an A
Collin Innes! easy and nice has some in class essays, but easy topics. Graded off essays and sometimes quizzes or one page analysis.

If you can, take Sarah Buckner, she's amazing. She's not too harsh of a grader for essays and a good chunk of points comes from participation and discussion. Quite a few readings, but you can get away with reading sparknotes, as long as you contribute once or twice per discussion and say something intellectual.
I took the class with Anderson and he was quite funny and easy going. Most of your grade is based off your essay scores. He is a bit of a hard grader so it may be hard to get an A on his essays.
I think english classes really depend on the professor. I had Watt and she was alright. Easy class to get a B in, but its pretty hard to get an A.

Had the class with instructor Quarterman, really fun and easy class if you’re a strong writer. The essays were enjoyable to write in my opinion. Not a hard grader but not an easy one either. Very discussion based class, not a lot of lecture so it was a pretty chill class. Only read two books and studied pop culture material (music videos, movies, tv shows). Our class was centered around madness so it was just a really interesting class overall.

I have Chelsea Keane, super nice and chill. Idk if its due to the pandemic, but we only had two essays, and majority of the class grade is on discussions/participations, as long as u do your work you’ll def pass the class.

Had it with Brandy Lewis. She is really nice and I could tell she cares about her students. Class was a bitch though she focused it around taxidermy, and animal semiotics. It was really hard to absorb and write about I dropped around week 4.

This class was a bit difficult for me since it was all argumentative. I had Wallace Cleaves as my prof but I had a TA (Soraya Zarook) teach all the materials. Soraya was really nice and open to giving ideas and helping students come up with topics as well as strengthening their positions. There's two required books but you can find one of them online as a pdf. Soraya wasn't that tough of a grader, just make sure to have solid evidence to back up your claims. She also gives out really helpful feedback.
took online with professor anderson, he was pretty chill but grades essays pretty hard. easy to get a B, hard to get an A.

I took this class Summer 2021, Instructor Enriquez was firmly one of the best instructors I've ever attended. His enthusiasm for the class was one that is very rare, and his slides and explanations throughout the course were the best. Definitely had a strong impression on what is like to be an English professor. He explained many things again and again, until he was sure that ALL students understood the material. He was clear about what he expects in his essays, and his grading were very generous in my opinion. He pushed back essay deadlines to account for his student's comforts, and he was so nice with his comments and grading. I went to him 4 times for one thesis of a particular essay, and he perfected it with me for as long as I went!

I had a TA named Nolan Goetzinger and he was super nice and a fair grader. I haven't received an A in English since freshman year of high school, but I was able to get a 97 in this class. Only drawback is his focus is on nature poetry but at least it's modern poetry and you don't have to write poems. I took it over this past summer (2021) and he gave us 3 essays, journal entries graded on completion, and a "final" journal where you write about your experience in the class.

TAKE CLASS with Chelsea Price. She's an amazing teacher and very understanding. Only have to do 3 essays. Topics were very easy: 1 Aladdin 2 Fate Zero Anime 3 Marvel Thor! Easiest class and she gives the option of not doing an essay. (taken spring 2021)
Prof. Sang Keun Yoo was really nice and his class was easy. 3 essays, 1 final paper (talking about your experiences in the class and how you improved).

This class was only difficult due to the professor. Professor David Hinckley is not a good professor. You don't learn anything in this class because he just talks about his personal life all the time and when you get your grade back it's just negative comments. All my essays were reviewed and revised by students who tested out of English 1C and students who are passed the course but this professor gave me F's for all my essays and the revised ones. The only positive note I can say about him is the fact he lets us revise our essays for a better grade but if you want to actually learn something and a fair professor, pick someone else.

Not particularly sure why but I found this class to be very time consuming. Took it with Jacelyn Vasquez, and while the class itself wasn't particularly difficult, for some reason I found myself extremely busy because of it. The problem is that, even though it is not a "difficult" class, it is still intellectually demanding. I was unbelievably busy and stressed the quarter I took it.

I had the class with Dr.David Hinkley, and I'll tell you, he made it so unnecessarily difficult. Throw everything you know about essay formatting out the window, because he makes you change it to "go in order" of the book. If there's a chance for you to take ENGL001C and Hinkley is your option, I suggest taking it a different quarter with a different teacher.

Taken fall 2022 w/ Aran Park. She is not mean but assigns a lot of reading (&pop quizzes) and long essays so the class was time consuming and kinda scary as a freshman. Go to office hours for essay help! Final project was partly a group project:((( The class itself was about fairy tales so it felt unnecessarily demanding at times. Also she wouldn’t fully excuse an assignment even with a doctors note. Grading was quite harsh; really hard to get an A, and it was all graded very last minute so I had absolutely no idea how I was doing.
Great biases in class and a C+ is very normal don't expect to be getting any A's this class was harder than 1a and 1b
I had Dr. Van Zandt and enjoyed every class. The essay topics were very enjoyable and the class discussions were very interesting. 10/10 would take class again
Do not slack in this class. Try your best on every essay since professors (maybe just mine) mark every little thing.

The teacher (Reminded us she was not a professor yet) graded harshly due to the fact that no one participated in the class. Once students she got to know her, she good feedback. Do the work ahead of time, listen to feedback and participate makes the class easier. Essays play a huge part in getting that A. Homework and points do count sometimes.
Grades are almost all dependant on essays. Can be a difficult class.
Prof. Schnarr was nice and overall an understanding professor. If you go to office hours she'll basically write the essay with you.

I took the class with Dr. Potter and he made it enjoyable. Just don't mess up on the 4 essays and you wont have to worry as much for the final. Everything is marked for all the professors in this course, so an A isn't expected. Also, one essay is allowed a revision.

Had Potter as my professor. Put in a lot of work on my essays going to the arc 2 or 3 times per an essay just to get a C on all my essays. This class destroyed my gpa. Currently in ENGL001A and I have an A so avoid Potter at all costs.
Snyder grades WAY to hard, it’s incredibly difficult to get A’s straight off the bat
4 essays and a final

I took ENGL004 with Julia Brett. She is a very nice person and on the older side. I wouldn't recommend her because she did not teach how to write good essays or use the "Write It" textbook at all. She primarily wanted us to focus reading Ecotopia which was not interesting to me. The only good thing I could say is that I didn't have to buy the "Write It' textbook.

There are 4 essays and a final. I had Prof.Brett she was easy but this class is very grammar heavy so make sure your grammar is up to par. She lets you revise one essay which is so great. Also you need to do online grammar and reading exercises which is just busy work.

I had it with Albert Anthony and he's a pretty nice prof. He really wants to help you improve and if you put in the effort, you should be fine. He tries to make jokes during class and might even bring out his parrot. He does kinda give a lot of work and there's 4 essays, but he guides you through it and you could always go to office hours for help.

Had Stefan Torralba and he is a really considerate and helpful teacher. He really wants to help and make you a better writer. Take advantage of his generosity by asking for feedback and really incorporating it into your writing. A lot of students did not care to go to his optional rough draft help office hours and they suffered.
No one gets an A in this class lmao. Grading is super harsh no matter what professor you get. 4 essays and 1 final in total.

I had Karen Polster, and she was amazing!! The class consisted of 4 essays + the final. She's super nice and really wants to help you pass the class. The essays are easy, especially since she tells you exactly what you need to do to get A's on them. I found the class to be pretty easy, but the final was a little bit tough.
Professor Smedley is  clear on what to do on essays you just need to make sure you follow the essay requirements like a good directed summary

Had Professor Julie Cline and imo I think it was okay other than the fact that there everything is kinda rushed. There are 4 essays and she did have one quiz. She didn't give any explanation on certain essays and expected us to know the hidden meaning behind it then would call us out if we focused too much on the wrong thing. She assigns additionally reading and work but never goes over it in class so there is no point of really doing it. Wasn't aware that ENGL004 was harder than 1A/1B but this is a class you get placed in based on the writing placement test so i dont suggest actually taking this class
Had Dr. Cummins, nice professor but harsh grader. Picky about grammar but you can pass if you put in the work.

I had Todd Luce. I recommend participating in class discussions which will reflect a little bit on the harshness of your essay grading and his flexibility with deadlines. There are random 1-point assignments and quizzes twice a week, I did not do over half of them and did not try in the class because essays carry the grade for the class. So you can just not do any hw or readings and as long as you ace your essays you should get an A.

I took this class with Benedict Jones Winter 2022. He was understanding but you need to do the work in order to be able to reach out to him. His assignments are very helpful towards the essay. You do need to show up to class though, to get a passing grade. He's thorough and very helpful.
Harder than ENGL 001A and 001B

Had Potter Fall quarter 2022. A super difficult teacher, never gave As. He doesn't want you to be creative (it's not a creative writing class) but at the same time he wants it to be unique and engaging. His standards were ambiguous and contradicting. His TA (at the time) was telling us the exact opposite of what Potter was teaching (Potter didn't want us to do the 5-paragraph structured essay and our TA kept telling us to do so).

Overall do not recommend. A very chill class with little homework but the grading was absurd and tanks your GPA.

Dr. Musgrove is a really sweet teacher. The course involved a lot of grammar. You should make sure to be aware of your grammar when your write your essays. There are about five essays including the final which is an essay. I read Antigone and Electra, but she might choose different plays. It's good to get drafts reviewed by her during office hours.

Prof Guenther gave a lot of material each week but most of it was really interesting. We were assigned 3 papers but got to choose 2 of the 3 to complete. If you are interested in the subject then it is great but there is a lot of reading.

Online Summer course with Francisco Ramos. Very laid back professor. He grades mostly on effort of your assessments. There were 4 assignments, each being 1 - 2.5 pages (MLA format). For the online course we only had to attend class once a week. You could honestly get away with not readings or modules. Not sure how much will change once we go back to in person classes but he practically hands out A's. Textbook is given for free by professor along with any other reading materials.

Taken with Josh Pearson- It's a really fun class! You can get away without doing the reading (about 2-3 short stories a week) but you'll have trouble following the discussion. There's a few papers that aren't too bad (and he frequently pushes the due date later.)

Super interesting class that defines a lot of different subgenres of science fiction literature. The professor is very passionate and humorous about the subject he teaches. He has all kinds of knowledge. He's also easy going. There is a lot of reading, but nothing too much.

Prof Gutierrez is great, and if you're interested in Chicano theory at all you'll love this class. The only assignments are journals every week, and class time just consists of watching presentations by other students (you also have to present at least once in the quarter btw). Attendance isn't mandatory, and she uploads recordings of the lectures later on for whoever needs it. One essay at the end of the quarter and that was it. Really cool professor, also really flexible with deadlines if you need a bit of extra time.
Had Professor Kenny.  Really nice lady and easy multiple choice exams.  Take good notes and try to read as much of the plays as possible and you'll be fine.

Professor Brayman's really nice and is passionate about what she teaches, but she tends to drone on during lectures. Some of the readings for this class can be pretty hard, but she at least gives you most of them. Midterm for this class was tricky, and most didn't really pass it. Essays are pretty toughly graded, but grades are consistently updated on iLearn.

WINTER 2022 (Half online and half in-person) Dr. Kenny is super nice, and the course is so easy and fun. No exam and final. You read British literature (4 books) and we discuss them in class. Quizzes are take-home (on canvas) and just the things on the reading, if you are lazy just google them and they are all up there. The final project is just creating artwork and writing an artist statement on it. This class is a free A+. This is Dr. Kenny's first time teaching this course. I recommend taking any other course with her if possible.
All you have to do it keep up with reading the poems, Professor Long and his TA's are very gracious graders when it comes to the midterm and final

Had Emma Stapely and she's great! She's a lovely instructor and you can tell she LOVES talking about whatever she's teaching. I will say though, it's sometimes hard to follow along if you're trying to take notes because she seems to read off a very elaborate script. But, I didn't read any of the books besides just using an online summary tool and got 100% on every single essay. Just google quotes or something and you'll be fine. So long as you answer the prompt (at least for my TA, Loren Barbour), you get full credit

Took it with Robyn Johnson, Summer 2022. Really chill class overall. It's a pretty easy pass if you don't care but if you actually put in a little effort and try to understand the readings this is an easy A to boost your GPA.
a lot of readings but i never did them, cancelled midterm and final, just 2 papers for final and midterm

Took this course with Professor Jennifer Doyle. She's such an understanding professor in the sense that she knew her students had much harder courses for their schedules. As a result, she changed the original structure of the course from: 10% reading exam, 20% difficulty assignment, 30% discussion participation, 25% final essay, and 15% reading exam, to the same format but converting the two reading exams into Notes Submission (Credit/No Credit). The way she structures the prompts is that there is no correct idea, as long as you are able to relate the core concepts and theories with the assigned readings. She genuinely wants her students to succeed. Lectures sparked in-class discussions that engaged everybody with the difficult concepts.

Took it with Professor Doyle (Fall 19). Super easy. she does not believe in 'grading', so she has a list of assignments that you can do. Once you turn in the assignments you get the points no matter what. 75 points was from the assignments list, and another 25 is from an reflection essay, attendence, and a plan of what assignments you were going to do. She didn't tell people that attendence was being taken for credit, so not a lot of people showed up to lecture. So a lot of people lost points for no attendence. On another note, the class structure was constantly changing, so it was slightly confusing. This also means there is a good chance the class might be a bit different next quarter.

Never went to lectures and got an A+. I had Jennifer Doyle. She's really funny and entertaining so if you aren't the type to want to skip class, you won't suffer at all. She's also very understanding and gives good feedback on homework. You get to choose which homework assignments you do and there are no finals or midterms. Her homework is also based on participation not actual content. If you actually follow directions, you'll get full credit. And as long as you do a decent amount of the homework or at least one's that are worth a lot of points and one of the graded essays, you'll get an A.

Took with Stapely online bc of quarantine. Highly recommend, super easy and written assignments were short (3 pgs max). An easy A as long as you complete every assignment.  2 discussion posts each week based on readings.

I had Dr. James Tobias. He is very kind and caring, he tries his best to make the class easier on students, emphasizing how "quizzes don't do much, but a research paper will help you in the real world." He teaches very interesting subjects, sometimes he talks a lot, and gives a lot of information. It is important to attend class but you don't need to write about every subject he talks about, though they are connected and will give you many ideas about what to write about. The TA I had was super helpful,  so I am not sure what it is like to take this course without a good TA. There is a lot of reading and writing, and the writing is pretty difficult, however, you just have to be organized and keep a good schedule and it should not be too hard to complete. Grade depends mostly on TA, professor is open to questions and likes to be challenged/ asked questions or when students bring up topics for discussion.

Professor Nunley is trash. Peep his RMP. Don't take this class under any circumstances 'cus guy does NOT know how to teach. His tests are cruel and he cannot explain HIS OWN essay prompts, point blank period. Completely disorganized.
Wasn’t too bad. Had to write 5,000 words total this quarter but it was broken up into mini weekly 500 word assignments. All on Hamlet though

The class focused on the works of Toni Morrisson so it was really interesting reads. With Professor Nunley, there are no writing assignments, just a midterm and a final. It is very important that you pay very close attention to what he says in class as in his tests he will have questions about things he mentions briefly in his lectures. He gives extra credit the more you participate/ talk in class which is a bonus!
Literally just show up, get credit.
You just have to show up to class.
Don't skip classes as that's the only thing you have to do to get an A in the class. Pretty useful class for a 1 unit class. You learn a lot and Professor LePendu is amazing.
Hardly a class aside from the weekly homework. Make sure you go to class and do the homework, otherwise you will fail the class. I had professor LePendu and he was a beast
Had Paea. "Mandatory" attendance (just get someone to send you the attendance link). Weekly homework that takes 20 - 30 min tops. No final or midterm.

just show up to class. Not even really, becuase there were no in-class activities or anything. Just 3 homeworks, and a final. The 3rd year equivalent of ENGR001. Once a week for one hour. What else do you want me to say?
Show up, learn about industry stuff, leave. Took it with Payne. We had some homework (not that hard) and a final. The final was only hard because none of us really studied for it.

With prof. K barsanti, this class is easy if you habe programming experience, (understand function calls, executions, declarations, and how to work with arrays) if you dont then it will set you back, lectures are boring she reads off the powerpoint and always be in class cause she gives clicker and it counts toward grade, skim through the book for more pointers on the numerical methods, not a hard class but Barsanti is new and very disorganized at times
Take Dr. Toan to learn MATLAB or Take Dr. Barsanti for easy A.
If you take Barsanti, you might notice that she does not know any matlab.

Barsanti is an easy A if you know MATLAB. If you don't know, work with the TA as much as possible. HW/MATLAB grader can be a pain. Though, her class is a bit unorganized and you'll see that she doesn't know MATLAB too well.

If you have coding experience this class is a joke. It's literally basic applied calculus with MATLAB as the tool for approximating solutions. If you can understand for loops and function calls you will ace the class. The TA will carry you if you go to lab sections, which were optional attendance for fall 2021 (but you needed to do the assignments given in lab for credit).
Easy shit, just make sure you have a good group for your project. Class is 30% quizzes from the videos, 70% is the project grade. Easy A if put a modicum of work into the project
The homework is easy, but the existential dread isn’t.

Bonni and Sharon. The dynamic duo. This was a great class. I've heard bad things about ENGL001C, this is the alternative for BCOE majors. And it's not that bad either. You can tell both of them are passionate about their topics and like to share their lives with the class. They take turns alternating lectures and present material relevant to life. The first half is pretty much introducing the concepts and exercises, the second half of the class is producing a technical spec to standards. Extra credit is given, both before the midterm and after the midterm. I believe in our quarter 300 extra points could be earned by doing all the extra credit. If you do everything and put in a decent amount of effort, this class shouldn't be too bad. The workshops were often only 30 minutes or less. Time consuming, but difficulty wise not too bad.

There's a lot of writing in this class and you will work in groups for the quarter-long functional specification project. If you struggle with essays, this might be a challenge. Otherwise, it doesn't require much effort.

Overall, the content of the class is super easy, but the professors make it extremely annoying. 

Group Assignments:
PRAY that you're assigned quarter-long group mates that are competent and FUCK YOU if you're the group mate that makes everyone else do all the work :(
Beware the writing guidelines. I can't stress enough, for group assignments make sure all members of your group follow the writing guidelines or everyone in the group loses points. I easily could have gotten an A in the class, but I had to do all of the heavy lifting for 3 other people in my group and couldn't focus on writing my extra credit essays.

Essays:
Long, tedious, and professors are annoyingly strict on their "writing guidelines". Very straight forward though. Set aside like a Saturday morning to bang out an essay and you'll be fine.

Extra Credit:
DO ALL EXTRA CREDIT. The class offers so many opportunities to make up any points you lost because of dumb mistakes on assignments. It's entirely possible to skip the written part of the final if you do all of the extra credit.

This class is so annoying. 1000 word essays due every other week, and they're so nitpicky over every little thing. Do as much of the extra credit as you can to avoid getting out of the final. I did it, but I got less than half the points. It was like one little thing. Sure, I might have missed half the prompt but I should have gotten at least 1 point for what I did write. You'll also be working in groups for a good chunk of it, so make sure you're working with someone who's competent.

Class was a JOKE. Essays were ezpz. Labs were done in under 5 min. Follow the writing guidelines and you're chillin.

The only somewhat difficult part of this class was the presentation. But even that was only five minutes.

Do the extra credit and you can skip part of the final. Fr do it.

Lectures were not suuuper helpful but Bonni and Sharon are kinda cool to listen to.

Easy A. Just do the work and you're fine.

The class is easy. Essays are tedious, but for the most part they seem lenient on grading. Just follow the writing guidelines and start early.

Group assignments aren't that bad. The work is much shorter than the essays if everyone does their part. Just make sure that everyone follows the writing guidelines and does their part correctly. My group was competent overall, so we got away with doing assignments during the day they were due, but if you don't trust your group you should start early.

Do all the extra credit. You can skip the written portion of the final entirely if you get all the points from them. The written portion was around 3,500 words for my class. It's still not fun to do even if you have over a week to do it. All ECs combined likely have the same word count as the final, but you probably don't want to do this final when you'll have other finals to study for.

Class is really easy. It just takes a lot of work. Final is 3,500 words. Midterm is 1,500 words. Week 0 you're assigned a 1,000 word essay. There's presentations, homework like weekly, etc. It's just very tedious to do but not difficult whatsoever (unless English is not your first language, then you might be in some trouble). Just make sure you follow their guidelines religiously. They will dock your grade mercilessly for each assignment if you don't follow their rules. 
Also, there is group work and a stand-up presentation involved. The group is assigned in like week 2 or something and you work with them until week 10. If you get lazy/inattentive group members like I did, your grade will suffer and there's not much you can do about it. You might just have to suck it up and make up for their apathy by doing twice the work. The groups are assigned randomly and you cannot switch members, barring extreme circumstances like a member is straight up refusing to do anything, etc.

Follow the writing guidelines and you'll do great. There is only one large assignment (presentations around midterms) and everything else is pretty easy. If you're up for it, do all the extra credit offered. It should let you skip the final, which is a huge 3000 word essay. Bonni and Sharon can be a bit much, but if you can ignore their "LOOK WE'RE OLDER THAN YOU AND THEREFORE KNOW MORE THAN YOU" attitude, the class is entertaining enough.
Pay extremely close attention to every rule they mention. It's obvious what they want, but if you don't do it then your grade will suffer

Sharon and Bonni are good profs who know what they're talking about. The course isn't hard, but luckily you learn a good deal of work advice. As long as you submit your assignment with on time with the correct file name, you'll be fine.
It's a lot of writing. Follow their guidelines on the writing requirements and do ALL the extra credit. Easy A.

Like others have said above, just pray you get paired with people that actually follow their writing guidelines otherwise your grade will suffer in the group assignments as a result. Do as many of the extra credit assignments as you possibly can so you can skip one or two essays on the final and start writing those final essays as early as possible. As long as you follow their writing guidelines you should be in good shape. And make sure you name your files properly, you don't want to end up like my partner who did 1500 words worth of extra credit just to get no points because he forgot to change the file name.

If you do all the extra credit and follow writing guidelines you will get an A. Bonni and Sharon have the most entertaining lectures and while the rules for the class seem odd, they are easy to follow.

One of the most tedious and time consuming courses I have ever taken in my entire life. The amount of work you have to do is ridiculous, and around the last week is absolute nightmare.Also you cant choose your partners, so you better pretty you get paired with someone who is a competent writer.

Look, you're just going to have to learn to suck it up with Bonnie and Sharon. This means absolutely no complaining or whining because it will just hurt you. They are the only people that are teaching 180W at UCR.
When they grade your writing, they can accuse of you absolutely anything and you can't really do anything about it. They will have a fair share of criticism to give you. Remember to follow the writing guidelines they give you, and naming convention of your file.
There is a group project that you will do throughout the entire class, and hopefully you get paired with a good team. If you don't get a good group, you may be in trouble.
It's relatively easy to pass the class, just don't be a pain in the butt. Do every extra credit assignment they throw at you, and you can skip the final.

I also want to add that these two are woke. You'll get deducted if you aren't inclusive to all groups. Godspeed to anyone taking these two.
A lot of assignments with Bonnie and Sharon but it's pretty easy to get an A if you follow the guidelines closely.
Easy Class with Professor Volz
Easy af go to discussion for debates and participation points and go to lecture for participation points. READ THE SLIDES ALL TESTS ARE STRAIGHT UP FROM THE SLIDES.

No essays, two exams, and a final. There's also no homework other than discussion section debates, which are really easy too. Professor Volz shows he knows what he talks about really well and is easy to understand. There's extra credit if you win the debates in your discussion section. The exams are literally just copy pasted from the slides he shows in class, so if you read over the slides you should be fine. The final is made up of around 80 questions from the past two exams and a few from the lectures that were left. I finished the class with 102% and I'm pretty sure the average for the final was around a 94%. By far the easiest class I could've ever taken.
Two debates in discussion, but they are easy. Two midterms and a final, you get two attempts on them.

Lectures were asynchronous. The debates we have to do as work are really interesting and pretty fun. It kept everyone engaged. Professor also provided a lot of info on his lecture slides so that was very helpful. Exams are all on things mentioned on slides so it's very easy.
Had Volz and was easy. the midterms/final was open note and all the info on the slides was on the midterm and final
Easy class but how 94% is an A- and not an A in this class I will never know
Easiest class ever

Do not take with professor Yates unless you're a environmental science major (and esp. if you're a CHASS major, stay away!). Extremely difficult exams and she purposely will try to trick you. Pretty rude. If you're late my one min. to the exam, she will give you a 0. This happened to a few people the first exam. 3 cumulative exams, and final is cumulative but optional. No textbook for the class, only PPT slides. Mandatory lectures through the usage of Kahoot.

Honestly the content is pretty straightforward and easy if you pay attention to lectures, but if you don't then the content might be kinda tricky to remember. We had the class online so both midterms and final was online (open notes and book). But overall pretty easy class if you put in effort.

Took it with Professor Peter Homyak during Winter '23 the class required attendance through pollseverywhere and tests were 50 qs multiple choice with 100 qs for the final ! The professor was super passionate about the course though very lecture heavy and homework was mainly preparing for discussion debate and reading the textbook! Only offers 1 extra credit through a 1 page essay on a debate topic reflection that counts for the participation portion of the overall grade! Midterm averages were around 66% but dropped the lowest of the 2 and final was around 68.2%.

Didn't really learn much and the TA just gave answers to the homework. Midterm and final are kind of hard but heavily graded. Choose the participation type grading and go to every class and you should be ok. But only take the class if you really need to

Professor Foster Tellez is so nice. Overall grade is extremely curved. Just make sure to attend lectures & discussions since they do kahoot for attendance points. Choose the grading scale of homework/attendance/exams instead of only exams.

If not for the generous curve my grade wouldn't have looked so pretty. Edgar Tellez-Foster lets you choose between midterm and final being the only parts that matter or incorporating clickers into your grade. I recommend choosing clickers bc he curves the class if you have >80% on it.
Make sure to study and just understand what he teaches because the midterm and final heavily rely on application of concepts you learn in class.

Class isnt hard but prof ryan rusich can be rude. The lowest exam was dropped. You have to buy a book by Jaron Lanier because all of the homework is based on it, but it isnt expensive. Attend class and the exams wont be hard because he talks about everything on the exam. The labs were pretty easy too.
Sam Ying is by far one of the best professors/instructors I've had. I highly recommend. Overall the material can be slightly difficult but the midterms/finals are easy money.

Took this with Andrew Gray. There's heavy emphasis on reading scientific research, so if that's not your cup of tea, you won't enjoy the class as much. Definitely study the lectures since he bases the exam questions off them. Due dates for assignments + projects are very lenient, even if submitted late. Overall, easier than ENSC 101

Midterm is pretty long but the final is simpler (still long tho). Grading is fair as long as you study in detail. Most of the info is in Dr. Hopkins' slides and lots is repeated throughout the quarter. Pay attention to examples that are talked about in class, and you'll be fine. Also, there is a teabag group project to do throughout the quarter so keep up with that and just make the presentation and paper p thorough.

I took this class online with Stouthamer. It is insanely difficult. He curves the class so that only the top 10% of students will get an A. If this specific course is not recommended for your major, I strongly urge you to avoid this class. There's a lot of memorization.
Professor Stouthamer expects you to memorize a LOT. The midterms were pretty tricky, weekly homework and quizzes

Dr Baer is one of the kindest, most caring, and best professors I have ever had! I took this class online so unfortunately we didn't get to work with the bees but I still learned so much. Midterm and final were very comprehensive (take-home), and lectures were very interesting. Each student has to present a research paper to the class and the presentations went quite well for everyone. If you're looking to take a good life science elective or simply learn more about these cute little creatures, take this class!

This class is super good! It is always small so you meet the professor and get a connection. It is a really good classs to learn how to read and write research and better than english 001c and you get credit for it! I love the class so much and it was such a good experience!
Paine is a great prof and gives extra credit opportunities. Most enjoyable class I have ever taken.
Perring is a fun prof, but very lecture heavy. Study study study your insect orders!!
Dr.Murillo was a super nice and involved lecturer. Take this class if you definitely like topics such as parasitology or pathology. One of the most interesting classes I have taken at UCR.
No final, no midterm
i had macias. extremely boring professor, but the midterm and final are just a take home essay. you can get away with not going to lectures, just make sure you’re on top of the readings.
Took it with Andrea Smith. No exams at all. Just had to take notes during lecture and turn them in. Also had really short essays due every week, but those were pretty easy.
No need to go to lecture easy A, prof. macias

So the other guy said that the midterm/final were take home, they weren't. Professor Macias is pretty bad at lecturing so lecture isn't necessary but make sure to go to discussion, theres attendance and quizzes. Course readings weekly, midterm is write an essay with a notecard for sources and final was the same but no notecard. Course content isn't too bad. Just read the stuff and have a general idea of what's going on in the course and you should pass. Lots of people take this as an elective so you can S/NC if you really want to.
Andrea Smith is an easy professor

do not take w najera!!! she was so bad and unprofessional too! one time a couple guys weren't paying attention and couldn't answer a question so she kicked them out of lecture..but yeah this class is lowkey a trap bc ppl say it's easy but tbh it's kinda a lot of work
(COVID ERA) Easiest A+ next to dance 5, you only have to do essays each week but you get full credit as long as u try. No midterm or finals.
No homework, just midterm/final/discussion attendance. Was pretty easy as long as you put in some effort.

They randomly take attendance in the lecture hall or put films and make you turn it in at the end of class; make sure to attend film days. One midterm and final. Teacher's and TA's are kind of unclear about what we are supposed to study for.
Lopez made us write four short papers and counted attendance occasionally.  The midterm and final were a joke.  He posted study guides on ilearn.

with prof najera, 2 reading analyses & 1 annotated bib (instead of midterms and a final), attendance is taken with clicker questions, and attendance is taken in section. super easy as long as you just do the work and show up
Professor Felix was teaching this course. The course only required two essays, one midterm which is an essay and a final essay. The class was very straight forward.

Intro to Chicano’s super easy the professor Anthony Macias really boring. Never went to class just discussion make sure to read at least 2 readings before the midterm and final and you should get an A

I had Chicano Studies with Professor Gonzalez and his lectures were conversation-style where there wasn't much to go off the slides. There are a LOT of readings for this class to the point where I stopped even checking them anymore. You have to submit a 2-page single spaced response paper every single week. The grading is quite lenient on this, so if you just do your papers and get participation points then you should be fine.

Took with Gonzales during Covid-era... grade is made up of weekly writing assignments(1.5-2 pages single spaced), participation, and one community participation write-up. Not an easy A if you're prone to skipping class or find it difficult speaking up because participation is a large chunk of the grade, but no exams is a big Plus & this class is great if you love something discussion-based. Pretty inconsistent reading (some weeks had really dense material, or just a lot of pages, some were just short articles), but all interesting.
The rate my professor ratings dont  lie.
The readings, assignments and tests were not hard at all. The professor on the other hand does not teach at all, and spends all class time venting about personal past problems. Don't take his class.

I took Professor Enrique Lopez's Intro to Chicano Studies class in the winter quarter of 2021. There is no structure at all for this class. The lectures are all over the place. There are no slides or lecture outlines, just him ranting about Chicano history and stuff. Also, he requires our camera to be on for attendance purposes, and most of us just woke up. The readings, though short, are shared through blurry jpgs, so they are tedious to read.   His assignments are film review essays. He makes us watch hour-long documentaries and write about it with a very vague prompt.  Honestly, I learned more from those documentaries than I ever did in his class. He also expects us to email him the assignments instead of having us submit them on ilearn. One of my assignments got lost in his spam folder! He takes his sweet-ass time grading assignments.The midterms and finals are just as bad as the assignments, except the TAs are grading them so each TA has their own guidelines. At least they are take-home. The timeline of this class is also very messed up. Our first assignment is assigned on week 5. Our midterm is on week 7, the same day a homework assignment is due.  Our last assignment is due the day of finals, and also can be submitted hours after the final is due.  This class would work much better asynchronous. Do yourself a favor. Do not take this class. Take a different ethnic studies class. Take Asian-American studies or African American Studies or religion. If you decide to be brave and take this class, take it with friends, join group chats, and have a solid support system. You're going to need it.

Do Not. I repeat Do Not!! Take this class with Enrique Lopez. He is super unorganized. Made class mandatory but talks in tangents and doesn’t go over much material assigned. Class work is not hard but his grading scale is weird. Changes information often. He took a month to grade papers.No rubric. Your TA will make or break your grades.
Graded on 3 papers with Professor Felix and lectures were optional!

Avoid Professor Ariane Dalla Dea. She is the most disastrously unorganized professor I've ever had the misfortune of meeting. Without the TAs, I would not have done well in this class. There was no structure to the class or her lectures, and all her essays lacked a prompt or grading criteria. Also, we received our midterm and essay grades the day after the final, so you did not how you were doing until it was too late.

Readings are super hard and confusing, there are quizlets out there that do help for the exams though. Teacher himself is not useful, he just goes over his slides that he posts on iLearn. Took it with Paul Green. Trust ur TAs and ask them for help if you need and search google/quizlet for help :)
This class was a joke and an easy A!
For an ethnic studies class this class was pretty annoying. If your looking for the easiest A possible just take race.

This is not a class that you can get an easy A in. You actually have to do the readings in order to get some form of understanding on what's being asked. This is important as the take home midterms/final would be asking for specific examples from the readings. Be prepared to read at least 80+ pages a week, too.

Edward Chang; Easy A depending on your TA. He was very cranky and couldn't accommodate online. There's no doubt in my mind that he is passionate in what he does, but he has a really bad attitude towards the class. He has blocked people from zoom (to join his class) because they were a few minutes late. When he finishes lectures early, before we can ask questions or anything, he ends the meeting. He seems like he hates it online.

loved this class, professor, and TA so much. Tanaka and Lawrence Lan are very passionate about this class and it makes you more intrigued about asian american studies. i don’t think there was any homework, only one “midterm” project and one MC final. the project could be individual or group and you get to choose the topic. final was easy peasy. love love loved this class (took this summer 22)

Perez is a cool professor. Lectures are laid back and almost never have a lot of notes, if any. The midterm and final are in-class essays and you get to have some notes with you. Pretty interesting class overall

Krisha Hernandez was by far the most unorganized instructor I’ve ever had. Completely clueless and taught through YouTube videos. However, this class was essentially full credit, easy 100%, if you showed up to every class. Literally got 100 on the midterm just for turning it in on time. Absolute joke of a class
I took Gerald Clarke (online), very good speaker and the class was overall not hard. If you need a chill class, take this class with Professor Clarke.

Online Covid/Zoom time: Super easy I didn't even do the readings (they were long, interesting, but you didn't have to do them to pass) 1 research paper on a tribe TA Micheal super easy grader it's an easy glass and Prof Gerald Clarke was really interesting and teaches you a lot he's funny too

Really easy class (I took Gerald Clarke), just go to lecture even though you don't really have to since they're recorded, but the professor is such a good speaker and passionate about the subject, you're going to be missing out. Grades was based on a few discussions, 1 essay paper, and a final. 10 questions were given to you prior to the final, only 3 shows up on the actual final.

I took this class with Professor Leonard. As a first year who has 0 interest in linguistics and about ethnic studies in general, I won't recommend it as an "easy pass" class. Lots of reading needs to be done, a 6 page autobiography, and you WILL NOT PASS THE EXAMS if you didn't do any of the reading. Not necessary to attend lecture, but you're required to attend discussion. You'll definitely learn in this class, but if you're lazy like , good luck.
Easy class except for the final essay, absolute cakewalk for STEM majors looking to take an easy breadth class

Took this with Lucia during Covid Winter 2021 and it was a pretty easy class for honors. Everything was prerecorded and the discussion was just a discussion post every week. The class was on Canvas and really easy to navigate through. 2 mandatory office hour meets with your TA and a final paper (definitely start early). Final was open note and proctored on zoom and was pretty difficult so definitely take notes throughout the course.

The hardest section was Africa; all the music sounds the same so it makes it hard to differentiate between them for listening questions. The term paper is really easy just do it before the last week so you don't rush

Very easy class. There are weekly short answer responses based on documentaries or movies (about 1000 words), and she only requires that you turn in 5 of the 7 assigned. Final exam is take home and pretty easy if you refer to the readings. Discussion section weekly assignments are super easy, too, and Adam Tyson is the best TA! Professor Shiekh is kinda blunt and sometimes calls students out in a rude way, but the class is easy and lectures are fine.
Took it with Redak. This man expects too much out of you. STAY AWAY. Way too much memorization, exams are super hard and he does not care for his students.

Concepts aren't difficult, but heavy memorization. Reminds me of Bio 5B but insects and somewhat easier. Weekly quizzes and hw (basically another quiz) on ilearn based on this week's and last week's material. They're straightforward and open note. There were 3 mts instead of mt + final. Thought this was good bc I'd die if there was a fat cumulative final.  I'm a BCOE major who took this in winter 2021 with Stouthamer online as a filler class...do NOT do this. Registered bc I'm interested in insects and need 12 units but it became my least favorite class ever because of the professor. Lectures prerecorded and sucks the life out of me even at 1.5x speed.  He also grades based on bell curve, so that the 60-90 percentile students are in B range. Cool, right? No, not cool when you're at the 60% percentile with a 86% overall in class. Your grade heavily depends on how well your peers are doing. Rip gpa over some stupid grasshoppers.

Took this with Stouthamer during COVID, interesting material but professor is unorganized and does not care about the students. TAs are just as confused as you and Stouthamer does not provide a study guide for exams but expects a lot from his students - especially for an intro class. There is a lot of memorization and information is very specific. Grading scale is also all over the place, would not take again!!

I took this class in the spring 2022 with prof Redak, it is honestly heavy on memorization. You need to rewrite your notes a couple of time in order to memorizes them. But the material is very easy so just do not miss any lectures or discussion because you will fall behind. Overall, prof Redak makes the class fun.

I took this course with Boris Bar. Such a sweet and understanding professor so take it with him! It's a relative small class and that affects the structure of the class. Lecture and discussion are usually on the same day and attendance is mandatory. Lecture is early in the day and covers the basis of the bees and beekeeping. Although, the professor does upload the lecture slides, they are not helpful at all. I suggest going to lecture and taking notes because he is more of a verbal person. Discussion is solely based on student presentations about scientific articles. Since it is the only thing covered on that day, the presentations are a big part of your grade. However, the professor and TA know that the majority of the students who take this course are not CNAS majors. So they understand if someone has difficulty doing the reading and the presentation and won't hold it against you. For lab, you get to explore the bees habitat (which is the fun part) you get to suit up in a beekeeper suit and work with the bee hives. The TA, other beekeepers from the lab, and Bar and his wife (who is also an entomologist) are present to help students. At the end of the course, you get to make honey and beeswax candles to take him as goodies. 
There is a midterm that was take home. The final is cumulative, but it's not bad if you took good notes since the majority is just memorization. If not, there is quizlets online on this class that will definitely help you. Overall, a good class

Took it over the summer. Every day we were assigned 3-4 readings and we just had to respond to one of them. Each response was 5% of our grade. 8 different reading assignments, so 40% total is just responding to readings.  Participation was 25% and it was just chiming in every now and then when she asks a broad question mid lecture.  Final was 35% and was just a big essay.  I honestly did it the night before, and sprinkled in some relevant and modern happenings and aced the class.  Very Easy class, and takes out like 3 of your graduation requirements

I took this class with Carol Park. The class is super easy as long as you do the minimal work required. There is reading, but she goes over everything in class that you need to know for the midterm and final.  The midterm and final are mostly essay questions. Attendance is required, but you could probably miss a few classes and make up those days with active participation. However, it is not a good idea to miss any classes as she gives lots of hints as to what will be on the midterm and final. There is a 5-8 page research paper that is due a week before the end of the class, but she assigns it early and is usually pretty simple to complete if you are making continual progress. The professor is pretty interesting to listen to and class is not a bore, whether you agree with what she is saying or not even though the class is mostly her lecturing. (There are some instances where you talk in groups). If you have a breadth class requirement,  I highly recommend you take this class.

Took with Keith. It was entirely group based except for the final and biweekly reading journal. Professor was super forgiving with the grading and as long as you wrote something related to the material that wasn't total trash you'd usually get most of the points.

No live or recorded lectures, just slides that are basically quotes from the readings. The class is reading heavy but I did just fine skimming the readings. You make 3 posts on iLearn M-W-F which is a good portion of the grade. There were 4 analysis papers based on film/documentary (everyone received full credit for the last one due to COVID plus the uprisings). Professor Krebs was understanding and quickly adjusted to students needs. Make sure you manage your time well and you’ll do good.

Professor Carol provided lecture slides that basically summarized the readings for the week. Midterm is based on study slides that she provides. For creative assignment there is an option for 5 min video or regular essay. Term paper based on the two books make sure to read. Overall stay up to date with lecture and materials you should be good.

The class was boring honestly we had 3 hrs discussions. Make sure to participate, he takes notes on who spoke. Discussions are based on films (1-2 hours) & readings (~30-40 pages) assigned that week. You submit weekly 5 quotes which is like 30% of your grade lol. The final is a term paper based on your selection of films & readings. Reading is very important to do well in the class!! The professor is not understanding of students and kept promoting his book the entire quarter.
Jennifer Ramos is the best French professor, she is fantastic and tests reflect exactly what she teaches.

Take with Professor Ramos if you have a chance! She makes the learning environment very comfortable to participate, and is passionate about teaching. She is very funny and strives to make a genuine connection with each student. Lectures are hands-on and participation is vital, but exams are easy.

Professor Ramos is the best. The class isn't too bad, and shes very forgiving with grading and exams. Attendance is the only annoying thing, since it's 4 days a week and worth a big chunk of the grade lol. The workload is light and she is a really fun teacher.

Really easy class if you're good with language learning. Even if you aren't, it doesn't require much studying. Also try to take with Jennifer Ramos. She is very approachable and more kind than I can express here...she helped me with both educational and personal issues while I took her class, she will do anything to help her students succeed. Great teacher.

Christine Duverge is amazing! Her lectures are easy to understand but very interactive and you're able to practice a lot. The weekly homework assignments are very short and there is no class on the day the homework is due. Her exams are take home and are easy, too! She's understanding and kind and is one of the best professors in the French department.

Christine Duvergé is pretty nice overall, but she will be VERY critical of your writing and holds nothing back/does not go easy you, but when you follow her advice she will be very encouraging and your writing will definitely improve. Absolutely DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH DUVERGÉ IF: 1) you don't have a great grasp on French, because it will be a huge amount of work for you (this class is ALL writing and grammar), and/or if 2) you are not ready to basically have a damn therapy session in French, because she wants you to write about your deep feelings/someone who influenced your childhood in a super meaningful way + doesn't accept anything even somewhat surface level. It's annoying as hell honestly, though she says it's so she can "get to know us." There are ~1-2 page essays due about every other week and you will use them to construct most of a large final essay at the end. Even if you are ready to do both of the things listed, I don't really recommend this class....

I had Professor Clark for this class. I enjoyed the class because it talked about relevant topics such as climate change, disease, globalization, and other topics. BUT it was a lot of work and you needed to go to class in order to get the notes. He posts the slides on Canvas, but the slides only have the bullet points of the topics and he talks about the topics. So in order to get the full notes, you have to go to class. The course had a midterm, a final, quizzes based on reading during discussion, and a paper. The paper was fun-ish to write bc you wrote a story using the topics you learned in class with a bit of research/citation included. Overall, would recommend the class if you're willing to do the work.

Took this class with Gareth Funning. An introductory level course covering physical geology with daily quizzes in iLearn, and weekly readings outlined in syllabus. Professor grades rather harsh on exams, which are all in essay format. Lab final average score was about 68%, so if taking the course, be sure to begin mastering the concepts covered in lab early and often.

I had professor Gareth Funning. It's an easy class if you're actually interested in the topics being discussed, i.e. what's a rock and how's it made (how exciting). He doesn't expect you to memorize everything and only really cares about the concepts. There's required textbook reading and an online quiz due before every lecture. The online quizzes are super easy if you glance through the reading and he drops the five lowest quiz scores. There are three midterm essays and two finals essays with the lowest scoring essay dropped. He provides the prompts for the midterm essays a few days in advance (in addition to extra prompts that aren't included on the midterm). Finals prompts are not given in advance, but they are mostly past midterm/finals essay prompts. All essays have multiple prompts to choose from and you are allowed to bring unlimited handwritten index cards. Lab is fun if you like looking about rocks and thinking about how they're formed. As long as you understand and pay attention in every lab, the lab final shouldn't be that hard.
Gareth Funning grades the essays hella hard, not as easy of GE as it seems.

Avoid Gareth Funning. 3 online quizzes a week(4 questions each), 2 essay midterms, and an essay final - but you can use index cards for both. Big issue is the lab class, lectures are no problem. Lectures are done through prerecorded lectures. In class lecture is just going over quiz questions. The lab is horrible. After the info dump of a lecture, in the lab you are expected to be an expert in rocks and processes. After the first lab no one was getting more than a 70% on the labs. They are usually 14 pages long and you have to finish. They are also full of questions that need corrections or further explanations. Professor is super condescending and the lab TA was reluctant to give explanations on lab.

2021 Fall, took with Gareth Funning. FOR MIDTERMS: Essays. He gets you to bring notecards to exams and gives out essay prompts ahead of time, choose 3 out of 5 prompts and look through textbook to find stuff to write about, when exam comes just elaborate from your notecard. FOR FINAL: Essays. You can still bring notecards but he doesn't give out prompts. Bring your notecards from the 2 midterms and pray that there'd be a related prompt. FOR LABS: always, ALWAYS, ask TA if you can't identify. They'll tell you pretty much everything.

Tim Lyons is funny and all but he can be a real tool sometimes which made me not want to go to class. That being said, the class is a breeze if you're a STEM major because it's designed for non-math/science majors to fulfill a requirement. Even so, it's not terribly hard considering there is a generous curve.
The class is easy if you take excellent notes and make sure you note down whatever the professor speaks during lecture. They drop your lowest midterm as well.
Took it with Lyons. Not super complicated, just remembering definitions and concepts about geology. Not the most interesting imo but easy breathd credit. Lab was very zombie (busy) work.

Had Lyons Winter 2021, he was super sweet and cared a lot abt student success, provided study guides and extra credit opportunities. Attended lecture and labs and got an A. Not too hard if you put in minimal effort.

[COVID-19 SPRING 20] Had this class ONLINE with Aaron Martinez. This class is oriented more towards fossils and evolution instead of pure geology. Attending the Zoom lecture was not required and was more of an office hours. He uploaded multiple short videos a week, breaking down the information into smaller chunks so you don't have to sit and drudge through hour-long videos. There are a lot of different species, characteristics, and time periods to remember, but everything was open book so the class itself was not too hard.

Took this class with Heather Ford. Online weekly discussion, and HW assignments are worth the same as your midterm. Easy class because she gives tons of EC opportunities and plus, she drops your lowest HW, midterm, and quiz grade. HW takes about 1-2 hours, but it's just busy work. Final project in the end just tests your knowledge of the concepts in the textbook, and it's about the same as the HW. Some of the questions from the midterms + final were confusing because it wasn't something that was on the concept quizzes or HW, but other than that, this class is a good phys. science breadth that'll also boost your GPA

Professor Ford is super friendly and funny. Very approachable. She gives a ton of extra credit opportunities throughout the quarter. Probably >95% of what she puts on the tests are in the notes. Her style of notes are easy to understand - but the class gets much harder if you skip lectures. As long as you attend almost every lecture and study minimally you can get an A
homework and final project were super tedious but you could fail the midterms and still pass the class easily!!

Dr. Ford is awesome and genuinely cares about her students - she deliberately sets up the class so that it's not hard to get a good grade. Attendance is not mandatory, but lectures are very easy to follow. 1 concept quiz and 1 homework due each week on Monday and Friday respectively (all done through Canvas online), discussions are just helping us with the homework for that week as they can be a bit tedious sometimes. 2 midterms (non-cumulative, 40 questions each) and 1 cumulative final. Your lowest homework, midterm, and concept quiz grades are all dropped. Very low-stress and low-pressure but I honestly learned a lot. Great for an interesting and breather breadth class!
The material isn't super easy to digest but getting an A in her class was the easiest thing ever. Professor Ford is the sweetest woman out there. She wants her students to do well.

Took this with Barth during Covid Winter 2021. Honestly wasn't an easy A but if you do the work you can get it. Weekly quizzes are really easy but the weekly homework take a while and they're sometimes difficult because of how specific you have to be. The class uses WebGIS which created some technical difficulties for a lot of people. He uses Yuja proctoring for midterms and the final. He also drops your lower midterm grade and offered an 8% extra credit onto your midterm grade which was really easy to do. The final was cumulative and really hard.

Took it half online and half in-person. We had all exams online and professor ford was super understanding on that. There were 3 EC assignments and we can drop 2 lowest hw, 2 lowest quizzes, and one mid-term. She takes one midterm (15% of ur final grade), one final (15%), hws (20%), quizzes (15%), participation (15%), and a final project (20%). Overall you need to memorize a lot of stuff but some of them were common sense. The professor is a nice human being and knows how to teach, super-supportive. I ended up with an A+ and my friend had an A++ cuz those EC bumps lol.
Took with Heather Ford. 1 dropped homework, 1 dropped quiz, and 1 dropped midterm. Each quiz has two attempts. Just study a bit and watch the lectures.
Taken with Professor Douilly. Class not hard - lots of work though. Think HS science class. Easy A. Lots of intresting movies

Took this class with Professor Douilly. This class is a breeze if you take notes with the textbook and pay attention in class during lectures. Make sure you do well on the reading, movie, and weekly quizzes which is based on the material you learned that week. While there is no curve in the class, he has a modified grading format which makes it super easy to get a good grade. Also, this class is just really fun in general. Ended the class with an A+ without really trying.

Took Roby Douilly. Relaxed and organized teacher. Every week there is a short (5-10 question) reading quiz, a short (5-10 Q) movie quiz, and a short (5-10 Q) lecture quiz. There are 10 in total that line up with the weekly topic and movie. 2 lowest reading and movie quiz are dropped. No midterm or final, just 3 exams. Exam 1 and 2 are 50 questions, exam 3 is 100 questions (mixture of info from lectures and readings; will need green scantron). Exams are not comprehensive, they cover a couple topics and do not bleed over into the next exam. Before every exam there is a very helpful exam review sheet. He has every lecture recorded and if you miss something you can just ask him to post it to elearn.

typical geoscience class about earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanoes, etc. with movie elements in it in lecture. a couple 50 question scantron midterms and a 100 question final; weekly movie and book assignments, and quizzes on canvas
Starts easy and suddenly gets hard. Tests are way harder than the assignments so study even if you feel confident.

I found the class to be relatively easy if you have some basic understanding about how earthquakes work. I connected the class with real life (the info is interesting about living in SoCal). The class does get somewhat confusing prior the 2nd midterm but nothing too difficult. The exam midterm and final were similar to one another. Exam heavy weighted class.
Avoid Professor Ghosh at at costs. The course should’ve been easier than he made it to be but don’t get me wrong. He’s a nice guy and he knows his stuff, he just made it difficult.
pay attention in class because sometimes the most obscure things he says will be on the midterm
The class is super easy before the first midterm, then it suddenly gets insanely hard. Professor Abhijitat is super boring.
I took this class with Roby. The material gets sorta specific. The movies are ok but he gives an unnecessary amount of work.

I took the class Fall 2022 with Prof. Ghosh and he is a very kind professor that is willing to clarify any concepts you are confused on. He assigns reading from a textbook that he uploads on canvas but if you pay attention in lecture and discussions, you don't really need to read it. If your T.A is Shankho, he uploads a recording every week breaking down each question on the activity and basically giving you the answer, so you can easily get 100% on activities. There are two multiple choice midterms and he will drop the lower score and also a multiple choice final. You can find quizlets of the exam online. All the concepts are pretty straightforward and easy to understand but some of the math can get confusing but he provides all the formulas on the exam and you just need to plug in numbers. He also gave 50 extra credit points just to take a photo at an earthquake booth on campus and a photo of you doing duck, cover, hold. I thought it was a pretty interesting class and you can easily get an A.

Taken with Ghosh, who teaches dry but does what he can. For a lower-div, it goes a notch above in material than it should.  There are better options for breadth.  Easy B, moderate difficulty for A.  Cumulative and repeated questions on tests.  If you struggled in algebra I don’t recommend it.
Everything is on Tophat, slides, hw, etc. Basically AP Environmental Science in HS, but only the ocean parts. Pretty steep learning curve after the first midterm.

Kind of an easy class, if you focus during lectures. Take it with Professor Brounce if possible. There are two midterms, but she'll drop the worse grade of the two if you bomb either of them. Homework is super easy, and you don't really need the textbook at all because she uploads all of her powerpoints to Top Hat. She can be pretty helpful during office hours, too.

It wasn’t that rough. I took it with Maryjo Brounce. My first midterm I got a 68% (the average score) w no curve because I didn’t really take the class seriously. Studied for the next midterm and final and ended up getting an A in the class. She only takes one midterm (the highest one). It’s ust a lot of memorization and information, but not difficult to understand.
took it with Brounce. If you can memorize everything on the recap slides it guarantees a b high b ish. Its easy to get an A if you can memorize just the recap+ weird nitty gritty stuff

Oceanography with MaryJo Brounce wasn't too bad. The material isn't difficult to understand, but there can be a lot of material to memorize if you aren't keeping up. There's quizzes every friday during discussion and she checks attendance during lecture via TopHat questions, but they're extremely easy. She assigns homework but the homework is super simple too. I got an A in the class.
Took it with Gordon Love, everything is based on slides and open note, no need to go to lectures. The content was heavy though, with around 50 slides for every lecture.

FALL 2020: Had Gordon Love. Not mandatory to attend lecture but his poll questions that he does during his lectures help sometimes for quizzes and tests. Poll questions aren't counted towards anything; he just does it to help you. There were quizzes every week in your discussion sections on the previous week's material. All quizzes and exams were open note. Straightforward questions. Just make sure to know your stuff and stay on top of the material. Even though the class is open note, it takes a lot of time to search through the slides for the answers since his slides are quite heavy for every chapter/lecture. He drops your lowest 2 quiz scores and takes your best midterm score out of the 2. Final was cumulative and formatted like the quizzes and midterms. Overall, pretty easy class and material isn't that hard to understand.
Had this class with Gordon Love. Extremely straightforward class with tests based on lecture slides. Tests were open notes so control F is your best friend and pretty much all you need in this class.

Professor Wei Liu explains the material pretty well, GEO011 is comparable to GEO009 if you've taken that before. Tests were open notes and control F is pretty much the only thing you need. However as a warning, Professor Liu has a pretty strong accent so if you have a lot of trouble with accents you may need more assistance.

took online with professor allen, he's a little boring but his lectures are basically the textbook. 2 multiple choice exams, lowest score is dropped. first exam was very hard but after feedback from students he made it a bit easier.
The material is pretty difficult and the exams are hard. Not anywhere as easy as I thought it would be.

Professor Allen was super chill and posted both lecture slides AND recordings on Canvas. Attendance was taken through pollevs, and you only had to get 50% correct in order to receive credit. He gave us the choice between online, open-note exams vs. in-person, closed-note exams and we all chose online. All 3 exams were also multiple choice and I got A's on all of them just by ctrl+f-ing my lecture notes & occasionally the textbook (which has a free PDF available), and I didn't have to actually study for any of the exams. Only downside was that his voice was incredibly soothing and easy to fall asleep to, but overall he's a really knowledgeable and easygoing guy!
Tests not curved

Took this with Prof Schweiterman. It was an okay class. Since this was about the solar system I thought it would be easy but there’s a lot of information to retain. Take it if you like science and physics. First test was hard and I think he realized that cuz the second midterm and final were easier. Not the easiest breadth course out there but not the hardest either. Need to put in a bit of work to get an A. Weekly reading quizzes through Smartwork which means you need to buy the textbook online. Also weekly discussion sections. Lowest quiz was dropped. Exams curved.
German film class but everything is in English. Very few class requirements, nice movies, and the professor is super nice!

Professor King is my hero. I'm not a classic major but decided to take Ancient Greek as my foreign language, and only because he's such a cool professor. The class is very organized, and if you're willing to put in the work of doing all the assignments and going to class you'll do well. Definitely not an easy class per-say, but King makes it interesting and goes out of his way to help you succeed, plus he gives you lots of feedback so you can do corrections.

Ariane Dalla Dea is a mess. She is a poor lecturer. She also has a bad attitude and doesn't like being confronted. The class is worth a total of 100 points and it leaves little to no space for error. If it weren't for our TAs fighting for us, we would all have gotten lower grades.
prof ho is very disorganized across online and in person classes

Super easy class just pay attention and you'll be fine. There are 2 out of 3 essays you have to write so I would recommend writing the first 2 to avoid the last one just for the sake of burnout. Grading is pretty straightforward and most people pass with an A or B
Every other day is movie day, assigns 2 essays which are easy, teacher is very boring but she takes attendance in lecture

Easy breadth class, but the material is boring and Guenther does not post her slides online. The weekly assigned readings total around 40-50 pages consisting of several articles. The professor is very biased and shows favoritism in class.
Professor Riley amazing professor the grade is one movie analysis paper discussion points small quizzes in class and the final very easy basic vocab. Easy A.

Professor Guenther’s lectures were amazing. The class had weekly open book iLearn quizzes & piazza posts as well as 2 papers throughout the quarter. To do well in the class make sure to read the material max 20 pages weekly.

Professor Riley was an extremely engaging lecturer, which is important when over zoom. She was very attentive to the chat, and encouraged participation and interaction with the material presented in the lectures. Reading assignments can be dense and difficult, but the TAs will help!

Prof Guenther gave a lot of material each week but most of it was really interesting. We were assigned 3 papers but got to choose 2 of the 3 to complete. If you are interested in the subject then it is great but there is a lot of reading.

Winter 2023 all online with Prof. Juliann Allison. Asynchronous. This class was really easy. Weekly discussion board assignments that you can get done real quick. However, the instructions and syllabus for this class are extremely vague. There is a midterm and final. The midterm is a 30 question multiple choice test with T/F questions. But the questions are extremely vague. However, it is open note. No textbooks. Justen was my TA and he wasn't the best. Anytime I would ask him a question he was always like "ask the professor". It seemed like he did not know the guidelines to this class.

Took it with Prof Guenter Fall 2020. It was taught asynchronously, with 2-3 hour long recorded lectures. Easy participation points available, a learning worksheet due every week, and 3 opportunities to write 2 papers. (2 papers required, 3 prompts with flexible timing). No final! Reading/Viewing material was sometimes a lot. Highly recommend nonetheless for a very unique lower division course.

Wilcox was an amazing professor. This class is new so I recommend going to her office hours for help/to discuss. Not that hard though, but make sure you at least skim the readings. There's no tests, just 2 essays for midterms and one final document of short answers/a really short essay. And TAKE NOTES. Slides are uploaded so they're easy to make up if you miss, but either way make sure you take good notes.
READ. READ READ READ.
