If you take it with Professor Allison, just pay attention during lecture and go to discussion. If you go to lecture 85% of the time you get extra credit, but if you don't you lose points. You don't have to do the readings. Only read the ones that are mentioned during lecture. Also on exams she gives multiple questions and you can pick and choose the ones you want to answer.

Fall 2021. Professor Sasser's asynchronous class. The TA does most of the grading, very rarely I would actually hear from the professor. She just does the lecture videos. There are weekly quizzes, one pagers, and a final group project which sucks. I got stuck with procrastinators. No textbooks for this class. Pretty easy but the final project is your choice. I just don't think asynchronous classes should have group projects. Join the group me for this class.

Had Addison Davidove they were great with lecture and made class very interesting by having us doing discussion with one another ! Class consist of participation, midterm project on the lecture material, final reflection, and 5 page double space essay also on the course material ! Homework is only made to watch a video and read depending on the week!

Took it with Professor Allison, it was very straightforward- lots of readings and weekly discussion posts. There's an analytical essay (2-3 pages), final group project, project essay and no midterm/final exams. If you go to 85% of meetings you get full point for participation.

Took this class with Prof Womack. A good lecturer and made class interesting (Attendance mandatory btw). My only issue was her grading with papers and the final, which was 4 essay questions. She is tough, which I am sure is great for majors that need to write a lot, but I was taking this course as Depth. She was not a fan of my writing to say the least. If you are looking to take this class for a Breadth/Depth requirement, don't. You will find easier A's somewhere else.

Super easy class. Mostly is just a class to help ease you into the recources available on campus and help you set up goals you want to acheive while at UCR. There are short essay assignments, but they are all opinion essays that you can BS in an hour or two.
Boring with McGarry, but easy class overall. A paper, midterm and final.

Brian Lloyd taught the class and the entire grade was 50% midterm and 50% final, each test is 10% multiple choice on the reading, 10% multiple choice on lecture, and 80% essay that is turned in on test day 5 pages. His grading is very difficult and no rubric is ever given. Extremely monotone and enters tangents frequently. Asked my friends after the class was over what they got and highest grade was a B. Would not take the professor again.

Took this class with Professor Gudis and it was a breeze. She has readings every week that are time consuming, but super interesting. She is incredibly flexible and understanding, so if you have trouble just reach out. We had weekly quizzes, a midterm essay and a final essay. They all had due dates, but you would not be penalized for being late. That being said, you really have to discipline yourself because otherwise it all piles up at the end and is overwhelming. Overall though, easy class and really enjoyable if you stay engaged. Gudis also helped me to get my internship, so she's a really cool person to make a connection with.
This was such a fun class! I took with Gudis, she's so awesome. The material is genuinely so interesting, and this is coming from a non-history major.
3 required essays about 3-4 pages long and a final. Fair amount of reading but easy to do. Brennan is a must have professor at UCR.
Brennan is a stickler for attendance. Easy class with only 3-4 papers based on prompts he gives you.

If you have Lehmann you are super lucky, he is a really nice. Lecture and readings are MANDATORY. Don't read them or go to lecture you will fail. His quizzes are straight big concepts from the readings and from his slides. If you go to class and do the readings its impossible to fail. Easy A
You actually have to buy 7 books and read them all no midterm just a final and a 7 page essay and participation was 30% of your grade. I took it with Michels

Chrissanthos: Great lecturer, story format, no slides, so take your notes on a laptop. 2 MTs (short answer/fill in blank Q's from lecture and Q's from TA) 1 Final (cumulative, short essays) 1 Term Research Paper on topic of choice. TA/discussion matters! Some TAs grade hard on exams and easy on paper, and vice versa.
had chrissanthos, if you have a nice TA you’ll be fine, but make sure to study for the midterms and finals! a lot of memorization
Chrissanthos, story type lecture that is interesting. Two midterms, final, term paper, and discussion material. Get Engin the TA super nice and not too much work. Just pay attention in class.

Class was easy, overall. There were some aspects on the second midterm that you had to read from the textbook (first midterm didn't really rely on the textbook) but other than that, tests are fair. Really depends who your TA is as they will be the ones grading everything in this class. Also, don't really depend on writing your notes if you have Chrissanthos. His lectures are more story-telling and he doesn't upload his notes.
One essay the entire course. The midterms and final were pure memorization. Easy stuff.

No lecture slides, just pictures and a general outline of the lecture for the day. It's easier to take notes on a laptop if you're a fast typer. He'll talk out loud in a storyteller fashion and you half to copy down every single thing he says. Unless you want to read the "required readings" that aren't really necessary to get an A.

Chill class. Had Professor Chrisanthos, who just told history like it was a story. I just took notes on my laptop, kinda like a transcript and highlighted things he emphasized. Exams were fill in the blank and free response. There’s no test bank so I’d get the list of term down as best as I could. I wish I didn’t read the main textbook as much and read the YJC more. TA’s make the quizzes so it’s really up to who you have. No hw, just a term paper on any topic within the time frame of the class.
Video lectures were easy to understand. Midterm, Paper, and Final. Midterm was fill in the blank and short answer, and the the final was 5, 1 page essays.

There was a five page research paper and a test that consisted of writing 5 one page essays in 3 1/2 hours. There’s no small assignments, so the only things that count towards your grade are the research paper, two tests, and the final. If you’re not a great test-taker, this is a very difficult class.

Definitely don't take for breadth req, although Chrissanthos knows what he's talking about. His lectures are kind of aggravating since he doesn't have slides and just kind of storytells the lectures. The TA you get really determines your grade for this course, and if you get Richard he's super nice. Two midterms (long answer & short answer), one term paper, and one essay final. Lots of memorization, and you'll definitely need the textbooks for this class. Not hard, but not an easy A either.

Chrissanthos is a lovely professor but if the format of the class is not to your particular learning type( he will post a lecture video with an outline) it's probably better to take HIST020 because it is much better formatted to online classes(exams are fill in the blank and short answer and no one likes free response for some reason). If possible take John as your TA, he's not only a great teacher but his questions are very fair and similar to Chrissanthos. You can get away with just reading the book and can get a C but getting an A watching lectures does actually help! do have to read the various primary source parts of the textbook but it is not too hard to do outside of class.

I took this course with Professor Chrissanthos online. He had asynchronous lectures twice a week, which were only around 30-50 minutes each. They were pretty interesting, but he doesn't have any slides so it can be hard figuring out how to spell the names of cities or people from that time period. The grade is made up of your discussion section, two midterms, one term paper, and one final. The midterms were okay, but only because of the way they were graded. It's basically 10ish questions from the professor, which are either fill in the blank or ask you to write five bullet points in response. Then, there are a few questions from your TA. Honestly, some of the questions had nothing to do with what we learned in the lectures, but the TA seemed to grade easy so it was okay.. Next, as for the term paper, its 5-7 pages and you can't really use sources from the internet (history.com, etc), which is a little difficult. Overall, the class is okay, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it unless you're super interested in the time period.
Not an easy A, you actually have to watch the lectures and read the book.. sigh

I took this course with Stefan Chrissanthos in the Winter of 2022. While this course wasn’t too difficult, there was a lot of work. In total, there are 2 midterms, 1 cumulative final, and a term paper. While the midterms/final were open notes, there is almost no extra time during the exam to look at them. A lot of students were not able to finish the exams in time. However, if you have a good TA that grades easy, you’ll be just fine. If you’re taking this as a Breadth course, I suggest you take another history course. I finished the class with an A+.

Love Professor Chrissanthos. His lectures are really fun and he does it in story format. Make sure you go to lecture!!!! He does not post lecture notes or slides so you have to go (or at least have a friend who can help you out). If you go to lecture and do a little bit of studying before the midterm and final you'll be fine. Midterm is free response format and the final is essay format but both were relatively easy...straight from the lectures.
Chrissanthos - lectures are interesting but the exams are hard

I had Chrissanthos for Spring 2023 and it was actually so much work. There's so much to memorize and he does not post any notes or slides; he kind of just talks slowly during lecture so you have time to write everything down. This class is also extremely exam heavy so make sure you study. There's 2 midterms & our final is 3 one-page essays that we only have an hour & 20 mins to complete. We are also assigned a 5-7 page term paper. Also TAs matter!!!! I got lucky and had Carlos & he was super lenient with the grading but I heard other TA's grade harsher.

Graninger - 75% of your grade is your exams (there are 2 1-week long midterms & a final). Final was easy--especially if you looked at his study guide since his study guide is literally the final! But the midterms can be a little difficult depending on your TA. The other 25% is participation in discussion and these points are rewarded based on your TA... I felt like the class wasn't structured very well and the grades were kind of arbitrary but it might be because it's the first time that he taught this specific honors class?

I took this class with Dr Randy Head online and he made the class very easy and fun to follow. Essay prompts were easy enough and my TA (Jordan if you're reading this thank you!) helped a lot during office hours to help develop my ideas. I'm not a history major so I was pretty worried going into this class but honestly the professor and the TAs alleviated a lot of my concerns.

Took this class with Prof Eacott.  Grading is largely determined by how picky your TA is with your essays/midterms.  Please keep in mind there are multiple essays and many assigned readings for this class.  It isn't extremely difficult but not a cakewalk either.
Take Patch if possible. He's a very fun lecturer and his TAs aren't ridiculously difficult graders. If you put in a decent amount of effort, you'll get an A.

Took with Professor Patch; he was a really friendly guy that had a very enjoyable lecture style & demeanor which made the class easy to absorb. It's not a hard class, just a lot of writing. Your assignments & exams will consist solely of essays.
Lots of reading, two assignments (fairly easy), both midterm and final were in class essays. Professor doesn't upload PowerPoints on iLearn so make sure to go to lecture.

For Eacott, make sure you do the readings and attend lecture. There was a lot of readings, but manageable if you do them regularly.The final consists of short responses and two essay questions. The class was interesting, but my TA graded pretty intensely.

Professor Eacott made the lectures really engaging, and does not post the slides online, but going to lectures anyways helps a lot because he gives verbal hints on what's on the midterm/final. There is 3/4 books you need and weekly readings, but it's manageable if you can schedule everything. I procrastinated all readings til finals week, and I passed but with a C, so this class isnt the hardest but if you put in effort it can be fairly easy. Also, your TA plays a large role on your grade because they are the ones that grade your paper. Go to office hours and show you care about passing, and undoubtably it will boost your grade.

Hughes won't put slides online and themes the class in a kind of odd way but isn't bad as a professor. No tests, just in-class essays. Reading-heavy but you don't have to read everything in full. Almost everything is really based on opinion, you can take a little bit of historical fact and as long as it seems thoughtful and you justify it, you can say any bullshit you want.
Jennifer Hughes...2 midterms (2 in class essay each exam)....Take home final. Please don’t take this woman. She’s only here to boost her ego.

professor hughes = a lot of reading! the class is made up of 3 midterms and 1 final, no tests, all essays based on the readings in class. 2 in-class essays, the last 2 are online. she puts up the lecture slides online, but she doesn't put up all of the slides (ie. you have to go to class to see some key facts/slides), she also gives you potential essay questions in-class and she'll choose one for your midterm. not the hardest class to take, but it will require a lot more effort

Took it with Prof Hughes, she treats the class like a W class; the midterms and final are all essays. There are 3 midterms on books and articles that you have to read; she doesn’t talk about them in class or give you enough supporting evidence during lecture. She didn’t really know what she was teaching. Half the class was either asleep or just didn’t come to lecture. Discussion’s really important, talk to your TA’s and go to office hours because they’re the one’s grading the essays. Class is easy but she’s difficult.

had Hughes for lecture, gives 3 midterms and 1 final, all essays. each midterm is based on a book she has you read and it's very boring if you don't like history. If you get a ta who is an easy grader you'll be fine with a decent amount of effort. try not to fall behind on readings as the midterms and final are based on what you read.

Took with Patch. Class consists of one essay (based on readings), a midterm (IDs and an essay), a final (IDs and 2 essays, one based on the entire course and another based on 2nd half of course). There's a geography quiz in discussion towards the beginning of quarter. Lecture was pretty fun, but the notes he posts on iLearn are pretty vague so you have to pay attention in class. He doesn't have slides, just kinda rambles on about history. Discussion sections and mandatory and you need to do the readings to participate. THERE IS SO MUCH READING IN THIS CLASS. There's 3 assigned books, weekly assigned readings on iLearn, and weekly assigned readings from the textbook. You will be reading every single week. If you get behind it's hard to catch back up.

Robert Patch explains everything you need in lecture, so go to his lectures and record them. His outlines are good, but all the details are in the lectures. Lots of readings and essay due at the end of the quarter. Prepare for essays for the midterm and final as well

Attending lecture is only necessary for the first half up til the midterm for Patch. Afterwards I just used my notes from discussion. My TA (Emily) was great though idk how useful the other TAs are. It's useful to make a document of all the readings and a summary of them. In general though look for patterns in the history, he'll point some out too.

It's not a hard class but god, it is a lot of reading. I took it with Professor Robert Patch and I did not learn anything. His class is really disorganized, so try to get a good TA. The reading was basically 100+ pages a week. This class is not for lazy people. But I got a B in the class without managing to do any of the readings. The tests are not multiple choice so they are purely essay based. It is do-able, but stressful. Honestly I would take HIST010 if I were you because this class requires you to spend a lot of $$$ on books

[COVID-19 ERA: SPRING 2020] Took this class with Eacott. I was honestly dreading this class because this was the only lower-div class I had to take with my other upper-div classes, but Eacott made this class really interesting. He was also VERY understanding because of COVID-19 and the entire quarter being online. No exams; just two papers, lots of readings (which I will admit I forgot to do a lot of lol) and a big final project (in groups). Papers can be hard depending on how picky your TA is. If your TA is Clayton, then you're good to go, he's a super chill TA. The second paper was made optional and we got an extension on the final project due to #BLM. Highly recommend Eacott. Class isn't difficult, but definitely don't forget about this class either. Also, Eacott is very handsome :)
Take with prof downs if you can! During Winter 2021, just weekly readings and listening ti podcasts. No midterms or finals, just a book review final which was 6-8 pages

Don't take this with Eacott. He's very charismatic but this class was unnecessarily difficult for an intro level History class. Lots of required readings. If you're interested in the subject I say go for it because Eacott was pretty cool but otherwise look for an easier option.

Took it Winter '22 with Prof. Jennifer Hughes. The class itself was not all that difficult, it was actually the first time I found a history class somewhat interesting. You read 3 books (I did more skimming than reading tho and was fine), and you write an essay about each book. The hardest part about this class was having to deal with the prof. She would post everything late, assign things Fri or Sat night and make it due 8am Mon, and literally banned technology from the class (meaning we had to take handwritten notes & actually buy the books). Lectures were absolutely useless, but are still required. Everything you need to know will be learned in discussion.

I had Dr. Albert Dorsey, a guest lecturer and he's chill and kind. Midterm was a couple of multiple choice questions, fill in the blank, and 3 short essays. I think how you do in the class depends on the TA since they grade everything. Homework is just reading chapters in the textbook. One actual assignment is an analysis of a book. Your grade is made up of 25% of attendance to discussion, 25% midterm, 25% final, 25% book review.

I have professor Nicolette Rohr. She is a good professor. You need to be in class at all times because it is an oral class with absolutely no text book. She never repeats anything. You can't take pictures or videos of lectures. The slides are not posted. I got an A- on the essay and the midterm. Honestly I had one of the highest grades on both. It's harder than it should be for a breadth, but it's not bad. Discussion is really chill but mandatory. She gives a study guide with what will be on the test (exact questions)-she picks from them but they are all written tests. 2 essays, 1 midterm, 1 final + discussion.

Professor Hawkins is one of the BEST professors at UCR. I was never much of a history fan but the way he lectures feels like he is reading you a story, it's so engaging! 2 Midterms, both essay questions, which are really simple since the answers are in his lectures. One 4-5 page paper, which was really easy as well. Laid back class, no traditional tests, & took it asynchronously.
Lots of reading and essays. Midterm/finals were short answer/essay questions.
I barely went to lecture (about half before midterm, twice after) and I got out with an A-.
Do the readings, David Biggs’ lectures are a mess but go anyway, papers were graded really lax but actually put some effort in and you’ll do great

dont take this class this professor assigns 30 pages per lecture reading.. insane and has a super strict TA that grades like crazy i did all of the readings and he gave me a F. im super pissed rn and waiting for my response why i got this grade.

Be careful with the TA you pick. I had Prof. Hawkins and TA David Shanta and he was much more tedious when it came to grading. Go to office hours with your TA to figure out what they want since they grade everything (1 midterm 1 final 1 paper) very interesting material and loved the assigned readings! Best history class to choose in my opinion. Hawkins had a young spirit and kept us interested especially with his jokes

Professor Juliette Levy's class is SO easy. There's NO EXAMS, only small writing assignments. The lectures are asynchronous and are in the forms of short podcasts (that she provides transcripts for). I hate history but this class is actually really fun I'd definitely recommend. Also a lot of extra credit.

Took it with Hawkins, he's a really nice professor! Your grade is composed of 2 midterms, a final, and discussion section. Each midterm is 2 long essay questions, and the final is based off the books you read in class, not lecture material. Took it online: asynchronous lecture, synchronous discussion. I feel like your grade depends on your TA since they do the grading and some might be more strict with their grading than others.

(Taken online during Winter 2021) This is probably the easiest history course you can take since there are no exams. There are only quizzes that are extra credit, which can boost your grade up to 10%. There's also short weekly podcasts that you have to write comments for, but are graded on completion. Most of your grade depends on the decade assignments, which are short 400+ word essays. The prompts were sometimes confusing, but it didn't take up that much of my time to write. There were 4 of these assignments and it is graded by your TA, so you grade kinda depends on how nice they are and if you basically follow the rubric, it shouldn't be too hard to do well on these essays. Apparently, there was supposed to be one decade assignment per week (pre-COVID), but she changed to biweekly assignments to make it easier for students in the pandemic. She also made the final optional for us. It was a relatively easy A class for most people as long as you complete all the assignments, come to discussion, and do all the extra credit quizzes.

Took with Professor Levy. Instead of lectures, she posts podcasts with transcripts and has u listen to those. They mostly assign busy work and there's A LOT of extra credit. There's one final paper in the end but u pretty much work on it throughout the quarter. For grades, u either get a check or no check for the assignments. It depends on how closely u follow the prompts and if u did what they were looking for

2021 online fall. Dr. Levy is nice, 10 points of EC!!! No tests at all. The extra credits are merely quizzes but easy contents (you can google for the answer). I get 50% on my final project but still have a A(95) on the overall grade.

Asynchronous with podcast as lecture, long assignment every other week leads up to the big essay for the final , you either get full points or 0 so as long as you put in some effort into your work, you'll pass with an A.

Super easy class with Juliette Levy, the TA Betul was a picky grader which was annoying, but the class was easy extra credit was available (can boost up to one full grade) you would listen to weekly podcast and do a little review on it and every two weeks there was a writing assignment pretty easy class

Took it with Professor Biggs. He's chill and passionate on 20th-century World History,  but his readings (all pdfs) and lectures are hugely overloaded. Participation does matter for discussion sections and also recommended for attending lectures as well. 1 Paper, 1 midterm, 1 family project (paper & artwork), and 1 final are heavily based on the readings, lectures, and historic movies (one of them is Godzilla). All of them are graded by TAs, so your grades depend on how well you know and relate to the reading materials and the professor's themes for 20th-century World History. You have to keep track with the syllabus for vocabs and specific reading questions for each week if you truly want to understand and ace this course. Take this course if you're comfortable related to or you know more about 20th-Century World History than other history courses.
Took with Leal. Two quizzes with a week to do each. The short essay was graded relatively easily.

Fall 2022 with Levy. Really nice prof, no scheduled lectures just three podcasts to listen to weekly. Lecture comments are extremely easy, 10% extra credit thats really easy to earn, research assignments were a pain but wasn't that bad, we got the option to opt out of the final due to the strike so the class wasn't bad. Prob a 5 difficulty if I had to do the final

Winter 2023 all online with Prof. Downs. Super easy class. Weekly podcasts and short responses every week. Two essays based off two books that you choose. Lynda was my TA she is super nice, a fair grader, and very helpful when going to office hours and emails. I learned so much from this class and it was not boring at all.
Jordan Downs is AMAZING. Instead of lectures, he does weekly podcasts that are entertaining and easy to digest. The 2 term papers are pretty easy and the TAs are super helpful.
Just take the online version
Lectures delivered in form of podcasts, one 10-question quiz each week (multiple choice, easy), one written assignment - includes research, final project (a paper) in place of final.

first 2 essays are pretty easy, final prompt was a nightmare
Dana Simmons is a good lecturer

I think we had around three essays, a midterm, and a final exam. I took this class in the Spring Quarter and had Professor Tomoff. Seemed like a good guy but his lectures were meh, so I ended up going to class around 4-5 times total (UV theater didn't help at all). Regardless, there's a lot of reading that goes into the class that you SHOULD do, and the discussions are pretty good. Good luck with the essays, as the TA's are really stingy with the stuff you write.

DO NOT TAKE! If you can take English 1C. The essays are a nightmare. You do not really understand what heck you are writing about. You have to go to workshops that only help you with your structure and not the essay itself. The prof. will not help just tell you what guidelines are and move on. Your TA will only help you to a certain point and not really explain to you exactly what you need help on.

I took it with Dana Simmons. She's a very knowledgeable professor who clearly knows her stuff. She does a great job in lecture and truly cares about the students and is super approachable. The TAs are generally knowledgeable and do what they can to help. One midterm and one final that are both just ID terms (choose 5 of 7 she gives you). Three essays, they can be kinda tricky. Required writing workshops. Get ready to read a whole bunch and spend a lot of time outside of class.

really easy!! about three essays and theyre phrased weird but theyre very easy prompts. the in class midterm though is very simple its define 5 terms and give an example. Simmons is cool to!! david is the best TA

Had Professor Tomoff, it's fairly easy material to digest but you particularly get stuck during essays. For Spring2020 online classes, he uploaded lectures to a google drive, three each week. You also have about 3 readings for each lecture, I suggest you not to read all and consult the Midterm/Final and Paper prompts that are uploaded early to know what to actually read. There are 3 essays, midterm and final. Midterm and final exam are the same format, he gives you 3-6 prompts and he chooses which one you'll have to complete. For the midterm, he gave us about 24 hours to complete and upload to iLearn whereas, for the Final, he'll give you 36 hours to complete and upload. The essay prompts are broad and hard to grasp at times so I suggest you attend a workshop to better understand it, my TA was also broad on what he expected so it made it worst. No memorization needed for anything since everything is open book/notes!

Took it with Professor Samuel Fullerton on Henry the 8th and his wives during Winter '23 . The professor was chill and laid back but pretty lecture heavy in terms having to be very attentive to listening carefully since his slideshows does not cover any bullet points and homework assignments were just to read ! The class is based on 3 essays that are based from the homework reading assignments and a fun part of the class was watching a performance video from Six the Musical and watching the 1st episode of Showtime's The Tudors ! Also as a piece of advice do carefully proofread essay since he does grade them slightly strict .

Professor Trafzer is a really passionate dude that loves his history. He makes the class interesting and always tells stories about his experiences with Native Americans. The overall class is really interesting and taught well. TA Amanda is super helpful for preparing for essays and exams. All the exams are open book, so make sure to take good notes. There's two essays on readings, but honestly I read 10 pages of both the books and I got an A on both papers. This is a really good class if you need an easy A, just be prepared to take notes because Trafzer's slides aren't very detailed

Asian American History with Prof. Asaka (Fall 2020). She’s really cool and makes the class easy. Weekly mandatory discussions but asynchronous lectures. It’s really really interesting but make sure you read the readings before the lecture if you want to get the participation points and talk. Skimming over them works too but know the general idea. Weekly discussion posts based on the readings due the night before your discussion,  but you only have to do 5/10 and a final paper.

History of Cartography - the entire class is reading and writing but the writing assignments aren't hard. The required book is pretty cheap, $20, and the rest of the readings are online. The course load for the readings can be a lot sometimes. The writing assignments are summary and analysis and the professor is willing to read drafts and help before the due date. She drops the lowest score for the five writing assignments. As long as you go to the class and keep up with the writing assignments, its really easy.
Super easy class for history majors, just keep up with the work, and it is an easy A. Most local libraries have the World War Z book online so just make an account to access it.
It's a mandatory workshop for History majors. Take Professor Levy online. Easy assignments even if they're tedious. Easy A.

Took the class Fall 2020. Online. Professor Lentacker was very reasonable. Instead of meeting our scheduled times, he separated the class into 4 discussion sections where we meet only once a week. No exams but there was a final paper and other writing assignments throughout the quarter.

taken with Hackel Summer 2022, who would refuse to record any lectures due to his inexperience with technology, but overall the course was very easy-- pay semi-attention to class, his slides are mainly pictures and he goes pretty fast when he talks and there is a final about lectures (all multiple choice, and the answers are pretty obvious if you pay a little attention to class and take notes). there are also 2 readings that I literally just found reviews for and wrote the short essays based on the reviews and got 95+ scores; you don't even need to read the entire book to achieve an A overall in the class. there are also sometimes some in-class writing activities you would complete for points since participation is not graded and class is not recorded
Pretty easy, almost always gives out A+ for minimal effort, 3 multiple choice tests are open everything
Ramps up in difficulty towards the end, papers are a joke but I have no idea how they grade the papers (fall 2020) so just do the 1 reading a week
Very easy upper division breadth course. Took in fall 2020 with Tofigh. 3 multiple choice tests, 2 essays plus a final essay
Class grade was based on three multiple choice tests and two essays. As long as you read the required readings and went to lecture it was pretty easy to get an A.

Took with Tofigh. People complaining are probably because they don't follow his essay instructions. If you want to ace his essays, literally open a google doc and just spill all your knowledge on the subject that comes DIRECTLY from the reading or the powerpoints. Dont use any fancy stuff or fluff or anything that doesn't come from the reading or powerpoint. Easy A. Study powerpoints for tests, test material comes straight from powerpoint/lecture material
Got an A- with zero effort, just do well on the multiple choice exams to get an A. The midterm and final are essay-based that focus on mentioning all the key points.

Took it with Tofigh Heidarzadeh. He's super passionate about it so I would recommend going to lecture bc he makes it interesting. But even if you skipped all the lectures it's still an easy A. He's the only teacher I've had that said not to cite your sources, he actively told us to not cite your sources. The essay prompts are based on the book anyway so I guess there's no point in citing it since he always know what your source is but I just thought it was funny.

3 multiple choice tests, midterm and final (all open note btw) are essay based which sounds a little bit scary until you realize that there is no deep analysis at all, you literally just answer content knowledge based questions. Don't use Google for these essays though, get the content straight from the reading and the powerpoints because thats what they look for. Personally I never really showed up to lecture or did the readings and got by really easily with an A just using my resources during the tests since you're allowed to use any material. If you need the extra points Professor Tofigh offers a grade bump with iEval (i think it was 10% extra on the 3rd mc test).

Professor was Tofigh. No homework for this class, required readings from textbooks that to be honest you don't need to read until the final. 3 tests total which are multiple choice. Only the third one is more difficult. Honestly, don't even need to go to lectures since the powerpoint slides are super helpful.

took the class with a professor with a really complicated name. winter 2022. Not bad at all. only reason to go to class is for pollev. there are assignments total: 1 essay, 1 mcq, midterm(essay), 1mcq, then final(essay and mcq). everything was online and we had to take it with a lockdown browser. very simple and easy class, you dont have to read the "required readings" just skim the slides a week before each tests and youll be fine. its all open note so you can download the slides and look at them as you take the tests. only struggle is finding the motivation to go to class so you can do the pollev.

Taken with Heidarzadeh Winter 2023, there were PollEv questions at the last 10-15 mins of class that counted towards participation points, which essentially made up 15% of your grade. If you did not show up to the lecture in person, just pull up PollEv on your device and wait for the questions to pop up. The PollEv questions were also what made up a majority of the midterm questions, so knowing the right answers to the questions was important. The essay questions/exams were not difficult nor lengthy, just make sure to address ALL subquestions when writing the essay, and do not go over the word limit. The TAs would be the ones grading the essays, so pray you get a nice TA. Overall, though this class gives you no HW, it was a lot of busy work during exams season, and an easy A.
Extremely easy. The essays are 1 page long, and the written exams require you to write a few paragraphs about the subject.

Dr. Tofigh Heidarzadeh I thought it was kinda difficult, but then again I'm really bad at history. Everyone else thought it wasn't too bad. Making flashcards to study the definitions are really helpful. One midterm, which is written in blue book, and two tests, which are scantron. Just study the given definitions and clicker questions and it shouldn't be too bad. Final is also bluebook. Two essays on various topics. Make sure to be detailed on the essays, everything is in the textbook or available online so make sure to include the important bits.

I had Professor Tofigh Heidarzadeh. Very good professor/lecturer, very engaging and very friendly. The class has clicker/attendance which are worth 10% of your grade so be warned. The most important thing in this class is understanding KEY WORDS / BUZZ WORDS. In his essay/midterm instructions or even when he reiterates several times in lecture, he will tell you to follow a certain essay format (introduction, 1-2 paragraphs, conclusion, etc) but do not listen to him. The key is memorizing KEY WORDS to do well on the essays/midterm/final. For example, if a prompt asks about energy changes in the industrial revolution, you only need to say "energy changed from wood, wind, water to iron, coal, steam" and that's basically 20% of your grade awarded to you. You do not need to be exceptionally formal; this is not an English class.

Took it with Tofigh Heidarzadeh. Two essay tests, and two take-home essays. Overall, this class is like any other history class: boring, a lot of memorize, and annoying. The midterm and final; you're expected to memorize more than 10 prompts, and you're basically expected to write paragraphs about those subjects. The subject material in this class is sub-par.
What really makes this class either suck hard or easy-mode are the graders; you can have all the keywords needed for a prompt, and end up with a D on your paper all because you forgot one keyword that wasn't even part of what the prompt was asking you for. If you're looking for an upper-division DEPTH course, don't take this class. It's a trap.
Honestly don't know why people are complaining about this class, really easy essays and multiple choice tests and everything is open note (might be different when we're back in person though).
This is a BS class. GPA booster. 2 essays, 2 presentations, just show up to the discussion.

Took this online. Cardullo is the professor who gives the lectures which are very insightful on real world problems and important things about Riverside, so it's more interesting than English classes, but the TA grades everything including essays and participation. Lectures were asynchronous and we had to submit a google form reflection on them which were simple, but discussion with TA met once a week. We had to read 2 books and had discussions on those/lectures each week and also had student led discussions. I struggled in this class because I'm a reserved person and found it hard to participate since a lot of honors students are well-spoken and always have something to say. I also dislike writing essays, so that was a struggle to me too but there were 4 essays of increasing length. I averaged A- on the essays(which was about the class average of each essay) and somehow ended up with an A in the class, so I'm guessing most people get A's in the class or at least half the class does as long as you participate, show up to discussion, and do decent on the essays. If you struggle with writing, they offer lots of help/resources. Don't procrastinate on the essays, so you can get advice/feedback from TAs and other writing helpers. I also never got the score for my participation/last essay, so I'm not sure how they grade those lol, but I didn't participate every time, I only made sure to participate in the student led discussions, but it probably depends how picky your TA is. If you're good with participating in class and don't struggle that much with writing, then this class should not be too bad.

I believe Professor Cardullo is the only professor to teach this class (I could be wrong). The class was pretty straightforward as long as you kept up with the work. The probably most difficult aspect of this class is participating in the discussions since class participation is part of your grade. So if you're an outspoken person, this class should be really easy but if you are more quiet, you need to push yourself more to speak.

Dr. Ricky's Punk and Post-Punk Culture seminar was incredible! Most of our time was spent discussing the material, and the professor was amazing at facilitating the discussion and making everyone feel included. The grade is mostly based on participation but there was one midterm and a final project which is your choice (I wrote a paper but some people made 'zines, for example). I had a wonderful time in the class and would definitely recommend it to anyone.

Had Link Fall 2020 for Literary Response to Natural Disasters. He's a very sweet person, definitely one of the best professors I've ever had. But his class is very very very reading heavy and I spent around 3-5 hours doing the reading for each class. He gives a few questions before each class which you will be going over, which I highly recommend working on beforehand. You have an essay due every week which are pretty easy, and he drops your lowest grade. But I didn't my grade the whole quarter until after the quarter was done which was nerve wracking. You have no tests but there is a final paper which you can ask him to go over, which I highly recommend.

This is magic realism, and it is taught by one teacher, Prof Tyler. I know this is one of the newer mandatory honors seminar classes, and it was probably the most stressful classes I've had to take. Prof Tyler liked to rant about off-topic subjects in her mandatory seminars, but that wasn't what made me hate this class. She assigned annotating homework weekly, but never posted it on time and when asked about it, ended up extending the date to weeks after it was originally due. This happens almost every week. She never put in any grades for the annotations, and all that was just mysteriously factored in to our final letter grade at the end of the quarter. (I still don't know what kind of annotations she expected out of us bc she provided literally 0 feedback). The midterm was take-home, and had around 10-11 questions that required paragraph responses with a short essay at the end of the exam. At the end of the quarter, she got rid of the final and instead posted an essay for us to do. She did not provide the promised feedback on everyone's essays until a few days before it was due. If you do end up taking her class, just know that your final grade will be a toss-up, because even if you ask her questions and go to her office hours, the prof will not give you a clear answer about anything.
Attendance is required. Professor Corey was the best professor I have had so far. Do the work and you'll get an A.
Fairly easy if you are able to memorize vocab and grammar structure. All tests are free response except one section of the final. Essays are required but you have to turn a rough draft before.

Professor Tinozzi Mehrmand. Spring 22. Easy class. All online. Requires cameras on during lecture. Make sure you participate. Attendance and participation matters. You learn a lot about Italian literature. (no Italian language knowledge is required). Two tests (one midterm one final). Easy if you do all the readings. Make sure to read all of the readings as there is homework for each one (answering simple questions about the reading). No textbook

took it with miura. great professor, and will do his best to explain something if you ask, but can come off as kind of intimidating lmao. tons of quizzes and homework assignments that really do add up, and are pretty simple, so don't slack off. 3 exams, and one oral exam at the end of the quarter. passed with an 89%. don't take this class if you hate cold calling tho

Took it with professor Sato who is the sweetest professor I've met. She's accommodating and patient, her teaching method is also very kindergarten like because it is an introductory language class so if you're into that style I recommend taking her. She does get a little stricter after the Katakana portion because it is a lot to remember but does genuinely care about the grades of her students and makes the class fun.

A lot of writing and reading. 2 texts every week and discussions about text for participation points. only 4 assignments excluding final, 2 quiz 2 essay. 2 essay are small but you will have to read the text to get a good score, quizzes are BS and you need to know the smallest details disucsseed during lecture. Otherwise professor is good and helpful but there will be 0 extra credit so your final grade is ur grade. I ended up getting a A- just cuz i was short 1 point he was not willing to give.

This class isn't difficult. Rather, the professor is super easy going, and lenient. However, the downside is that the professor is disorganized when it comes to giving assignments/sources for papers/emailing. I recommend this class to people interested in Japanese literature. The topics are sure interesting.

Took with Professor Hong. Should be generally easy like the rest of the intro to language classes. The quizzes, midterm, and final will be testing you on vocabulary and the conjugations that you learn in class - it really just takes practice and are literally taken from lecture. Make sure you know the spelling! There are vowels that sound the same but are spelled differently - the only way to learn the difference is to remember it. The only "difficult" thing might be the group project. We have a choice to do a skit in class or through a video, so a majority did the video. As Korean 1, you only learn the very basic grammatical structures, so the video, if a more fun/creative idea (ex: Kdrama parodies), it requires you to speak in sentences we wouldn't have been able to learn. Using Google translate would probably be okay but it'd be obvious and wouldn't sound too great to the professor. The professor is super lenient with the video so just have fun with it. Filming and editing does take a while so I'd recommend to start early. It's a pretty fun class, would recommend it if you're not sure which language to take.

I took professor Hong and landed the class after taking a placement exam. I'm Korean American but don't speak it at all at home so I struggled than most of the other kids but she was very accommodating. She did have scary ahjumma energy at times but that's just how she is, the biggest part of the class is spelling and grammar. Vocab occasionally which is the easiest part and a presentation towards the middle of the class. This was all during COVID so it was online and she did require cameras, so I'm not sure about now.

Had Prof. Brookes and the topic revolving labor studies is pretty self explanatory with many background history of how labor studies came to be. Pretty easy if you studied the slides and attended lecture bc there are things Brookes explained in person that aren't on the slides. She also goes over the reading that was hw in class the next day which counted as 10% of your participation grade but your also given an opportunity to participate on canvas if you dont like talking in class. some of the exam questions were fill in the bank with MCs. she does curve the grade if the class average is lower than what she expected. she is pretty chill and laid back overall

Dr. Brookes was amazing and caring when it comes to understanding the class needs. Exams( Regular and final) mainly focus from readings and lectures through mc/ short answers. Participation matters in class and no separate discussion course.

Prof C makes learning Latin extremely fun and he genuinely cares about the success of his students. He is easily accessible and responds to messages so fast. The class is easy if you stay on top of memorizing, pay attention in class, and practice the assignments. He grades fairly and offers extra credit. Really fun class and excellent professor.

I took the class with Stephen James in the Spring of 2022. This was honestly one of the easiest classes I’ve ever taken at UCR. It’s a class that critiques elements of the Liberal Arts education system such as the humanities and social sciences. There are no midterms or finals, just a 6 page paper at the end of the quarter detailing a course schedule for your next few years at UCR. Just turn in your discussion assignments on time and do well on the paper. I ended the class with an A+.

Quizzes are super easy, but weren’t worth a lot. Quiz questions were given ahead of time. Homework is a BIG part of your grade & the TAs grade homework in a very strict manner. Do not use internet sources or peers for your homework or else you’ll be excused if cheating & reported to student conduct (our professor would threaten us every week about this lmao). Exams are fairly easy, study the study guide slides & you’ll do fine. Our prof said she’d curve the grades at the end. But avoid Prof Chidambaram PLZ lol
Professor is a horrible teacher. Relatively unhelpful TA. If you somehow still want to take this class, do NOT take it with Vrinda Chidarbarm.

This class is basically the same as LING021 except 21 is much more focused on grammar; 20 is more broad and easier, in my opinion. If you're someone who's naturally good at English/foreign languages then this is an easy A as long as you take notes during lectures (even if you're a STEM person this class still isn't very hard). I had Dr. Heidi Waltz, she's really sweet and tries her best to keep everyone engaged.
Buy the book, get Dr. Waltz. Class is pretty simple, every lesson is taken straight from the book!

I had Heidi Waltz as a professor, would recommend. Just attend lecture, and take notes. She only tests on material that you go over in class. She gives helpful study guides with topics that tests will go over. Just look over the study guide with your notes and you should be good. The final exam was not cumulative and only tested on material learned after the midterm. She gives full credit on homework as long as you attempt it.

This class is unnecessarily difficult. The material isn’t even that hard to comprehend but Vrinda Chidambaram is a bad teacher and makes it too complicated. On top of that, homework is graded based on accuracy out of 5 points and it’s worth 40% of your grade. You lose points very easily on homework; the answer may be correct but if it’s not written correctly you will lose points. It’s obvious Chidambaram does not care about her students and their success. In lecture, listen attentively but DO NOT ask a question that’s been asked before. She will yell at you. This class desperately needs discussion sections. Everyone I know is failing.

This class was so hard with Professor Chidambaram!! do not take it when you are have a lot on your plate. She made this class wayyyyy too hard than it seems. Thank God I took this class during remote learning. If I took the class in person, I probably would have done credit/no credit or failed.

Professor Chidambaram is really difficult. She isn't understanding at all when it comes to technical difficulties. The TAs are doing their best, but because the material Is so difficult and the professor is hard to get in contact with, its not easy.

I had Heidi Waltz. All of the homework was online, and my discussion was online. I did not attend lecture like almost ever, just have access to the textbook and you can complete the HW. There were only 3 HW assignments, a midterm, and a final. Everything was online so as long as you collaborate on these assignments you dont need to rlly study. the material is super easy to grasp and self-explanatory as someone who doesnt attend lecture and will skim the textbook occasionally when doing HW.
lectures were so boring, but the textbook was very helpful! i took this class fall of 2022 during the teacher strikes which meant that her grading was super annoying and took forever.

I took it with Prof Heidi Waltz to fulfill my additional humanities course, and it was surprisingly an easier class than I thought. Maybe it's because I had prior knowledge in grammar from high school, but the class consists of no discussion and 1 midterm (half is split in a span of two days) + 1 final + HW assignments = your grade. You'll be lost if you don't go to lecture because the textbook doesn't explain things in detail as the professor does. Overall, I learned a lot about linguistics and would recommend taking it because it's an easy concept to follow. Exam questions are literally from the hw/textbook, and Dr. Waltz is really sweet and caring.

Grammar. Took it with Heidi Waltz. In person lecture and mandatory discussion attendance. We had 5 hw assignments that were pretty easy and very similar to the stuff she taught us. Midterm and Final were online, open note and everything. They were both very easy too, final had extra credit points on it. If you're an international students that learned grammar in school, this class should be very easy to you.

the prof, jorge montesinos, was very into the material and gives u  chances to redeem ur grade via extra credit assignments after the midterm. 2 exams which were just a takehome midterm and takehome final which were graded pretty easy. he doesnt post lecture notes so going to lecture is a must and ur grade is basically just the exams but he curves slightly dependuing on class avg

I took this class twice, one in Fall 2021 and the other Summer 2022. First time taking it, the class was taught by Cranor virtually and he does talk a lot but overall did learn a lot. Attendance was 10% of our grade, one midterm and a final, along with discussion and participation counting for 20% from what I remember. We were given case briefs that were due weekly and were fairly easy and took about an hour total to complete. When I took the course again in Summer 2022, I had Soofia Lateef and she did an excellent job! Her class was structured the same as Cranor’s. She answered all your questions, made lecture slides available, and was very clear about the topics discussed. We talked about tort law, criminal law, and admin law only due to the 5 week condensed summer course. I also had a very fun and helpful TA! Only drawback to the course is that you have to purchase the textbook that Professor Cranor wrote himself which was around $90.
David Weisbart is a really great guy, but I pretty much taught myself the material. There was a lot of homework and lack of coordination between the Prof and TAs.
Professor Mike curtis is cool but hates teaching pre calc. Finals and midterms are hard, do well on the quizzes
curtis, was good if attend lecture and pay attention, tests and quizzes are basically the entire grade
Took with Mike Curtis. Study and you will do fine. He tells you to study for the midterms and finals during lecture.

I took this class with Burdick, a new professor. He's a poor lecturer, and I rarely went to class. The two midterms are an easier version of the sample midterms he posts (same problems, easier numbers), be sure to practice those. The midterms themselves are easy. The material itself isn't too hard, just try to understand the homework. The final was unfairly hard; I had a high A before and it brought me down to an A-.
quizzes are super easy, attendance not mandatory, no quiz makeups, Ben Russel is super understanding

try to get BENJAMIN RUSSEL because he's a really great teacher, easy to follow, and is really flexible. Quizzes and midterms are easy. The material is pretty basic, didn't really have to study much outside of class if you pay attention during lecture and do the homework.

I had Professor Curtis and he's really not bad at all. He teaches the lesson pretty clearly and always stays for office hours to work on questions that kids are struggling with. Personally, I had a really good Pre-Cal teacher in high school so it made the class go by a lot smoother. There were several homework assignments due every week, 1 quiz about every week, 2 midterms + 1 final. This class was pretty time consuming, mainly because I was always studying for the quizzes. If you've never taken Pre-Cal before you might struggle, but if you practice then you should be fine.

I took this class during covid times with Michael Curtis. AVOID HIM. We had a quiz every Friday and we had 3-4 homework sections due on Tuesday's and Thursdays. each section was about 12-17 questions long. in my personal opinion he did not make the study guides like the tests. His study guides were a bunch of random questions from which he would make similar questions for the tests. Unless it is a complete emergency he does not try to understand students needs.

Curtis is pretty cool professor but he is not flexible with the pandemic at all, the course is pretty fast paced so try not to fall behind, the workload is decent you have quizzes and online homework.
The midterms and finals are really hard. The online problems kind of help but a lot of studying is required.

I had Curtis. As someone who is good at math and put in my full effort in this class, it was a struggle. Course work is decent, but midterms and final were really rough. It's nothing like the content we learned during lectures, or like our homework. Your best bet is to study the textbook (even though we barely go over it). Discussion quizzes are based off of textbook questions, and he creates questions using the textbook exercises for the "big" exams. Also, go to office hours since he helps go over content plus gives hints about exams that he doesn't give during lecture. He provides you with everything you need: section questions to study for quizzes, what material will be on the exams, small curves, but again he makes the class more tough than it really is. Also, avoid asking repetitive or his definition of "easy" questions, he is really snarky.

I understand why people don't enjoy this class- it's very inflexible and black and white, but the information is pretty okay to learn. A lot of it is high school math and not terribly difficult. Pay attention in class, go to lecture, and use homework as a time to review questions. Professor Curtis is pretty good with a couple ec points during exams because he knows that students will make careless mistakes. Overall, pretty solid. He also drops a couple assignments too.

Heavy work load with a lot of material to cover: make sure to stay up on the WeBWorK and written homework. Hope for Dr. Eric Weisbart - he is a very passionate and caring professor who'll jump through hoops to see you pass with a high grade.
Xinli Xiao had a really thick accent which made it hard for me to understand his lecture. So I never went to lecture and just self studied with ALEKS

Dr.Weisbart was a great professor. His classes and his notes were useful as a quick refresher. The exams were exactly the same as the ones on the midterm and the final. Homework is a good part of the sections. Get to know your TA they basically grade your homework and whether or not to get credit.
David Weisbart was confusing during lectures and sometimes did not have examples that matched with homework problems. Had to ask TAs to solve and explain a lot of the problems.
You're gonna have to learn this class on your own. The lectures aren't great

Weisbart is a nice guy. He will however literally fuck you world up as his style of teaching is completely different from everyone else's. I took calc and I had no idea what he was teaching. Exams are hard and he expects a lot from you. His class really is the 5 units its worth.
Avoid Weisbert. Makes some concepts unnecessarily difficult. Study a lot and do the homework for discussions. 2 midterms and a final.

David Weisbart is a really nice and caring professor, and you can tell he wants you to succeed. However, he over complicated a lot of the material and it will take a LOT of hard work to pass the class.

Try to avoid Weisbart, he's a cool dude, kinda funny and is really passionate about his work but honestly he sucks at teaching. However, he does post his outline/notes from lecture. Way he "takes" attendance are through in class quizzes maybe 2/3 times a week at the end of lecture, and he they're random, but you get full credit even if you answer is wrong.

This class was built for life science majors in CNAS specifically so don't take it unless in that range of majors. The math is not essentially hard once you understand it you just have to practice and re-practice to really get it. Had Prof. Weisbart, he's cool but his teaching style is entirely different than anything I have experienced. He doesn't give equation formulas during lectures other than in 2 instances. Go over ALL the syllabus questions and example exams as many midterm and final exam questions are literally derivations of those or similar. 2 midterms and final. My TA was Adam which really helped. Ended with a B thanks to failing the 1st midterm

If you get David Weisbart, get ready to study. But it is definitely not that hard to get a good grade in his class if you go to every lecture, go to office hours, do the extra credit, and ace all the worksheets. Since he doesn’t assign any homework, it is easy to fall behind but if you force yourself to follow along and do the syllabus questions he has posted, you’re on your way to an A!
David makes the class harder than it should. Just study ALL the solution problems in the syllabus ASAP! I can't emphasize enough! ASAP!
Weisbart is seriously the worst teacher I have ever had. Good luck.
If you got prof tran, the lectures wont help you understand shit. Focus on the slides and vids, also attend the discussion, they teach more. ALSO the prof doesnt use his mic
Lectures were not very helpful so you have to do a lot of self study. It was mostly fine but there were a couple lessons that take a good amount of time to understand.

Easy to pass if you have any sense of precalc in Highschool. Impossible if you're going in blind. After first 3 weeks, don't bother going to lectures, especially if you have Tran, the worksheets he goes over are useless. You're basically taking precalc in another language, nothing you google will make sense since everything is abstract and made up by Weisbart. Final is 50% of grade, however you're basically guaranteed the other 50%, and you only need 40% on final to pass if that's all you care about.

I highly recommend skipping lectures, and instead use all the time to watch the videos and practice over and over the hw exercises and midterm practices. Doing this got me an A+ since the final was easy. Don't fall behind, this class is harder to fail than it is to pass.

I had Karl Schmidt for my professor and he was very easy. His lectures involve Kahoot at the end of class for attendance and extra credit. Most of everyone I know that had other teachers in this category of math did online math homework. The math homework is easy, but the online program is often difficult to use and requires a little bit of time to get used to it. Use Desmos a lot or the quadratic formula, don't do advanced calculus to solve the problems.

I had Prof. Sara Lapan. She's not a particularly good teacher imo. She definitely is very knowledgeable with math, but just isn't very good at teaching it. HW is weekly, and can take a while if you get confused. Midterm is ok, but she'll give you the opportunity to make up some points on it. Her point system is setup where it isn't too hard to pass, but learning the content itself is kind of tricky along the way.

I had Prof. Lapan and she isn't that great at teaching. Knowing how to do some of the math is expected, or only taught once, and the lectures are her having us work out "puzzles" sitting with our discussion groups. There's a kahoot at the end for her to track your attendance. You can get points back on the midterm, but it was at most 20. Self study is key to passing. The online homework takes a lot of time to complete so don't procrastinate it. Final is cumulative, no curve,  same with midterm.
Professor Lapan is a terrible professor but she has tons of make-up points that help your grade out.

Took it with Dr. Lapan. Basic introduction to geometry and pre-calculus. Kahoot clicker questions, two midterms and one cumulative final. She really tends to take a simple concept and complicate it, so make sure to ask questions.

Took it the quarter that Lapan wasnt the primary instructor so I cant offer insight onto her teaching style, but I can say this about the class material. It is not hard math at all. Mix of Algebra II and Pre-Calc concepts, and if you honestly do all the homework, take notes, and make sure you understand all the concepts, you can easily get an B. Isn't hard to get an A, so long as your on top of the material and study like one to two hours a week outside of class and homework. Discussion is worksheets(graded on correctness) and you get groups, so it's not difficult. Otheriwise.. easy B, if the average effort is put in.

Pretty easy class, had professor Lapan. Just make sure to study and do the homework. It’s the hardest part of the class in my opinion but I honestly learned most of the material by just making sure I got 100s on all the homework assignments. She also gives lots of opportunities to get extra credit and has this thing called a midterm redo which allows you to get points back if you didn’t do so hot on the midterm.

Had prof Lapin and shes actually pretty nice but confusing when it comes to asking her questions. Her way of explaining questions makes no sense most of the time unless you truly understand the concept. Her homework consists of online homework that you get 3 tries on so it was relatively easy. She also lets you do midterm corrections to boost your midterm grade so thats helpful. Overall I would recommend taking her.

Class was simple overall...took with Lapan in Fall 2020. It was review topics from algebra and geometry for most of the quarter and got into more complex topics like logarithms the final few weeks. Class has 3 unit tests and a final, all weighted the same, and Lapan drops the score of your lowest test, so technically if u bomb the final it can be wiped. There are also quizzes for each chapter (4) which are similar to homework problems. You can easily pass with Lapan by completing all the homework and doing decently on the quizzes and tests so TRY AND GET HER AS INSTRUCTOR.
Everything was online(including tests). Pretty easy class, do the homework and understand it and you should be good for the tests.

Had Dr. Yeakel. All homework, quizzes, and tests were online. She gives lots of extra credit opportunities so take them while you can. Not a hard class, just make sure to put in the work and it should pay off.

Had Cannizzo for this class. She talks pretty light, so it's kinda hard to hear her. The class uses IMathAS that contains questions which gives you unlimited tries on hw and 3 tries on quizzes. All of the exams are also taken on this website, and you won't be able to see the answer until it gets graded grade, BUT the exams aren't in person. Write the work and submit the work into gradescope after the exam. The worksheets that I got during discussion correlated with the contents in the class for the most part. There are journals weekly, which requires to write the steps for 4 questions of your choice, which is honestly a bit tedious. Overall, the class isn't too bad; it's basically just a refresher from high school functions.

Your grade is 100% dependent on your effort, if you study every worksheet and excersice sheet  and go to office hours and every discussio you will get a B minimum but if you go specail to the professor watch evrey lecture video alongside live lectures you will get an easy A. Concepts are not taught like your usual math class, a lot is giving foundation for your future calc class and understanding why a concept is the way it is.

took it with dw fall 2022. videos that were provided to supplement the homework would only show you how to do the very basics, and leave you to parse out the word problems on your own. for someone who sucks at math, that was a little tough, but I went to discussion and I was fine. just make sure to keep up with the homework and it honestly isn't bad at all
The work itself is easy, but if you have Lizheng Tao consider yourself done for. Curve is strong though.

Took over summer so it was more fast paced, but even then the class was not bad at all. No curve, but there is a redo your lowest page on the midterm from 6A. Covers modules 5-8 and they are all easy but the only one I found challenging was 8 because its trig functions and they don't click in my head lol. Got C's on all exams/finals, but completed all homework/ discussion worksheets and ended with a 85% so do the homework and worksheets.

I took this with professor Hung Tran spring quarter 2023. he just goes over worksheets during lectures so its kinds hard to learn that way for me. I had to search up everthing myself. HW due ever fridays at 11:59 and you have to pay for that website. The midterm was just like the practice tho. I just suck at math.
Midterms and finals are just like the sample ones, memorize them and you'll do fine
Sample midterms and finals are very similar to the actual exams.

Had Professor Karl Smidtch. He is a horrible lecture (over complicates things) but his midterms and final are wayyyy easier than the ones given by other teachers. I would take his class because 7A is just derivatives and applications of derivatives so it isn't hard and his midterms/final are pretty easy. If you took calc before you're straight chillin in his class, but I didn't take calc in hs and still found 7A pretty chill. Study the mictotutorials though, he puts one of them on his final.

costello is a really good teacher, he explains his work it detail so you can understand how to solve similar problems. 2 midterms and a final, hw due every week online but you have unlimited tries per problem so its an easy 100%

Took with Costello, great professor. Has 2 midterms 1 Final that are relatively easy imo, as long as you attend lecture you’ll get a good grade because his lectures are clear and easy to understand. Final is worth 40% of grade and is cumulative, also has micro tutorials that aren’t due till finals week so lots of time to get them done. Online hw every week with unlimited tries so no excuse not to do, plus they’re relatively short. Discussion and lecture attendance not necessary but highly recommend you attend lectures, discussions were a waste of time imo.

I had henry tucker. he improved his organization skills every class and layed out the possible math questions for each concept on the following test. he gave us 4 sampe mid terms each midterm and gave us 4 sample finals which were, if not, identical to the real midterm and finals.

I had Dr. Constantini during Fall 2020 and she's the sweetest person ever. Her lectures and TA discussions are not mandatory but she offers supplemental notes and recorded lectures. Homework consists of Microtutorials, worksheets,  and MyMathLab. She really does want you to do well and is always willing to help her students out. Her practice exams are really similar to her actual exams and all of them are unproctored and open notes. You don't even have to be in Zoom, she just emails you your version of the test and you have to turn it into GradeScope by a specific time. Material is mostly the first semester of AP Calc.

i had robbie lopez as prof even tho he's apparently a grad student? super easy going jacked as fuck literal chad super good at explaining concepts. just do the homework and don't forget the micro-tutorials and u basically get an A

I took this class with Matthew Harper, it's pretty typical of what you would expect out of a Calculus class. His teaching style was a bit confusing/hard to follow at times but other than that it wasn't too difficult.

I took it with Professor Costello. He's pretty amazing in lectures and pretty chill. He's very informative in lectures where he'll explain how to do each calculus problems/examples along with some extra problems just for extra practice/pre-cautions. His office hours/emailing him are also pretty helpful as well where he'll guide you on the problems/questions in order to solve them. His exams are fair and average (not too easy nor too hard) without using a calculator. One thing to note for his exams is that there's one altered question based on the microtutorial vids, so do the microtutorial vids early as you can and try understand how to solve them. So, do the practice exams he give along with the microtutorial vids. Overall course is based on 1 midterm, 1 final, 5 discussion quizzes based on the recommended problems he give (1 quiz with lowest score will be dropped & you can use a calculator for the quizzes), weekly homework, and microtutorial vids. Grading is based on the percentage of each materials. Do recommend taking him for MATH007A.

As someone who never actually learned anything in my pre-calc classes in high school, I found this class pretty challenging. However, I had Prof. Yang and he's honestly one of the nicest and most reasonable teachers I've ever had. His class is not hard, and his midterm and final are basically identical to the practice exams he posts. The curve for the class (found in his syllabus) also gives you a pretty big cushion, so as long as you put in a bit of effort, you should be fine in his class.

This class was really, really easy. I had Christina Va..(something complicated; greek) and it was fun. I did not pay much attention in class, but I was there. It was easier than AP calc. I used like 10% of my brain in class and got an A, but I know some people who had a hard time. I say just study, do the homework, and be attentive and it will all be okay.
Very easy with Dr. Christina. Show up to office hours and you’ll definitely get an A
Had Stefano Vidussi. Does not teach very well, rarely shows examples in class, so you're better off studying on your own. Midterm is easy, but final is much harder
Avoid Gindi at all costs. He will show up to class at least 10-15 minutes late every lecture, give out hard exams, and will be condescending to those who asks questions.
HELL

If you took calc AB in high school, this is basically the 2nd half of that class since it is all about integrals. Quizzes are very easy and midterm/final aren't as easy, but are not hard. I had Scott Atkinson who was a good professor and had a good TA as well. Some newer concepts not learned in calc AB are taught in the second half of the course. Make sure to understand all the concepts as some people struggle(maybe due to bad math background or using symbolab to do all the homework)

Took it w Atkinson. He's not a bad prof, but I feel likes he's a little too roundabout and has a tendency to overcomplicate concepts. If you took Calc AB in hs, this is mainly a review w a few new tricks on familiar concepts. Homework is weekly and kind of a bother bc the system can be picky about "correct" answers. For instance, it often does not recognize answers that are equivalent to its own so you kind of have to solve problems very formally. Weekly quizzes in discussion, but the TAs do a great job of walking you through the concept and then quizzing you at the end of discussion. Tests aren't too bad
Took it with Prof. Atkinson. Amazing guy but at times can be boring and repetitive. Make sure you pay attention and take notes :)

I had professor Zhanar Berikkyzy and hands down the best math professor at UCR. She is hella patient, and does not go fast at all. She truly wants nothing but the best for her students and even if you show the slightest interest by asking questions or office hours, she is extremely helpful and considerate. I struggled through 7B material, but she was extremely helpful in office hours and after class. I flew through 7A, but 7B was a struggle for me because I hate integrals but overall 7B isn't hard. Her midterms are similar to the ones in her class examples and quizzes that were given in discussion.

Had Burdick. HONESTLY GOAT you have 1-2 homework assignments due every Friday with unlimited attempts. Asynchronous class but he held optional class at normal times and had office hours to go over any homework questions you have. Recorded lessons for the week posted Sundays and he records all his office hours and lectures. One worksheet a week for discussion (attendance optional) that you would turn in for grades. Provided four samples for every midterm (1&2) and the final exam. Very helpful.

(Fall 2020 Via Zoom) I gave this class a 4/10 in difficultly because the concepts are not hard to grasp if you do the assigned homework and attend discussions as they do a good job of working step-by-step through difficult problems. I had Dr. Chen, and he was great. He gave us enough time to do homework problems and they were not long. The homework problems are more complex than those on the exams which I think is good because you will be prepared for the exams. The averages were about 80-85%. The midterms (2) and final are all free-response and must be worked out and turned in via Gradescope. As far as proctoring, he required us to log into zoom and have our cameras on and no calculators allowed. He also did offer one extra credit quiz. DOWNSIDE: He only uploads his notes that he takes during the live lecture but does not record the actual lecturing. However, he does upload example videos of him going through various problems for the modules.

I took this with Prof. Chen in Fall 2020, and I thought he was a really nice prof that wants his students to succeed. If you need anything, just contact him and he'd be happy to help you out however you need. Lectures were pretty boring (although I find all math lectures boring) but it was easy to follow. I took Calc BC in high school, so having had a lot of practice with integrals, this class was a breeze for me. My friend, who took Calc AB in high school, was less familiar with some of the material but they're still getting through the class with only mild difficulty; so make sure you pay attention in lecture!!!
Took with Noble Williamson. He focuses on theorems and propositions on quizzes and exams so make sure you understand them.

I had with Professor Zhang Zhenghe. He's a fast lecturer where he talks fast and sometimes do shortcuts during lecture examples without explanation as he may expects you to be familiarize with the learnings of 7A materials. All his lecture notes are just examples of the problems of the contents he'll be teaching. There's still online hw with unlimited amount of attempts to pass. Microtutorials are also there, but Zhang won't include the qs related to the microtutorial vids in the exams. Exams were quite average with some mostly doable and others a bit diffcult/tricky. Weekly discussion quizzes are based on the optional textbook problems that he'll give as part of extra practice.
