The midterm is based on what was taught, whereas the final paper was on a topic assigned by the professor based on a recent event in media. I got a 69/100 on the midterm, but did well on the final paper so I passed with a B.
Wendy Su is a good professor, as long as you are fast at taking notes and attend every lecture you will get at least a B.
attend review sessions before the midterm and final and you should be okay for the exams.

Midterms are specific about the readings and lecture notes. Go to lecture, she (setsu) tells you what is going to be on the midterm. She seems nice but is kinda unapproachable because she judges you so hard. Rachel (TA) was the best!! she replied fast on emails, graded things on time, and created summaries for the readings (i read those summaries for midterms instead of doing the readings)
Grade is determined on effort, bigger assignments are left optional but as long as you turn in all the assignments you will get an A, highly recommend if the class if with Sheryl Vint.
derek burrill. take the class
Prof Burril is an excellent and cares about his students truly. Class isn't hard just need to watch 8 movies. The midterm and final was to choose a movie and write a review. which were really easy.

I had Professor Burrill for Fall 2020 online. The class was asynchronous, but the professor had office hours. Powerpoint lecture slides were lengthy. Only hw was watching a film each week. Midterms weren't proctored, and we had a generous amount of time to complete them. They were essays, and nearly everyone got A's. Don't try to take advantage of Professor Burrill's kindness.
Took this class Fall 2022 with Prof. Burrill and it has been one of my favorite classes I've ever taken. Personally, not only was it an easy A, the material and professor made the class enjoyable.

[COVID-19] Professor Jeong is an amazing professor with such passion for Korean film! Very easy breadth course. You watch films, answer weekly discussion questions, and take a multiple-choice weekly quiz. Lecture slides are asynchronous with no attendance or discussion section. She had only 5 live lectures that were recommended but not mandatory. 2 quite easy 1-2 page reaction papers to one film you enjoyed, she gives you all the resources needed to write it.

Setsu Shigematsu. Pretty easy class, one class and one screening per week. Lots of the class is student presentations. Points come from your journal, tests (easy, she tells you exactly what is on the tests), and presentations. Overall an interesting class with not too much effort required. Some of the readings can be a bit long though.

ACTUALLY DO THE HOMEWORK. If you truly understand the concepts of the homework you'll breeze through the midterms. If you have Princevac be warned the final will be the factor that determines whether you pass the weeder course or not.

You cover the basics of the whole ME curriculum in this one class. Two midterms, one final. You need to do good on at least one midterm because the final ends up killing everyones grade. There is a class curve at the end, but you need to make sure you make the original cutoff for a passing grade. I had stahovich so the cutoff was a 62% for a C. The majority of the class does fail however. 

Homework will take a good 6-8 hours to complete, quizzes are really bad, and you're expected to spend the majority of your time on this class.

Stahovich was a good professor.
This was probably the hardest class I have taken so far (entering 2nd year), so STUDY UP AND DONT SLACK. I barely made it through with a C, but most of my friends did not

Hands down the most difficult weedout course in engineering: they told us on day 1 that only a third of us were expected to get above a C (there is no curve for Princevac), 60% of my class failed. ME2 is designed to make you think like an engineer, not teach you material, which trips up a LOT of people... questions are based on “figure out how to solve the problem” instead of “plug numbers into an equation”. No equation sheets, majority symbolic (mass m1, etc) and only simple calculators, all about your ability to solve problems. If you’re into that, ME2 will be your favorite underclassman course; if not, join the 60%.
Material isn't particularly hard, there is just a lot of info that is covered and the test problems tend to be fairly complex. Your set up is more important than the actual calculations.

You are going to be surprised when you take this class in your first or second year because it take a lot more effort to get good grades than other lower div classes. It probably exists just to scare off students and make them feel ME is not right for them. I sure wish someone told me this class would be so disgusting beforehand because I was definitely not ready for it.

I took this class with Princevac. Class is difficult because of content and heavy emphasis on exam scores, only about 7 A's my year out of a class of 80+. Huge help if you take PHYS040B concurrently (a lot of the topics align such as buoyant forces, and efficiency).

What helped me the most to get an A is having access to 100% correct answers from Chegg or solution keys from previous years. Having accurate solutions helped in two ways: one, saved my homework grade and, two, gave me the right answers to study from when it came to the exam time. Midterm 1, 4/5 problems were seen previously in either homework or quizzes. Midterm 2, 3/5 problems were seen already. Go to office hours to check if your solutions are 100% correct, so you don't miss any points on the exam. Outside of his lectures, you should start applying the principles in the real world and think, "what are the forces acting on this system?" or "Why does this work/built this way?". Ultimately this class should start to make you think like an engineer. Keep in mind this class is supposed to be somewhat enjoyable, and stay humble because it only gets harder from here.

I took the class with Akula Venkatram for winter 2021. EXTREMELY ROUGH time, he knows his stuff, but horrible at teaching. Would act like a child with poor test scores, and doesn't seem to care about his students. But gave nice curve at the end. The homework did not reflect the quizzes and tests much, hes a very conceptual based professor.

Stahovich Summer 2022 Online: The class was pretty easy for the first half but definitely picks up albeit gradually. If you're comfortable with PHYS40A&B, MOST of the class will be review and straightforward. Homework takes awhile and is graded on correctness. It's possible to do it in a day, but not fun. Quizzes are fine as long as you understand the homework. First midterm was easy, second was harder, and the final was rough. Generally though, the exams are pretty similar to the homework, so there is no review material given before the exams. There is no bell curve, but the grade margins are shifted-- ex. 90% for an A, 86% for an A-. Just stay on top of everything and realize that this is class is not only to introduce you to ME, but to teach you the problem solving skills needed for the rest of the classes to come.

CAD Assignments were ridiculously easy at first but slowly progressed in difficulty. You also take the CSWA Exam at the end of the quarter and only 40% of my class passed the exam (which is apparently normal according to the professor).
Honestly, if you just read the textbook and do well on the CAD Assignments (CAD is 40% of your grade), you'll be fine.

Took with Sawyer. The class itself was relatively easy. You should be fine as long as you do the CAD assignments and the homework. When he does examples in SolidWorks in class, it'll be hard to keep up with him at first, but it should become easier over time. The questions on the Midterm and Final were almost identical and looked like it turned the textbook readings into questions themselves. Okay class overall.

CADS is 40% of your grade, always do them and make sure there's annotation. TA grades super harsh, if you make one small mistake, you get 1/3 to even more than half the credits off your assignments/midterm/CAD. I had to take it as a first year student, with 0 experiences in Engineering because of block, I had so much trouble and everything feels like there is suppose to be a prerequisite class.

Im a CE major, took the class for the "other" engineering requirement
if you dont want to go into ME or you didnt do too well in physics then this class will be HARD otherwise you should be fine

I'm an MSE and this class was a struggle. I pushed all of my other classes to the side for this class. Tons of time put in outside of class to understand the concepts that Stahovich zooms through in lecture. If you love ME, physics, and have a good understanding of MATH010A ahead of time, you'll be fine.

Prof. Eskandari taught the class very well. HW were easy, quizzes were her lecture notes. 2 Midterms; midterms represented of homework problems and lecture example problems. Final were problems from practice final. Every time she says hint hint or wink wink, that's an indication you'll see that problem either on a quiz, midterm, or final. Take her hints seriously if you want an A. Also go to her office hours for extra credit. Great professor

Taken with Dinsmore (Cal Poly) because no other professor wanted to teach this class. Professor had very specific, annoying guidelines for homework. Uses physics free-body diagrams and trigonometry. I've been able to get by with discussion and homeworks. Definitely feel my time would've been better spent in another "in-engineering" class.

Difficult if you have no coding experience whatsoever but you do get used to the syntax as the quarter progresses. Attend the labs and ask the TAs for any questions as that's apparently your substitution for office hours. Don't slack off on the final as it was pretty difficult if you don't review for it. It was a mix of hand calculations and writing code by hand. There was a design project due at the end of the quarter. It was pretty difficult so start early. While it is something you can do in 3 days, it is not worth the stress.

Many MEs hate coding or have no experience with it, and ME18 (Intro to MatLab) isn’t meant to teach those skills. Thus, if you come in hoping to touch MatLab as little as possible, or are playing catchup with coding, good luck... best to study ahead by learning Python (lots of great tutorials online) as the syntax has a number of similarities. Sawyer is a babe, but he means it when he says to start the design project early: it’s pretty complex and will devastate novice programmers. Beyond that barrier, ME18 is a chill A :)

I had Dr. Tom Stahovich for this class. He barely answered questions and his assignments were littered with mistakes. I have never been more irritated with a class. Lab assignments took hours. No exams besides the final (which was optional in the end). He had intended to have a half paper half matlab exam and was only stopped from doing that because students didn’t have printers to use. Strongly recommend taking someone else for this class. I learned nothing from him just figured things out on my own and with the TA’s help.

Took it with Venkatram aka "Venky" Fall 2020. Transfer students with no coding experience / MATLAB experience beware, he will expect you to teach yourself coding. His grading system is whack. The TA and other students are teaching the class at this point. No one knows how he grades the labs. However, if you are good at math/manipulating physics equations, and know coding, it's an easy A.

ME18A introduces coding in MATLAB. It gets very difficult after week 2 if you don’t know anything about coding beforehand. They say you don’t need to know how to code but most students who are in the class understand a fair amount before taking the course but if you don’t know a single bit, it is better to learn about MATLAB before taking this course.

ME 018A is also called Intro to MATLAB or Engineering Computation. It's supposed to teach engineers the "basics of MATLAB" and is a "introduction to programming". It is not an intro class and the level of programming is intermediate to advanced. Learn Python before taking this class.

Coding labs will suck out so much time in your schedule. You'll think the first lab is easy and it's alright, pretty straightforward, but it climbs in difficulty. For example, you have to program recursive sequences without being taught what is recursion. Note that you cant use in-built tools on MATLAB and you have to create these tools through code.

Pray you'll pass the class if Sundar or Stahovich is teaching it. Hardest engineering class I've taken at this school. I took the class with Sundar teaching.

Sundar lectures decently, but his exams, coding assignments, coding final, was on a whole different level. When it came to coding for the labs and projects he would concoct the most insanely difficult assignment to do. Sundar will work you into the ground if you want to succeed in not just this class, but any ME class he teaches.

I believe that Sundar does care to some degree but he is incredibly harsh when it comes to grading. Often he doesn't reply to emails. Honestly even stressful talking to him.

Took it the first time the class was being offered. ME018 was split into 18A and 18B beginning Fall 2018. This class involves a lot of theorem. You really need to understand the theorem, not just the formulas, or you will fail the class. You will have homework every week -- do not slack off on these. The homework will help you understand the material on the exams (2 midterms and 1 final). There are also quizzes almost every week in discussion. In addition, there was a project due at the end of the quarter. Start the project early cause it's something you can not procrastinate. In fact, a majority of the class didn't finish the project. Class had a huge curve at the end but I'm guessing it was because we were the first ones to take it so be wary. There may not be any more curves for future classes.

There's no official textbook for the class, but looking into some dynamics and fluid mechanics books will certainly be helpful. If taking this with professor Sundarajan, beware of a LOT of homework. Our first midterm had a 50% average score.

Many MEs hate coding or have no experience with it, and ME18 (Intro to MatLab) isn’t meant to teach those skills. Thus, if you come in hoping to touch MatLab as little as possible, or are playing catchup with coding, good luck... best to study ahead by learning Python (lots of great tutorials online) as the syntax has a number of similarities. Sawyer is a babe, but he means it when he says to start the design project early: it’s pretty complex and will devastate novice programmers. Beyond that barrier, ME18 is a chill A :)

Sundar literally combines every engineering topic into this course (heat transfer, fluids, mechanics, statics, etc). You need an extremely strong math foundation going in and good work ethics if you want to pass. Sundar is extremely hard but will make one hell of an engineer out of you.

Taken with Professor Sundar. Ignored all of my classes and put all of my focus on this class. I didn't think it was too bad, and it would have been worse in person. Still a really difficult class though.

barely felt like I was passing tests and understanding how to apply concepts correctly throughout, came out with a B+ somehow. Center of mass, forward/inverse kinematics, MATLAB, and other concepts are hurled at you rapid fire, be sure to utilize all available resources for this class (TA, discussion, other students, study groups, discord, HW help sites)

There is a project for this class and I recommend starting it early as possible.

Class appears to be pre-curved.
No midterm only, quizzes and final. Hw 20% quiz 30% and final 50%. Professor Xu is funny and all, but he doesnt really know how to teach
Study early! There are only 2 laws you need to know but there are hundreds of ways to use them. Do as many practice problems as possible!

This class was one of my easiest ME courses so far (would give a 2.5 difficulty), probably because I took it with Professor ChenLi (Fall Quarter). His class is generously curved and he is a rather good professor. Some might have trouble understanding him due to his Chinese accent. Discussions are optional and I attended only one. To excel in his class: (1) attend every lecture and take THOROUGH notes, (2) allocate some time to study in a small group or to self-study, and (3) actually try to understand the material, even by studying homework solutions while doing the "optional" homework.
Took it with Sinisa Coh. Easiest ME class I've taken in UCR. Material is difficult but Coh really makes things easy to understand. Make sure to go to class.
Professor Eskandari is an amazing professor. She will put more focus on learning than grades. Exams are very fair but beware of pop quizzes.
*if you see a review for ME114 but it says Eskandari in the review, i meant for it to say ME110. Sorry about that.

Kumar went super easy on the first midterm and then made the second one deadly hard. The final was horribly difficult but the average was so terrible that the curve was immense. Just try your best and at least stay average with the rest of the people in the class. He also gives pop quizzes so pro tip if you plan on not going: go to every lecture and stand outside to see if there is one lol

Professor DInsmore is a joke. He does not listen nor respond to any of his students' concerns regarding grading for the class. The average for the midterm was a low F and he was not willing to curve the midterm nor change the grading scale for the course. The only piece of information he gave was to do better on the final because it can replace the midterm, leaving the final to be 95% of the grade for the majority of the class... Be prepared to teach yourself the material. He doesn't respond to his emails in a timely manner and gives extremely short notice for exams. It become impossible to reach out to him and it's gotten so bad that I had to reach out to our faculty advisor Professor Sundar to speak with him just so that his students' concerns reach him. I would avoid him at all costs if possible

Professor Dinsmore covered the material very broadly, making it so that we had to learn from the homework and from Youtube on our own time. He decided to curve at the end probably due to pressure from the students and administration. Otherwise, the material and concepts learned through this class are actually pretty fun.

I took this course with Professor Martinez, and it ended up as one of the hardest classes I have ever taken during the first half of the quarter. I believe the class was difficult because the TA's teachings were inconsistent with that of the professor's, so there was a lot of confusion. The professor's office hours are extremely helpful and she actually is a good professor. She's new so she's still testing the waters regarding grading and structure. Overall the class was challenging, but it was a good experience.

Took this class with Professor Dinsmore, wasn't bad at all. He gets kinda side tracked sometimes and the hw can be pretty long. Just study the hw before each quiz and you should be fine. Go to every discussion because he doesn't say when the quizzes will be.
Took it with Aguilar, great guy. Although for the midterm and final he says that he pulls questions from homeworks and lecture problems, but he doesn't.
I had Kumar for this class, do your work an you should get an A. Fairly easy concepts.
Took it with Professor Eskandari. She is an amazing professor and will explain all the concepts thoroughly. The only downside is that she loves giving pop quizzes.

Took with Professor Ozkan. Super easy if you remember basic chemistry. Extra easy if you took CEE135. I never went to lecture and just reviewed his slides before exams and it went fine. Very fun concepts.
The math can be very challenging and hard to grasp at first. You need to study. Matlab is important but barely relevant to final grade.
A lot of math, linear algebra and differential equations. I took it with sundar, he expects us to do 2 projects, but doesnt really go over them
Took it with Sundar. He writes very fast. Excellent professor. Assigns a lot of hw. Exams and project pretty intense.
Avoid Luat Vuong at all costs

Extremely difficult with Sundar. He breezes through lecture and his notes/HW solutions are super sloppy. He skips a lot of steps in his HW solutions making it not that helpful. Definitely read the book for the class.
One midterm, two projects. Took it with Sundar. Overall, this class was difficult but if you do the homeworks/review the quizzes, you will be fine.
Avoid professor Vuong! Shes a great helpful person, but teaching isn't really for her.
LTV isn't bad, but book and lecture are teach differently. Office hours are helpful

Absolute Pain in the clASS. 30%quizzes, 30% midterm, 40% final. Venky takes textbooks problems and creates his own formulas and writes class notes. Strategy is probably to understand his impossible class notes and learn from other online sources. Will take a lot of time and effort studying with friends to understand anything.

Took with Professor Greaney, granted it was online but it seemed like nothing he was teaching was on the exams? Content on the exams wasn't even in the book. I stopped attending lectures around week 6 and just studied on my own. Somehow I got a B+ but I was beyond stressed out the entire time, so good luck :)

The class was quite easy, but that gave me a false sense of security so I didn't perform as I expected in the end. The class material is diverse, but relatively simple. Take the labs seriously, as the lab memos (the assignments) make up most of the class grade. There's extensive use of MATLAB when examining the lab results. Overall, don't slack and procrastinate,  just put in some effort and it's an easy A.

The class is pretty easy and is almost a guaranteed A. The final was a bit harder than the midterm so I had a false sense of security that almost made me lose my A. Really focus on the labs as those make 50% of your grade and can make or break your grade at the end.

Lasers and Optics- One of the Mechanical Engineering Tech Electives, one of the coolest TE's out there, if ur interested in light waves, polarization, refraction, etc. Course still in development. Some topics were difficult, but Prof. Luat Vuong did not test on the difficult stuff.

Professor Vuong will listen to u if u guys collectively complain together. The TAs were super super helpful and she does leave out some of the details of what u should include in ur lab reports, hw, etc. but her passion for this subject is pretty cool pretty easy tech elective if u know how to set expressions given a diagram (sometimes she doesnt really tell u what ur solving for or what variables to use for said expressions but it's ok that's what makes this class pretty easy) if i can get an A in this class so can u. also like 2/3 of the class stopped showing up after the midterm (myself included ofc) bc honestly we only had 2 genuine lectures and never again since every lecture got turned into a lab time lol the only thing u have to worry about are finals tbh bc midterms count just as much as this quiz thing that ur guaranteed 100% on and lab reports are iffy depending on her mood or the number of people that complained about it for an extension or something i recommend easy tech elective fr oh and if ur bad at coding pls dont ask her to take the final online bc she doesnt really teach u lines of code ur expected to know :)
Great professor, but lots of homework
Trash class
Trash class, trash professor. A lot of my friends failed

This class was a pain but maybe only because of the quarantine situation. Her midterm was 70 questions in 70 minutes. Her quizzes in lab are so oddly specific and timed so it's almost as if they expect you to memorize every small detail about the machinery. She is not lenient what so ever. No curve.
Francis Moore is a super nice violinists. I have her as my violin instructor. Just do the work and put some effort and you'll get an A
Super Easy A. I took it with Frances Moore and it filled my humanities breadths. Attendance is mandatory tho.

Dr. Walter Clark is good. He doesn't care if you don't show up, though you REALLY should because he doesn't upload lecture notes, which tests are 100% based on, and you can't really get the information anywhere else. Not much material to memorize. Just go to lecture and copy what he writes down + you'll be completely fine

Women in Music with Professor Xochitl Chavez was an easy course but it does require work. There is a final presentation that you have to do that can be presented for extra credit or turned in without presenting. It is much better to present since you get the option to have questions from your selected artist to be showcased in the final exam. There are listening parts to the exam that is best done by taking time listening to the examples required every week. There are plenty of extra credit options, but show up to lectures because attendance is a huge part of your grade (a whole letter in fact). Presentation lectures will not be posted on iLearn so take notes and read the book. (Currently there are no options to get a free ebook, and purchase the book through the site the professor recommends or you risk paying $50 more.

Professor Nana is a great teacher, if you want to know more about music from different cultures, this is a class for you. However the workload for this class is fairly big. She does not upload her powerpoint slides nor any listening examples on iLearn so you must go to lecture. Total of 3 tests, one big final paper, and a final test.

Professor Ritter was energetic and was fun to see him perform some of the music. Make sure to attend lectures (quizzes will be based heavily on them). Professor was so understanding he cancelled one of the quizzes and the final due to COVID and the uprisings across the nation. There is a term paper make sure to include all the things it’s asking for and you basically get a good great. Discussions are helpfully it’s a review of the music learned that week. Overall easy class.

Professor Ritter is always enthusiastic and makes lectures very fun. I would say it was a little hard trying to identify certain sounds and instruments only because I knew nothing about music. He was very helpful though so that was good.

Mandatory attendance, 3 listening quizzes (MCQ), no midterm, a 5 page term paper that for some reason cannot be about something he covered, and the final was basically a collection of questions from the listening quizzes + 1 short answer (~450 words).
Dr. Ritter is very energetic and fair. The class covers a lot of the world and knowing how to play music prior will likely help you a lot. Memorization is key.

Taken with Panikker, who was friendly.  Discussion Responses and class/discussion participation points were practically freebies.  Study notes and study guide for an hour before each quiz (MC) and you should get a B or better.  Paper required attending an in-person event, but was graded casually.  Easy A.

Took it with Prof Deborah Wong (amazing prof makes class enjoyable). There are 4 quizzes (not cumulative) and 1 essay, no final and no homework. She uses PollEverywhere for participation so attendance is needed (or you could just be on PollEverywhere all the time).

Literally dont take the class. Everyone says that its easy but its NOT. I had to S/NC the class because I was so close to getting a C. No matter how much you study, she will quiz you on random stuff in the textbook.

A fun and easy class! I definitely learned a lot more than I thought I would. Dr. Wong is very engaging and is enthusiastic about the material and makes sure to teach it with a very non-white-centric viewpoint to make sure we get the full "story" and context of American popular music of days gone by. 1 1000-word paper on a biopic of her choice (we did Selena), and 4 non-cumulative quizzes (the last quiz is the "final" and covered 1970s-onwards) - the criteria for the biopic paper is easy to understand and the quizzes are extremely straight-forward. Discussion is nice, we sometimes talked about stuff that wasn't covered in class but is in the textbook, and each discussion before the next quiz was dedicated solely to review.

Took this class with Professor Wong. Decently harder than I expected. It's not that the material was difficult to comprehend, it's that there's 4 quizzes in the class and each has 15 questions and is worth fifteen percent of your grade. So getting a few questions wrong means you're screwed. And it's pretty easy to mess up since some questions are based on memory of what an artist looks like or a certain part of a song out of a required 30 songs that are required. Study for quizzes, go to discussion. This was my lowest grade of the quarter, but I got an A.
I took this class fully online with Professor Moore. It was pretty easy, although it's hard to learn music online. Concepts are easy and not too much work.
Ez pz. Go to discussion, don't procrastinate the essay, exams is stuff on lectures. You should probably at least read the textbook pages.

Had Walter Clark Winter 2023. His slides contain a lot of information so more than anything take notes on what he says. However, he tends to get off topic a lot making it difficult to say what to take notes on and what not to take notes on. His exams have a listening portion (music) and a written portion. Memorizing the composers and the songs they wrote is crucial during the exams.
Took it with Chavez, exams were fair but a little bit on the hard side. There were two midterms and 1 final
I took Xochilt Chavez online, it was not that hard, but it was very disorganized.

Took it with Prof Walter Clark and he was honestly the best. Yeah, the subject did get boring sometimes during lecture and he doesn't post slides, but overall it was an easy class if you just look over the study guide before the test. Exams include a multiple choice, listening, and essay section. Essay is given on the study guide, and it's exactly the same questions on the actual midterm. Grading policy is straightforward, but the only thing I wasn't a big fan of was the mandatory attendance for lecture. Would recommend taking this class as a fine arts course

This class is an easy A with Walter Clark. Only need to go to lecture to write down the notes he puts on the projector. 2 midterms, 1 final, 1 essay due at end of quarter. The exams are all MC, only have 3 options to choose from, and can be taken on a phone. Some of the listenings were confusing but easy if you study 1-2 days before the test.
Literally, go to class. BS the assignments. Go to class, and he will give you answers to the final.

Dr. Barnett is a pretty funny guy and really cares about his students and their success. His assignments are pretty easy and straight-forward--he tells you everything you're being graded on and grades fast. Attendance is mandatory and so is accessing the textbook (you use the same textbook through the whole 30 series and even the MUS131 series)

Individual private Voice Lessons with either a male or female instructor. Worth 1 unit. There is a required final performance in front of other classmates taking this class. You will be given a music piece to sing to, could be classical or before 1980s pieces, but no contemporary music. You do have to practice by yourself for at least 5 hours a week.
Violin Class
Concert Band/Wind Ensemble, literally only graded on attendance. Dr. Andress is pretty chill.

(Fall 2020 Online) This class is for the PERSIST Research program. I had Dr. Nugent and it was honestly a pleasure. She is a sweet soul that is absolutely intelligent and intimidating because of it haha. Nonetheless, she allowed a welcoming environment that had room for errors and asking questions. I learned a lot from her in this course even though at times the course seemed to be a little unorganized.

Freshmen Advising Seminar: Just show up, take notes, and learn. The class requires homework but you do not need to buy the textbook. You will never use that textbook so go only for the online things to access.

The main lecture is by Morrison and she is very chill...the only problem you would have is when you have discussions, try to avoid getting Nancy Vasquez. Remember one thing for the class, if you miss the class or are late you can't make up for it and it will affect your grade. The classes are both pass/fail so it isn't bad but if you miss a class that is your only strike. Miss more than one and you will be failed for both the discussion section and lecture section. Oh yeah there's a textbook which is completely useless but you need it for the access code. Honestly it was a huge waste of money because you never use it. The only thing you will use however is Launchpad. Make sure to keep up with ur discussion section person because they don't always update your grades correctly on there.
Aquaponics. Fun.

I had professor Bruce Babcock. He's pretty cool, slightly unorganized. But if you go to lecture and do the 3 assignments, you'll be just fine. If you're interested in government you should have no problem taking interest into this class and getting a good grade. Readings not necessary

Took with Prof Babcock. Attend lectures and you'll be fine. Exams are fair and easy. Weekly readings but he goes over it during lectures so you don't really have to do them. 2 midterms and a cumulative final.

Honestly read the book before you attend lecture and really try to listen to professor Ramakrishnan. Doing all that reading and cramming the night before your Policy Brief, final, and midterm really isn't it, so get on top of it. Also T.A.'s will give you a long list of things to study, but like only a quarter of those things will be on the test. I barely attended lecture and I studied the night before my finals. Passed the class with a B+.
Taken with Babcock. Easy class somewhat tedious assingmnets.

prof brady fall 2020: exams & first two writing assignments were dumb easy, third 2000 word assignment should be ok if you don't procrastinate. dr. brady's really nice and although he's not v flexible for individuals he did make the final optional and promise a curve

Taken online with Professor Serieux-Lubin. Professor was extremely uninvolved, most interaction was through the TA. Never started anything before the day it was due in this class & got an A easily. 

-3 Written assignments (~200, 800, 2000 words)
-Exam every 2 week on 2 weeks of material that you learn from videos + linked readings. Used to be 2 short answer + multiple choice, was just multiple choice by the end of the quarter
-attendance taken once a week from discussion with the TA
-plenty of extra credit offered via discussion boards/submitting early drafts of written assignments

Took it with Brady and Babcock Spring 2021. Please avoid this class if you are a stem major as it will get in your way of focusing on your major classes. I have a few complaints. 1. There is a lot of reading. They are mostly 5-10pg articles and they average about 7 different articles A WEEK. The exams are reading heavy so you have to read the articles to do well. 2. The TAs are absolutely useless. It sucks enough that all lectures are recorded so you have no contact with the professor. My TA took an average of 1 week to respond to my emails, which would be too late anyway. The only actual class time is during discussion and most of the TAs for this class will straight up say to not ask them about the material because they don't have time to look at it. For exams, they tell you to do the reading, give you a study guide of what they think will be on the exam and call it a day. 2. There are 4 midterms and 1 final exam. Basically, there is an exam every other week on Fridays, so be careful about what classes you might have on Fridays. 4. The assignments are tedious and boring and the TAs grade harshly for things like citations, grammar, word count, etc. If you go over or under the word requirement, you will get points deducted. 5. The professors are not empathetic. A peer of mine got sick with covid and was in the hospital. When they let the professor know since they missed an assignment, the professor said that they should have told him sooner and the student received a 0 on the assignment. Good things about the course: 1. open-note exams 2. recorded lectures if that's your thing 3. Sometimes curves exam scores. 4. They drop your lowest exam score. (somehow got an A, but still. Good luck lol)

I took this class online, for spring quarter in 2021, because I had read some threads recommending this class. This class is basically Busywork: The Class, and I would strongly, STRONGLY advise against taking this class if you don't need to. I took this class for credits, and the amount of time I had to put into this class was ridiculous. I ended up having to put more time in this class than the other two classes I took this quarter combined. The grading for this class is based around biweekly exams (that's 5 exams total - 5!!) that are open-book, but because they are open-book, the professor takes that as an excuse to grill you on minute details of the readings assigned for that week. Readings are pretty lengthy, and on top of doing readings as well as studying for each of the 5 exams, you are also given writing assignments that progressively get longer on creating your own public policy. I did fine on these writing assignments, as well as the exams. It feels like you only have to do the bare minimum to succeed in this class, but the bare minimum is still a ridiculous amount of time.
The papers were annoying to write and I feel like you don't really learn that much. It's easy especially with Dr.Ahumada

If you don’t delay this class is a cakewalk. The teacher pushed the quizzes back till the last day. I’m not sure if this is Covid specific, but the quizzes were also open note. If you are interested in writing research papers or like researching specific stuff this class is perfect

Taken with Bruce Babcock. It is ridiculously hard for an intro class. He prides himself on the fact that students get Cs on all his exams. The material is convoluted, and the TAs can't explain the material effectively. There is a quiz EVERY day, so if you miss one lecture, you're losing points. The exams are so hard and purposely confusing.

Took with Prof Brint. Group/partner discussions every lecture. Pop quizzes every week. 1 midterm and final. Interesting class and enjoyable. Quizzes & TA can make or break your grade. Optional debates that you can do but it is limited and assigned during the first lecture.

Taken with Professor Brint. Excellent teaching methods. Sometimes a bit slow on getting to the point. Class not difficult. Optional debates that can be substited for Midterm/Policy Report. Decently easy.
Relatively easy class, usually taught by Dr. Brint. Just study the slides and it is an easy A.
Took it with Prof Vergara-Tapia, class content was interesting and straightforward. There is a midterm and a final, and weekly quizzes. Most test questions come from lecture
Easy class - completetly asynrchronous. Taken with Serieux-Lubin. Super easy midterm and papers. Easy/Free A basically
Took it with Prof Serieux Lubin, she was really understanding and kind. The class is 2 papers, 4 discussion posts, a midterm and final. The test questions are straight from lecture too. Great class.
Class wasn't too hard, took it with Prof Seriuex Lubin during Fall 2020 so it was online and asynchronous. Open note midterm and final. She gives a lot of opportunity for extra credit near the end.
Very easy! 2 policy briefs that were short (minimum 500 words) and the TA was lenient.
serieux-lubin winter 2021: so, so many extra credit opportunities. really don't have to read anything, although the readings are pretty interesting in their own right
Easy class if it is online. Took it asynchronously and the professor was good about announcements. Only 1 midterm, 1 final, and 2 papers. Lot's of extra credit.

Taken with Brady. Nice class a lot of application of sociological concepts and ideas. A lot of reading but the class is completely doable. Super nice and curves exams. Make sure you read/skim read for the exams - completely fair!

Taken with Jeffrey Allen. Amazing professor and definitely recommend. His lectures are informative and he keeps them interesting. His midterm and final are straightforward free response tests from the lecture content and there is one paper. Great guy to talk to as well!

Taken with Newman. Super easy class consisting of reading quizzes. You dont really need to read the readings - just need to know how to skim the content appropriately. Besides that a short paper and attendance and thats all. Super accomodating and very good class
As long as you attend some of the public policy events that are approved for this class and write reflections on them you'll pass. It is an S/NC course.
Public Policy Internship. Just do the 5 easy papers and get an evaluation and you are set.
You don't even have to read for this class just memorize the slides and listen to the lectures. Took it with Andreja Novakovic

Really easy class. The readings are basically useless because all the material you need for tests comes from the slides. Professor Novakovic isn't challenging anyone that much in this class since many people just take it to fill a breadth requirement. Just listen to what she says during lectures
Novachovic: If you attend the lectures and pay attention, you can succed. Paying attention and reading the passage ensures an easy B+ or A
Don't take it with Keller. He teaches the subject in a strange way and is difficult to listen to.
Professor Wood is a great professor. No mid term, no final, just 3 papers throughout the quarter.

Took with Dr. Joshua Wood. Pretty straightforward class. 3 essays, and each essay added an extra prompt on top of the previous one. (Ex. If essay one asked you to explain an argument, the second essay asked you to do the same, and give a counterargument.) Essays were graded by the TA, No Midterm or Final Exam

Had Joshua Wood. This class really shouldn't have been that hard, but I had a picky TA who didn't use the professor's grading scale for the essays. No midterm, no final- just papers. Go to your TA's office hours to find out what exactly they are looking for in the essays. Barely have to show up to lecture

Took with John Fischer, extremely easy, your grade really depends on your TA, was able to get extra credit points, read the lecture slides and you're fine, you don't need to do the readings, no paper just 2 midterms and a final; show up to discussions
The class itself was fairly easy. You don't even need to read. The people who determine your "fate" are your T.A'S. Everything is graded by your T.A.

Taken with Luca Ferrero. He is a good professor, but he over-explains a bunch of concepts for most who are taking this class as a breadth course. The quizzes are TOUGH. You have 3 hours and it is technically open note, but its nearly impossible ton find the answer in a straightforward manner. Very weird grading scale - TA's do literally determine your grade and fate so be nice to them.
Dense and boring lectures, but the information is interesting. If that makes sense. Discussion is where it really matters, it'll help you retain info better.

Took it with professor Swanson. Just 3 papers, rarely attended lecture all slides are online but ask the TAs for help if you want a good grade on your paper. It seems straightforward but they have high expectations for them
Took it with Dr. Wood & very helpful if you go to lectures, the exams and finals weren't too bad as long as you went to lecture
took it with Swanson, just 3 paper, nothing hard

I took it with Wood. I would say, if you can connect with what's being said at lecture with the readings, this is an okay class. Somewhat lots of reading (ranging from like a short article to a chpt) for each class but overall, I think it was actually okay. The lectures and readings are kinda interesting and I didn't feel drowsy/kept up with the lectures. Would recommend if you're okay with reading/looking at things from someone else's POV

I had Swanson as prof and Andrew as TA. The material itself wasn't that bad, however the lectures (asynchronous on mondays and synchronous on wednesdays) were really long and full of information. Taking notes is important because a lot of the quiz/test material was from the lecture. For the papers, ask your TA what they're looking for because they help grade. Our midterm was 25 multiple choice and 5 essay (~ a paragraph answer) questions and was curved because not a lot of people finished and our final was an essay. we also had weekly quizzes but you could work with other people on them
This class definitely requires some effort but honestly it was pretty interesting and I really liked the prof (Snelson).
The TAs never coordinate with each other so the writing and the philosophy ones will never say the same thing. The professor is also boring and the readings can become quite difficult to understand.

I had this class with Professor Frost for Fall 2021 and ended up with an A. I believe the course itself is pretty interesting, but the readings/lectures are very long and sometimes confusing. The TA really makes or breaks the class imo but personally I loved my TA. As long as you finish the journal assignments, then you should be okay. Also, there's no final!! just two essays due (one on Week 5 and one of Week 7 I believe).

I had Ethics and the Meaning of Life with Kim Frost as my prof. Frost is pretty chill and accommodating. All lectures were asynchronous, 1 in-person discussion section a week. No tests, no finals. There were two 5-6 page papers and weekly journal assignments (3-4 questions). The grading is a little confusing, but basically the more work you do the likelier you will have a good grade. There are no books to buy, everything is supplied with PDFs. TA’s are really important, my TA was wonderful and explained things well and helped us with everything. In general, if you keep up with the assignments and double check your ideas/thesis statements with the TA before writing papers you will get an A. Not a difficult class. Also, asynchronous lectures & readings can be skimmed as long as you can do the journal assignments well. 

Pre-requisite is Eng 1a and 1b. This is an English 1c class. Need to be good at forming ideas, actual writing is not as complicated.

Taking it with Prof Cherry Myisha. This class isn't offered every quarter, according to my TA. Must go to section as HW is 45% of your grade and discussion itself is 15%. Other than that, the midterm was pretty easy if you paid attention in lecture or at least went over lecture notes. HW is a 1 page "essay" on 2 questions from the book, but discussion is amazing. My TA Victor is great at explaining philosophical concepts and does a great job of utilizing section time.
Exams are free response. TA was amazing

I took this class with Professor Cherry. It was pretty interesting as it discussed the origins of race, along with present implications. The professor seemed pretty interested in the course content and she only had one 30-40 minute lecture a week, which was pretty nice. There were only 3 homework assignments, 1 midterm, and 1 final. But, your grade really depends on your TA. Everything is free response and this class doesn't use rubrics. There's also a participation grade so you're required to have your camera on and discuss each class.

Overall, I would recommend taking this class. The content is pretty interesting. Just try to do some research on your TA. The TA is the one who really determines how you do.
class is very conceptual, few key details you have to memorize for exams etc, but overall the class really opens your eyes about racism and how its in our daily lives

The class is fun because it talks about the root and foundations of races. Your grade is all dependent on your TA cuz they will be grading ur essays (yes the class is just writing, no multiple choices), so try to pick a good TA. the whole grade is made up of discussion participations, 3 writing assignments, one final, and one midterm (no curves on exams and ECs). I had Sammie and he is A LEGEND. Super understanding and will grade you more easily if English is not our mother language. Professor Cherry’s lectures are fun and you can tell she is actually passionate about the things she is teaching. But, be sure to read the textbook and material before heading to the lecture and discussion. The midterm and final are super EZ, just make sure to do the study guide BECAUSE EVERYTHING on the study guide IS THE EXAM ITSELF. In conclusion take this class, and make sure to read.

The professor made the class much harder than need be. As a fourth year taking a lower div. I can honestly say that was the hardest class I have ever taken. Even a friend of mine who majored in philosophy looked at what was expected for the final and thought it was ridiculous for a intro class.
Eric Schwitzgebel teaches this course. It isn't difficult as long as you attend lecture and read the material.

This class is a fair bit of reading but Prof. Schwitzgebel makes sure to clear up any confusion with extremely engaging lectures. Attendance is not mandatory but showing up to lecture is incredibly worth it as they're really interesting and he covers some topics not mentioned in the overheads (such as examples). 1 500-word essay, 1 1200-word essay, 2 midterms, and 1 final. The midterms are 10 quote ID, 10 multiple choice, and 2 short-answer, with the final being 20, 20, and 4 respectively. Essay rubrics are extremely concise and easy to understand. The professor is a wonderful, sweet man and is definitely one of my favorite professors on campus - he always makes time for his students and is incredibly understanding and personable. He teaches the class in the fall, so definitely take it with him if you can!
I took it with professor Wettstein. He very much focuses on religion. It wasn't that hard but it was boring and very theological.

Took it with Eric Schwitzgebel. Ridiculous amount of reading. It's not hard to understand but it's the most reading I've ever had to do for a single class. But if you do all the reading the exams and essays are pretty simple.

10/10 amazing class. I took this class just because its a funny name, but god its great. It will completely change your outlook on evil. This class isn't easy, but it is one of the best classes Ive ever taken. You need to do the readings, and although some are long they are very fun. Essays aren't easy, but I did them near the last minute so not really sure. Get a discussion that is when youre able to be focused, because discussion's were great. The TA and the Teacher know their stuff backwards and forwards, its incredibly impressive. If you need a philosophy credit, or hell if you just want a good class, take this one.
took it with professor erik. i only took it because people who took it prior, said it was easy. I DIED during this class. the test is so difficult, but the essays were easy

Professor (Coleen) was very poor at using time effectively in class. Often rambled/discussed some meaningless corner case for our content. Course material itself isnt too hard however. Book is also somewhat verbose and reading it can be a challenge. Quizzes are 90% of your grade (10% each, 9 total, during discussion). I HIGHLY suggest getting Akshay Ganesh for TA. He releases his personal notes the day before his discussion and they are extremely helpful. There are in class quizzes which are worth around 5% of your grade. The class is curved to a B-. As long as you do well on the weekly quizzes in your discussion, you'll do fine.

Professor Londen was really nice. The only way to prepare for the quizzes and to get an A honestly is to meet up with him during office hours and ask him to give some more examples of the sorts of questions he wants us to answer. Show up to lecture!

Prof. Londen teaches this class and is super nice and willing to help, you just have to communicate. This class was very difficult because you are learning a new skill. The class is curved though so I believe a 50% was actually a C. If you want to pass the class with an A which is 100% possible, start off strong and go to office hours starting week 2 before your first exam. There is a test every week so go to office hours every week because everything is built ontop of everything so if you dont understand something from a previous week it will harm you the entire quarter. The TAs and prof all grade each individual exam together so they try to give you as many points as possible. Final exam is optional.

Loved this class. Really interesting topics, although the essays can be difficult at times. I had Sammie as my TA and he was VERY helpful. He guided me through my essays when I needed help and replied quick when you emailed him. Professor Cherry lectures very well but she is NOT accessible at all. I've emailed her multiple times and have not gotten a single email back. Keep in mind that I'm writing this on Week 8. She's a great teacher, but it's just annoying when you have specific questions or comments about class and you're getting no reply.

*Spring 2022 Online* I had Professor Wood and he is like the Bob Ross of teachers. He is so nice and super helpful. It's clear he has a passion for teaching. We had 10 question Canvas assignment due every Thursday but you could redo up to 3 times and a quiz every Friday which you could retake 2 times. He dropped the 2 lowest quizzes. Lectures were easy to understand and the homework and quizzes were not hard at all. I just skimmed his lecture notes before doing them and got 100s so you should be fine. I don't know if this is the format for in person but if this class is online TAKE IT.

Took this with Colleen in Winter 2023. Overall, a pretty easy class. Participation in lectures was required in the form of Poll Everywhere questions. Generally, an assignment was due before each lecture, but they were graded on effort and not correctness. There were 3 exams, but (at least to me) none of them were too hard and could be completed with relative ease if you paid attention in lecture. The concepts taught in the course were also not terribly hard to understand. I remember only having a bit of trouble with the concepts in the first 2-3 weeks, but after that, everything felt easy.
Since I was in honors, I had the professor as my TA in discussion. Very helpful and easy class. Got an A. It was more of an online class
very easy to learn everything, the end of the quarter is where it gets a bit hard, but nothing scary.

The professor Nagashima himself is a nice guy who is trying his best to teach. The class however I found a bit difficult. In the beginning the class was very easy to follow and was going at a steady pace Then out of nowhere towards the last couple of weeks we get thrown these difficult concepts which had little relation to what we learned in the beginning. Must have time to study outside of class or you will bomb the second midterm and final. I managed an A on both midterms but I invested quite a bit of time in study groups etc. It’s passable but as a breadth class it was a bit stressful.

The class can get confusing if you have Michael Nelson but as long as you go to every lecture and disscusion and pay attention then you should do fine. 4-10 problems for homework a week but some hw sets may take a few hours. The concepts can be a little hard to grasp but the classwork is fairly low. Never studies for both midterms and I got an 88% on both.

Took it with Michael Nelson. This guy is so confusing in his lectures, and he wrote the book, which is worded just as he talks. Hard class tbh. Got an A minus because the final was hard as hell, even after getting a 94 and 100 on my two midterms, and over 100% on my homework.

this class is definitely hit or miss; like either you'll find it super easy and get an A+ or you won't understand jackshit. if you're familiar with cs this class won't be too bad bc it's basically all boolean like true/false. but prof nelson is definitely not a good teacher and is super confusing. if you have mcdonald as your ta you'll be fine tho.

I had Professor Erich Reck, the materials might be difficult depending on how much you can comprehend logic, but the class is relative easy to pass. You get 3 tries for homework, extra credit problems on (most) quizzes and midterms. It is an easy A if you do homework, attend discussion, and watch lecture

I took this class with Andrew Law and he mentions this early on in the course but this course is easy in the beginning but it gets extremely difficult towards the end. We used an online website (Carnap) to do basically everything on but it was free so you don't have to pay anything. Just make sure you pay close attention especially after the first midterm since that's when stuff really picks up and gets confusing. I recommend attending every lecture because if you miss one you can get really far behind. There's also weekly homework, 2 midterms and the final.

In my experience, CS/CE/EE majors easily carry this class while other majors may struggle a bit. The first half is just truth tables and logic functions, which are both super easy. The second half is all proofs, which is where some of the class started to struggle. About half the class ended with As and the other half got Cs/Ds. This is basically a math class disguised as a philosophy class so just keep that in mind.

Took it with Prof Andrew Law online, he's an amazing lecturer and professor. He really cares about his students and is always available for help and questions. He would host review sessions before the midterms and the final. The first half of the class was a breeze but the second half (derivations) was a lot harder. The class is like PHIL007 in that there's no philosophical readings, rather learning a skill set and applying it to arguments and checking if arguments are valid or not. 2 midterms, 1 final, weekly homework sets due sunday night, discussion, book readings were recommended and uploaded on ilearn.

Took with Erich Reck. If you go to class and pay attention to lecture, this is an easy A. It's more of a critical thinking/reasoning class than anything. Was able to get a 100 on the first midterm after going to only half of the classes, and didn't go to any from week 7 - week 10. Still got a 94 on the final pre-curve with 2 cram sessions before the final. Final was curved to a B average, no one got below an 85 on it. Midterm curves aren't as severe, but are definetly helpful. Go to discussion, TAs are incredibly helpful.

There's only 2 mandatory essays. 4 if you count the first one, which is a practice essay to get feedback and stuff, while the fourth one replaces your lowest essay score (provided that it was above a 70%? I believe). I got an A- but you still have to work for your grade, especially since the readings are pretty difficult to process BUT the professor (I had Joshua Wood) will give you outlines of the articles, so it's easier to understand. He's also pretty funny in the slack channel. One girl was like, "Where is the 10th assignment?" when we only had two essays, and he was like "you're scaring people" LOL. Make sure you don't procrastinate on your essays! My TA liked a direct approach to writing, so be concise with your wording and make it easy to understand.

Took it with Dr. Joshua Wood during Fall 2020. No mandatory lectures and he gives you an free version of the textbook online. Dr. Wood is super sweet and his lectures (if you do decide to go) are essentially a discussion about the assigned readings. If you choose not to go, he offers recorded lectures and notes as supplements.  Homework are the assigned readings but you don't really need to read any of them unless you're choosing that specific one to write the essay about. No exams only four essays two of which are mandatory; the first one is a practice one and the last one is an extra credit opportunity. Each essay increases in page limit; the first one 1-2, second 2-3, etc. Essays are super easy and basically an analysis essay on the argument of the document. TAs grade the essays so it really depends on them. I had Gustavo for my discussion and he was pretty easy going, attending was also not mandatory. The only assignment was a discussion question regarding the material due every Wednesday and in the discussion he'd address those questions.

I took it with Dr. Wood. The class will be relatively easy, however there is a lot of reading. Some of the readings are interesting and will keep you entertained in a way, but sometimes they can be a bit hard to read. I recommend taking notes! Your grade is all based on papers! So, your TA will determine your grade. Averages for papers are B's, so as long as you have decent essay-writing skills and actually read the papers or looked at lecture notes/videos, you'll do fine! Grammar doesn't seem to matter too much on papers, but the information will matter A LOT! Don't push off all the readings till last minute!

Had Professor Wood for Fall 2021 (asynchronous). Pretty chill class, Wood's lecture vids were ~15min long and he provided notes that summarized each reading. No exams, only four papers (the first one was optional). How well you did in the class depended on your TA since they're the only one who read your essays. I had John Green, and he was nice but graded ruthlessly. General consensus was that TA's liked papers that were concise and straightforward.

If you're taking it with Jeremy Pober, expect a pretty easy class. He's a great professor and lectures very clearly so that the material (which can be sometimes challenging) is broken down into simple concepts. You're going to write two papers, with the first paper being 10% of your grade and the second paper being 15%, but both are only 1.5 pages long. The midterm was easy for me and I anticipate the final on being equally simple. On his exams, he dedicates 5 questions for you to explain your previous answers and, if he thinks they're acceptable explanations, you will be able to earn the points back if you missed the question. Overall, pretty enjoyable experience; I would take him again.

Professor Muller is a bit quiet when he lectures but he’s helpful for using examples to simplify concepts. Midterm was not so bad but your grade depends on your TA. Likewise for your essay too since there’s only one. Entire grade is balanced by midterm, essay, and final!

Took this class with Professor Harmer. IMO a decent professor, but the lectures were pretty dry and boring at times. 4 open-book quizzes ONLINE worth 5pts each (20% of grade), along with 2 essays (first is 3pgs, worth 10%, next is 5pgs, worth 30%). He posts the lecture notes on ilearn, but I recommend going to lecture because he breaks down all the confusing concepts/explains pretty well. Just do the readings ahead of time, go to discussion (TAKE IT WITH ANDREW LAW, bc he really helps clarify everything; I understood the material more when he explained it than when the professor did lol). Passed with an A, but you definitely need to put in some work to get an A in the class. Forgot to mention: on the final, you get to bring a cheat sheet (1 page handwritten) with anything you want to write down: Prof Harmer distributes the essay questions for the final a week before, so you can just write down your final essay on that piece of paper walk in and copy it down on the final exam.

Took this class with Professor Harmer. Overall, the class was okay. I have no interest in Philosophy and was only taking it because it's a requirement, so I found the class boring majority of the time. Class is reading heavy, but he breaks them down really well during lectures and in my experience, my TA did well on breaking them down during discussions (mandatory) too. 3 quizzes, 2 papers, 1 final. For the quizzes, the questions ask you to find a specific quote from the readings and explain them, so read closely! The papers aren't too bad and he gives you a lot of time to finish them; make sure to go to office hours if you need help. The final wasn't too bad; there were mc questions, free response questions, a long answer question. He gives out the long answer question a couple of weeks ahead and also allows a double-sided cheat sheet. Due to certain circumstances, the final was online and not the normal in-person style.

Fairly easy class to get A if you put in the effort. Attend lectures since Professor Harmer will break down the texts so you can understand it better; do the readings because it will help you on the free-response quizzes and essays; and attend discussion since that's part of your grade. Final is decent since he allows a cheat sheet and gives out the prompt one week early.
Pretty easy class. Two essays, open note/book quizzes, and a final
If you are a philosophy major, take this course as early as possible. The skills learned from Dr. Macnamara are invaluable. You'll feel capable of tossing out a few publications before you graduate.

Took with Andrew Law Winter 2021. As a BCOE student it's not bad at all, pretty much just a 10-20 page reading before each class and he just explains it in more detail during lecture. No homework or exams, you only have to write two essays the entire course. The hardest thing is coming up with new contributions so you can't just write a compare and contrast essay on two of the readings. Just try to think about the most interesting thing you read and why it's interesting, then talk to Andrew he can definitely give good suggestions for essays. 

Also for BCOE: this class does not count towards your DEPTH, I thought it did and I had to fight to make it count.

Easy class, confusing professor, TA is anal over everything. I had Nelson as a professor, and while he isn't super strict or anything, he could elaborate on a few points here and there. I had Tayor as a TA, and while he's way better at teaching the material, he sucks at grading. Not only that, but he's inconsistent with his grading. He does not believe in partial points for any extra credit questions. We had weekly homework and some example problems on iLearn. The example problems were way easier than the homework problems and were more focused on teaching material than helping us see patterns in derivations.

This class is really easy if you took PHIL008 (Intro to Logic, maybe that's 8 I don't remember which one it is). I think only Michael Nelson teaches it. He's a very unorganized professor that likes to randomly change the homework and lectures at will. If you didn't take PHIL008, I hear it was very difficult and troublesome to pick up the course content because they assume you know PHIL008 stuff from Week 0. Nothing from PHIL008 is reviewed, they just assume you already know it and they move on with the schedule.
The course involves 9 homeworks (assigned every single week starting from Week 2 to Week 10), two midterms and a final. It also has a bunch of in-class quizzes involved (to incentivize people to come in at 8AM I guess?), some "improvement" score that's worth 5% of your grade and discussion attendance is mandatory. If you miss discussion, your OVERALL course grade gets docked 4% every single time if you don't have a valid excuse. 
Course content includes semantic proofs, main operator identification, truth tables, countermodels, logical consequence, propositional logic (AND / OR / IF, THEN / NEGATION, etc), quantificational logic (For All, There Exists, etc), and A LOT of derivations. Like, A LOT of derivations. If you took PHIL008 then you know how the derivations go; they basically just build on the derivations from PHIL008 and added some new operators for propositional logic. In the last few weeks, they'll teach you how to do quantificational logic derivations which is much more difficult but manageable.

I had this with Michael Nelson. He's not that great at explaining the material, but since it's not that particularly difficult, you should do fine with the book and example problems he posts online. Though for my class, discussion was mandatory otherwise you'd lose 4% from your final grade, and the TA was better at explaining things than the professor. The class isn't exactly easy per say, but if you put some effort into learning the material, you should be fine. Some derivations can be difficult and time consuming, but the class is manageable overall.

Took with Nelson in Winter 2020. This class gives you DEPTH and TECH ELECTIVE credit. I didn't take PHIL 008 before this so derivations made me go "wtf" for the first 2 or 3 weeks. Difficulty was 6/10 at first since I didn't know how to properly construct derivations and then apply the rules. Go to the TA for help and have them go through the fundamentals. Once you catch on, the class becomes 4/10 in difficulty. The other reviews of this class still apply.
It’s not that hard… but it might make you really sad for the people waste their lives studying philosophy.

Took the class with Nelson in Winter 2022. Not a great experience. His lectures are so confusing that even a classmate did a better job explaining than he did. The beginning of the class is fine and all the derivation rules are easy to understand. Then the class got super hard when it comes to semantic proofs. Finally it became fairly easy again after that. The real pain in the butt is that if you fail any one of his three exams, you fail the class. IMO it is a ridiculous system and puts a lot of unnecessary stress on the students. I hated it. But since this class fulfills multiple requirements for me, guess I'll just grind it out anyway... 
P.S. Anthony Stoner is a fantastic TA though. Do take his discussion if possible.

Took with Alexandra Newton. As a computer science major, I found this class pretty interesting due to the professor. One in-class writing assignment (20%), two take-home quizzes (10% each), one 5-7 page final paper (25%), one in-person final exam (25%). She grades pretty leniently, considering the fact I haven't written an essay in 4 years, but still walked away with a B+. Attendance mandatory (10%). Overall, found the class easy and fun as long as you attend class.
Take Gabor. He's absolutely amazing
Hai Bo Yu doesn't help with MasteringPhysics and the textbook isn't good.

Professor Hai Bo Yu was a nice guy, but his accent made it hard to understand sometimes, and he mostly just read off of premade lecture slides straight from the textbook. I learned everything from doing the homework and from watching videos online, not from him.
Exams are unpredictable. Avoid Joshua Lui. Other professors are much better.
Joshua Lui is okay, but exams were a bit hard. Allows you a formula sheet.
Easy homework and clickers. Hard tests

Had Yongtao Cui. Was concerned since he has 0 ratings online so I didn't know what to expect. However, he's a decent professor. Exams are quite hard, midterms averages about 40-50%, same as final. Important to not fall back in this class as the material is quite hard to understand without going to class. I scored 20-25% above exam averages and that got me an A.

Difficult because many students are balancing this class with CHEM 008A. Definitely recommend you to read up on each chapter during the weekend before the lecture. It helps you understand the material early on. I also recommend that you do the practice problems in the textbook for additional practice outside of HW. If you have Peng Wei, I recommend to go to office hours and ask him for help especially if you're falling behind.

Took it with YongTao Cui. A very caring professor but a hard class. Averages for exams were about 40% but there was a fat curve at the end. Definitely do practice questions and make sure you understand the concepts.

I took this class with Beyermann in the summer of 2020. Would not recommend. His tests are difficult. Furthermore, the hw he assigns aren't similar to what the tests looks like. Granted that this class was in 5 weeks so take this with a grain of salt.

Took the class with Beyermann over the summer, would not recommend with him because it was my first time taking physics so I was really lost, midterms were really hard 30-60% averages, final was doable. Try finding someone else first

"Never took PHYS, but taking it with Professor John Ellison was the best choice ever! He is very patient in answering questions during lecture, reexplains concepts that are hard/what he thinks most students struggle with, and is very very understanding of the pandemic conditions! His midterm is very similar to his practice exams and homework is difficult so if you struggle with that don't worry to much just make sure to understand the practice exams and concepts. Final is NOT cumulative so that helps too. Does online clickers for credit so class is kinda mandatory and I never read his reading notes before lecture, but doing that would've helped me .
PHYS 2A is known as a weeder class, but I learned a lot and walked out with a B+ because of Prof Ellison so definitely take it with him!"

Took it with Beyermann online during Spring 2021. His grading system is very fair; I just suck at physics. Study a lot and do extremely well on the first midterm, because the material gets really difficult after that. Also try to get as many points as possible on the poll questions because the amount to as much as a midterm. We had 2 midterms and a cumulative final. Try to stay on top of the material as much as possible, because it is really easy to fall behind.

Joshua Lui was very clear, but his exams are hard. It's almost unfair. His lectures glosses over the topic for the day. His homework was okay. It didn't help. His curves are okay, but theres definitely professors who has better. I would not recommend.
Good grades if you do the labs properly.  Easy final.

They may have changed it, but I took Fall 2018 and the labs were literally the WORST experience I've had at UCR. However, the final was really easy and there was a curve so it isn't hard to get an A, just an annoying class to take.

I think it is imperative to read the lab before you come to class so you have somewhat of an idea to complete the lab. It will help save you a lot of points and time. It also helps to ask the TA for certain sections in the lab. In addition, final assessment was done online (as a timed iLearn exam). Honestly, if you are well prepared for the lecture and know how to do the labs, you should be able to ace the final exam. P.S. You are allowed to use your lab notebook during quizzes and the final assessment, so write down those formulas and concepts if you need it (as a cheat sheet). :)

Took it online during Spring 2021. The lab notebooks were extremely difficult because they are very concept-based and require you to derive formulas you learn in lecture. To study for the final, read through your lab notebooks and the corrections TAs make so you know what you did wrong.

Super difficult and completely dependent on the TA. My TA was horrible (spoke very softly, didn't make sense when he talked, didn't understand the lab) so both I and my grade suffered. The lab manual has grammar and procedural mistakes and throws a bunch of information at you at once. It is also very unclear with what it wants sometimes. TA's would give lab quizzes that were completely insane and out of left field. The final was ok if you had a thorough lab notebook, but still there was no way to prepare for it.
Take Wimpenny for his good curve, by the class is still challenging no matter who you take it with. It's hard to understand what exactly is going on most of the time.
Wimpenny is boring but he has written exams so partial credit is possible
Mulligan is a good prof.  Look through all his slides and practice.  Big curve for class overall.
Had Mulligan. Very chill and relaxed with the course. Curve/cutoffs are very generous. Try to take him if possible, he didnt fail anyone!
Alot of forumlas to memorize. IF you get Jory Yamorff make sure you study, but he is a fair grader. Decent curve but not huge.
Mohideen has large curves with the avg being a B. Lots of formulas to memorize but not to difficult if you look at the units.
Took the class with Harry Tom over the summer, would not recommend, got an A+ but I had to sell my soul cause his midterm, quizzes, and final were some of the hardest things I've ever done.

Took it online with Harry Tom during summer 2021. Got an A+ but the worst experience of my life. Honestly, the content itself isn't that difficult, but the prof expects so much of you as a student. The exams and quizzes were super unreasonable and difficult, and even the TAs said that, too. He didn't even give us a formula sheet. The TAs said they were going to try and do something about how difficult he makes this class, but I am not sure what or if it will work. If you can avoid him and don't mind spending 10 weeks on a physics class, I would recommend taking the class at a different time with a different prof. If you can't avoid him, I would suggest reading each chapter before the lecture and doing the homework way early on so you can ask questions at office hours. The best way to study for exams is to review quizzes and discussion worksheets, because there's a lot of similar themes since he writes his own questions. Even though he curved the midterm, quizzes, polls, and the final exam grades by A LOT, the midterm average was a ~39% and the final exam average was 49-50%. 71.5% was the cutoff for an A, and passing was a 40%.
curve saves everyone 2nd half of the class is very hard
If you don't know lecture stuff, it's hard to follow along.  Final is easy if you know where to put equations.
The exams are mainly theory based now with few calcs. Write down impt in your lab notebook and chill.
Avoid Anderson. Google "UCSD 1C final exam" and there's over 100 practice problems from the equivalent course at UCSD
Simple class, simple work, and extremely high grade boosts in Barton's class.

(Took online in Winter 2021 with John Barton) This was the easiest of the Physics 2 series for me. Content-wise, it has some topics from gen chem, which makes it familiar and a bit easier to understand. His exams were all multiple choice and open note. Quite a few problems were similar to practice exams and it was not difficult to do well in the class as long as you know how to do practice exam questions and the lecture examples. A lot of it is just knowing how to use the formulas/equations, so sometimes just knowing how to do math can help you solve the problems! Since the exams are on the easier side, he doesn't curve much so 90 = A, 75 = B, and 60 = C, but if averages are low, he may change the cutoffs slightly. The professor you take for physics in general will determine how well you do since some professors give more difficult exams, but will curve or adjust cutoffs accordingly.

Anderson; I would say this class is the easiest within the series. Though, it doesn't mean that it's a walk in the park. Anderson was one of the laziest professors. He sent us into breakout rooms so we can discuss with each other. He goes into the breakout room one time and ask if everything is okay. He leaves before we can respond. The only perk is that his study guide/discussion questions is almost exactly like the exams. He changes the number, but it's not difficult to grasp.
