Took it online during summer 2021 with Jory Yarmoff. The material isn't that bad, but don't underestimate the exams. Try to do well on the polls and hw because those will help your grade a lot at the end.

Took in in Spring 2023 with John Ellison, in person. Homework - 10% (weekly, not one HW after every lecture), MT1 - 15%, MT2 - 15%, In-class quizzes (pollev) - 5%, Discussion section - 10%, Final exam (cumulative) - 45%

Good lecturer. Has an accent. Posts a pdf word version (condensed and more detailed) version of his slides. Then after every lecture he posts the slides of the words separated and more organized, but all the words are the same from the condensed version). Posts a practice test before each exam. They are semi-reflective of what I have seen before, but some questions felt kinda new to me. Goes over PollEv questions. Writes on his tablet during class, draws pictures to help visualize concepts and works through the example problems with us, but does not post these notes. The work for the examples are in the condensed version. We finished in a timely manner, and often early (5-10 minutes). Class is manageable with other STEM courses. He was a great professor. Approachable during office hours (on zoom) as well as answering any quick questions after class.
Write everything in your lab notebook and the final is a piece of cake.  Labs weren't too difficult either.
Homework was based on effort.

I took this with Professor Canalizo fall 2020. This was a super fun class to take if you enjoy science. It was basically an astronomy class including learning about different types of stars, gravity, planets, and things of that sort. There were weekly homework assignments around 10 questions, but the answers come directly from the lectures. Discussion sections are optional to attend, but found them very helpful. The TAs would be there to go over any homework questions. 2 midterms and a final (all open note).

Tests and quizzes are easy if you attend lectures, everything is on the slides. There is a weekly quiz thats only 2 questions and taken from the homework assignment. The homework assignment is essentially a study guide, it’s not actually due and the TA’s go over all the answer in discussion.

I recommend Bill Gary as he is a very accommodating professor and cared about the difficulty of the course for those who did not have a strong science background. This class focuses more on cosmology and overviews the main contributors and topics in physics. There is little to no math at all since learning was more conceptual. Weekly homework, which the quizzes are based off of and the TAs basically give you the answers beforehand anyways. One midterm and final, which he recycles questions he used  previous exams.

This class is a good mix of memorization and conceptual math. It can be difficult for some people who struggle with memorization or math. However, if you put in a lot of effort, you'll definitely finish with at least a B. Attend lectures, practice on MasteringPhysics and do the practice midterms/finals. There is a major curve at the end, so don't stress too much. The midterm and final averages were around a 60 percent.
Everything is curved and extra credit is provided so you cant fail
Taken with Brian Siana, super cool professor the class overall is fine and easy to follow but since it is made for non-science majors it can be difficult as there is a lot of math required

Took with Brian Siana. He is so nice and inspiring. He genuinely cares about the environment and actually does every day activities that reduces his carbon footprint. Class has a lot of math problems so make sure to study with the homework. Homework is optional but weekly quizzes during discussions. TAs makes the quizzes so if you're lucky, your TA might make easy questions/give you hints during discussion.

Took with Frederick Hamann, it was online because the campus shutdown. Midterm 30%, Final 40%, Quizzes 30%. We took the quizzes each week at the discussion session, it's only 2 questions. He gave us study guides for the midterm and final and also released all the possible quiz questions for the current week every week, that's how I managed to get an A in the class. No math to do or formulas to memorize in this class, you just need to remember vocab and concepts. Go to lecture and take notes.

At the time of writing this, I haven't finished the class, but it's the 8th week and I already know I'm going to pass, so I feel like I can write a pretty good review of the class. I took this class with Laura Sales in Spring 2023 and it's a very easy class. There's lecture participation in the form of PollEverywhere, but you're only required to do about 80% of the them to get full credit, so you safely miss two or three lectures throughout the quarter. Every week we get a Homework assignment, but you don't really have to do it as your TA in discussions go over the answers with the class. At the end of discussion you're given a quiz, which are just three questions from the Homework assignment, meaning they're quizzes you can easily get 100% on every single time. Then there's three exams. All of them are 10 questions long, online, and open-note, which makes them pretty easy. Only reason you should get a bad score in the exams is if you don't know how to navigate through your notes or the textbook. Now she decided this halfway through the course, but only two highest scoring exams will go into your grade, making this class even easier. Not to mention, she also offers 5% worth of extra credit where all you have to do is say one good thing about the week's lectures and one bad thing.

TLDR: Easy class if taken with Sales

I had Prof. Mobasher. He curved the course almost a whole letter grade after the final. The class was all theory of the Big Bang and the events after it.(Almost five weeks were spent talking abt the Big Bang) No math involved.
Homework is easy since you can just google it but the material is hard to understand if I could go back in time I wouldn't take this class again.
There's a lot of difficult content but Mobasher curves the tests greatly

Love Mobasher as a professor but the material is dense and hard to understand for non science people. Final and midterm is worth 25% of overall class and hw is 50%. Do with that what you must, but I personally would not take again not worth the stress.
Had it with Prof. Mobasher. Curves the test and google is your friend for homeworks and tests.
Took the class online with Prof. Mobasher. Super easy class, all homework could be found online, and both the midterm and final were open notes.
This class the exactly equivalent to AP Physics 1(but they don't give credit for some reason). Pay attention during rotation(moment of inertia, rotational kinetic energy). It's harder than it looks.

You definitely need to read the textbook thoroughly and watch a ton of Khan Academy videos or else you're going to do really bad in the class. One midterm and one final. No quizzes. Do your homework. Mastering Physics is a pain, especially with significant figures, but that will definitely make or break your grade.
If you have any physics background (high school, etc) this class will be easy peasy.
Most people weren't Reedy for the final. Overall pretty easy class; homework, clickers, 1 exam, 1 final. Just follow along with the class & know how to use the equations.
Professor Reddy. Overall grade is curved at the end.
Honestly, this class was harder than 40B and 40C for me. I got a C in 40A while I got a B+ in 40B and an A in 40C... Make sure you do a ton of practice problems and read the book.

Read the textbook, do a lot of practice problems. Bombed the final and got a C in the class but I also didn't do most of the homework and stopped going to lecture consistently. Just keep up and you'll be fine. Curved at the end; Reddy

Took this class with Reddy. Max all your other scores because you never know how the curve will affect you. Got a B- on the midterm  and then proceeded to get a D+ on the final and barely ended with a flat A so I got lucky solely because I made sure everything else was near 100%. As for the labs, don't just read the lab manuals beforehand - try and set up your lab pages/tables and answer the questions too. And if they don't provide excel spreadsheets to do calculations in, make them yourself because it'll save you a lot of time, especially if your TA is strict.

basically like AP Physics 1 with some other topics included and excluded. If you've taken AP Physics 1 and put in the work, this should be an easy A. No quizzes, only need to participate in 80% of clicker questions for a 100%, labs were sort of confusing at times but if you understand labs then you will be an A on the lab final.

took it with Reddy. his lectures are boring and all he does are problems. huge curve i got a 45 on the midterm and 81 on the final 79 on the lab portion 100 on discussion 97 in homework and it came out to a solid B+ with the curve
In discussion, the TA gives optional physics questions that are far harder to solve than those in class. Instead of doing everything, learning to solve these will ensure you succeed!
Professor Thomas Kulman was chill and funny for this class, homework was easy but the midterm was kinda hard. Overall alright class

I CANNOT STRESS THIS ENOUGH DO NOT GET MICHAEL ANDERSON UNLESS YOU WANT TO TEACH URSELF EVERYTHING. It's not worth it either switch profs or drop him. He does not teach anything nor does he explain anything in lectures. His style of "teaching" is to give a worksheet and have u do it on ur own. He does not provide answers for said worksheet nor explain how to do any of the problems ever. If you know physics by all means take the class for the units but if not avoid Anderson at all costs.
Screw Michael Anderson, worst professor I ever had at UCR, avoid him at all costs for any physics classes.

Had Anderson, class is very simple in terms of format, midterms (total of 2) are pretty much the same from class examples, and final takes questions from the midterms and practice tests. Make sure to attend lectures since he has clicker questions and participation activities. class is easy if you put some work.

I came into this with no physics knowledge at all since I didn't take it in high school. Physics as a whole is hard, but for the most part you just use equations and combine them together to solve word problems. I had Reddy for this class, the class average for the midterm was somewhere around 40% (free response), and the final was multiple choice. I absolutely bombed the midterm and did average on the final, ended up with a B by some miracle. The curve was absolutely huge for Reddy (45% was a C- lol).

Took this class with Naveen Reddy in Fall 2022. His instruction was okay but I found that the textbook as well as previous high school physics courses (such as AP Physics 1) were more helpful. Make sure to put in the work in at least skimming through the book and the equations, especially if you haven't had experience in prior physics classes. Topics covered largely resemble AP Physics 1 curriculum from kinematics all the way up to rotational motion. The class also had generous curving, especially for the final (though that may be because of the UC strike going on at that time). Overall not a very difficult class, you just need to put in the work.

Thomas Kuhlman one of the best physics professors. Good lecturing skills and will answer any questions you have.

The class itself is based around My Lab and Mastering a software through Pearson. Your grade comes from your performance on the grades, one midterm, lab, and the final. The grading system is based on points. The more points you earn the better your overall grade.

With the attached lab section, make sure to do well cause the grade from lab is added to the overall for the class. LSA pretty difficult so study.
Tsai is a terrrible professor but huge curves
homework was difficult. Practice exam was almost exactly the same as real exams. Hardest of the 40 series imo

I had Boerge as my professor and would honestly recommend him to anyone. He posts his lectures online and is very passionate about Physics + wants everyone to succeed. Make sure to go to his office hours in order to get any clarifications sorted out. If you also have Boerge, he basically covers 99% of the material from the textbook so you do not really have to read (although he will quiz you some concepts from the textbook during clickers).
In terms of the class, if you suffered through 40A, you will definitely suffer through 40B. The midterm was fairly simple, as it only covered about three chapters, but the final will definitely kill everyone's grade (however, it is not cumulative).
Discussions are mandatory and there was a quiz every class -- something not mentioned in the syllabus. According to my TA, 50% of one's discussion grade is based off attendance and the other 50% is based off the quiz grades.
Clickers were not based off participation -- something that is different from 40A. Make sure you attend every class as those points will matter.

The individual concepts and homework aren't too bad, the main difficultly in the class comes from the fact that all 3 professors write 1/3rd of the final and how Mills combines different concepts from the entire course into one question. For example this quarter(winter 2018) he somehow combined pistons, ideal gases, heat of vaporization, and thermodynamics into a single fucking question. Even if you understand the physics behind all these concepts perfectly, his questions feel like a puzzle. As far as I can tell, the other two professors make extremely "easy" straightforward questions and the curve is usually pretty nice. 

In the past, you would want to avoid Mills because he makes the hardest questions and he doesn't teach that well but now that all the professors are making the final, it might actually be beneficial to have him as a professor because you could get used to his madness before the final.
The class is pretty reasonable and doable and the midterm isn't that bad. The final was nothing like any of the practice or homework. It was extremely difficult and ridiculous

Content is relatively straight forward and homework reflects what is taught in class. Quizzes are ripped straight from the homework, so do the HW before discussion. Midterm and final are difficult, but practice exams should prepare you for them. Fat curve at the end of the class.

Most people will have a harder time with this than 40A, so it's important to read the book and make sure you're keeping up with the material. It mainly focuses on waves, but there is some heat transfer involved. I had Igor Barsukov. His tests are pretty hard but the curves are huge, I got a 45% on the midterm, which curved to a B.

Tsai is unbelievably boring. The lectures are legitimately a waste of everyones time, too bad there are clicker questions for points. The lab is shitty, but easy. Online homework is on chegg. Pretty sure I got an A despite missing most lectures. Definitely a self-study class.
Professor Long was so nice but he expects a lot of outside reading and work especially if you wanna do well on the exams. Hardest class in the phys040 series

I had Pryadko, and it's very hard to follow lecture. The textbook was a lifesaver. I would rate this class higher (I ended up rating it a 6), but Pryadko's curve makes it so a 55% is a C-. Without that curve, this class would be a 9 at minimum.
Labs were quite time consuming as the manuals weren't very well written. Not too bad of a class though, just know how to use the formulas and you should be good
Do not take with Long. He makes the tests unnecessarily hard.
About the same difficulty as Phys40A. Took it with Tanedo Winter 2021. If able, take this with Tanedo, he will make your life and physics so much easier.

Took PHYS040B with Tanedo. With Tanedo, this class was super easy. No quizzes, no tests, no midterm, no final. We have to make these weekly videos explaining how to do certain problems from the textbook every week and grade our peers on their videos. i think it's an effective learning format. Tanedo is genuinely such a nice guy and an amazing prof. Highly recommend taking 040B with him if you can. The labs are kinda painful imo, but they aren't too terrible.

try to take with Tanedo. he's the absolute best. no examinations, and he genuinely cares about how you are doing in the class and wants you to learn. grade based on you making explainer videos to show how to solve 2 physics problem given by him every week. made physics easy and entertaining, really is one of the best professors

Take this class with Phillip Tanedo if you can. It was literally a free class and the easiest A+ out of any class. About two videos a week and that's pretty much it. You'd have to try pretty hard not to get an A with Tanedo.

currently week 5 for me and mills is horrible. just reads off pre written google doc, does irrelevant demonstrations and practice problems. for the midterm practice exam he didn't even want to give us the solutions. When we convinced him to give them he said "here you go I dont even know if there right." We have video proof of everything

(Taken w/ Comron Nouri) This course was the most unorganized class I've taken at UCR. The MasteringPhysics signup code wasn't posted until Wednesday of Week 2, and after it was posted, it got changed twice until it was finally the correct one. The syllabus originally had a 10% grading category for Poll Everywhere (clicker questions), but it got removed and the 10% was added to the midterms instead, which ended up making the midterms worth more than the final exam. Our TA said that the class average on the 2nd midterm was about a 55%, but Dr. Nouri never confirmed that the midterm grades would be curved or scaled. Personally, I scored well above the class average on that midterm, although it was in no part due to Dr. Nouri's instruction. I believe that I only did well because I put effort into the assignments, went to every discussion, and attended SI sessions. 

Also, starting from halfway into the quarter, I began attending Dr. Wei's (the other professor for PHYS040B) lectures instead, and as a result I understood the content much better. Compared to Dr. Nouri's slides, Dr. Wei's were much better at helping me learn the material, and my notes were much more detailed after switching. Most importantly, Dr. Wei's slides were adequately annotated, whereas Dr. Nouri wouldn't even provide solutions to the example problems in his slides. On multiple occasions, I was confused on an assignment, and after finding Dr. Nouri to be unhelpful, I got a better answer from a TA. 

Overall, I definitely wouldn't recommend Dr. Nouri for anyone planning to take PHYS040B, and I strongly urge the Physics department to reconsider having him in a teaching position.
Much more difficult than 40B.
About the same as 40B, but no practice exams provided means I didn't do as well on the midterms/finals.

The class, itself, is really difficult and I struggled through it the entire quarter. Professor Sales, however, was a wonderful professor and explained the material thoroughly. I honestly recommend having her for your physics professor, even if it isn't for PHYS040C.
Side note, you really need to know the right hand rule for this class or you're going to suffer second half of the quarter.

Requires a bit of studying, but is ultimately not too difficult. Just pay attention in lecture and watch youtube videos to fill in gaps. Just don't take Monday labs as you will have to go over concepts that are taught in lecture later during the week.

Laura Sales was my professor. Very good teaching style, explains things well and does examples in class. Midterm is free response and multiple choice, while final was all multiple choice. I personally found 40C and 40B easier than 40A.

Took with Becker. I found this class a lot more difficult than 40A and 40B since I wasn't used to a lot of the concepts (I also fell behind so lol dont do that). The curves are gonna sharper since there was no helpful practice midterm or a practice final. But, if you score higher on your final than the midterm, the final replaces your midterm which is great!
Topics are tough so put in extra time to learn the concepts. Try understanding the concepts instead of memorizing as Becker tests more on understanding and applying. Much harder than 40B and 40A.

Took it with Yanou Cui. It was her first time teaching it, so she did not offer any practice exams. I personally wouldn’t take it again with her as I don’t like how she explained things. It seemed like all she did was read off lecture slides from the textbook. Her exam questions were also mostly theoretical instead of working with solid numbers.

Laura Sales was very easygoing during Fall 2020. She offered a modest amount of extra credit too. She really cares about the students learning, and overall, she was definitely one of my favorite professors at UCR so far. 4 exams total, each 5 multiple choice questions, and she drops the lowest score. If you're taking EE001A at the same time, you'll see a lot of nice overlap.

Professor Sales. SHE IS THE BEST PROFESSOR IN THE DEPARTMENT. Take this class if you are a non-physics major and would just like a class on physics taught in a casual, chill way. You will definitely learn from her class, and she is a great teacher. But she is also a practical person, and understands that not every one of her students wants to dedicate their entire lives around learning physics.
This class was made unnecessarily hard online, only 1 lecture a week (fall 2020),  a bunch of useless videos and a garbage textbook, if you have prior physics knowledge it is not that hard

dont do it with becker, he spends all of lecture rambling and not even half the class understands what hes saying. also he worries way more abt catching cheaters than making sure students understand material.

Took the class with Jonathan Richardson and the only reason I learned anything in this class is because of the TA. The homework and tests had no correlation. If you take it with Richardson, good luck.

Prof George Becker - Spring 2022. The class itself was not easy, but if you pay attention during lecture, Becker explains everything pretty well. 
If you do better on the final, it replaces the weight for your midterm. Example, if the midterm was worth 25% and final 35%, and you do better on the final, then the final would be worth 60% and midterm 0%. Shouldn't be too bad, as long as you pay attention in lecture.

Taken with Michael Anderson Spring 2021 (ONLINE), who assigned MasteringPhysics as a form of HW. The exam questions were slightly harder than the HW, but it was manageable due to a lack of proctoring. The lectures were mandatory, as you will be assigned into random groups to complete problems and the professor would come to every group to ask if there are any questions and the problems/worksheet needs to be completed at the end of class.

This class is simply introductory kinematics; it's graded on a very nice curve where there is hw ,lab , a midterm, and a final. Professor Seto is an excellent teacher who will provide encouragement and insight; you can also get him to lighten up on grading if you beg him enough.

The class covered about 18 chapters in 10 weeks, about 2 or 3 chapters a week. Homework was due everyother day sometimes 2 or 3 sets were due. Homework sets were set by leve i.e. CH14-1 ("easy" homework) CH14-2 (harder homework). 2 labs a week, they were not bad, but required a lot of work. Quizzes were every Monday on the chapters we covered in the week. No midterm, the quiz scores determined you grade, if you fall below 40% You will get an email to either drop, change majors/class, or stay. The final was exactly like the homework question, but some where not. During class hours we worked on homework problems, he did not lecture, reverse classroom setting. TA were always helpful when asking for help and forgiving when it came to grading. Overall the instructor is great, but the class is insane.
Hw was  all online. This class is all self taught; professor Harry Tom rarely lectures. The quizzes and final are given without a formula sheet.

The homework, quizzes, and labs alone are worth 50% of the grade, a passing grade (C-) is 40%, which means you can get a high C even if you get a 0 on the final. 

Not sure if it's because we have really nice TAs, the lab write-ups were cut off during the quarter, which means you don't have to write lab reports at all. 

Make sure to get to class every day from 9 am to 12 pm, the professor is literally doing the homework for you during class, and he does a really good job of walking you through - he doesn't get tired of your questions, in fact, he loves it. (The instructor was Professor Tom.)

For the quizzes, there is 10 quiz total, a quiz for each week except week one, and two of them at week 10. You will be asked 3 questions on your homework/lab, and as long as you get one right, you'll get a full score. He sometimes even goes over the questions before the quiz. 

This class is hard for two reasons: one, too much content within too short time. Two, it's really a jump from "Oh I know all those, kind of associated with common knowledge" (PHYS041A) to "I actually gotta learn and participate in classes". 

This is probably the class I had the most fun in, if not because I got really sick and had to skip two weeks of class, it would be an easy A+ (80%)

It's being taught by Anson (Dr. D'Aloisio) and Dr. Long.

 Anson's part was supposed to be easy. Daily reading quizzes are fair and homework and quizzes are fairly easy (and fair lol). The midterm will kill a great portion of the class. Since it was his first time teaching a lot of us were unprepared for the difficulty of the midterm, but aside from that the material itself is okay (you will need to sit and think about it though).

Quantum physics (2nd half) hurts. It makes no sense, and everything is counterintuitive. The textbook is exceedingly complicated and the homework problems are often never going to show on quizzes or the final (a few essential ones did but you will be able to tell what those are). By the way, Dr. Long's quizzes and final are based almost entirely on lecture notes (which he posts), but if you are cool with going to lecture, do so from time to time as sometimes some of the things he says reflects what you could see on a quiz.


The math gets so complicated you will need to use Mathematica. You literally only do that so you can get homework points smh. This class will force you to constantly ask the most fundamental of questions only for you to still be confused. Good luck!

Hamann isn't a straightforward professor- he'll assume you know some stuff about astronomy and will carry on through the lecture. His lectures are very poor: doesn't do example problems, assumes you know the astronomy stuff, and barely goes over the material in class (literally will just go through the surface of the material and wants you to read the textbook). He doesn't understand that many people in the class aren't concentrated in astro; they are other types of physics majors in the class.  He only has office hours an hour per week. His homework assignments aren't the easiest to do as well; you'll have to do some digging in the textbook. He doesn't do any example problems in class so that's where you'll struggle too. Midterm/final were difficult: he'll give you a study guide but each study guide had about 60 questions and each question required a 5 sentence answer. Too much to memorize/ understand

Phys130A is classical mechanics, conceptually the class is straight forward but mathematically it can pose a challenge. Like any other upper division physics course it is expected that you are proficient in mathematics. Dr. Beyermann was the professor when I took the course and he did a great job of building the conceptual foundation needed to tackle the HW from the Taylor book. His tests were mostly conceptual but also had some calculation problems thrown in. Make use of the textbook as IMO it is written fairly well. Also, your TA's should be an easy go to resource if you need it.
will exams be difficult? how should I prepare before taking the class?

Prof. Gary is a very good professor. His lectures are really good, no need to read the book. Midterm is only on the first 4 chapters, final exam is on material covered after midterm. The curve is quite generous. Homework every week, but was easy to do. Understand the application of each formula and go over this lecture notes every week to pass his class.

Even with covid, Professor Gary was a homie and really made the class as fair as possible. He's a great professor and really knows his stuff. The curves are generous and you will succeed if you keep up. It becomes very very hard if you fall behind.

Took it with Dr. Bill Gary during the pandemic. Problems are much harder than expected on the exam but time was enough. The midterm was fair but not enough time. Homework is crucial. Work hard and it will pay off.

Peng Wei is an excellent teacher. Teaches the topics very well! If you get all A's on homework assignments and at least an 80% on the midterm (midterm was homework problems), you're set for an A in the class. Final exam were 2/3 star problems so expect a difficult exam. Material in the class, in my opinion, were easier to comprehend.

Thermal physics isn't an easy topic, but Zandi teaches the topic alright. Homework are textbook problems, which you should understand. Midterm was basically homework problems/ lecture notes (very fair). Final identical to homework problems/ lecture noes (very fair). Ask her to give you a practice midterm/final and she'll provide you one.

Aji is a caring professor, but teaches way too fast. Homework is doable, but can either be easy or hard. Midterm/ final weren't horrible, but also not simple. As long as you can understand the application of the formulas and the concepts, you'll be fine.
The concepts are abstract and math is insane. Luckily the textbook is really good

Barsukov is a great professor! He is very blunt and straight forward when it comes to teaching; no loopholes nor tricks. Simply teaches the material straight to you. Notes are at most 2 pages of big writing. Midterm and final are very fair. Homework takes more than 2 days to finish as they are pretty difficult. Overall hard class, fair class, great professor.

Yu is an alright professor, the material's difficulty isn't too bad. Book explained the material somewhat well, just wished Yu elaborated more on the topics. Sometimes, he had issues with his iPad, and made the material a bit confusing. He didn't do alot of examples, wish he did.

Dr. Barton is a very good professor. Class is an easy A for physics electives. Just do your assignments. TA pretty much grades whether the code runs or not. TA and Dr. Barton pretty much set up the assignment for you as well. I didn't know how to code, but still got an A+ in the class. Easy A.
fall 2020: 3 small writing assignments & final. prof. ng is kind of funny

Took the class Fall 2021 with Professor Ng, the workload for this class is pretty light but everything is heavily graded and not doing well on one assignment/quiz can bring your grade down a lot. Taking the class as a GE is tempting since it has no discussion or lab as a biological science but be prepared to do well on each and every assignment to get a good grade.
Mycology is easy show up pass the class

I had Prof. William (Parkes) Riley. His lectures were an absolute drag and nobody went to them. He literally put paragraphs on the slides and then just read off them and uploaded them right after lecture so there was no point in attending. 3 papers, and the midterm was just two in class essays, the final was 3 take home or in class essays (your choice so I did all 3 take home). So basically, your whole grade is determined by a series of papers and your attendance, which made it quite easy if you're a strong writer. However, I would never take this class if I didn't have to. It was so boring and basic and I was bored within a week.

Took Prof. Riley Williams. We had to attend workshops (worth 7% of your grade!) for each of the essays we had to write (3 in total, not including the midterm and final). His lectures were boring, his powerpoints would just be huge paragraphs he'd read off of....which he'd later upload on iLearn. Only bothered to show up because he randomly takes attendance and you get points for that. Got an A in the class, but all the writing -and books to read- get really tedious...

Taken with Professor Laursen. Lectures without any sldies. Sorta boring - sometimes gets really intresting debates. Writing heavy - WAC Course though. Easy Midterm - 60% of Grade is based on essays with TA

Took it with Parkes Riley who is a very sweet old man. Lectures online were kinda hard to pay attention to. A LOT of reading. If poli sci isn't you're thing and you're a STEM major honestly wouldn't recommend ://

Took Online during pandemic with Riley Parkes. He's very knowledgably about the material, but his lectures are long and often boring. There was a lot of reading, but it is still interesting. Overall I would say the readings are the most important and sometimes the lectures are. There were 3 papers and a midterm. There was supposed to be a final, but it got dropped.
Professor Kehlenbach is amazing. Lots of reading and writing, but not too bad.
I found it difficult cuz I delayed the essays. But also the Mean score on the essays were always like 83-85

I had Professor Godrej, and grades were based only on a midterm, a final, and discussion. She is a fantastic lecturer and speaks very clearly. Her voice is gorgeous and she made the material easy to understand. The average on the midterm was a 78. She lets you make your own cheat sheet for it, too. I got a 99 on the midterm and the final was optional (thanks Corona) so I got an A+.

i had prof godrej. theres a lott of notes you will take. tbh you dont need to buy the books cuz its hellaa $$, just make sure u go to the lectures bc her lectures r very dense and will help you the most for midterms/final. shes a rlly good lecturer and answers all the questions she gets, but sometimes she talks too fast and the info can be a lil difficult. i studied using the notes i took from her lectures and ended with an A.

Took it with Professor Godrej. She really does have a beautiful voice. Lectures were online and not mandatory. I hated the midterm, as it was really difficult and my TA literally didn't do anything to help us. I've heard TA's in this class only give surface level in class activities and they don't really help. ASK questions if you need to during class ! Professor is really good with answering them as well. A lot of information about white philosophers, but she explains everything very well.
Lecture's were so boring and there's only 1 quiz, 1 midterm, and 1 final that goes into your entire grade. If you mess up on one of those it is extremely hard to repair your grade

Professor Mannies has been one of the most helpful and informative instructors I have had while at UCR. She demonstrates a vast range of knowledge across all of the topics discussed throughout the course. Professor Mannies was always there to support and accommodate for the needs of her students. Her evident passion shines through the interactions she has with her students. In every instance where I believed something was off, she helped me and did not have an attitude of annoyance while doing so. Great professor. ALSO: IF YOU HAVE ZACH DORSON AS A TA....BE PREPARED FOR HELL.

Had prof. Wood. The class is pretty boring imo, it consisted of 4 essays (1st one is optional) based on the readings you talk about in class. Attend lectures bc he gives random pop quizzes. Make sure to pay attention to lecture and plan on taking pics of the slides bc he goes really fast to the point where its almost impossible to type it as he speaks and doesn't post them
Focus on the essays, they are worth the most. Overall super easy
Term paper graded pretty hard by the TAs but the exams were mixed MC/essay and graded very easily along with a curve. Easy A
Prof. Ritchie is so nice and easy. No Midterm just 2 papers, an online quiz, and a final. TA's are really chill

Prof Daniel Biggers online course doesn't require too much, except for mandatory discussions, a term paper, a midterm, and a non-cumulative final. Focus more on the term paper since it's worth as much as the midterm. Attending lecture will help you pass.

DO NOT take with Bruce Bordner. It's a breadth course but he treats the class as if everyone is a polisci major. The midterm is worth 25%, the term paper has to be 8 pages long and is worth 25%, attendance in discussion is worth 20%, and the final is worth 30% but there's 13 pages in the final review that's packed with vocab you need to memorize! Just do yourself a favor and avoid him.
Took with Prof. Bishin. Chill dude, talks a lot about the Constitution (but not in a weird PragerU way). Follow the instructions and you'll at least pass. Do is a pretty nice and understanding TA

Professor Bishin is pretty chill with one synchronous lecture on zoom per week and the rest are lecture videos. 1 open-book quiz per week, 2 papers, no finals/midterms. The only things to keep in mind or pay attention to are his quizzes which can have specific questions and answers which can be very tricky to answer unless you double check with his readings and lectures where the answers can be found. Another thing is his reading materials which are kinda vague to read and half of the texts aren't that clear on what the readings are talking about. Overall, recommended for breadth courses but you just have to pay close attention and get some help from the TA which can help you succeed in his course.

I took this class with Professor Benjamin Bishin and I hated it. He does not post the lectures online. His lectures are extremely redundant, goes over the same things for weeks. Does not really go through American Politics, all he does is go through democratic events currently and back in founding days. 1 explanatory paper and weekly quizzes. It is extremely reading heavy on awfully boring readings.

professor dan biggers is a really good teacher. the class focuses on civil liberties, civil rights, voting and political representation, the branches of govt., and separation of power and federalism in the american government. 1 midterm, and a non-cumulative final. Also, one term paper thats 6-7 pages.
Took with Prof Busacca.  Short answer essays on midterms and multiple papers.  No final, at least for my quarter.  Easy as long as you get a easy-ish TA grader and pay attention in class.

Had Gabe for Fall 2019, he was pretty funny and passionate and knowledgeable about the subject. There were a LOT of readings, like way too much and for one of the midterms, everyone basically bombed it but he curved it so most people passed. He won't be teaching winter 2020 so idk about the other teacher but this class pretty interesting if you like politics, if not, it is probably gonna be very boring for you.

Easy A. I highly recommend you read the assigned reading. 2 midterms, one final. The tests  compose of multiple choice, fill in the blank and short answers. That may seem a lot, but if you go over the book and lecture slides, it's a breeze. I had Heba Hodaly.
TAKE WITH IREPOGLU CARRERAS. So easy, just a bit boring but def an easy pass, and an easy A with minimal effort. Provides extra credit opportunities.
Irepoglu-Carreras is the best! If you can choose, take it with her.

The first time you read a new topic it’s “I don’t understand anything.” The next read, you understand it slightly better, and the next  it’s interesting and you understand well. I’ve talked to other people in this classes discord and they all basically agreed. It is a pretty easy class that I would recommend if you want an easy class, with a little bit of a large reading(and a teacher that always sounds tired)

Lectures are pretty boring and the reading is overwhelming. However, the midterm and final are very straightforward and the content is not difficult. If you put in some effort and actually study, getting an A is easy.
Professor Dionne taught this course - super easy, exams are given ahead of time and essay questions are drawn out of a hat. Your preparation matters for the exam. Thats really it

Honestly lecture is kind of interesting and my discussion was too especially if you have Ian. Not hard midterm was just an essay and some term definitions, final was two essays and two essays (fall quarter 2019)
Easy class as long as you put some work in and go to office hours. Professor Dionne is great!

This class is honestly so interesting and fun, it made me want to go into political science. I had Andrew and he kept lectures interesting & funny, really good at explaining things and I was rarely ever lost in the class. I don’t really think you need to do the readings, midterms and finals are accumulative so you can just read the textbook the week of to get more info, otherwise he explains it all in the lectures so no hw either, hw is up to the professor. For mine, we just had to ask a question on week 3,5,7,9 really easy but not in a bad way, made it a relaxing yet interesting class!!

Took the class online with Freebourn for fall quarter 2021. Pretty easy class overall, that doesn't require too much effort. All my class had to do for homework were three surveys and we had to take at least two exams. There were a total of three exams (all of which were open note) in the class, but the third one was optional and could replace your lowest exam score. There are quite a few readings, but you can usually get away with simply skimming through them as Freebourn would usually talk about the material of the readings, during the lecture. As long as you pay attention during lecture and take good notes, the course shouldn't be too difficult.
online lectures were confusing but pretty interesting class. not the easiest class but if u try hard u can get a good grade

Irrepoglu-Carreras talks way too much; you don't need to write down everything she says. The 2 exams/final and notes are based on the slides/study guides. Reading the textbook helps to clarify the slides but you definitely don't need to do any more than skim the chapters.
If you take this class with prof. Marissa Brookes, it's fairly easy as long as you just show up to lectures and discussion. there's 3 exams + the final exam so one bad grade won't kill you
Prof. D'Anieri knows his stuff. Prof. provides a study guide with the exam questions on it. There are usually 30 questions and 5 will be on the exam. TA's are really picky about the answers
Had Brookes, her exams were hard since they were fill in the blanks and she wanted you to be very specific about things.
I had Brookes, the class was awfully boring and the exams were hard since they were all fill in the blank. The TAs were strict on grading and wanted you to be overly specific.
I would stay clear of Professor D’anieri, it’s not that the material was difficult but the sheer amount of reading and relatively broad study guides made the class a big pain.

Paul D’Anieri is extremely helpful in office hours, intelligent, kind, and has damn good music taste. DO THE READING. you have to know a lot of concepts and how to make a good argument. Overall a great and eye-opening class, just s lot of work

Took it with Paul D’Anieri. He knows what he’s talking about, and is a great lecturer. His office hours help so much and he’s overall just a cool guy. Into music, always plays a song in the beginning of class. A lot of reading, but he wrote the textbook and it’s pretty good. As long as you know the concepts you should be okay. Two midterms and a final. Each midterm has five short answer questions and an essay for 50 minutes, which isn’t as bad as it sounds. The final has the same layout but with an extra essay and 25 more minutes. Loved the class!
no homework or papers, the test were difficult because of the time constraints (50 mins)

Took Irrepoglu-Carreras over Fall 2020 quarter, attendance wasn't required (even in her live session).  Ridiculously easy, her quizzes are graded by completion, not performance, you can just speed run through the quiz and still get 100%.  Her mid-term and final was open book and was not proctored, both were extremely easy.  The class only gets difficult if you have a TA that assigns quizzes on the readings every week, I got lucky and got a chill ass TA (she never assigned quizzes).  Shout out to Bea-Sim!

Professor Irrepoglu-Carreras made course very easy. Grading is based on bi-weekly quizzes that are participation based and 2 take-home exams. All course presentations and materials were easily available. Vocabulary heavy course, but easy to understand.

I had professor irepoglu-carreras and she was really great! there's biweekly quizzes but they're only participation based and don't effect your grade. the midterm and final are take-home and aren't very hard at all, most of the answers you can find in her lectures. other than that, there's readings every week, but they're usually like no more than 12 pages and are pretty interesting!
Irepoglu-Carreras is the best professor! Take it with her if you have the choice!

Had Prof. Brookes and her lectures were pretty long and boring. she goes over slides pretty fast and its a lot of information to take in. my notes from 1 week could be as long as 11 pages. she curves grades if the class average is lower than her expectation. i got a D on the first exam cus there were many fill in the blanks (w the curve i got a C), but for the second exam she made it much easier and the last question was a free one ;) posc does slightly touch on econ but its not a lot

I took in person fall quarter with Marissa Brookes. Super interesting and funny lecturer. Readings not needed as long as you take notes in lecture because the slides are just an outline. As long as u go to all the lectures and take good notes ull get an A. TAs dont assign much, midterms and final are multiple choice and long answer and she is lenient about accomodation for test days.

i took this class fall 2022 and professor brookes is amazing! she was very lenient and has a good sense of humor. the class focused on international relations with some game theory and also monetary policy and transnational institutions towards the end. her slides are creative too

Took it with Professor Leebaw and it was easy, the midterm and final were take home (no multiple choice, all short answer for both exams and an essay for just the midterm). Her study guides were like 15-24 questions and the exams had 10 questions from there. There was also one project which was a 7pg essay or a powerpoint presentation + 2 pg essay.

Took this class with Prof. Wilkes Riley and didn't find much info online on what the class is about. Focus on ancient democracy (mainly Greek aka Plato, Aristotle, etc). He is a really sweet professor and has a lot of knowledge on ancient and modern issues/topics but can really drag on and digress in his lectures. Lots of reading and your grade is basically based on only 9 essays throughout the quarter. Besides that overall the class is pretty easy

I took this class with Kurt Packzowski in summer 2022 and he’s the most laidback instructor I’ve had. Doesn’t require attendance because every thing he says in class is written on a doc which he gives all student access to. He gave us the option of doing either the midterm, final, or both. If you did both, they would count for 40% each but if you only did one it would count for 80% of your grade. Participation was also 20% of your grade. He also told the class that if you wanted more assignments to count towards your grade, you can just email him and ask. We studied the social contract theory and 7 of its theorists: Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Rawls, Mills, Pateman, and Fanon. The class was super interesting to me and whenever I attended class, people would have great discussions even if opinions differed. His midterm and final review are pretty self explanatory and quite literally tell you step by step how to write an essay that would get you an A. I only did the final and never participated hence why I got a B+ in the class, but I’m pretty sure if you participate and put a little more effort than I did, it would be an easy A class!
Professor Mannies was cool a lot of opportunities for extra credit

Taken with Diogo Ferrari. Was a weird class since he teaches weirdly. Covers a lot of topics and ground. He was a bit frusturating at times since he would not answer questions directly, but the TA was amazing. Exams were similar to psets but asked for more analysis. Attendance was a factor

Taken with Ferrari. Hard course with a lot of theoretical concepts. He explains the concepts, but NEVER shows you how to actually apply them. If i did not have my TA, I would have failed. Midterm/Final are always curved because of how people perform. Most either do really well or fail

Yasemin Irepoglu Carreras taught the class. Tests were very easy. Class had a Midterm, Final, 6-8 page term paper, class participation (random activities), and discussion. No textbook and weekly readings are not really required. Term/vocab heavy.
Jeremy Busacca taught the class. 80% of the class was based on 3 essays. Reading heavy. Teaching style is very freestyle. Id say many in the class are split between hating his style and loving it.
Taken with Professor Serieux-Lubin. The class was very easy and flexible. Two easy term papers and multiple-choice midterm and final. The only tedious thing was the discussion boards.

I took this course (online) with professor Grittersova. It was made up of 2 take-home examinations, an essay, and participation. We had a weekly live session and some asynchronous lectures. It was an interesting course, you learn about a economic models that progressively built on top of each other. It goes from learning about absolute/comparative advantage to contemporary strategies of economic development (and their rationale). The class requires a lot of books/readings, she provides some but you're expected to buy the rest. If you look hard enough, you can find the pdfs online, so I wouldn't recommend buying them. Overall, enriching course. The professor expects a lot from you (she is rigorous), but it's obvious she does this due to enrich our learning experience. I highly recommend the course. You must do the readings to pass the course (at least skim them).

Took it with professor Irepoglu-Carreras. It was a fascinating course, I'd say that half of the course is learning about political theory (e.g. theories of international relations) and the other half is applying them to contemporary issues (e.g. current environmental issues). The course was online: we had live sessions once a week and multiple short asynchronous lectures to watch. She provides all the readings (you don't have to buy any books). Grading was composed by 4 quizzes (1 each two weeks), a take-home midterm, and a take-home final exam (both exams had a multiple choice section and an essay) . All was open book. Overall, it was an excellent course, so I highly recommend it. Also, the professor is extremely organized (e.g. she color-codes questions), so you won't have any issues with not knowing what to expect.

Taught by Gregory. Content was not too bad, but there is a lot of writing assignments associated with the course. 1 Midterm, 1 Final, 1 Book Eval, 1 Research Report. One opportunity for Extra Credit (worth 1.5% boost). Needs props because she was very responsive to student needs and adjusted deadlines if asked

Took with Professor Jana Grittersova as a business major elective. If you're okay with multiple weekly readings, then go for it (if taking it as an elective). As someone with bad study habits, this class was extremely tedious. It isn't necessarily hard material, it's just a lot. Skipping a lecture or not reading and waiting to catch up later is something that will bite you in the butt. Good and bad thing about the grading - it's only based on the midterm, a policy paper, participation (attending discussion) and the final. There was one extra credit opportunity which was just attending a seminar that counted for 10 points in participation. The midterm and final are the same format. Not sure if the same method of the midterm and final was done in previous years, but for Fall 2019, it was 4 ID questions and 1 essay question for the midterm and 2 for the final. She didn't tell us how many words she was going to put for the exams beforehand so we had to make sure we knew all the vocabulary (20+ words for midterm, then cumulative for final) and the essay questions (midterm ~8, final ~12). It seemed pretty overwhelming since other classes would usually tell you how many choices they're going to give you. She gave us 5 choices for IDs and made us write a paragraph of its definition and why the concept is important for 4 of them. If you tend to skip lecture, which I really don't recommend, you should always go to discussion. There's only one TA and he's super helpful. This was basically what made me pass the class. Honestly wouldn't recommend the class if you're a business major looking for electives to take, unless the reading and grading of it appeals to you (as in, no homework but the midterm and final will matter a lot more).

Took it with Professor Leebaw and it was not a hard class just a lot of readings. The midterm and final were take home (no multiple choice, all short answer and an essay for just the midterm). Her study guides were like 15-24 questions and the exams was 10 questions from there. There was also one project which was a choice between a 7pg essay or a powerpoint presentation + 2 pg essay.
Take all the classes you can with Weller. Super slow pace, can get by w/o reading, one midterm, one final group paper. Easy A imo

Course taught by Professor Merolla. Can get by without reading since most of the information is on her lecture slides. Need to purchase TopHat though. One group assignment about GOTV efforts. Not hard at all

Taken with Professor Bishin. Super intresting lectures - hes a fun dude who really wants you to learn. Extra credit pop quizes. Take as many classes with him as possible. I learned more with Bishin than any other lower-div courses

Taken with Ben Bishin. It is so ridiculous how hard he and his TAs grade. I thought this class would be fun and interesting, but the harsh grading is ruining it. His weekly quizzes are based on the readings, but he words them so carefully that it's really difficult even to understand what he's asking. On our term paper, almost every student was given a C or lower grade. Paul Teten is the TA, and he grades unbelievably harshly for no reason. He told me my paper was good, but I got a C+ with no feedback. It is nearly impossible to earn an A in this class because of the grading. We are given the option to write a second paper, but the TA states that getting a grade over a B would be an anomaly. Ridiculous.
Professor Merolla taught the class. Lots of assignmnets and group work. She is very helpful and approachable.

Took it with Benjamin Bishin. He is nice and understanding, but his lectures are dense and kind-of boring. He does not post slides and talks very fast, so it's hard to take notes. He assigns 7 quizzes in random weeks, so you never know what the topic will be. These quizzes are VERY hard. You need to not only complete the long and dense readings but understand the complex topics wholly because the questions are worded really difficult. I really liked how he assigned the term paper, though. He split it into 2 rough drafts that we turned in early in the quarter and used those and the feedback we received to complete the final paper. I ended with a B+ in the class.

Took it with visiting professor Boniface Dulani. It was an interesting course, made up quizzes (1),Summaries of the readings (3), participation in the afrobarometer hackthon (a data-related event), a midterm, final exam, and participation. Since the professor was new to the school, there were some logistical problems, but other than that it was a fascinating course. Pretty much it is an overview of Africa (pre-colonial to contemporary times) from a political perspective. We covered governance systems, the impacts of colonialism, contemporary issues, among others. Highly recommend it! You can get a good grade by skimming the readings and going to lecture.

The class is very interesting, but readings are extensive and difficult. The only assignments are 2 essays and a research paper. D'Anieri is a great professor, but expects a lot and is a bit of a tough grader. Participation is heavily expected in lectures. I loved the class and got an A-, but if you're not dedicated to doing readings and are not a strong writer, you may struggle.

Professor Irepoglu-Carreras is AMAZING. This class was very easy and was set up almost exactly like her lower div classes. 3 10-question quizzes, 1 midterm (mix of multiple choice questions that are mostly from prior quizzes and fact-based written questions), and a final set up exactly like the midterm. She posts all her slides and records lectures, and all quizzes and exams are open book. Nearly impossible to do bad in this class! She also randomly will do polls in class that can earn you extra credit if you do them! Best polisci professor ever :)

Took it with Irepoglu-Carreras. She is the best. Her lectures are simple and she always posts them on Canvas. The class grade is entirely made up of 3 quizzes, 2 exams, and a discussion section. The quizzes are so easy (10 questions, open book). The midterm was written and in class, while the final was a take-home mixture of written and multiple choice. She doesn't assign many readings and there are no papers. She is one of the best professors in the POSC department!

25% first two exams, 30% final, 20% discussion section. I took this in-person with Pion-Berlin, and if it wasn't for my TA, most of the class would have done very poorly on the final. Prof reads off the slides, and the exam questions are worded very poorly, almost like they're meant to trick you. I spent hours upon hours studying for each exam, and couldn't get higher than a B.
Taken with Pererya-Johnston. Very straightfoward class with 2 exams and a paper. Only slighly annoying thing is that discussion section attendance was mandatory

Spring 23, asynchronous with Prof Noel Johnston. This was my second time taking this professor. I like this professor a lot as he is very kind and knowledgeable. The midterm is extremely difficult and I would not suggest having Eun-A as a TA and she does not help you. Eun-A also requires cameras to be on for discussion and she is not very nice at all. The one thing I liked about Prof Noel is that he curves grades so this helps with your overall class grade.
Taken with Serieux-Lubin. Straightforward asynchronous class with somewhat long video lectures. TA was a bit of a mess and graded wildly, but besides that, the classroom components are easy.

Took this with Serieux-Lubin and was the easiest upper division polisci class I've ever taken. I took this online and it was asynchronous, I honestly forgot about it most of the time, and I managed to get a 98% in the class. She offers a TON of extra credit to the point where you can fail every test and still do well in the class with the EC. Take this if you want an easy A.

Ethnic politics with professor Dionne. It was a fascinating course, I feel that you'll question and/or consolidate your identity after taking it. It's made up 9 quizzes(so one per week, based on the readings and class material), a 500-word essay (based on a transformative moment you experienced due to the material of the course), and participation in class. Overall, as long as you do the readings and participate in class it will be a breeze. Additionally, the professor is passionate about the material, so she will help you no matter what. Highly recommend it!

I took this with Dionne, she’s a sweetheart. This class was really eye-opening and such a great experience. The grading is 70% weekly quizzes (9 total, 2 dropped), 10% reflection paper (500 words), and 20% participation (self-assessed). The quizzes are based on about 80-150 pages of reading and about an hour worth of videos/podcasts, and are open note. As long as you pay attention in class, and do the readings, you're golden.

Taken with Professor Indridason. While the lectures move quickly, they're very interesting and honestly pretty fun. Professor Indridason is incredibly knowledgeable and very very helpful, as long as you do not hesitate to ask questions. His lectures are thorough and grading felt very fair, though that may be because I had a very understanding TA. Grades were based on papers, I think we did 2 or 3, and are fairly easy to write with clear prompts. Taking notes and paying attention is CRUCIAL to the course.

Taken with Cioffi. Dude's exam was hard and his lectures are delivered in a boring fashion. He is SUPER smart though. He sorta drops hints about his exams when he talks so you should pay attention to EVERYTHING he says. 70% of grade is determined through Midterm Essay and Final

Taken with Cioffi. Super hard course with so much readings. He literally could bury you with his readings. They are also super boring and pretty dense, but that is conlaw itself. Hypotheticals are not as difficult as he makes them seem to be. Need to memorize so many cases and doctrines

Taught by Osorio. Course was very easy, but had a lot of daily assignments (e.g. daily quizzes and readings). Made memes and listened to podcasts. Not taught like how a traditonal law course, but learned some cool stuff. Participation makes or break the grade though

Taken with Noel Johnston. Simple asynchronous class with a lot of application of theoretical concepts. It can be tough, but the concepts themselves are broken down very well. Midterm's and Finals are very fair and require a lot of application. Some extra credit opportunities are available

Taken Fall22 Online Asyncrounous with Prof Noel Johnston. This class is hard, but the professor doesn't make it hard. The concepts are a little difficult to understand. He uploads two small videos a week which are really helpful. there are no assignments for this class besides the three tests. The tests consist of 7-10 multiple choice/response questions. The tests are quite tricky but you can use your notes, videos, and TAs during the exam.
Do the readings and Loveridge will give you a good grade. Essentially, don't be exceptionally lazy.
Methods class taken with Weller. There are so mant readings, 4 short but concise papers that was really tough, and a lot of application of readings. You must read or you will fail this class.

Taken with Professor Ritchie. Grad seminar that foucsed on a lot of readings and hard discussions. This course has a research design component that is pretty tough to do. Good professor who makes you feel very comfortable in class
He gives you most of the answers to the test questions every lecture. So I got a B just by studying all the test questions he gave us. Never went to lecture.

Steve Clark is an amazing professor. I didnt even open the book for my two midterms and got an A and a B. Just go to his lectures, a lot of the quiz content is about his anecdotal examples. 10/10 would take again
Rosenbaum is a gem. Easy A. Gives you 20/25 exam questions ahead of time
Very easy for people who aren’t into psychology. Highly recommend taking it for a requirement.

Huffman is amazing at explaining the material and really funny, definitely take it with her if possible. Everything is based on the notes, don't waste time buying the textbook. You'll definitely have to do some studying but most of it is easy

Took it with Dr. Huffman. Good professor especially if you are desiring to take more PSYCH classes. Reading the textbook isn't super super important, so you can probably get away with not reading it because she mentions how theres only like two to three questions on the exam where the information comes from the book. Key to doing well in the class is memorization and understanding the notes she post on iLearn. Lecture is important to as she says things that rewards those students who attend lecture, but can get from a friend. Got a B+ and read the book and went to lecture, but beware of the Neuroscience part, required a lot of memorization but is doable. Note... on her power point there are presenter notes when you download them... OPEN THOSE and study those too.. questions from midterms and final were from there I vividly remember that.

Had Dr. Huffman. There was 2 midterms and they were mostly from lecture slides and a few extra credit questions from the random things that she talks in lectures. You don't really need the textbook since the exams are mostly from lectures

Take this with Huffman. She's funny and actually made me want to come to lecture. Studying required a bit but you can pass without using the textbook at all. Write down some of the weird stuff she says in class, they come up on the test.
prof huffman: easy to get a B, hard to get an A

If you took AP Psych in high school, it is basically a review of that. I never went to class or studied and got a B. I had Dr. Huffman, she's really kind. There's no homework but there are pretty much quizzes every discussion and 2 midterms and a final that make up your grade. Also, she drops the 2 lowest quiz scores

Took it with Professor Steven Clark. Always attend lectures because his exams focus more on what he discusses in class than the book. He posts his slides but they are extremely vague, so it won't be that helpful if you don't pay attention in class.
Easy A with Rosenbaum

took it in the summer with Dr. Huffman, intense 5 weeks. 9 quizzes (lowest one dropped), 1 midterm (average was 87% - 80 multiple choice questions, no backtracking), 1 final exam (80 multiple choice questions, non-cumulative), discussion attendance is mandatory for points, and some zaps & inquiztive assignments weekly. The whole course was on canvas, each week was posted in advance, no required live lecture meetings!
Took it with Huffman. I think overall, it was decently easy. If you followed the textbook, read what you needed to, you could ace the exams. Recommend

Had this class online with Professor Ditta and would highly recommend. She is very passionate about what she teaches, and offers a bunch of extra credit. The assignments themselves are not very difficult. There are weekly assignments for discussion section, and lecture attendance is not mandatory.

Professor Ditta is the best! She made the class flexible and very straightforward. There was 1 final, weekly assignments that are pretty easy, and extra credit quizzes. I'm really going to miss her class because she's just so kind and you can tell she enjoys teaching. Overall, an amazing class!!!

Took this class because everyone said it was easy but I almost failed. I took it with Professor Clark. He was very nice but I just couldn't stay engaged during lectures. His lectures also don't have words with bullet points so it's mostly just listening, which makes it hard for me. He is very approachable and willing to help so that is nice.

Taken with Ditta in Fall 2020. Extremely chill online zoom lectures which I RECOMMEND TAKING NOTES ON (it'll help for the PSYC 001 study guide she releases a week or two before the final). I 100% RECOMMEND DITTA... EXTREMELY HELPFUL AND WANTS TO HELP YOU LEARN THE MATERIAL...LOVES TALKING WITH STUDENTS ABOUT VIDEO GAMES, OTHER TOPICS OUTSIDE OF CLASS AND IN OFFICE HOURS. She gives no midterm as well, only the final, and there are weekly assignments as well as a final project. On another note, she requires 4 hours of "research participation", which is done online. The research consists mostly of taking online quizzes that are used in UCR studies and each one is worth an hour, so do 4 quizzes on the UCR research site for easy completion.

took online with professor ditta, she's great at teaching the material and gives you everything you need to succeed in the class. 1 midterm, 1 cumulative final & a final media project, all free response but it's open note/textbook. there are also lots of extra credit quiz opportunities!

Took this class Winter 2021 with Professor Ditta! AMAZINGGGG PROFESSOR I highly recommend her! She kept online lectures interesting and fun, & also provides a synchronous or asynchronous option for her students. The workload was not hard at all and the midterm and final was easy if you just watch the lectures. She is super organized so it made things so easy. Chapter in the textbook every week (although you don't really have to but the textbook is super interactive so it was very easy to read), Quizzes for every chapter (but you can just keep going till you get 100%, questions are unlimited), and then an assignment every week (but it was lowk busy work, only takes about 20 minutes). At the beginning of the week she also sends out what should be done for the week which is superrr helpful. Oh and media project at the end (I just did a tiktok and got a 102%, super easy) and UCR research hours (just participate in a study) Take this class!!! You'll enjoy it. Got an A+

Rosenbaum gives you all the answers in the lectures and in the reading. He is so adorable and sweet. He makes me laugh and makes it interesting. Make sure to go to every lecture and participate in every discussion if you want points. Hunter the discussion TA is really nice. Don't miss the midterm or the exam or you will have to write a paper.

I took PSYC1 with Professor Ditta. She's really nice and tries hard to make the class engaging. It's pretty easy to get an A if you put in a little effort. Most of my friends and I ended with a 100%. The main assignments are a midterm, final, and a project. There are also discussion activities and weekly "quizzes," that you can take until you get a 100%. 

This class is basically just about putting in effort and it's pretty interesting!
Took with Rosenbaum. Easy A if you just put in a little work

Took the class with Annie Ditta and she slays. She is very nice and considerate. She hold her lectures in person but will have live zoom and records the lectures. Assignments are pretty easy the midterm/final are open note.
Had Professor Ditta in-person. A great professor, very flexible and understanding. Easy A if you do all the work. All quizzes, tests, and finals were open-note and open-internet.
Easier than PSYCH001 imo
Its an ipen notes class
Extremely easy if taught by Prof. Sy. Barely went to lecture and passed with an A
Pretty easy, especially if you have  Dr. Rachel Wu. She does an amazing job breaking everything down. Don't really need the textbook because all of her tests/quizzes are based on the slides!
professor murray makes it fun and interesting, lots of EC opportunities in class but has clickers (20%) also in class, 4 exams each 20%
You are required to go to discussion like 25% of your grade depends on this...
Taken with Barton. Easiest of the series, most people will do better than they did in A and B. No curve, but tests are very fair.

Took with Rachel Wu. Really easy class. Quizzes can be taken twice, no midterm, final is online and open note. Assigned homework is minimal, just 3 simple newspaper article assignments throughout the quarter. Discussion section attendance part of grade. Go to lecture, read the textbook.

Had it with Professor Davis Spring 2020 and she is so nice. My TA was also amazing - Pamela Sheffler. Only thing you need to do to ace the class is memorize the slides. 4 exams, the lowest one gets dropped so if you're satisfied with your grade you don't need to take the "final".

I had Danielle Delany in summer session A for psych. She was super nice and easy-going. Her lectures were easy to understand. The tests were pretty much about the material covered in lecture. If you have her just make sure you know the lecture slides and you'll pass.

Took it with Prof SETO during online format and it was horrible to say the least. His exams required deep understanding of the material which he did not equip us for. I aced phys2A/B but I struggled with his teaching method in 2C. A lot of people would agree he could do MORE examples similar to what he would expect from us and just overall put more effort. I ended up with a B+ so its "do-able"

HELLA easy if you take this class with Professor Sy. Took this class during Fall 2020(online b/c of covid) and he only had 2 lectures live and made the rest of them asynchronous. Just keep up with watching the lectures(like 2 per week) and use the notes you take from them to fill out the study guides he sends out before the exams and you are guaranteed an A on the exams. Exams including the final were non-cumulative and open note + open textbook. Also, go to discussion because they take attendance and it counts towards your grade quite a bit.

I had Prof. Wu for PSYC002 during online classes. All of the lectures, quizzes, and exams are asynchronous, so it's super helpful to go at your own pace. My advice to make sure you don't procrastinate because it WILL screw you over in the end. Make sure you watch the lecture videos and attend the discussion and you'll be fine. I finished with an A.

I took PSYC2 with Professor Sy. Honestly, I would recommend if you just want an A. I feel that I didn't learn a ton, but the class was really easy. All the tests were multiple choice and open book. The professor is also super nice and upbeat. There wasn't much homework, just reading, which I guess was optional. The textbook is a little boring, but hey, it's free!
Took with Rachel Wu Winter 2021. Super easy class. Hardest part is just remembering to do it. Look up a psych article and write about it, sign up for studies, do the open note quizzes. That's it.

Professor Elizabeth Davis is awesome and her class is soooo easy. You have to buy the textbook to get access to InQuizitive, which is a downside, but the material is really interesting, and it's so easy. There are weekly quizzes on canvas, weekly inquizitives, and a weekly discussion assignment, which was a 500-word response based on the topics for the week. Her TAs are all super nice and very passionate. No exams either!!!!
*Fall 2022 Online* Since it was online everything was open note so I don't know how it'll be in person. Professor Sy is a great professor and made lecture really fun!

Had with prof. Sy, just go over the slides, 90% of the test content is on there. The exams have a generous curve and its all multiple choice. Only a ~1k word essay at the end of the quarter is needed, but you get full credit if you even try a bit, can finish in 2 hours because the prompt is very easy.
Take with professor psy because he makes course easy

Took it with Coulombe. She talks really fast, but she makes the content pretty easy. If you took AP Stat, you're chill, but if you're not good with stat, you might need more practice. It's pretty straightforward except for the last two weeks (It's a little confusing, but still okay). Somewhat of an easy A if you pay attention tbh

Take with Dr. Annie Ditta if at all possible! She is overall extremely nice and understanding, and allows a cheatsheet (front and back of one paper) for exams. She also breaks down the concepts super simply and goes fairly slow/thorough to make sure everyone understands. Just understand the basic concepts/write down the differences between the types of tests for exams and you'll be fine.
Take with Prof. Natsuaki- makes sure you understand material and TA's pretty good

Took it with Duyen Trang. If you took AP stats in high school, then you'll be fine. If you didn't, Duyen does a great job at showing how to do it in a neat and easy way to understand. 2 midterms and 1 cumulative final - all open notes - that are open for several days for you to complete. About 3-4 homeworks are due before each midterm/final that are graded based on completion. Duyen also holds review section a day before each exam. Attend those because she goes over the study guide and it really helps.

Very math intensive. However, Natsuaki made this class pretty okay. I've never taken stats and I did fairly okay. Conceptually, it gets a little iffy at time and oh boy, the calculations are endless but not overall a super hard class. Lectures a bit boring but would recommend with Natsuaki overall.

Took it with Natsuaki in Fall (Online). Honestly stats was really scary going into this but I came out loving the subject. The course is vigorous so carry your weight and you’ll do well. Also don’t be afraid to go to office hours for your TA since they do all your grading. We had 3 midterms and  a cumulative final. Also one paper and 2 weekly assignments. Like I said it’s vigorous but it’s not innately hard. Discussions were not mandatory except the last one to show a portfolio (another assignment). I would definitely invest in an iPad or a tablet so you can hand write upload your homework and test work easily. It saves a lot of time during exams. Exams were not proctored but make sure you show your work.

Asynchronous with Natsuaki. Really good professor who understands that students may be anxious about this course and provides a lot of examples. TAs are also really helpful when it comes to reviewing material or hw. There's 3 midterms and a final but she drops the lowest midterm grade. There's 2 hw each week but they're not too bad. I'm not a math person but Natsuaki and my TA made this course not as bad as it seems
Take over the summer so you don't have to complete 2+ research papers.

Took it with Prof Franchak. The textbook comes with inquizitive so make sure to do those assignments for easy points. 3 midterms and 1 cumulative final. Study his slides and take the practice quizzes and you should do fine. Grade is split 50/50 between lecture and lab (aka research papers) papers are most important ask your TAs for help and don’t procrastinate those

I had Prof. Ditta and she was honestly one of my favorite professors I’ve had. She allows a 1-paged (front&back) cheat sheet on all exams and allows test corrections to get points back on midterms. She is genuinely super helpful and wants her students to succeed.

Dr. Calanchini is a great professor and a very understanding person. He's great at applying concepts to relatable/funny real-life examples. Overall the material itself is easy, there's just kind of a lot of it. He does a "midterm" every 2 weeks (5 total, 20 questions each) which sounds awful but it makes the class way easier because you only have to memorize 2 weeks worth of material at a time rather than 5. They're usually pretty easy, and at least for Spring 2020 (online/during the pandemic), they were all open book/open notes. Usually there are 2 research proposals throughout the quarter but for Spring 2020 there was only 1. Either way, don't get behind on it! Also, DO THE INQUIZITIVES. They are basically practice for his "midterms"/final.

Took this online during Spring 2020. Dr. Calanchini is an awesome instructor and also very nice/pretty lenient. The material itself isn't hard but there is a LOT of work, mainly because of the research proposal project.

Dr. Franchak was good professor. I enjoyed his lectures that would often have a bit of humor embedded within.
