There was a lot of content that was covered, but Dr. Franchak did a great job of organizing how the content was taught. I appreciated his willingness to be lenient on assignment due dates. He explained everything well and gave plenty of opportunities for students to improve their grades. Everything was on quizlet pretty much (Online Spring Quarter 2020 btw).

This class was actually pretty nice. For a 6 unit class during Spring of 2020, it was manageable. The Prof (Franchak) was SUPER understanding of the events that were happening at the time. Just off of how lenient he was and understanding of how people were dealing with things (1 paper instead of the usual 2, dropped lowest test, very communicative) during those times, I would recommend.

Took with prof Franchak, he posts the lecture on Yuja. He is a great professor, there are 5 quizzes, final is a quiz as well. The quizzes are open note but you still need to know the material to answer the short answer questions. There is one 6 page research paper, but the discussion assignments help with it.
Calanchini - just do the inquisitives and take extra credit opportunities; materials are organized and it’s easy to reach out to the prof for help
Took with Professor Calanchini. Super kind and gives a good amount of extra credit opportunities.

took it with Megan Robbins. low rmp rating but she's actually rly good. no curveballs in her exams (some convoluted questions) but not terrible enough to where you'll get any lower than a B+ if you try hard enough. grade based on midterm, final and research proposal paper. procrastinated my paper to the last week but was able to get a 98% on it. just follow the rubric and you'll b okay! overall super easy and she's super kind and accommodating

Took with Dr. Megan Robbins. She explains things really well. Heavy emphasis on making sure no one plagiarizes. The discussion assignments are fairly easy and pretty straightforward. The midterm and final are tough so make sure you review, but you'll get a good grade if you study! Had one final research proposal paper (got 100%). Much of the discussion classes prepare you for the paper. During discussion, you will also learn to analyze data (applies concepts from PSYC011), as well as the use of excel. I recommend you go to TA office hours for help on the paper where they can make direct connections!
PROFESSOR CURT BURGESS CANNOT FUCKING TEACH

Best advice, create a google doc with the whole class and work on it for your midterm and final exam. Attend lecture if you can understand the topics easily, but if not, just take notes from the book. The final exam is 50% of your grade, but he does curve! Lecture and discussion aren't mandatory.

Psychology of Creativity: Professor Ditta is probably one of the best professors ever. She really prioritizes the learning and understanding of her students in terms of making her lectures very engaging by adding activities that help you understand the concepts. She has weekly quizzes that give you a sense of how she writes her exam questions which I find very useful. There are 2 midterms and 1 Final project (no final exam).

Annie Ditta was the professor and she was a new professor to UCR. She makes the class so engaging and brings in interesting guest lecturers. Exams are extremely easy if you just simply memorize the content/ use common sense. There's a project at the end of the class, it's very simple practically everyone gets 100s. Just make sure to show up to every discussion.

Prof. Brianna Mcgee was great and funny. Her lectures are actually interesting and the class is super easy, no midterm and the final is basically what you will be working on during the second half of the quarter.

My professor was Dr. Abdulrazak. The class has a lot of information to remember, which made it difficult. Just read the lecture slides and textbook. There are 3 tests in total (“final” is not cumulative). Tests are fair, nothing too tricky. Average is usually ~76%. Also, there are 3 pop quizzes given in lecture so be sure to always attend class.

Dr. Peter Hickmott is amazing and uploads all the slides. Tests are totally based on lecture slides and it isn't that big of a deal if you miss some classes (attendance isn't taken), but he explains concepts really well and it's easier to study if you attend lecture. It's kind of a lot of work because there is a lot of material to study, but most of the concepts themselves aren't very hard and the class is enjoyable overall.

I had Dr. Hickmott. Two midterms, one final, no homework. This is a very difficult class, but his passion for the material and teaching puts the course in a propitious perspective. Best advice is ALWAYS stay on top of the material, especially if you're a neuroscience major!!! The exams cover lecture/discussion material, so attend both. He doesn't try to trick you - everything is straight forward - but do pay attention to the greater details.
Korzus’s exams were super hard for no reason. The exams were nothing like the study guide.
Quiz and essay/project heavy. Final is much harder than midterm.
Kathleen Conner led the class as a TA. She was very easy. Half the class got a solid A. Midterm and final are literally based off the slides. Highly recommend for an easy A.
Took the class with Hickmott. This class was online and the midterm and final was open note. Don’t know how in-person would be, but he was very easygoing during online.

Don't take this class with Daniel Ross. Even though he apparently was nice during previous quarters, he suddenly got pretty unaccommodating during Fall 2020 when I took this class. He also did things like give us a bunch of things due at one time during finals week when we were all stressed out. He also wasn't very considerate of COVID messing with our time/money. Unlike most other professors, those of us who had to get a job/extra jobs during school because of the pandemic weren't accommodated in terms of participation we had to miss (and it was 25% of final grade). He was also really inconsiderate about money, for example he said that a $50 2nd textbook cost couldn't be waived but it's "just a fraction of your tuition anyway" (he also mentioned during this announcement that people told him they were struggling to afford food/rent and he basically responded with "That sucks but I can't do anything about it," it was unbelievable). The topics in the class were fairly interesting but Daniel completely ruined it for basically everyone in the class.

Took the class with none other herself: Annie Ditta. As all the students know who's had her: she is the BEST. Super duper accommodating, super duper understanding, super duper organized, and clearly cares about her students and the courses she teaches.
However, this is a tough class. The concepts are interesting. BUT: you have a lot of assignments, and TA's were pretty tough graders. there are two exams (midterm and final), 10 extra credit quizzes, weekly discussion assignments (weeks 2-3, weeks 4-5, and weeks 8-9 were the three toughest ones, and weeks 8-9 was 20% of your grade). Lectures are not mandatory to attend, but lecture attendance does count towards your grade and she checks using PollEv. If you are unable to make it to lecture, you had the option to write at least 2 pages of handwritten notes to make up for it. 
Exams were pretty tricky, you cannot just memorize the concepts, you have to apply them as well. Both exams are 5 short answers. 
Overall, amazing and accommodating professor! But tricky concepts, and lots of assignments.
Took it with Ditta. It's fun and she's a pretty lenient grader.
Burgess. He expects a lot of class participation. There's a 15 page paper at the end.

Dr. Julia Revord is one of the nicest professors I've ever taken. She is super accommodating and taught the class really well. Lectures were asynchronous for the quarter I took it but honestly most of us only watched like 1 or 2 lectures and did fine, especially because it was all open-note/open book. No homework. Just some short multiple choice tests (20 questions) every so often, and the lowest one is dropped for your final grade. The topic is kind of interesting too. Highly recommend

Took this with Prof Hughes. Definitely take it with him if you can. He made the concepts easy to understand. Take notes and you’ll do well on the exams. Three 20 question midterms and a final and a short reflection paper. Best class
Prof. Sy is entertaining; he really makes an effort to be funny. Tests are easy and straightforward. The extra credit is crazy hard though.
Psy’s a fun prof, I didn’t go to lecture much (3 hrs at night? no thanks) but attendance is required for discussion and the TAs give pop quizzes in discussion on the chapter for the week. easy A.

For the quarter I took Personality I had Dulce Wilkinson as the instructor, and while most of the course content was mostly easy, she was the most unaccommodating instructor I’ve ever had….. so many fuck ups from offensive test content & final exam content that was never covered to not wanting to give students access to CC’s on livestreams of lectures when they needed them for disabilities…… she seems like she’s an okay person but it was incredible how much she fought ANY change or criticism to the course up until it was time for iEvals…. this is her last quarter at UCR as a grad student but on the off chance she tries to teach here as a professor this info should be known before taking any of her classes!!!!

A bit difficult, this professor didn't really present the lecture properly, as each of her lectures she would read off her slides like a poor TED talk. Then when it came to the exams, many of the questions would be worded weirdly, if they weren't questions that had been reused. Not to mention this professor would blatantly ignore students that would have questions about course content. One thing that really defines Professor Wilkinson is a very offensive question she put on the exam about personality disorders, asking the class "which one is worse". Now this question is subjective, but comes off as very offensive to those with personality disorders. She did apologize but made the excuse that other classes had no problem with this question. I do wish she was more professional with their work.

For the quarter I took Personality I had Dulce Wilkinson as the instructor, and while most of the course content was mostly easy, she was the most unaccommodating instructor I’ve ever had….. so many fuck ups from offensive test content & final exam content that was never covered to not wanting to give students access to CC’s on livestreams of lectures when they needed them for disabilities…… she seems like she’s an okay person but it was incredible how much she fought ANY change or criticism to the course up until it was time for iEvals…. this is her last quarter at UCR as a grad student but on the off chance she tries to teach here as a professor this info should be known before taking any of her classes!!!!
Memorize the diagnostic criteria as soon as possible to make exams easier to handle. The final covers all 60+ disorders and there will be multiple case studies on it so don't forget them.

(Winter 2022) Updated review on Professor Natsuaki. There were 3 midterms in the class (3rd midterm is the "final" exam), but you 1 midterm score is dropped. Basically, you have a choice whether or not you want to take a midterm. If you do decide to take all three, the lowest score of whatever midterm you took is dropped. Midterms were pretty easy. First midterm I didn't study much and ended up with a C on it, but I studied more for the other 2 midterms by going over lecture notes and reading the textbook (but only to get more detail on lecture content), and I got an A on the 2nd midterm and a perfect score on the 3rd. We had to write a max 8 page paper on a book (very interesting book!), and another paper on a movie (an amazing movie). Lectures were mandatory to attend since she took attendance using PollEv (but there were time where she didn't do polls). Discussions were required to attend, but you basically go over class content.
Professor Natsuaki herself is a gem. Really sweet person, did her best (and did an amazing job) to accommodate this sudden transition to in-person. She knows that the topics she discusses in class are really sensitive, so she explained the concepts well.
Your TA's grade the two papers you do (movie and book). How tough the grading is depends on your TA. My TA was a pretty harsh grader. I put a lot of effort onto the two papers and got an 80% in the movie paper and 90% on the book paper. One of the other TA's though (Erick) I heard was great. He's supposedly funny, and a hella laid back grader. Also he's pretty close to Professor Natsuaki since he's TA'd for her I wanna say 5 times.
Overall: Do you have to put in the work? Yes. If you do- you're guaranteed an A (hence the 5/10 rating because it depends on you).
easily the hardest class I've taken, test wise. Professor words exams VERYYY intricately and throws in the most ridiculous small-detailed concepts into tricky exam questions. Be aware!!

Took it with Pamela Sheffler and it was such an interesting class! You learn about the development of people throughout the lifespan, which is pretty straightforward and quite insightful. There was 1 midterm, 1 group presentation, a final project (paper), and a final exam. It may seem like a lot of work, but it really reinforced my learning.

Took this class with professor Murray, and while the class was obviously based on class/racial topics, she was extremely opinionated and most of the class was basically her ranting. She was also rude to students who asked questions and would often complain about them instead of answering them. Luckily the class was easy, just a few discussions with a final paper and lecture was mandatory, then a midterm and final that are both open note.

It’s an upper division class, but honestly SOOOO INTERESTING. This class is taught my professor Clark and he’s very well versed in it since he created the class. I loved this class so much and he’s an amazing professor. I took the class online so it was a little different. But- 10 quizzes = 50% of your grade and 1 final = 50% of your grade.

SPRING 2021 - Professor Melissa Wilson - Super interesting and easygoing class. The exams are basically just lecture material with a little bit of questions where you apply certain concepts to specific scenarios. 1 essay that is pretty easy because most TAs are really nice and helpful. 1 final, 4 "mini-exams," and reading quizzes.
Dr. Robbins was fairly straightforward with her exams, but her intervention assignment was a bit difficult. You don't learn what's expected until after the rough draft is due.

Prob depends heavily on who you take it with. i took it with Dr. Cecelia Cheung and basically the only “required” work was an in-class worksheet that we could work on together every week and a final project that was really minimal. No tests, no papers. As a psych major I can confidently say it’s by far the easiest psych class I’ve ever take, but this only holds for Dr. Cheung’s version of the class.
Dr. Rosenbaum made the class easy but the material itself was complicated. Interesting class but you need to go to lecture if you want an A.

Professor Alexander is not necessarily a bad professor. I mean, at the end, he did kind of deteriorate but overall his class wasn't all too bad. Make sure you get the general ideas in the books that you are required to read. Midterm and final exam are the same format and aren't really difficult. The one downside, and it's huge, is that the class was at the Theater and it was at 7:40 in the morning.

avoid prof oh. hes super unprepared for lectures and has a somewhat heavy accent, reading helps with the pop quizzes but you can easily just google his study guides for the midterm and final, essays are pretty easy and weekly discussion posts are easy points

took it with Dr. Isaac this quarter, at first I was reluctant but this was my easiest class this quarter. He gave us the midterm verbatim and plans to do the same with the final. Our only assignment was an essay in which it was basically just a writing exercise because he gave us questions to answer. Overall a great class and professor.

Prof Issac will lecture forever but as long as you study the study guides you will pass the class easily. one midterm one final and an essay. don't need to go to lectures if you do the readings... overall not a very difficult class just make sure to do well on the exams.

if new teacher, professor Isaac moise from UCLA, easy class, 2 exams 25% each, final 6 page essay worth 20% rest is just participation/attendance, and the study guides were word for word the exam questions, show up to lecture, he would give us important information that only he would give to the 40 or so people who showed up to the entire lecture hall. difficulty 3/10

This class is overly difficult and complex when it doesn't need to be. Although there are only about 4 assignments, readings are dense and lectures are dense as well. Professor knows what she's talking about, but there is just WAY too much information to process at once especially when lectures are not recorded.

Took it with Sagan. Definitely take Ali as your TA. One midterm, one final, one paper, and three quizzes in section. As long as you follow the slides, the exams are pretty easy. The TA was very helpful and made sure we were well prepared. Do not need much prior knowledge on Jesus or religion.

I took this class with Professor Chang and I had Kori as a TA. They were both very nice and easy going. This class requires two books, one of them you can just find the pdf but I had to buy the other book. It was pretty much easy, just do your section's reading (the online class is set up in a specific way where you're broken up into groups and are given questions that correlate with your group number to which you answer during lectures). There was one midterm and one final, both of which Prof. Chang gave out study guides to (the guides were literally the exact same questions so make sure to do it, he also lets you use the guides during the exams). It's a pretty easy class, you don't really need to spend much energy and time on it.

Professor Bayer is an awesome and chill professor. He knows that most of his students are only taking the class as a requirement and doesn't try to force the material on students. Course consists of three end-of-section exams and one final project.

Fall 2021. Eric Martin is a chill professor. He is always available for questions. Follow along the PowerPoint and attend every class. Attendance is mandatory. There are 3 free response quizzes and a midterm and an essay final. Easy class, just pay attention, don't slack like most of the people in this class. It is not as hard as people think.

I took this class with Professor Eric Martin. This was his first time teaching a class at UCR, so it took a while for him to get used to everything. While the class was a little disorganized, the content itself wasn't really hard. All the readings were optional, and the biggest grades were 2 papers and 3 quizzes. I got lazy halfway through the quarter and stopped attending lectures, but still managed to get an A in the class.

I took it Fall 2022 with Dr. Paul Chang. There is some reading but not too much. There is no homework. An extra credit assignment was to go to the Career Center. The exams contain some vocabulary and definitions that the professor goes over in class and some essays. He gives out exam outlines prior. He is empathetic and really passionate and knowledgable about his field.
Online, 2 written assignments a week(easy), 1 quiz a week. 1 research paper no midterms
Took with Alexander Michael, easy class. 4 books to read, 2 essays. Midterm and final was easy.

Took Alexander Michael, extremely easy class with a chill professor.  Lecture did not have mandatory attendance, but discussion section does (you won't have to worry about your grade if you actively participate in discussion).  Quizzes are given out weekly and contain 3-5 questions, it was multiple choice and you have three chances to get 100%.  I never read any of the books assigned and still maintained a 100% average on the quizzes (download the pdf and CTRL+F key words).  Our midterm and final were papers on the book you chose to read, prompt was easy and open-ended enough to read a few pages to get an A.

Had Dr. Lucia... She's very condescending and makes you feel ashamed whenever she's like "oh you guys should have learned this in high school right? my high schooler just learned this therefore you guys learned this in high school, too." Anyway, the material can be tough to get your head around at times with someone like that teaching you...  Had weekly discussion questions, quizzes after movies we watched in class, take home midterm that took a while to finish, a final paper that was 6-8 pages long, and a final. Overall the grading is pretty easy but she makes it seem like you're going to fail the class and I disliked the professor which made me dislike the whole class in general. She could have made the subject much more interesting but she instead made it dry.

For a breadth class, this was unnecessarily difficult. As an honors student this class was required W20 for first-years and it was insufferable. Even if the material was relatively easy, the workload was sometimes insurmountable in terms of reading and assignments - this is one of those classes where the professor acts like it's your only class and you don't have 2 or 3 others you're also doing readings and writing papers for. Dr. Lucia obviously knows what she's talking about and is esteemed in her field but sometimes acts as though we should already know half of the information she is presenting to us. She picks favorites and can be quite condescending. We also spent like 2 weeks on Native American religion but only 2 on Hinduism/Buddhism combined - of course there's only so much you can teach in 10 weeks but I felt that a lot of it was fairly disproportionate for a class about myth and ritual. Lecture was alright but discussion was based on Socratic seminar which I absolutely hated because attendance and participation (ie. speaking) were mandatory. If you have to take this class then just do as many of the readings as you can early so you don't shoot yourself in the foot later in the quarter before the final.

Took DEATH with Dr. Young Oh. No midterms, pop quizzes every week, & open notes final exam. Writing assignments every other week plus the additional writing assignments near week 8-9, one of them is about visiting a death site. A lot of reading so pop quizzes can make or break your grade. Discussion section is weighted similar to the final exam so make sure to attend. A lot of work but extremely interesting class.

Dr Ana Bajzelj is definitely one of the best professors I've had at UCR. I took this class online in spring 2020 and she was extremely accommodating for all students during that time, as well as very accessible outside of class through email and office hours. There was a fair bit of reading (academic papers, mostly) but it was very interesting and related to the lectures, which were also very interesting. I took this class for an elective but I enjoyed engaging with the material, even if it was a bit overwhelming at times. However, the lectures are very comprehensive and sometimes a skim of the reading is all you need.

Took the class with Professor Cristina Rosetti and I loved it! It's called "Death" and it was a very interesting class. She made it an interesting class. Was very well organized, no midterm/final but there is a paper proposal and a 5 page paper and a quiz each week. The quiz is just written responses to questions she asks in lecture (2) and she lets you know when the quizzes are. It's more so opinion based and to see if you understood the topic. The "final" paper is fairly easy, just make sure you write on time and not the day before.

Fall 2021. Thomas Calobrisi must be a new professor. He is pretty chill. J is the best TA. There are two small reading reflections (one pagers), one final, and attendance. Attendance isn't mandatory for lecture except for your discussion section. For the final you pick a book from a list an write about it, basically a book report. Pretty easy class, but weird topics. I feel like the textbooks didn't match with the class or course despeciation, we mainly talked about philosophy and death. Easy class.

Go to the lectures and actually listen to what Professor Chia is saying. If you do that the class will be easy to understand. Also, take notes; the tests are all based off of notes. Pretty easy overall.

Professor Chias midterms are short answer questions and one picture ID but it’s hard to finish the exam in the 50 minutes given. Students complained but were brushed off. There are discussion questions, 2 midterms, and a final. I would take another rlst/hist if you want an easy breadth.

Attendance not really required, no exams during class. 2 short personal papers, 3 academic papers, 1 take home exam paper, 4 minute group presentation, and 1 group report paper. Professor Ali was great.
Only take with professor simmons

Honestly if you put some effort in you should get an A pretty easily. Had San Juanita Garcia, tests were straightforward, but she's a bit unorganized. Just review slides or read the textbook and you'll be fine.

Really easy class. Garcia just kinda reads off her slides and goes really fast so be prepared for that. The textbook will be needed but only minimally; tests are based mostly on lecture notes and you'll get a study guide before each

Simmers is an awesome professor. Tells great stories. Threw a haymaker on the second midterm, but there are a couple of extra credit opportunities for discussion and doing the bonus synthesis (only if you did the first 5 synthesis activities). Final was noncumulative

Took it with Professor Simmons. Don't underestimate Sociology. READ the textbook, as it is where most of the information for the course comes from. Easy C if you just review the google docs before the midterms, but if you want a B or an A, you need to read and actually know the concepts as her test were not definition based but were more conceptual in terms of applying your knowledge to real life examples and context.  I got a B, and I read every chapter and attended all the lectures. She is funny AF, so thats always a positive of attending lecture. Does not post lecture slides, but can get them if you make friends. Otherwise a good and insightful class to take, but reading is required for a good grade.

Jennifer Summers is great. Extra credit just from doing all 6 synthesis activities and going to discussion. Got an A on the first midterm and was able to slack off on the second midterm and final and still got an A.

Took with San Garcia. Extremely nice and inspiring. Class is really easy and you don't need to buy the textbook since she uploads the lecture slides with the information you need for the exams. Make sure to do the packback on time since it's worth like 10% of your grade. Your TA can make or break your grade.

The lecturer is amazing. I could listen to her read off a phone book, but the course requires 3 midterms based off of 100 pages of reading each. It's just more work than I wanted to put in for what was supposed to be my "easy" class.

Schmitt’s both lecture & reading heavy for his course! Exams are lengthy & heavily worded so it’s quite neck breaking if you need to understand a question clearly. For an introductory class, it’s much more challenging & in depth than most. Study double the time & make your own charts to balance his lectures & readings!

Don't take Christopher Schmitt!! He gave a 2 day midterm, one was written answers and then multiple choice. The final was 100 questions multiple choice, although he told us we might have a written just to mess with our minds a little more. :) His lectures are unorganized and not helpful at all (he writes a few words on the slides and talks about random life experiences he had which he tries to relate to the class) and he makes us read random chapters in the textbook instead of just in order. Typos and confusing questions were a regular occurrence in his midterm and final. Hard final and it was 45% of grade while midterm was 40%. Anyone saying it was easy or a good class is a liar. Coming from someone who got almost 100% on that hard midterm.
The exams were difficult. They were mostly lecture based but the format of the the questions were overall hard. The readings were not all that hard and the professor gave a lot of exam hints.
the way professor schmitt taught was odd. there were no notes to write down. you had to catch everything he said as you never know what would really be on the quizzes and exams

professor schmitt makes this class unnecessarily hard, but if you do take him get ready to study everything: lecture notes, textbook, and videos he shows in class. the final was really hard compared to the midterm.

I had Rotondi, it was extremely difficult for an intro class. the class itself isn't bad, it's just him. he's a great lecturer and funny guy. there are 2 midterms, a final and a paper (which is basically the easiest assignment we got). however, his tests are extremely tedious. he over complicates the questions, and it's mainly based on readings (which are extremely heavy). class is interesting, exams and readings are unnecessarily hard for an INTRO class.
If u get prof. Rotondi, then drop it. He made the class way too hard. It is an intro class but didn't feel like an intro with him. He made the class way too hard.

Took it online with Prof Janet Hill, class material in itself wasn't too hard. Midterm and final questions come from lectures, readings, and videos/films. Don't know if it was because it was online, but it felt like the class required a lot of work for a lower div.

Not a difficult class but avoid Dr Hill if you get the chance. Was very vague about the midterm and yelled at me in front of a Zoom lecture of ~250 people when I tried to ask about it. Hard to reach by email and quite stubborn. Very unprofessional.
quizzes every week, rotondi pushed back paper and quizzes (pretty understanding), heavy reading and lots of recorded lectures
Had Rotondi was extremely hard, 120 pages of reading a week, a quiz every week two different books plus about 2-3 hours of lecture videos a week sheesh.

I had Rotondi for Fall 2020 and he made it really difficult for an intro class. The weekly quizzes are insanely specific and are based on 100+ pages. Irrelevant details you don't think are going to be on the quiz, WILL BE ON THE QUIZ. I spent hours studying the readings and worked really hard to get an A, so DO NOT take this class if you have other classes to prioritize. He gave an extra credit quiz but that might have just been because of the circumstances of this quarter. The paper was easy because the TAs are pretty lenient. You can not slack in this class, I know many people that failed this course because of his quizzes so be aware.

I had Rotondi for this class (Fall 2020). He’s a great professor. He’s very passionate about his teaching. READ! READ! READ! The class has quizzes and doesn’t have final.You’ll pass the quizzes as long as you read.
Spring 2021 no midterm, or final just weekly 20 point quizzes but they are easy if you do the reading. asynchronous only meet weekly for TA

DO NOT GET SCHMIDT, THE GUY GOT COVID AND HAD THE MIDTERMS AND FINALS WORTH 84% OF YOUR TOTAL GRADE. HIS LECTURE SLIDES ARE HORRIBLE, HE DOESN'T CURVE THE EXAMS. LITERALLY YOUR GRADE IS THE TWO EXAMS PLUS DISCUSSION. THE MIDTERM IS TWO PARTS, MCQ AND 7 PAGES OF ESSAY QUESTIONS. I REPEAT DO NOT GET SCHMIDTT
took it will prof simmers, super easy, no midterm or final. 30 question quiz and short writing assignments every week

Took with Rotondi winter 2023. Lectures and readings were very interesting, but so time consuming (40ish pages per lecture). 2 page paper based on 3 readings due every Monday and the midterm/final had hyper specific questions about content. The exams are open note, but if you don't have notes that reflect the readings and lecture verbatim, good luck.
Takes attendance in lecture, assigns 10 page long paper but he gives a lot of time to do it.

My professor was Christopher Chase-Dunn, he tends to extend lecture time by 30 minutes so if you have class right after, leave when you can. Sometimes has important stuff at the end of the class time, so it's pick and choose. He passes out attendance sheet at the beginning of class and you can sign in at the end of it if late.

Ignore the class, until midterm and final because they give you a very comprehensive study guide, which you can use to study well. The hardest part is the research paper, so invest a lot of time into it.
Intro to criminology professor Contreras very chill easy class basically soc through the eyes of minority crimes easy A
Aguirre is all recorded lectures, make sure to read articles too but overall not an abundance of material. Dropped lowest quiz score.

Very challenging course because there is a lotnof memeorization of theories and terms. However, it was insightful and interesting! I do only recommend this class to Soc majors or people interested in it. I know many people who failed the class...

I took this class with professor Rotondi, all I gotta say is run far far away especially if your major doesn't require this course to be taken. If you find yourself taking this class with him, expect weekly quizzes on the readings he provides. These readings will be long; don't take notes because they won't even matter. Converting the docs to a PDF and using command+f will be your best friend. Overall ended the class with an A because of that tip so I definitely recommend.

Tests were all multiple choice based off lecture notes, not reading. Assignments are repetitive and more or less busy work and the last paper was basically a repeat of the first five assignments compiled together. I took it with Prof. Hill and she’s not the best lecturer. Be prepared to listen to her drone on and on about her personal life during class.

Took it with Prof. Perry ( Amy Perry ). She made it an easy class if you attended the lectures, because thats what the 4 quizzes were based off of. If you attend the lectures, you don't have to read because she just talks about it instead. The lowest quiz is dropped.

Took this class with Schmitt, was pretty easy to follow cus it was online. Asynchronous lectures, 1 quiz, non cumulative midterm and final, both multiple choice, & 2 short response papers. The test questions were tricky and hard sometimes, but if u do the readings then it'll be a lot easier
If the professor is Amy Kroska, DO NOT TAKE THE CLASS. She's a terrible professor.
I took this class with Kalousova and it was pretty hard. Go to discussions and put in work, doing homework cost like $120. Not an impossible class but definitely not an easy A

Took this class with Matthew Rotondi, do not take if you're not ready to read. Easily 40 pages per class and the tests are very specific on material. An interesting professor but not worth the workload.

Taken with Matthew Rotondi. I assumed this would be an easy A breadth course but he made the class so much more difficult than it needed to be. Very heavy on readings (you can command+F most of the articles since the exams are open note) and strict grading on the short answer portion of the tests. The plus side was that there were no discussions or homework assignments, just 3 exams total, and lectures were completely asynchronous.

Took this class with Rotondi and there is a LOT of coursework. Tons and tons of articles to read and the quizzes and exam questions are pretty specific to the articles. Some articles are extremely dense as well.

Grade is based on three exams and an 8 page paper, not cumulative. The paper is a research proposal. The study guide is basically the same as the questions on the test. Also, the answers are the same as the notes from the slides.
Literally just exist and you'll pass

I took this class with Professor Rotondi and it was super difficult. I'm not sure who his TA was or how they graded papers. It seemed like he thought he was helping by changing deadlines. Remote learning was hard.

Horrible class; no TAs, Professor Chase-Dunn makes you read his own textbook + 4 other full textbooks, he grades all the assignments himself and the grades distributed are usually based on what he considers is correct; no rubric. Students were all extremely overworked and the curve still failed many of us. I spend 2 all-nighters in order to finish 40 assigned pages for this class and still failed. Ruined my love for sociology.

With Prof Kalousova, it's pretty easy. As with all of her classes, you're gonna need to do some math, but it's pretty basic stuff. Most/all of the info you need is in the lecture slides, which are posted online. I've taken every single one of Prof Kalousova's classes and I've enjoyed all of them so far.
Jennifer Simmon is a good professor, straightforward about what she expects. The material isn’t too heavy, I didn’t study as hard so I got a B. Decent quizzes & exams aren’t crazy.

Such a caring professor, clear criteria, optional zoom class because he records them all. A lot of readings & exams aren’t crazy unless you don’t read everything he mentions as well as watch lecture. Overall would take again but study!

For all you CSBA majors out there, this class's exams are harder than CS exams highkey. Questions on the midterm/final are so confusing and have you second guessing. Too many readings to keep up with as well. The content is pretty interesting don't get me wrong, but my god Schmidt's grading scale was hot garbage. If you can take it with someone other than Christohper Schmidt PLEASE DO!
Some TAs graded the essays much harder than the others.

I had Senora Ballester and she’s a very nice professor. She’s very helpful but she teaches at a very fast pace and gives a lot of work. Classes are also mandatory and she makes you show your face on zoom.

Professor Ballester is an AMAZING teacher! At first it seems like she is going really fast but her teaching style is great. I knew NO spanish and can actually understand it very well. Shes always open to giving feedback on homework and compositions so never hesitate to ask if you want that perfect score on your homework. Honestly  wish I could take her for spanish 2 because she ultimately wanted us to have a good understanding of spanish. Lots of class and homework though but pretty easy!

Yolanda Cardenas was my teacher, and I would highly recommend against her class. She felt rather unhelpful and spoke in Spanish most of the time, meaning I had no idea what she was saying, since you know this is Spanish one. For the final, 2 kids were bothering her about her not giving them attendance and told her supervisor, so what did she do? Not cancel the final exam like she "wanted" to and instead make us take it because otherwise those 2 students would have passed. Real nice.
Kind of tedious and annoying. Especially if you have Yolanda Cardenas. Good Professor, but it will require a lot of work from you with an exam one week and a composition the next.

Winter 2021: Antonio Montoya. I’m a non native speaker with 4years of high school spanish (including AP Spanish). Overall the grading is harsh but he does try to make it easy for us to understand. He’s very helpful when it comes to addressing questions or homework. You have to actively participate during Zoom and turn on your camera. He takes attendance. The class consists of using McGraw broken down into 8 sections and everyday (Mon-Thur) the assignment deadline is due the next day before class starts instead of 11:59pm. There’s also chapter quizzes based on the homework and textbook. Two writing compositions during class time. Midterm is an individual oral presentation. I feel like this class was way easier than high school but I tend to forget everything so it was basically a review course but also relearning what I forgot. He wasn’t mean or rude like I hear about the other Spanish professors. The class was chill. Take him if you can! If you know more on speaking Spanish then this class would be easy for you.

Taken during winter 2021. a lot of work and tedious especially if you aren't the best at Spanish. Lots of homework (every night plus studying). Grades somewhat hard for it only being Spanish 2. Attendance is also mandatory plus having your camera on

I took this class with Pedro Garcia Lopez and while he was nice, he was a tough grader and really expects you to get down Spanish. Class has 2 written exams, 5 textbook assignments and quizzes, 2 oral presentations (one for the midterm and one for the final), and a final written exam. However, the textbook assignments/quizzes are 30% of your grade, so do good on those and try to get B's on the other assignments. Be prepared because the quizzes can take a while to complete because of how lengthy the questions are. Plus the textbook was online and terrible (not to mention it was 50 bucks).

If you're taking with Oscar Valle, be ready to teach yourself all of the material. He teaches the class very differently than other TAs so he doesn't really seem like hes organized or has a lesson plan but he's pretty helpful. Spanish 2 concepts were okay, just lots of memorizing and I say if you're a decent spanish speaker and you're able to teach yourself, take him!

It is not too bad, I say 8 just because of the work load. Lots of McGraw Hill homework plus extra assignments by the TA. 2 writing assignments and 2 oral exams just like every spanish class. It is important to know your grammar very well to pass.

Took Hybrid online and in person with Oscar Valle. Very understanding and good TA. He really makes it easy for someone that is struggling with spanish. Doesn't respond much to emails so try to ask all question in person if you can. About 6-7 quizzes that you can work on and go back to and pretty easy to understand assignments.

If you are a Spanish speaker this is the easiest class basically GPA booster. If you are not a Spanish speaker this class will take a huge amount of time, make sure you practice a lot. If possible try to pair up or be friends with a Spanish speaker. Homework heavy!! professor navarro is honestly so sweet and he really does care, also super funny.

Taken Winter 2021 (COVID-19 Remote Learning). Class is taught entirely by TA/Student Instructor. Heavy reliance on online textbook for homework, quizzes, and final. The online textbook is very specific about what kinds of answers it accepts, so be prepared to go into Office Hours often to fight to get points back. Pretty much daily homework assignments (30 minutes max), 2 short essays, 4 quizzes, two oral assessments (1 presentation, and 1 conversation), and then an online final in the same format as the quizzes/homework. Sounds like a lot, but it is spaced out nicely over the 10 weeks. For my class, cameras were required to be on, which made the class really enjoyable! Nice to interact with people.

Took with Professor Navarro. Lecture was 4 days out of the week with daily homework assignments due one hour before lecture. Workload is ridiculous for a lower division class, and is more in line with an upper division class. Homework mainly consists of particiation activities such as filling in the blanks, readings, and auditory exercises. This would be fine if there weren't up to 150 probelms due daily.  Even when doing all homework activities and taking thorough notes, expect to get a 70% on the exams, which there are 4 of during the quarter.
Professor Navarro is a strict professor during lecture, and grades harshly. Navarro also has a tendency to be rude to his own students, and inconsiderate of students' hardships despite going through his own.
Do not take this class with Navarro, and, if possible, waive the requirement for this class until Navarro changes his attitude or is replaced with another professor. If you are currently taking this class, I highly recommend leaving a harsh iEval at the end of the quarter.
Hard grader. Professor Vargas very strict with native speakers, but prepares you well especially if desiring a major/minor in Spanish.

Took it Spring 2023 with Luz Landeros. Very nice professor; however, she is harsh on attendance and being on time. Many thought this class had a lot of workload, but I thought it was pretty explanatory and easy. 3 short essays and 2 in-class essays that are pretty reasonable topics. Easy grader, mostly grades on grammar/accents. There are Extra Credit opportunities & she gives you a midterm/final study guide which is EXACTLY like the exams.

Class is hella easy compared to 109A. Taken with Mirta Copa Vargas and even though the class was hella on her head for being hard, she was not. Her essay topics can be confusing but asking others in the class is key to understanding what to write about. Once you understand her essay prompt/expectations her class is cake. I did essays two days before and walked out with an A.

It was an 8am for me, and man boredom and 8am do not align. The discussions were ok, but  the class was incredibly boring, talking a lot about different variables wasn't my issue, but dedicating like the first half of the quarter to deciding which group each variable to go into was.

If you took AP Stats in high school then this class is way too easy. If not, it will require paying closer attention but still not super hard. Took it with Analisa Flores, she's really approachable and helpful. Everything is based on notes and they're easy to understand. No textbook.
Make sure to understand how to use a bit of R programming.

Took with Jill Smith. Never attended lecture, only discussions and labs. The labs honestly teach you with enough to get an idea of what's going on in the class. Easy midterms, but the final is cumulative and a little bit more challenging. Overall easy class.
Class was easy unless you weren't caught up with the material. The last couple of chapters were most challenging throughout the course in my opinion.
Jill Smith is the easiest professor
Jill Smith is a great professor--the class is easy and the averages are usually in the upper 70's.  That being said, don't fall behind on class notes.  There's a few tricky topics.
Professor Analisa is great.

Jill Smith was lecturer, she can be pretty boring but she isn't horrible. The material itself isn't that horrible either but I think it got pretty weird in the end. She posts half written notes online and doesn't post annotated versions so make sure you go to lecture and copy whatever she writes down.
Taken with Flores. Material is relatively easy, but be warned there is a discussion and lab, so be warned that it will require some work.

Took it with Joyce Fu while classes were online. She's extremely sweet and lenient, but not the best professor. I would recommend going to office hours regularly. Overall class was relatively easy, but the first few weeks' worth of material was definitely confusing because of her teaching style. Don't fall behind on the lectures because things start to pick up around weeks 3-4. The midterm, quizzes, and final were pretty ok. She let us have a cheat sheet for both the midterm and final, too.

Spring 2021 - Professor James Flegal - Overall the class was very easygoing and pretty easy. Flegal is a very understanding professor and is open to answering question. Material was pretty easy if you put the effort into learning it. Expect to work with groups every week. Had quizzes called Performance Assessments, which were relatively easy. He provided us with practice performance assessments, midterms, and finals. Many of the practice exams were reflective of the actual exams, so make sure to understand them well.
Super easy. Easier than Dirty 30 and I never even took Stat100A. Professor Cappiello and the TA's are absolute studs. Textbook is also free as a PDF or $20 (new) on amazon.

Dr. Yingzhou Fu (aka Joyce) is to be avoided if at all possible. I only understood her lectures because I learned the topics right before I took the course, otherwise I would've been completely lost like everyone else. The OpenIntro textbook isn't super helpful, I'd recommend looking up YouTube videos to teach yourself.

I took this class with during Yingzhou Fu's first quarter teaching, which make it unsurprising that I was quite lost for the whole quarter. Most people agreed that if not for the TA's in lab and discussion it would've been hard to actually learn. Since it was her first quarter, she made the class pretty easy to pass.

I had Dr. Fu. She was organized but would go off tangent at times so it was hard to follow through with lectures. But the TA's were super helpful and clarified many topics. Midterms weren't too bad, so long as you did the homework. A lot of the questions were from the homework, just different values. Labs were pretty straightforward as well. Just put in a little work and you'll get that A!
Take with Joyce Fu, she allows a sheet of notes on the midterm and final. No curve, but the average score was a B+. It is a lot of information to take in, so be prepared to practice a lot

the ta’s were really good however the course required a certain amount of self studying in order to truly grasp the material. Easy class to get an A but it was only so-so in preparation for other courses

Took with professor Zhe Fei and wasn't the best experience. The professor himself is a nice person, however the way class was set up was he literally just read off slides and zoomed through them too. Lots of topics were covered in class and lots of them required outside resources to learn since I personally couldn't learn from how this class was structured.

The professor himself was a nice and helpful person during office hours, however, the way the class was taught was not ideal for me. Lectures were him just zooming through slides, class examples hardly helped with hw, and overall class could've been much better if more time was taken to cover each topic with more examples similar to hw.

Took with  Prof Zhe Fei. The professor himself was a nice and helpful person during office hours, however, the way the class was taught was not ideal for me. Lectures were him just zooming through slides, class examples hardly helped with hw, and overall class could've been much better if more time was taken to cover each topic with more examples similar to hw.

Taken with Zhe Fei The professor himself was a nice and helpful person during office hours, however, the way the class was taught was not ideal for me. Lectures were him just zooming through slides, class examples hardly helped with hw, and overall class could've been much better if more time was taken to cover each topic with more examples similar to hw.

Taught  by Weixin Yao - Nice professor, but he doesn't really care about the material that much. Just take notes, study the notes, and it's an easy A. Office hour won't help because even he doesn't understand the stuff very well. It's formula plug and chug class.

Just RUN!(from subir ghosh)
The contents are ridiculously easy, but that doesn't mean an easy A at all because:
1. Prof Ghosh just makes everything difficult by always changing his idea.

Participation: Mandatory at first, halfway not mandatory, in the end included in the participation points of the final grade.

Grading scale: Refused to say anything about it until AFTER we got our grades by a lot of request emails from different students, and refused to show us the points we got for each section. Our grades were A/+- and B/+-, depending on whether you are in the upper tile or lower tile in the class. Like hell, does this even make sense? Why should other students play in my and your grade? We didn't even know this from the beginning. And some questions were not discussed in his lecture. Our final question points = final total points(no weight given), which means even if you gave a wrong answer in just one question then, bummer, see you in B/+-.

2. Prof Ghosh is extremely unorganized.

Lectures: Just writing down a bunch of formulas without proving/explanation. Use all the examples he made up, instead of real ones or at least from his textbooks. Contents were overtly easy. Usually spent half of the time going over last lecutre, and the last half sounded totally irrelavent to the first half because he never explained the connection between different parts of knowledge.

Textbooks: Enjoy reading children's ""encyclopedia"" rather a real textbook.

No good grade-wise nor knowledge-wise. Genuinely disappointed.

Dr. Subir Ghosh is really nice but in Fall 2020 he was trying a different teaching style where he went SO slow and didn't cover very much material....he didn't really explain many of the topics well/in detail and was kind of disorganized. We all understood the material a lot better during the final project where groups of students were assigned topics we previously covered to review for all of us. It was just really unstructured and confusing, but I've heard he was a lot better before he tried this new style......but yeah, because of him teaching the way he did, I learned pretty much nothing.

Subir Ghosh for Fall 2021. Avoid him teaching this class at all cost. He is a very nice professor but that doesn't mean he knows how to teach well. His class is very disorganized, shows up to every discussion and doesn't even let the TA teach. We didn't know what to expect for each exams because he doesn't explain very well, just writes a bunch of formulas. His review sessions aren't even review session so don't bother. The homework doesn't align with his teachings sometimes and it makes it much more difficult to do - on top of that they mark off the tiniest of mistakes so you lose points easier. Ghosh doesn't like to use canvas so every assignment/ graded material was emails to us back and forth so it was very unorganized and hard to keep track of your grade. Content itself seemed easy but the class makes it 10x more difficult to comprehend.

Taken With Professor Wei Vivian Li and she by far was one of the more considerate and accommodating professor that I have had. Midterms very much like the hw. The hw is similar to the slides shown in class. Main issue is the speed of the class. However as long as you do the hw you'll be fine.

Time Series, for me it was taught by Xinping Cui - She had amazing notes available, and she taught the material well. Made sure the students understood what was going on. There's a final project instead of a final, but it's not bad. Pay attention and it's an easy A. Might wanna take 160A before this though.

I had Weixin Yao for Fall 2021. Homework was given weekly and it was pretty easy as long as you refer back to the lecture slides.The midterm and final was all multiple choice and the questions themselves were pretty straightforward. He allows an 8.5x11 formula sheet front  and back as long as they have no examples problems/ hw problems.
Taught by Linda Penas - Boring professor, she reads off of her presentations. The tests are easy, because they're mostly open book.
Very organized and straightforward.
Strict grading but very straightforward class. Focus on labs and practice exams.
The the practice exam is very similar to the actual midterm exam

Took this over the summer with Luke Klein. He taught this course pretty well and was also a great TA for another class. 2 tips: 1) This is a (guided) coding class more than a straight up stats class. Be prepared to rewrite/retry lines of code. 2) ALWAYS WATCH THE VIDEOS/READ THE TEXTBOOK/use the other main materials. It basically gives you the answers verbatim anyway so it's worth!

I had Professor Analisa Flores and she is the sweetest. She clearly cares about her students mental state and is always willing to hear any concerns or questions in regards to the course. Thought the quarter, she was extremely helpful with homework and lab assignments, while quickly responding to emails. There is 1 midterm, 1 final where you must “study everything” but overall is not too bad. Homework, lab, notes, and practice exercises can be tedious, but is doable. Just don’t wait till the last minute to complete the work !

I had Professor Analisa Flores and she is the sweetest. She clearly cares about her students mental state and is always willing to hear any concerns or questions in regards to the course. Thought the quarter, she was extremely helpful with homework and lab assignments, while quickly responding to emails. There is 1 midterm, 1 final where you must “study everything” but overall is not too bad. Homework, lab, notes, and practice exercises can be tedious, but is doable. Just don’t wait till the last minute to complete the work !

The class was basically a guided coding class. Each week we were assigned a set of lecture videos to watch and take notes on, a practice exercise, a lab, and a HW assignment. The lecture videos and notes took less than an hour each week and the practice exercise normally took about 30-45 minutes. The lab was slightly more difficult but we were given some skeleton code to follow along with. The HW assignments were incredibly long and honestly pretty difficult. Experience in R is not a pre-req for the class but it definitely helps. The course covers pretty basic concepts related to data cleaning and operations performed on data but it's a great foundation course for developing skills in R.

I had Zhiwei Zhang. Zhang allows us to bring one paper of our own notes to exams. He doesn't curve, but if you have good notes and understand the homework, you shouldn't be struggling that much. The actual content is very easy for the most part. I only seriously looked at the lecture notes the day before exams to make my notes and ended up doing well.

Zhiwei Zhang. Lectures are pretty boring. The professor is pretty monotonous, not everybody can pay attention in those environment. Two midterms, one final. No quizzes in discussion, at least for spring 18. Homework is done on webassign, you can just google the problems if you don't understand. Just another statistics class needed to graduate. I don't understand but just do it it's required. You don't learn too much anyhow.

Not that bad. Took it with Zhang. First midterm was super easy. Second midterm was quite difficult. The final was slightly easier than the second midterm. Homeworks were annoying but doable. 

My advice is get serious after the first midterm.

Professor Zhiwei Zhang. Hard to understand during lectures but is a really nice guy that will always be eager and thorough when answering your e-mails or when you attend his office hours. This class is extremely easy(like Algebra 2 easy) during the first third of it up to and including the first midterm. The content up to the second midterm and final will be noticeably harder(I'd say probably 3-4x as difficult). The key to doing well in this class is doing well on the homework and spending a lot of time on your formula sheet to ensure you have no blind spots in your understanding. The average on the first midterm was 16/20 and the second was 10/20 so you can kind of see what I mean.
I had Jill Smith. It's not as hard as it seems, it just requires a lot of time and energy outside of class that I did not really have.

Had Prof. Smith, class ramps up in difficultly pretty quickly after the first midterm. Probably not the most challenging math course you will ever have but definitely not a walk in the park. Homework is through WebAssign, and is much harder than the exams in my opinion. If you can do the homework well without too much assistance you will do well in the class. Go to office hours and put in a decent amount of time studying for the class and you'll be fine. It also helps if your TA was as helpful as mine, Tyler.
Didn't go to class after the midterm, but still got an A in the class. You'll be alright.

CS Major's Opinion: Took this class with Jill and let me tell your this class will eat you alive if you're not into Math. 

First lets talk about the HW. It's Web Assign with three overall submission tries meaning each try counts for the entire assignment. The HW's are insanely long to do and all pretty much word problems so if you hated those well here they are to fuck you one last time before you graduate. The biggest helpful advice I can give you is to recognize what type of question each problem is asking you and to do each HW before the Quizzes.

The Quizzes themselves are the HW so if you do them before they are due you'll have a fighting chance. A lot of people didn't pick this up until too late. Every discussion ends with a quizz and yeah you get a quizz and HW literally a day before the final. Jill has no mercy.

All in all if you can get 90% and above on the HW's and Quizzes you may just pass this class but it won't be an easy task. THE HW IS HARD. This is a heavy class to balance and if you don't put time and effort into this class you'll definitely repeat it.

The exams and homework were not hard. But the way the class is structured with Shuheng Zhou are what make it frustrating to take. There are no recordings for lectures. No chat during lectures. Which makes it hard to deal with especially for a 3 hour block once a week class.

Probability and Combinatorics are the hardest part of this class. Sometimes differentiating between probability distributions can be tricky but if you keep up, this class will be easy. Make sure to do the HW as this is the most helpful part in ensuring a good grade on tests. Lectures are confusing so reading the book instead is useful. Teacher: Shuheng Zhou
Take it Professor Analisa Flores if you can, she's very organized and fair when it comes to grading and curves. Not a hard class, just hard to keep up with the content as it's a lot.

I had Analisa Flores. Wasn't too bad. Two midterms worth 15% each and a cumulative final worth 30%. Both were curved generously. Study the notes as much as possible and fill them out. Quizzes were worth 15% and are confusing at times, the correct answer choices often didn't make sense. All in all, great professor only thing I wish is that she could've provided us practice exams :(

Took with Analisa Flores Spring 2021. Dr. Flores is extremely organized. It feels like it's not possible to watch a lecture without learning something. She uploads her notes after class but never filled in, you have to watch the lecture to fill it out. Even still you should read the book, do the hw, go to discussion and stuff too because you can only get so far just taking notes in lecture.

Took it with Flores. She provides note outlines which are very useful. Tests/quizzes were open note so pretty easy. She’s nice and accommodating. Class teaches you useless stuff like high school math classes, so just think of it like that.

Material isn't too bad. Chapter 3 will appear kind of foreign at first, but once you get used to the rhythm of it, you should be fine for most of the content. Took with Flores. She's very fair and friendly.

Had Professor Flores for this class. Lectures are pretty clear and the testing is decently fair. The homeworks are pretty difficult and more difficult than any test questions so if you can do those, you're all set. There is calculus in the later materials. There are weekly quizzes that you have 2 attempts on which is nice.
Had Flores I think, lecture was kinda hard to follow, but all lectures were posted online and she made note outlines for you. tests aren't too bad, as long as you know what formulas to use

As long as you show up and get your hw and quizes you be fine. The class is just videos which is fine I didn't watch all just the ones I couldn't logic through. There are a lot of easy points in this class you just have to remeber to get them done.

Taught by Linda Penas - significantl harder, because you're only learning SAS. And SAS is a horrible program. The materials are actually a little bit harder so pay attention in class, if you can stay awake.

The course covered statistical computing with SAS. SAS is probably the easiest language you will learn as a STAT major. The assignments were kinda long but nothing was too difficult as long as you followed along with the lectures and the labs. The only hard parts of the course were the HW assignments which were very long but not super difficult. Copying and pasting from previous assignments is highly encouraged and essentially necessary if you forget anything.
Taught by Shemra Rizzo, it gets pretty hard if you don't pay attention. Homework was optional, but you better do it. Probably one of the hardest classes in stats major.
Why were the tests so difficult ):
2nd midterm ramped up in difficulty and final was hard. Curve helped. Do as many hw problems as you can and you'll be fine.

(During COVID era, with Li) homework was a super small part of our grade but you better do it. Quizzes during discussion really tanked my grade so be sure to study beforehand, I recommend having the homework done before discussion because the quiz was usually similar to a homework question or in-class example. Practice exams weren't super close to real exams however they help give an idea of what sections will be covered in the exam/how they will be weighted.

Took the course with prof Daniel Jeske. The material itself wasn’t too bad. We had a weekly homework assignment that was collected and graded. No quizzes only 2 midterms and a final. Extra credit was offered after both midterms. Prof Jeske was really knowledgeable about the material, but at times I felt explained certain things at a higher level that made understanding things difficult.

Took with Daniel Jeske. Really passionate about the subject taught at a good speed to follow, however some of the material he taught during lecture weren't explained the best. Was really generous when it came to grading. Midterms and finals were fair and not too bad. Recommend watching additional sources for this class.

Exam grades were so bad that the professor didnt even post the grades we got on the final exam. Curved the class without telling anyone when he was submitting grades bc theres no way i wouldve passed without that
Taught by Shemra Rizzo, it gets pretty hard if you don't pay attention. Homework was optional, but you better do it. Probably one of the hardest classes in stats major.
Without a doubt one of the most difficult classes taken by stat majors. do not procrastinate hw and studying.

Took with Professor shuheng zhou. Her teaching style wasn't the best for me. Things often felt too high level. Was hard to follow the in class lectures most of my learning came from outside resources.

Taken with prof Shuheng Zhou. Honestly not the greatest professor, goes over material super fast and struggles conveying things to the undergrad level. Additional outside resources for this class are helpful.
Taught by Flegal for me. He was a horrible teacher and the material was convoluted. Just like 160 A and B, there's at least a whole letter grade curve.
There was no curve for this class. You will question why you are majoring in this field.
Taken with prof Shuheng Zhou. Goes over material fast. Lectures are hard to follow. Best read your textbook or go to the TA or professors office hours.

Professor goes really quickly through material. Slides are really barebones that she provides. Use sources like your textbook or online sources. Get ready to write notes fast as she goes fast and doesn't give time to process during lecture.

Taken with Professor Kurum. Her slides aren't the most helpful and she tends to go by pretty fast in class. She didn't show almost at all how to do or think of doing these problems via R instead delegated that to the TA, but was unrealistic to expect one 50 minute session a week to be able to go over 2 lectures worth of material.
Taught by Esra Kurum - She's the best professor in the whole stats department. Won't make you memorize things, and her office hours are really helpful. She cares about her students a lot.
Taught by Jun Li - Not related to STAT 170A at all. She's a pretty boring professor, but the class isn't terribly hard.
Taught by Esra Kurum - Significantly harder than 170A, but still doable.

Taught by Karen Xu - Senior project class for stats majors. Joke of a class. The professor is teaching how to present, and she's a horrible presenter with stuttering. She doesn't really come prepared to the class. But the class is easy.

I recommend Professor Bucklin for this class. He is funny, grades easily as long as you put in some effort for your acting, and practically gives you an "A" if you show up to the lecture (participation counts). There is no h.w. for this class. He occasionally gives small quizzes on the plays/screen writes (which can be found online) and write a short review for a play. The final is also super easy (it's a 3-5 min group performance, you get full points for participation).
This class with Buklin was pretty easy. Only 1 midterm, 2 quizzes about easy plays, and no final. He's easy to understand.
Professor Carazo is so cool and the class is fun!

Prof. Floresislas is an amazing lady but unfortunately the syllabus was changed so much that we ended up completely throwing it away by week 5. Some of the assignments and work were done last minute and it felt very haphazard. Writing assignments are personal reflections on content covered in and outside of class and how they connect to course content. Be prepared as it is a theater class so you do have to act out some things, there is one midterm paper on a movie, and our final project was a one-act play that we write ourselves (although you can read off your script). Despite being confused with some assignments, mostly due to their last-minute nature I did learn a lot from the class, and the content covered was very interesting.
2 midterms with essay, the final is just a performance (monologue). Need to do readings. But overall the TA and professor are pretty nice.

Annika Speer has fantastic lectures that are entertaining and engaging, absolutely do the readings, they’re not bad and genuinely helped for the midterm. Write your speeches about topics you care about!!

1. Start the reading early and the class should be straight forward. Professor Speer is extremely helpful and engaging in class. Participating in class is useful for feedback that helps with your skills in class. The class is graded mostly by the TA through the speeches, so follow the feedback given.

Taken in Fall 2022 with Speer; This quarter was online so I don't know how it is in-person. My TA was really chill so it was a low-effort class where you can get creative. The assignments for "lecture" which was asynchronous were short (2-5 min) videos you had to answer questions to.

The class is no more than 25 students, class participation is key. Speeches are done in smaller crowds and feedback is given directly. The class toward the second half is great towards professional development and if taken seriously is useful. Examples of this included resume building, interview and cover letter for practice job interviews. Grading is slightly harder to get an compared to Public Speaking.
Do the work and it’ll be a breeze.

Michael Bucklin. Easy screenwriting class, I think he said something like 70% of the class get A's so. Mostly effort based rather than actual content based. Lecture, discussion and screening. Screening is one movie per week. Some basic projects but not too much of a time commitment to them to be honest. I just make sure to show up (attendence) and turn in assignments and it'll be pretty difficult to not pass the class. Midterm from the textbook, short answer form. No final, just final project 5-7ish page outline of script.

Honestly people should use this class if they're trying to clear out breadth requirements. This class can easily be taken with a full schedule, you'll have to put in 2 hours of "work" to watched assigned movies. On a bad week you'll spend 4 hours max. Just show up for attendance and do the work, it'll be impossible to get anything lower than a B.

Pretty easy class if you have basic understanding of viet or speak it at home. Heres the problem: theres only one professor so youll be stuck with her to level 3 or 4. Very strict on grading. Loves asking tests questions that contributes no help to the learning of language ex: unscramble this long 5 word phrase. ALOT of hw. My classmates helped me learn more than the instructor. AVOID unless Viet is the only foreign language you know.

Even if you already have good understanding of Vietnamese, this class can be difficult since we use vocabulary and phrases from the north, central, and south. You should know how to read and write before this level otherwise you will struggle. Cô Kim gives a lot of homework and is very stubborn. Attendance and participation is required.

Vietnamese is taught by only ONE instructor, Co Kim. She is old, outdated, and unfair in many ways. If possible, AVOID taking Vietnamese if she is still the only instructor. She assigns long repetitive homework for every chapter, which is one a week. But it is worth very little points. Homework takes an average of 2+ hours depending on your skill in Vietnamese and typing in Vietnamese. 
Her knowledge in Vietnamese has been said to be outdated and inaccurate by students who are more intact of their culture from their parents. Even those parents are confused by her teachings. She yells at students during lecture (on Zoom), and accuses all of them of being unmindful if they are unable to remember 100% of her past teachings if they took her previous classes like VNM001 and VNM 002. She expects you to be above and beyond in Vietnamese, meanwhile her English is not on par. 
She accuses students of copying homework even though she encourages you to work together... and homework does not allow for many unique variations between ~25 students.
